column2: Our very short national nightmare is over. Michael Strahan tells Jay Glazer of foxsports.com that he will not come out of retirement to help out the Giants. (Our story here.) That's probably just as well, says Fifth Down contributor Andrew Furman.
DENVER -- Senator John McCain's guerrilla warfare against the Democratic National Convention continues.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton prepared to give her speech, one of the most anticipated events of the Democratic convention.

Updated DENVER -- Former Massachussetts Gov. Mitt Romney, who is high on the list of potential Republicans for the No. 2 slot, assumed the lead G.O.P. attack role today, alternately criticizing Senator Barack Obama as a "charming" celebrity with no experience and his running mate, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., as being on the wrong side of foreign policy issues for as long as he's been in the Senate.
The Democratic National Committee issued talking points for its officials, some supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton and various pundits to use today about her speech.
After a long day of cooking, with a break for a game of boccie, the group of friends and acquaintances sat down for the meal.
Michael J. Cirino and Daniel Castano break down a boar with cleavers and saws.
Daniel Castano demonstrates the process of grinding the boar meat.
Jerry Contento, the owner, gives a tour of the 800-acre farm.

Vince Spadea is the epitome of a tennis journeyman. The 34-year-old American has played in 15 United States Opens and has never reached the quarterfinals. He has only one career title. His highest year-end ranking was 19th in 2004.

LACOSTE, France -- "Hell," as Jean-Paul Sartre should properly have said, "is other people's trousers." I know this will sound odd to the American English speaker, but in Europe to animadvert "Hell is other people's pants" would leave one open to charges of filthy-mindedness, and possibly a visit from the authorities. Perhaps we'd best leave it as: "Hell is other people's nether garments," together with the hateful - but in this instance necessary - speech tic: You know what I mean.

As Clifford J. Levy of The New York Times wrote last week, Russia prevailed on the ground in Georgia, but not in the media. From the first hours of the conflict -- a moment that is more than contested -- President Mikheil Saakashvili of Georgia was forcefully making his case to the West and particularly the United States. The stage, however, is no longer his alone.

On the Internet, popularity often draws the attention of hackers. So it is not surprising that Facebook has become the target of a spate of attacks, just as the membership on the site has swelled to about 100 million active users worldwide.
At least 22 million television viewers watched the Democratic convention Monday night, when Michelle Obama spoke about her husband and her family, according to Nielsen Media Research.

AT&T hasn't had a lot of good news lately. The new Apple iPhone 3G has caused headaches among buyers who are complaining about dropped calls and poor network coverage. The blogosphere is atwitter, too, wondering whether the iPhone is worth the hefty price.
It's two days after the Games ended, and all the delegations have returned home. Time for one last whip around the world to see what people are saying about the Olympics.

DENVER -- There is some real high wattage in the blogging tent - Craig Newmark of Craig's List along with the Daily Kos guys - but there are also all manner of people narrowcasting specifics interests at the convention. Linka Kellen Biegel and Vera Starbard were sitting side by side and said that no news organization from Alaska had sent reporters, so they were the sole presence for the state. Ms. Starbard blogs from her perspective as a native American and said that like a lot of bloggers in the tent, she brings something that is missing to the table.
Instead of conventiongoers, David Carr stalks members of the media. He doesn't have to look far.

Take a bunch of New Yorkers, drop them on an upstate game farm and hunting preserve, add a freshly killed boar, some hydrocolloids and a substance known as "meat glue," and what have you got? A look into the alternative culture of underground restaurants and word-of-mouth dinner clubs, as Melena Ryzik reports.
Tommy Haas outlasted 12th-seeded Richard Gasquet on Tuesday for a mini-upset. With only 41 winners to Gasquet's 74, Haas was the steadier of the two, winning, 6-7 (3), 6-4, 5-7, 7-5, 6-2.
Politics is off my beat, but I was struck by a news release the McCain campaign sent out today about next week's Republican convention. An excerpt:
Marimekko "Unikko" (Poppy), center, and designs for H&M.

Tribune may be seeing its business deteriorating and its debt slipping further into junk territory. But it may also be gaining leverage in its negotiations to sell perhaps its most prized possession: the Chicago Cubs.

Updated at 5:40 p.m.: At least 22 million television viewers watched the Democratic convention Monday night, when Michelle Obama spoke about her husband and her family, according to Nielsen Media Research.

The folks over at Bookfinder.com have issued their annual list of the most searched-for out-of-print books. "It's a glimpse of what the Long Tail might look like," said Bookfinder's Scott Laming. It's definitely a carnival of obscurity.

Dan Schnur, the director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California, was the national communications director for John McCain's presidential campaign in 2000. (Full biography.)

If Barack Obama is elected president, a good chunk of credit should go to Oprah Winfrey. Her early and enthusiastic endorsement of Senator Obama - and her heavily attended appearances with him in Iowa and South Carolina - played a big role in winning over bit parts of Middle America to the Obama cause.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation warned Tuesday that the nation's ailing banking industry was likely to weaken further.

PHOENIX - Senator John McCain defended "the liberation of Iraq'' and several other recent American military actions in a speech to veterans here Tuesday in which he accused Senator Barack Obama of being confused about America's global role as a "defender of the oppressed.''

You can still take the Traffic Quiz and get an instant score, but you'd better do it before reading any further. As promised, here are explanations and sources for the answers in the quiz, which was created by Tom Vanderbilt, the author of "Traffic."

This week's guest blogger is Grant Thatcher, founder and editor of the cult-favorite pocket-size Luxe City Guides. The U.K.-born Thatcher, who has lived in Asia for 12 years, began the series in 2002 with Bangkok and has since expanded it into 30 annually revised directories (supported by free monthly online updates) with a highly opinionated style that cuts straight to the style jugular. Read all of Grant Thatcher posts.
We knew things were slow in August, but this is absurd:

The Week in Review editors invite you to join their conversation -- a conversation about the articles, studies, opinions and, well, ideas, roaming the Web -- on their new Ideas blog. Each day Tom Kuntz and others on the Week in Review staff brief you on the things they're reading, so you can get much of your day's news fix, especially the quirkier, hidden kind, from one site. Here's a sampling: They recommended a Hudson Review article about the poetic inspiration for the boxing film "The Set-Up"; surfaced an informational graphic depicting the most popular body parts written about in song lyrics, categorized by musical genre no less; and provided a link to a BusinessWeek article about happiness -- all just part of one day's work.

Michael A. Cohen is a senior research fellow at the New America Foundation and the author of "Live From the Campaign Trail: The Greatest Presidential Campaign Speeches of the 20th Century and How They Shaped Modern America." (Full biography.)
Mark Bittman grills swordfish with a pimenton rub and pimenton aioli.
Mark Bittman grills swordfish with a pimenton rub and pimenton aioli.
From our colleages at Bits:
Attention Rangers fans: All of you who hate Michal Rozsival -- this guy wants to have a few words with you.

Daniela Hantuchova ended her practice this morning on the Grandstand court working on her serve. She used every last second of her practice time trying to get it grooved before she was kicked off the court for the Querrey-Berdych match.
More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Aug. 26:

So, the latest news is that the automakers are asking for another bailout. According to various reports, the industry wants Congress to appropriate $25 billion in low-cost loans authorized in last December's energy bill.

Update: 4:25 p.m.: According to Nielsen, the 10 p.m. hour of the convention reached about 12.3 million viewers on broadcast. NBC attracted 4.71 million; ABC drew 4.17 million; and CBS averaged 3.46 million.

Ivory Tower | Joe Biden and McCain's and Obama's campaign managers all went to the University of Delaware. That ought to help the school at No. 71 on the U.S. News best-college list steal some thunder from elite rivals. Four years at Delaware (in-state) cost about the same as a year at No. 1 Harvard. But it's less if you drop out, as did all but Biden above. [Bloomberg, U.S. News & World Report]
One day after the closing ceremonies of the Beijing Olympics, NBC continued to lead its network television rivals in the ratings on Monday, according to Nielsen's estimates.
The case against so-called "land grab" laws in Spain took a significant step forward this week when the European commission formally moved to take the complaint to the European Court of Justice.

If someone you know has returned from Beijing laden with dozens of little knicknacks, ornaments and gewgaws imprinted with arcane messages like "Kiribati Netball Federation" and "Ei Ei Ei Verpoorten," look not upon him with disdain. He is simply engaged in a competition as specialized as race walking, 25-meter pistol, team handball or Olympic hide-and-seek.
John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talks with Representative James E. Clyburn about unification in the Democratic Party.
John Harwood of The New York Times and CNBC talks with Senator Jim Webb about Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s experience and defeating John McCain.
Mark Bittman adds an unusual flavor to an old favorite.

In an Aug. 1 post, I noted that I hadn't seen Michelle Obama with her husband since the family had given an interview to Access Hollywood in early July (I rarely saw them together during their Hawaiian vacation either). I wondered if this was strategic:

PHOENIX - Once upon a time, about a month ago, Senator John McCain was mocking the celebrity of his rival, Senator Barack Obama, comparing him in a television commercial to Paris Hilton and Britney Spears.
The European venture capital industry pulled back on financings of start-ups in the first half of 2008, according to a report released Tuesday by Dow Jones VentureSource.

The two women who opened Little Giant in the fall of 2004 - and made a big hit of it - are plotting a follow-up. They just signed a lease on a space in Chelsea that will accommodate a restaurant nearly twice the size of Little Giant. And they hope to open the restaurant in the first half of next year.
How do a tax-free salary, a bonus 25 percent higher than what you'd get in New York or London, and being in the center of the next big source of deal-making activity sound?

DENVER -- Caroline Kennedy, speaking to New York Democrats a day after her uncle moved delegates to tears with his robust appearance at the party's nominating convention, described the gathering as a poignant one for the Kennedy clan.

My apologies for the terrible play on words. It's just that, by federal law, any fantasy football article about mock drafts must contain a play on the verb "To mock" in some way, shape or form. And I don't want to lose my fantasy football writer's license (available down at the Wal-Mart with the fishing licenses and crankbait) or be thrown in fantasy football jail, a place where all your first-round picks blow out their A.C.L.s and your quarterback is always David Carr.

When Deborah Gardner -- here is her blog -- mentioned the Northwest's "plague" of blackberries, I immediately asked her if she'd write about it for Bitten. Interesting stuff, and there's a pie recipe after the jump, too. --MB
We've only seen one night of the Democratic convention, but already critics are chastising the broadcast networks for only covering one hour of the proceedings each evening.
The Associated Press reports:

In his column today, Jeff Zeleny writes about Alyssa Mastromonaco and Molly Buford, who have been responsible for orchestrating many of the practical, nitty-gritty details from start to finish for not one but two running-mate searches.
It is not often that a 22nd-ranked player gets dominated in the first round of a major, but that is what happened to Tomas Berdych at the hands of Sam Querrey.
Most teen drivers fasten their seat belts when they get behind the wheel. But troubling new data show that teen passengers are far less likely to buckle up.
A salad with many variations on a theme of yogurt, cucumbers, garlic and fresh herbs.
The worst of the credit crunch may still be on the horizon.
If you bought a home in the last four years, you may be under water now.
Two trusted Obama aides were able to pull off a rare feat in presidential politics: keeping a secret.

Aired Monday night on NBC: The Beijing Olympics officially ended yesterday with the closing ceremonies. Yeah, afterwards, all the tourists went home to their countries, and all the Chinese women gymnasts went back to kindergarten.

Aired Monday night on CBS: We go from one exciting thing, the Olympics, to another, the Democratic convention in Denver. The theme of the Democratic convention is "unity." Unfortunately, they can't agree on how that works.

The American defender Maurice Edu could make his debut for Glasgow Rangers in this weekend's Old Firm match against Celtic, providing he arrives in Scotland by Thursday, according to Manager Walter Smith.
In his appearance on "The Tonight Show" on Monday, Senator John McCain had a chance to rebut Jay Leno's jokes about his age, but he also got to fire off a zinger about his host's job status.

Aired Monday night on NBC: Did you all enjoy the Olympic Games? I thought it was great. It was very exciting. Though there was one very emotional moment at the opening ceremonies, where they had children representing each of the 56 ethnic groups in China march into the stadium. Then the farmers and the sneaker factories said: "Okay, break's over, back on the bus. Come on!"
Gordon Murray is going green.
It wasn't just a soccer game, it was hope for Iraqis. It was like 2007, when Iraq won the Asian Cup.

In the search for the perfect television image, video engineers strive for ultimate black. Black, or the absence of light, next to white whites, allows the image to "pop." Deep blacks and a wide contrast ratio improve the perceived sharpness of the image and give the picture a three-dimensional quality.

Jarett Dillard is a senior receiver at Rice. He holds almost every Rice career receiving record and leads all active N.C.A.A. receivers inreceptions (205), receiving yardage (2,828) and touchdown receptions (40). He also graduated with a degree in political science. Jarett will be checking in with The Quad from time to time to give readers an inside look at his season. Here he writes about the difficulty of training camp and the pride he takes in seeing his diploma on the wall.

I shot the photograph above during a brief excursion to the coast below the cliff-top town of Erice, Sicily, where scientists gathered last week to explore ways to limit the chances of devastating Internet assaults, overcome hurdles to securing nuclear waste, balance the production of biofuels with limits on agricultural land, and attack other "planetary emergencies" (in the quirky parlance of the organizer, Antonino Zichichi; Erice sits atop that bluff in the distance in the photograph).
After I wrote about the untimely death of my Canon SD700 last week, a reader wrote me to ask why I didn't just take advantage of the Canon Loyalty program.

Film | It's not every day a poem inspires a classic boxing film. But that was the case with "The Set-Up" (1949), in which Robert Ryan beats his opponent to a pulp in a fight the mob expected him to lose. The poem-to-screen backstory is epic too: "Art and Mammon seem to be fighting for the championship." [Hudson Review]
Sold any new houses lately?
"Among the new entries on the fall television lineup and the lists of projects in development, a significant percentage started with an idea hatched in some distant locale," Bill Carter reports:

Now that China has been widely applauded for pulling off a successful Olympic Games, the less-than-genuine performances at the opening ceremonies are becoming a distant memory. An even more distant memory, dredged up and making the rounds today in the Australian press, may drive any lingering embarrassment still further into the shadows.
Jumptap, a provider of search and advertising for cellphones, raised more than $26 million in a Series D round of financing led by AllianceBernstein, TechCrunch reported.
Sean "P. Diddy" Combs has bottled his success into a cologne, modestly titled I Am King. (Photo courtesy of Sean John Fragrances)

DENVER -- An emotional and apparently exhausted Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. ventured out early this morning to address the delegates from his home state of Delaware, his first public remarks since arriving in Denver Monday morning.
The 2007 income, poverty and health insurance numbers are out. As far as I can tell on a first read, there's nothing deeply surprising. Still, they represent a landmark -- and not in a good way.

Politics | An essay places Barack Obama, writer and orator, in a tradition of eloquence dating from the era of slavery. As Obama prepares to accept the Democratic nomination in Denver, the essay's author wonders "if his example might also inspire a return to the written word among a generation that has essentially eschewed its necessity." [London Independent]

Jason Bay's eyes and ears will experience the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry at Yankee Stadium for the first time on Tuesday. When I asked Bay about this last week, he expressed excitement about getting a chance to play in important games this late in the season.
DENVER - The first round of speeches was over, the masses of attendees were filing out of the Pepsi Center and Day One of the Democratic National Convention was officially finished.
From our colleages at Bits:
ONGC, India's state-owned oil company, appears to be close to sealing a deal to acquire British-based oil producer Imperial Energy for $2.6 billion.
CTV in Canada has picked up a second season of "Flashpoint," a police drama set in Toronto. Will CBS, its production partner, do the same?
A trailblazer in the field of eco-advice columnists, Umbra Fisk serves as a sensible big sister to the growing tribe of the environmentally aware.
The gates open at 10. Play begins at 11. But the fans are here much earlier, and usually with a good reason. Some are after the last seats, some for a chance to sprint to the best ones.
Steven Alan button-front shirts for Urban Outfitters. (Urban Outfitters)

What's it like reporting on a conflict that never seems to end? Dexter Filkins, who covered Iraq for The Times from 2003 to 2006, recently completed a book titled "The Forever War," to be published by Knopf next month. An article adapted from the book appeared in The Times magazine on Sunday.

Rhubarb is so closely associated with desserts that it's easy to forget that it's actually a vegetable. With a mix of Indian spices and a mild chili, it becomes a stunningly flavorful vegetarian main course or a great side dish for a meal centered around strong-tasting meats.
Yes, Elvis in Germany.

Fashion | A writer can't wait for the Crocs craze to end (and it just may be over). Meantime, he approves as his boy calls wearers of the colorful plastic shoes "dorks." But a wearer says, hey, they're comfy! "I don't care if they make me look like I have cartoon Smurfy feet." [Time, Cincinnatti Enquirer]

As the Web makes it easier for U.S. companies to hire workers from Bangkok to Berlin, figuring out how to pay them is an increasingly pressing issue. Payoneer, an Israeli start-up now based in New York, aims to fill this niche in the international money-transfer market.
As Citigroup seeks to right its course, it has tried many fixes - many involving the pruning or restructuring of its organizational charts. But the banking giant apparently isn't satisfied.

DENVER - Day Two of the Democratic National Convention may offer drama on several different fronts. While Michelle Obama kicked off recognition of the 88th anniversary of the women's right to vote during her speech last night, many marquee events today will offer evidence that it's women's day.

As Rafael Nadal struggled by day, which many publications captured, few expected James Blake to almost go all James Blake on them, needing five sets to defeat Donald Young, 6-1, 3-6, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4, and finishing past 12:30 this morning.

Could John McCain pick Mike Huckabee as his running mate? Rich Lowry, the editor of National Review, posts some "idle speculation" ("There's no indication that Huckabee is being considered ...") at The Corner. He writes:

Music | Here's an informational graphic of body parts mentioned in songs, broken down by genre. The authors say they drew on the lyrics of 10,000 songs (database? they don't say). The eyes are the most mentioned body part in most genres -- but hip-hop has another preoccupation. [Fleshmap.com]

Citic Capital, an investment arm of the largest Chinese financial conglomerate, is in talks with China's national pension fund to start a yuan-denominated private equity fund, Reuters reported Tuesday citing unnamed sources.

World | Happiness researchers have again found that Denmark is the happiest place; Zimbabwe the unhappiest. But the real news this year won't surprise preachers and self-help gurus: i.e., money isn't everything. "A rising global sense of freedom in the last quarter-century has eclipsed the contribution of pure economic development to happiness." [Business Week]

Following press reports that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's private equity owners had retained Goldman Sachs to shop the film studio, the company moved to tamp down sale speculation Monday, saying that it "is not for sale" and that it had tapped the investment bank to "to explore enhancements to MGM's long-term capital structure."

The Summer Olympics - need I remind you, the highest-rated television event in history - provided a valuable platform for NBC to promote its fall shows. The network didn't necessarily do a good job - the ads, Stuart Elliott wrote today, "were more over the top than the NBC announcers who screamed their narrations of Michael Phelps's races" - but the air time was worth millions of dollars.
Silence from Electronic Arts about Take-Two Interactive Software may now mean that a deal is closer to happening.

Politics | The Times Week in Review and Book Review editor faults two new books for cariciaturing conservatives while giving short shrift to the idea of conservatism and its hold on American life. The conservative middle helped elect Eisenhower in 1952, L.B.J. in 1964 and Nixon in 1972. For John McCain to win, he'll have to return his party to the center. [New Republic]
Hewlett-Packard reportedly said it expected to close its $13.25 billion acquisition of Electronic Data Systems Tuesday.
Two of the biggest U.S. bond investors said they would get involved in a capital raising by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as long as the Treasury department participates in the new deals.

British oil and gas explorer Imperial Energy said Tuesday that it is in talks to sell itself for 1.4 billion pounds ($2.8 billion) to India's ONGC Videsh, in a deal The Financial Times said is expected to be approved by Imperial later Tuesday.
Citadel Investment Group, the $20 billion Chicago hedge fund, is looking to raise about $1 billion for a new global macro fund, Bloomberg News reported citing an unnamed source.
Amazon.com has agreed to buy Shelfari, the social-networking site for bibliophiles announced in a company blog post Monday night.

Pop | A columnist takes issue with the ever-repeated mantra that Madonna is the queen of "reinvention." Her S&M thing wasn't new; neither was her girl-kissing (Britney Spears) or blasphemous displays. Now 50 and at the start of a world tour, she's relies as always on the "slut take." [New York Post]
Enterprise Acquisition, a special purchase acquisition company, announced Monday that it had inked the deal investors in its its initial public offering had been waiting for.

Infosys Technologies on Monday announced a 407.1 million ($755.5 million) cash offer for Axon Group, a British consultancy company, in what The Financial Times called the biggest overseas acquisition by an Indian information technology outsourcing company.
The Caucus blog on John McCain's repartee with Jay Leno Monday night:

Efforts to overhaul U.S. financial regulation are expected to gather pace next year, as a new Congress and administration seek to safeguard public money put at risk by recent rescue measures, according to Reuters.

Temasek, the Singapore sovereign wealth fund that spent billions of dollars on shares in Merrill Lynch, sees value in banking stocks in the United States and Britain, a senior executive said on Tuesday.
After another brutal summer, Wall Streeters are enjoying the last of the dog days of the season, abandoning The Street for the Hamptons and other tony destinations.
The mouse wins for a change:
The Danish central bank bailout of regional lender of Roskilde Bank may signal the start of consolidation among the countries financial institutions, an analyst told The Wall Street Journal.
More of your "late night" humor (send Via the comment link below):
Two former Yahoo executives are reportedly set to announce a fresh $10 million round of funding for their online advertising start-up, Brand.net.

Whole Foods Market asked the Federal Trade Commission not to appoint Thomas Rosch or any other commissioner to preside over the agency's in-house proceeding against the grocer's $565 million merger with rival Wild Oats Markets.
Two hedge funds who won a battle for more control over Charming Shoppes seem to be getting their way at the plus-size clothing retailer.
Shares that went up on Friday plummeted on Monday. The markets dropped after a flurry of disappointing news about several major financial institutions.
Anadarko Petroleum said Monday that its board had given the go-ahead for a hefty $5 billion stock buyback at the current price.
Freddie Mac easily sold $2 billion of short-term debt on Monday, helping to reassure investors that both Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae can fund operations without a government bailout.
France's Societe Generale has signed a deal to buy 15 percent of Hanoi-based partly private SeABank.
Advanced Micro Devices' deal to sell its digital television chip business to Broadcom may just be the tip of the iceberg, analysts told The Deal.com.

Politics | Help yourself to Joe Biden on the "Future of the American Idea" in an article he wrote last year. It's short, a few hundred words, concluding that in 2008, America "will demonstrate to the world that the American idea is not just an ideal, but a living reality." Did we mention it was short? [Atlantic]

Merrill Lynch executives arrived in Taipei to clarify the company's role involving in the possible money laundering by family members of ex-president Chen Shui-bian, a local newspaper said on Tuesday.

Delta Air Lines said it tapped a $1 billion loan ahead of its planned merger with Northwest Airlines and renegotiated its credit-card agreement to ensure revenue is turned over in a timely manner, the Wall Street Journal reported.
Credit Suisse has bought an 80 percent stake in Asset Management Finance from National Bank Financial of Canada for $384 million in newly issued Credit Suisse stock.

Sport| With baseball being dropped from the Olympics, here's a modest proposal to restore long-abandoned sports to the London Games in 2012. On the list: the "100-meter swim for sailors"; live pigeon shooting; all-around dumbbell; dueling pistol; tug-of-war, and the rope climb. [Economist]
Artists male and female, young and old, American and European, famous and fledgling are all represented in “Photography on Photography: Reflections on the Medium Since 1960.”

Home sales in the U.S. perked up in July, rising 3.1 percent from June, according to the latest statistics from the National Association of Realtors. For optimists, the numbers were hailed as a strong indicator that buyers are jumping back into the market.
A look inside a not-so-traditional farmhouse on Vashon Island, designed by artist and designer Roy McMakin.
Properties on the market in North Carolina, Texas and New Jersey.
Rita Ferrandino, a Democratic delegate for Congressional District 13 in Florida, is attending the Democratic National Convention in Denver.
The Department of Commerce proposed to limit oceangoing ship speeds along migration routes of the endangered right whale.
DES MOINES, Iowa -- Sometime I'd like to drive the full length of U.S. Route 6. But not this week, thanks.
Mr. Ford, with his wife, Eileen, established one of the most recognizable modeling agencies in the world.
Mr. Mosel’s dramatic scripts for live television were regularly featured in prime-time programming in the 1950s, and his play “All the Way Home” won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1961.
Mr. Crane was one of Scarlett O’Hara’s twin beaus and spoke the opening line in “Gone With the Wind.”
Mr. Young was a singer best known as the English-language half of the popular multilingual duo Sandler & Young.
Mr. Urdang was a prolific lexicographer who had a hand in more than 100 dictionaries and other reference books.
The building at 614 Courtlandt Avenue, among the first buildings built during the Bronx’s transition to city from farmland, is being renovated and has just been put back on the market.
In inviting the Wounded Warrior Project to lead the Labor Day parade, labor leaders are seeking to underline the importance of unions and employers helping to find jobs for wounded veterans.

PRESERVING NEIGHBORHOODS Some cities hit hardest by the mortgage crisis are buying foreclosed homes and investing in social initiatives and community cleanup to prevent problematic neighborhoods from sliding into decay.
At least 50 H.I.V.-positive renters have complained to city housing organizations in the past months of being forced out or threatened with eviction because of foreclosures.

The Denver police used pepper spray on Monday night to disperse a small group of demonstrators outside the hotel where many of New York's delegates to the Democratic National Convention are staying, witnesses said.
Images of a Colonial-style house in Cuernavaca, Mexico.

A holistic health counselor who worked as a part-time booker for the escort service that the authorities say was patronized by former Gov. Eliot Spitzer pleaded guilty to a federal prostitution conspiracy charge.
About 1,000 of the city’s 2,600 traffic agents turned out to honor a colleague, Donnette Sanz, and her infant son, who were mowed down in the Bronx 11 days ago.
It came down to the 10th game of a fifth set, but James Blake survived a valiant assault from Donald Young, 6-1, 3-6, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4.
Photos of two homes on the Greek island of Corfu.
Authorities said that at least four people were under arrest on firearms and drug charges in connection with a possible plot to kill Senator Barack Obama.
Michelle Obama, wife of the presumptive Democratic nominee, Senator Barack Obama, spoke at the Democratic National Convention.
Gunmen fired at the chief American diplomat in the northern city of Peshawar as she was leaving her residence Tuesday morning.
Win
Even though Willie Williams lost his appeal to retain his eligibility at Division II Glenville State, he still hasn't lost his gift of gab. Here are some more choice quotes from Williams.
Caroline Kennedy spoke after a video tribute to her uncle Edward M. Kennedy, and the senator then made a surprise appearance.
The Democrats sought to present an emotionally powerful two-act evening, featuring Senator Edward M. Kennedy, struggling with brain cancer, and Michelle Obama.

Who can forget Pete Sampras's run to win the 2002 U.S. Open? Or Jimmy Connors defying age (and conventional wisdom) to make it to the 1991 semi-finals? Or the 2001 quarter-final match between Sampras and Andre Agassi?
The owner of the Indian Point nuclear power plants is backing off a plan to halt an agreement that was expected to give the state as much as $432 million over the next six years.
Come fall, don’t expect to hear much from the presidential candidates about what they would do to solve problems specific to this or any other American city.
The widow of a victim of the 2003 Staten Island ferry crash has settled a wrongful-death claim against the city for $8.7 million, lawyers for the woman announced.
A New Jersey company will announce a plan to use wind turbines to produce compressed air that can be stored underground or in tanks and released later to power generators during peak hours.
President Bush issued a memorandum signaling the administration’s willingness to declare two large marine reserves in the Pacific Ocean.
Two new indictments against members of a polygamist sect have added bigamy charges against men already accused of sexual assault of a child.
A proposal intended to ban gay men and lesbians from becoming foster or adoptive parents was cleared for this fall’s ballot.
The world’s first full-scale nuclear reactor is now a National Historic Landmark, the federal government said.
Three celebrated quilters from Gee’s Bend resolved lawsuits against an Atlanta art dealer whom they accused of cheating them out of earnings.

Representative Vito J. Fossella’s trial on drunken-driving charges has been postponed because of defense requests for information regarding the accuracy of the equipment used to conduct a breath test.
Flooding caused by a border security fence in southwestern Arizona shows that the structure is being built too quickly and without regard for the environment, critics say.
Twelve states are suing the Environmental Protection Agency for violating the federal Clean Air Act by refusing to control greenhouse gas emissions at oil refineries.
A political organization backed by the billionaire Tom Golisano made new endorsements in Senate races across the state.
Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced a pilot program that would overhaul the way children in 10 city schools are taught to read.
Once more, and perhaps for the last time, Senator Edward M. Kennedy brought 20,000 people at the Democratic convention to their feet for a sustained ovation.
Eight inmates, including a convicted murderer and a man charged with murder, escaped from a county jail by cutting a hole in the roof, the authorities said.
It is any outsider’s guess what happens next in China after a successful Olympics. We, like the Chinese proletariat, will have to wait, hope and see.

Kentucky horse racing regulators on Monday approved a sweeping steroid ban for the state’s thoroughbred and standardbred races, but dramatically toned down the proposed penalties for trainers whose horses test positive. With a unanimous vote from the Kentucky Horse Racing Commission, the steroid ban could take effect as early as this fall’s meet at Turfway Park. While the ban is tough, it is not nearly as tough as the one proposed by Kentucky’s Equine Drug Research Council earlier this month. That group called for suspensions of up to three years for trainers and veterinarians whose horses fail a steroid test, but the authority revised the penalties, capping them at a 60-day suspension for first-time offenders.

Fifth-ranked Florida may be without receiver Percy Harvin and middle linebacker Brandon Spikes for its opener against Hawaii on Saturday. Harvin, still battling a right heel injury that required off-season surgery, participated in portions of practice Friday and Saturday, but said he had been unable to go full speed. Coach Urban Meyer announced Monday that Spikes injured his right foot during practice last week.

The N.C.A.A. denied an appeal Monday to restore the eligibility of linebacker Willie Williams at Glenville State College in West Virginia. Williams, 23, a fifth-year senior, was declared ineligible by the N.C.A.A. earlier this month because of transfer rules. Williams will probably transfer to an N.A.I.A. university, where he would be eligible this season.

The Southeastern Conference has signed a 15-year deal with ESPN reportedly worth more than $2 billion to televise sporting events, including football and men’s and women’s basketball. The agreement announced Monday is the longest ESPN has signed and matches the length of the SEC’s deal with CBS earlier in August. The deal begins with the 2009-10 season and ends the league’s plans to look into starting a network to carry its sporting events.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has a responsibility to her party to concede defeat gracefully and rearm for another good fight.

When Tony Stewart, a two-time Sprint Cup points champion, leaves Joe Gibbs Racing after 10 years, he will be replaced by 18-year-old Joey Logano in the No. 20 Toyota. Logano will inherit Stewart’s sponsor, Home Depot, and his crew chief, Greg Zipadelli, next season. Stewart is leaving to become a driver-owner of what is now called Haas-CNC racing. While Logano has made a successful debut in the second-tier Nationwide Series, with three top-five finishes in nine races, he has yet to drive in a Sprint Cup race. “I’m cool with pressure,” said Logano, who will make his Sprint Cup debut on Sept. 6 at Richmond. “Moving up to this car now, it’s more pressure, but I can handle it.”.

RUSSELL--John. He left us on August 23rd, aged 89, after a long illness. Distinguished author, he was for many years the Chief Art Critic of the New York Times. Cherished husband to Rosamond, loved father to Lavinia, an inspiration to granddaughters Chloe and Isabel, proud greatgrandfather to Pablo. His many friends in many countries will keenly miss the sparkle of his warmth, his wit, his informed enthusiasms and his generosity of spirit. A celebration of his life will be held in the autumn. Details to be announced shortly. RUSSELL--John. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of this esteemed writer. His loss will be deeply felt.

An article on Aug. 12 about the record-breaking swimming performances at the Beijing Olympics referred imprecisely to the $1 million performance bonus pledged to Michael Phelps by one of his sponsors, Speedo. While Phelps did indeed receive the money after winning eight gold medals, the benchmark Speedo set was that he would get the bonus once he tied Mark Spitz's record of seven gold medals at the 1972 Munich Olympics. The error was repeated in a sports article on Aug. 14, a Sports of The Times column on Aug. 15, a front-page article on Aug. 16, a Sports of The Times column in some copies on Aug. 17 and a sports article on Aug. 18.

HANFLING--Martin, on August 25th. Beloved husband of Natalie; devoted father of Dan (Tanvi) and Jonathan; cherished grandfather of Eyal and Sarina. Loving brother of Robert (Phyllis). Preceded by wife Alisa. Services Tuesday 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ROBBINS--Martha. Congregation Ohav Sholom, Merrick, deeply mourns the passing of a founding stalwart member and past officer. Martha, by her very presence, exuded a quiet sense of dignity, decorum and intelligence. We extend our condolences to Bert and the Robbins family. She will be sorely missed. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg Brian Bertan, President ROBBINS--Martha Farkas. Our wife, mother, mother-inlaw and grandmother, Martha Farkas Robbins, who was devoted to her family and its matriarch and historian, died on August 24 at the age of 85. Committed to Judaism, she lived her life guided by its values and invigorated by its intellectualism, fostering its strains of feminism and fighting its strains of dogmatism. Though short in physical stature, she was a towering presence. A college professor and voracious reader, she had an encyclopedic memory and boundless curiosity. In fact, she was such a Renaissance woman that even in this age of Google, her grandchildren, when faced with a question, often said, ''I'll call Grandma.'' She was passionate about politics (an unwavering Democrat); a devotee of opera and talented if intermittent pianist; an avid traveler; and an incomparable cook. We will greatly miss her infinite wisdom, quiet elegance, unfailing perfectionism and, most of all, her deep love of family and friends that shone through all she did. She is survived by her devoted husband Norbert, her children Bill and Naomi and their spouses Patti and Mark, and her grandchildren Ben, Ilana, Hannah and Jeremy.

Tracking down a copy of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s suddenly red-hot memoir is about to get a little easier. Random House, Mr. Biden's publisher, said Monday morning that it planned to release the book immediately in paperback, and ordered an unusual printing of 100,000 copies.

The Denver police used tear gas on Monday night to disperse a small group of demonstrators outside the hotel where many of New York's delegates to the Democratic National Convention are staying, witnesses said. The police action stranded many delegates in the lobby and left one woman wheezing and coughing from the gas.

FEIN--Frances T. Horace Mann School mourns with profound sorrow the untimely death of Fran Fein, a beloved and greatly respected educator at Horace Mann for over 35 years. Fran was both the consummate teacher's teacher--the ebullient, creative, energetic teacher of threes and fours at the Horace Mann School for Nursery Years from 1961-1985--and the indefatigable, passionate, disciplined Director of the Horace Mann School for Nursery Years from 1985-1997. Always involved with her young students and with her faculty, she displayed great talent for coaxing the best from everyone she worked with. Fran implemented changes and contributed ideas that continue to influence the daily lives of the Horace Mann community. Her leadership skills, her expertise in the field of early childhood education, her years of dedicated service on HM's various committees are matched by her warmth, her sense of humor, and her love and devotion to Horace Mann. We mourn her loss and extend our deepest condolences to her entire family. Notes may be sent to Peggy Tobin (daughter), 21 Colgate Road, Maplewood, New Jersey 07040. The funeral will take place on August 26, 2008 at 1:00pm, at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall, New Jersey, 07088. (908-964-1500) Dr. Thomas M. Kelly Head of School Steven M.Friedrnan '72 Chair, HM Board of Trustees

BASS--Robert. The Collegiate Chorale Board, staff, and members are heartsick at the sudden death of our beloved Music Director, Robert Bass. For the last 28 years, Bob's vision, energy, and uncompromising dedication to musical excellence brought The Chorale to a new level of artistry and international attention. He loved to take risks and we loved and respected him for that spirit and for his extraordinary creativity. We were fortunate to have been inspired by him and to have made great music together. We join with the music community in New York and beyond in mourning this terrible loss. Our thoughts are with Bob's wife, Juliana; his children, Miranda and Jonathan; his brother, Alan; and his parents, Janice and David. Susan L. Baker Chairman of the Board Susan Shine Membership President Jennifer Collins Executive Director

Israel released 198 Palestinian prisoners as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice journeyed to the region to begin two days of talks aimed at giving Israeli-Palestinian relations a much-needed boost. The release was intended to bolster the Palestinian president before Ms. Rice arrived. For her part, Ms. Rice told reporters that it was ''extremely important'' to keep making progress, especially if there was to be a peace agreement by the end of the year. PAGE A10

An article on Aug. 12 about the record-breaking swimming performances at the Beijing Olympics referred imprecisely to the $1 million performance bonus pledged to Michael Phelps by one of his sponsors, Speedo. While Phelps did indeed receive the money after winning eight gold medals, the benchmark Speedo set was that he would get the bonus once he tied Mark Spitz's record of seven gold medals at the 1972 Munich Olympics. The error was repeated in a sports article on Aug. 14, a Sports of The Times column on Aug. 15, a front-page article on Aug. 16, a Sports of The Times column in some copies on Aug. 17 and a sports article on Aug. 18.

HWANG--Rosamonde Ling-E Rowena K'ung, age 92, passed away in New York City on Friday August 22, 2008 to be with the Lord. She was born in Shanxi Province, China on September 19, 1915 and her home was Shanghai. She was a member of the K'ung family and a 75th generation lineal descendent of Confucius. Her father, Dr. H.H. K'ung, was a wealthy industrialist and banker who later became the Premier and Minister of Fiance of China. Her mother, Ai-Ling Soong K'ung, was one of the 3 famous Soong sisters. Her aunt, Mayling Soong, married Generalissimo Chiang Kai-Shek, who led the Chinese against the Japanese during WWII and later against the Communist regime. Her aunt, Ching-Ling Soong married Dr. Sun YatSen who formed the Kuomintang Party and established the Nationalist Government of China after the end of the Manchu Dynasty. Her uncle, Dr. T.V. Soong was also Premier and Minister of Finance at one point. Her deep Christian faith came from childhood, as her grandfather Charles Soong had come to the U.S. and had been educated and converted to Christianity. He printed bibles in China and spread the word of God. She moved to New York in 1948 and married Col. Hsiung Sheng Hwang in 1962 and had forty four years of blissful marriage until her husband's passing in 2006. She devoted her life to family and others. She ministered to her mother and father and to Madame Chiang Kai-shek until their deaths. She was a faithful and loyal servant of God. Rosamonde Hwang is survived by her nephew Gregory K'ung and her sister-inlaw Debra K'ung who love her and will miss her greatly, as will many other of her extended family and friends. A viewing for family and friends will be held at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 81st and Madison on Tuesday 9:30 to 11:30am. Funeral service 1:00pm at the Ferncliff Cemetery.

SCHUCKMAN--Lois (Berk). Beloved wife of Stanley. Mother of Lisa and Craig, Kenneth and Kimberly. Grandmother of Avraham, Harrison, Bailey, Bella, Eliezer, Naava and Avery. Loving sister of Carol Malawer and Bonnie Warner. Loving aunt.

While Phelps did indeed receive the money after winning eight gold medals, the benchmark Speedo set was that he would get the bonus once he tied Mark Spitz's record of seven gold medals at the 1972 Munich Olympics. The error was repeated in a sports article on Aug. 14, a Sports of The Times column on Aug. 15, a front-page article on Aug. 16, a Sports of The Times column in some copies on Aug. 17 and a sports article on Aug. 18.

BLUM--Bernard. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Sr. Rabbi Hon. Richard Kestenbaum, President BLUM--Bernard G. With profound sadness we announce the passing of beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather Bernard G. Blum on August 24, 2008 as the heart and soul our of family. He was a guiding light to us all. His wisdom, integrity, compassion, grace, humor and unassuming manner were only surpassed by his immeasurable love and devotion to each of us. He was the founder and president of B.G. Blum Associates and Homemaker Industries, Inc. He was a true pioneer in the rug industry for over a half century, from its humble beginnings in Dalton, GA to becoming one of the industries leaders. He shared a lifetime of 68 years with his true love Molly who completed him in every way. The epitome of family and goodness, a great man who has blessed us and now sadly has left us. Words cannot adequately express how much we will miss him. His legacy of devotion to family and friends will carry on in all our hearts forever. Survived by his loving wife Molly, devoted children Judi and Arnold Lashin, Marilyn Kaplan, his treasured grandchildren; Stacey and Michael Mintz, Wendy and Todd Sinett, Gregg Lashin, Eric and Susan Lawrence, Marc Lawrence and Jacqueline Reeves and his beloved great-grandchildren; Casey, Zachary and Lindsey Mintz, Taylor and Kyle Sinett. He will always be with us. Services today 1pm at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

NEWMAN--Muriel Kallis Steinberg. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of Muriel Newman, who was a beloved Honorary Trustee and benefactor of the Museum for nearly 30 years, and whose enthusiasm for collecting, adventuresome taste, and remarkable generosity transformed the Met's collection of 20th-century art. A painter herself, and a friend in the late 1940s of artists such as Franz Kline, Willem de Kooning, Robert Motherwell, Jackson Pollock, and Mark Rothko, she was also among the first of her generation to recognize the significance of their work, forming a stunning personal collection that also included earlier modern paintings and objects from Africa, Oceania, and the ancient Americas. Although a native of Chicago, she promised her collection of modern art to the Met in 1980 and over the years donated important works to the Costume Institute and department of photographs as well. After she transferred her collection to the Museum in 2006, it was shown to great critical acclaim in a special exhibition. Muriel had the rare talent of seeing a radical new art movement around her, understanding its importance, and acquiring immediately with pitch-perfect accuracy. That talent, combined with her love of her spiritual home, New York, added depth and quality to the Museum's collection. Through Muriel's generosity, museum-goers will treasure her magnificent gifts--in the context of the entire history of art at this encyclopedic museum--for generations to come. We will miss her greatly, and extend condolences to her entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Dir. Emily K. Rafferty, President

The virus that causes AIDS is spreading in New York City at three times the national rate — an incidence of 72 new infections for every 100,000 people, compared with 23 per 100,000 nationally — according to a study released on Wednesday by the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. When last we left the new Big Ten Network -- in a column I wrote last October -- the new all-Big-Ten-sports-all-the-time network was in a long struggle to gain carriage with the big cable companies, starting with Comcast, Time Warner and Charter Communications. The cable guys were outraged because the Big Ten wanted a dollar per subscriber per month -- nearly triple the price commanded by, say, CNN or the USA Network -- and was further demanding a primo spot on extended basic, which is where everybody who starts a network wants to be. For their part, the cable companies wanted to relegate the Big Ten Network to a sports tier, where the fans who watched the games would also be the ones who pay for them. For the record, while I do not believe in a la carte cable pricing, I do think that sports should be treated as an exception: sports channels are so expensive -- ESPN alone is some $3 a month a subscriber -- that it is the single biggest reason your cable bill is so high. Putting sports channels on a sports tier makes sense, it seems to me.

I once got into a prolonged argument with the editor of a conservative magazine because he thought The Times had "buried" a story deep inside the paper that he felt deserved to be on page one. (The story contained some good news about the situation in Iraq.) For him, it wasn't a judgment call: the piece "objectively" belonged on page one, and by running it inside, The Times was displaying its liberal bias. After much heat, the only thing we were able to agree on was that one of the virtues of a free press is that different editors can reach different judgments on such matters. But there's a more complicated question than deciding which facts are fit to print, and where. Sometimes it's not even clear if a statement is expressing a fact (objective) or an opinion (subjective). This problem came to mind recently when I read a story in The Economist magazine on politics in Colorado.

SEILER--John A. , 81, of Wayland, MA, died suddenly August 20th on a favorite lake in Maine. Born March 23, 1927, Newton, MA. Married to Catherine W. Seiler until her death in 2003. Graduated Harvard College, Harvard Business School, and the Harvard School of Design. Professor, Consultant, Architect, Mediator, Lobsterman. Survived by daughter Marcia, her husband Keith and their children Hallie and Lucas all of Harvard, MA; Son Matthew, his wife Russlyn and their three daughters Charlotte, Catherine and Hope of New Canaan, CT and West Falmouth, MA. Also dear companion Sally Linden. Ever the iconoclast, John was as much known for his goofy hats, many pocketed pants and love of off-road vehicles as he was for his great mind and ready humor. Services at First Parish in Wayland, MA on August 29 at 2pm. Reception immediately following. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in John's name to the Salvation Army, c/o Sharon Smith, 120 West 14th St., New York, NY 10011.

The Pour column last Wednesday, about traditional Napa Valley cabernet sauvignons that do not appeal to many critics, referred incorrectly to the vintage and varieties of wines from Dominus Estate that received tepid appraisals in Wine Spectator magazine. The magazine said that the Dominus Napanook 2004 -- not the Dominus 2004 -- was ''smooth and harmonious, if on a modest scale,'' and gave it a rating of 87 -- not 89, the rating given the Dominus 2004. And the magazine said that Dominus 2003 -- not Dominus 2001 -- was ''disappointingly dry and austere'' and awarded it an 81 -- not an 88, the rating given Dominus 2001.

DUNKEL--Dr. Morris . It is with deep regret that we report the death of Dr. Morris Dunkel. Dr. Dunkel was Chief Chemist and Senior Scientist at Elan Chemical Co. for the past 16 years. He was responsible for many of the unique chemical processes and techniques for which Elan is well known. His vast chemical knowledge and high moral standards were a model for the company. His loss is deeply felt.

BASS--Robert . The Board of Directors of The Olga Forrai Foundation, Inc. are deeply saddened by the loss of our great friend and Artistic Advisor, Robert Bass. His courage and grace in facing a terrible illness were formidable, and certainly a bright light in our lives has gone out with his passing. Bob was one of the first grantees of The Foundation in the early nineteeneighties and has served as our Artistic Advisor for the past twenty years. His impeccable musical taste and instincts for realizing the potential for artistic success of opera singers and conductors in the early stages of their professional careers, made his advice to us invaluable in the process of our making decisions in how best to support and nurture these emerging artists. Bob's caring influence carried beyond his professional expertise and as one of our most recent grantees has expressed, ''...though I only knew him briefly, Maestro Bass seemed to me to be an extraordinarily lovely man, leader and musician. The way in which he indicated to me his interest and encouragement for my future career was very genuine and I felt that I had gained a real friend.'' We have no doubt that similar feelings must be shared by all of our grantees of the past two decades. The members of The Board of Directors of The Olga Forrai Foundation send their heartfelt condolences to Bob's wife, Juliana, his two children, Miranda and Jonathan and the rest of his family. His loss is great but his life and career, are an inspiration to us all who love music, those who make it, and the glory of the human voice when raised in song. BASS--Robert. The Kaufman Center extends deepest sympathy to our students Miranda and Jonathan and former trustee, Juliana Chen. Your family and the music community have suffered an incalculable loss. Bethany Millard, Chair Lydia Kontos, Exec. Dir. BASS--Robert. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Robert Bass, and send condolences to his family.

IT is standard operating procedure on Madison Avenue for a product to inspire a campaign. But for a leading liquor brand, a campaign is inspiring a product -- actually, a series of products. The brand is Absolut vodka, which is bringing out limited editions of flavored varieties that celebrate spirited cities where the residents enjoy their spirits. The first one, introduced in July 2007, was named Absolut New Orleans; the second, introduced last month, is called Absolut Los Angeles.

HAWKINS--Robert G. , of Spencertown, NY, died suddenly at his home on August 22 at the age of 72. A well known economist and academic, his career spanned three universities culminating at Georgia Tech, where he was professor Emeritus and Dean of the Ivan Alan College of Management. Prior to GT he served as Dean of the School of Management at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute for eight years. His academic career started at New York University where he received his Ph.D. in economics in 1966 and later became professor of Economics and International Business. He also held roles as chairman of International Business, Chairman of the Finance Department and served as Vice-Dean of the Faculty of Business Administration. He served as a consultant to many organizations throughout his career including USIA, the US Treasury, the Port Authority of NY, GE, IBM, and Morgan Guaranty. He was an active board member of numerous corporations and served as president of the Academy of International Business and Executive Secretary Treasurer of the American Finance Association. An active, generous and compassionate man, he will be missed by the many whose lives he touched. He is survived by his wife Estelle, sons Paul and Kenneth, their wives Andrea and Kristen, grandchildren Henry and Amelia, and his sister, Rae Marie Hastings. At his request, no service is planned. Those who wish to remember him may send donations to the American Parkinson's Association or charity of their choice.

WEYMOUTH--Katharine Lewars (duPont), 87, passed away peacefully on Friday August 22, 2008 at her summer home on Fishers Island, NY. She was born in 1921 in Philadelphia, PA and was the daughter of the late Katharine Price Lewars and the late Thomas Belfield Lewars. She attended the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, PA and Lower Merion High School in Ardmore, PA. She graduated from Wheelock College in Boston where she served on their Board of Trustees. Katharine was the widow of State Senator Reynolds duPont of Greenville, DE and Fishers Island, NY and also the widow of George T. Weymouth of Greenville, DE and Boca Grande, FL. Katharine is survived by a wonderfully large family which includes her daughter, Katharine duPont Sanger; son Reynolds duPont, Jr.; son Thomas Lewars duPont and his wife, Ruth; daughter Natalie duPont Lyon and her husband, Frank R. Lyon, Jr.; and son Michael Belfield duPont. Surviving her are a long list of grandchildren including Penn duPont Sanger and his wife, Jennifer; Christopher Durant Sanger and his wife, Nina; Heidi Anne duPont; Reynolds duPont III and his wife, Elizabeth; Jameson Coffey duPont; Jessica duPont Thiel and her husband Eric; Molly Becker duPont and her husband, Trevor Schaffer; Sarah duPont Hendriksen and her husband Edwin; Kate Lyon Jackson and her husband, Matthew; Brianne Lyon Jarvis and her husband, Benjamin; Kyley Wallace Lyon, Michael Belfield duPont Jr.; Edward Reynolds duPont and Bennett Lammot duPont. Greatgrandchildren include Peter and Cassie Sanger, Eleanor duPont, Tommy, Tyler and Greta Thiel, Teddy and Wilson Schaffer, Sophie and William Hendriksen, Stephen and Connor Lyon and Mason Jarvis. Katharine is also survived by Patricia Weymouth Hobbs, George A. ''Frolic'' Weymouth and Eugene E. Weymouth and their many children and grandchildren. Katharine was pre-deceased by her brother Thomas Belfield Lewars Jr. and her twin sister Margaret Lewars Ogden. She is survived also by several nieces and nephews and Godchildren to whom she was most deeply devoted. Katharine was pre-deceased by an infant grandson, Frank R. Lyon IV and a granddaughter, Emily A. duPont. She was also pre-deceased by her son-in-law, Peter Durant Sanger. Katharine's involvement in a myriad of organizations in Wilmington, Boca Grande and Fishers Island left an indelible imprint. Her volunteer service to cultural, medical, historical and educational boards spanned many decades and her roles as both a leader and mentor will long be remembered. Her greatest legacy will remain that of her family. Katharine's generosity and grace, engaging smile and love won her the love and respect of people of many generations. Her gifts of a wonderful sense of humor, undying love of family and loyalty to friends and her willingness to help others will serve as reminders of her wonderful spirit. The family is most grateful to the many years of companionship and friendship offered to her by Kathleen Rupprecht and the compassionate care given to her especially by Josephine Flinn and Ann Egerton over the past two years as well that of many other caregivers in particular East End Hospice of Westhampton Beach, Long Island. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 28, 2008 at St. John's Church, Fishers Island, NY. Interment will be private. A memorial service will also be held in Wilmington, DE at 11am on Friday, September 12, 2008 at Christ Church Christiana Hundred, Greenville, DE. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that gifts in Katharine's memory be made to Christiana Care Health System, Office of Development, P.O. Box 1668, Wilmington, DE 19885-9320 and also St. John's Church/ Sanger Fund, P.O. Box 505, Fishers Island, NY 06390. Services by Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory. www. chandlerfuneralhome.com

ELSBREE--Willard H. , 87, Athens, OH, professor emeritus of government at Ohio University, died August 19, 2008. Dr. Elsbree had been a professor in the Ohio University Government Department from 1952 until retirement in 1990, serving as chair from 1963 to 1968, and 1975 to 1976. Born Preston Hollow, NY, he attended Dartmouth College and Harvard University, receiving his Bachelor's degree magna cum laude in 1941. He joined the U.S. Navy in 1942 and was sent to its Japanese Language School, where he served as an interpreter in the Pacific, including day three of the Battle of Iwo Jima. Professor Elsbree returned to Harvard where he earned his Ph.D. in government in 1952. His area of expertise was Eastern Asia political science, notably Japan, the Philippines and India. Memorial service will be in Athens, Ohio on September 21, 2008. Online guestbook at jagersfuneralhome.com

Health | Does alcohol have more of an effect at high altitude? "Probably not, but alcohol could make your altitude sickness a little worse," says Slate. The popular wisdom that thinner air is bad for boozing (or better, depending on how you look at it) came from a 1930s study. But it hasn't been backed up by later research. Now they tell us, say Denver conventioneers. [Slate]

The young woman standing in line at the kettle corn stand on the upper tier of Invesco Field could have been a spokesman for Colorado's appeal. Blonde, healthy, friendly and fun, she started chatting up the guy behind her to make the time pass. Asked her name, she said, Cindy Lamm.

Hillary Clinton got most of the attention on Tuesday, but another woman who spoke at the Democratic convention that night also brought the delegates -- especially the women delegates -- to their feet.

As Senator John McCain nears an announcement on his choice for a running mate, nearly 4 in 10 of the Republican delegates preparing to head to St. Paul, Minnesota for their party's convention say they would like to see the presumptive nominee select Mitt Romney, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

The Yankees have not forgotten about Phil Hughes, who started the season in the rotation but is now laboring for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre. On Wednesday in Buffalo, Hughes worked 6 1/3 innings, allowing two runs and six hits, striking out seven with one walk. It followed two dismal starts that put into question whether Hughes would return in September.

We haven't got to Belgium yet, and already my appetite is being teased for Monza with the test times. Felipe Massa fastest yesterday, and now suddenly Nick Heidfeld pulls a rabbit out of his hat the way he so often does when under pressure - and just as his teammate Robert Kubica has his contract confirmed for next season....(but Heidfeld hasn't):
I learned the other night at dinner that a family we know, who'd recently gotten a puppy, had decided, with much sadness and soul-searching, that they had to return her to her breeder.

There's been a lot of buzz today over the statement by John Goodman, the president of the National Center for Policy Analysis -- which is, despite its anodyne name, a hard-right think tank -- that nobody is uninsured in America, because you can go to the emergency room. Goodman has described himself, as recently as July 30 in the Wall Street Journal, as a McCain adviser. But now that there's a stink, the campaign says that he hasn't been advising them since "earlier this summer." (How much earlier?) And the campaign says that it doesn't agree with his views.

A cadre of large shareholders in Huntsman, including some of the biggest hedge funds around, are proposing at least $500 million in financing to help close the sale of the chemical maker to Apollo Management's Hexion Specialty Chemicals.

Anwar J. Ali is an Iraqi journalist working for The New York Times in Baghdad. She recently went on vacation to Turkey. It was her second trip outside Iraq and her first outside the Arab world.

Gallup is reporting the beginnings of a "predictable bounce" favoring Barack Obama in its most recent election poll. He's now up 6 percentage points over John McCain. And the spread may continue to widen. According to Gallup, the poll probably doesn't reflect the impact of the speeches by Bill Clinton and Joe Biden, and it obviously doesn't reflect the impact of the speech Obama will deliver tonight. Next week: the Republicans.

Phil Hill, the only American-born Formula One champion, died today at the age of 81. He died at Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula. He had suffered from Parkinson's disease and another degenerative neurological disorder.

International buyers considering Florida should take note of the latest statistics from the Florida Association of Realtors. First off, the volume of sales of existing homes in July was actually up from the same month a year earlier. Only six more homes were sold-which means it may fall short of indicating a "stabilization in Florida's housing sector," as FAR's release suggests-but it is the first actual increase in sales activity in two years.

Eighteen-year-old Alize Cornet moved into the third round of the U.S. Open today with a straight-sets win over American Bethanie Mattek, 7-6 (5), 6-1.Mattek, who until this year, was probably better known for her getups than her game came into the open having achieved her highest ranking this month at 43 in the world. With unemployment on the rise, New York State's jobless benefits fund is likely to run out of money again in early 2009, if not sooner, according to state officials and labor market analysts. It would not be the first time. The state's unemployment trust fund is so poorly financed that it has repeatedly run dry in the last several years, most recently in the early months of 2008. To fill the gap, the state had to borrow from the federal government until it collected enough payroll taxes to cover the weekly checks it sends to the state's unemployed.
Television executives talk a lot about lead-ins, and for good reason - the size of the 9 p.m. audience can have a make-or-break effect on the 10 p.m. show on a network.

As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg considers challenging New York City's term-limit laws, all eyes are turning to the City Council. It is the 51-member Council -- not the mayor -- which has the authority to revise the city's term limits. Such limits will force Mr. Bloomberg out of office in 16 months.As reported this morning, a telephone survey conducted by The Times found that 27 of the 51 council members support -- or are open to -- extending term limits to 12 years from the current eight. Eight members oppose the idea, four are undecided and 13 could not be reached this week.

In early September, Yale University Press will publish "The Great Age of the English Essay: An Anthology." It's a useful crash course in what the periodical essay once was. There's Addison and Steele; Dr. Johnson and Boswell; Hazlitt, Lamb and De Quincey. There's gossip and scandal, obsession and addiction, even the blurring of fiction and nonfiction. All of a high order, of course. It certainly seems as if there would be contemporary equivalents of such fare. But, all due respect, I don't see much of it on the so-called literary blogs, including this one. The collection's editor, Denise Gigante, writes of the "clubby environment" provided by the coffeehouses of Enlightenment London, reminding us that the best essayists of today are unlikely to be hanging at Starbucks. For that matter, who - and where - are the great essayists working now?

Michael Phelps will be a presenter at MTV's 2008 Video Music Awards, the network has announced. The Olympian will join Miley Cyrus, Lindsay Lohan, Ciara, and other presenters at the event in Los Angeles on Sept. 7, according to the Associated Press.

Russia | Russia's strength is also its Achilles heel, a blogger says. One of two new gas pipelines crucial to its energy strategy would pass through countries where America has influence: Bulgaria, Hungary, Serbia and Austria. Washington could get them to freeze support for the line. Ditto Germany -- it's the main European partner on the second pipeline. [Business Week]

A majority of New York City Council members support - or are open to - overturning the term limit laws that will force most of them and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg from office in 16 months, according to a telephone survey conducted by The New York Times. With Mr. Bloomberg considering a bid to change the term limits to 12 years from the current eight, the results of the survey suggest that the mayor would find ample support for such a proposal in the Council, which has the authority to rewrite the law with or without voter ratification.

Missouri quarterback Chase Daniel led the Tigers to a 12-2 record and the upper levels of the national rankings last year. He finished fourth in the voting for the Heisman Trophy and passed for 4,306 yards and 33 touchdowns, both team records. He will contribute a diary to The New York Times during the college football season. In this entry, which was told to Thayer Evans, he talks about preparing for the season opener against Illinois, browsing for computers at Best Buy and trying to corral tickets for friends and family.

Struggling to free itself from the mires of a court battle with the Federal Trade Commission, Whole Foods Market on Tuesday asked for the whole U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to examine a recent decision made on its deal for Wild Oats Markets.

Society | An essay explores why the Patty Hearst kidnapping resonated so deeply. She represented a nightmare to which many families caught up in the turbulent 1970s could relate -- a "largely naïve young woman who was being fought over, in public, by two powerful forces: her parents and 'the culture' in its most extreme and violent manifestation." [Atlantic]

There have been delays on the 7 train, whose Shea Stadium stop serves the National Tennis Center. A train accident had suspended service of the 7 train in both directions between the Shea Stadium stop and Main Street until about 8 a.m. Main Street comes after Shea Stadium for those coming from Manhattan, but delays are still possible, and as of 8 a.m., only local trains were running.

Two French banks showed the scars of the financial crisis on Thursday, with heavy asset write-downs stripping Credit Agricole of all but a sliver of profit and plunging Natixis to a billion euro loss.

Andy Roddick had his fiancee, his brother and Patrick McEnroe in his box (funny how having a new coach, like being newly in love, puts a spring in a player's step). Roddick hit a 147-mile-per-hour serve early in the match and, just before it ended, hit another 140 m.p.h. serve too close to Fabrice Santoro, who refused to lift his racket at match point and lost, 6-2, 6-2, 6-2.

Film | It bombed in 1998. But now "The Big Lebowski" is an oft-quoted cult and commercial hit (on DVD). It has inspired Web homages and dozens of academic papers, and praise from the likes of Seth Rogen ("Pineapple Express") and Jonah Hill ("Superbad"). Why? For one, the "Dude" rules! Jeff Bridges: stoner anti-hero for a striving, wired world. [Rolling Stone]
MBIA agreed on Wednesday to take control of nearly $200 billion of municipal bonds currently backed by a rival bond insurer, FGIC, in a move that could help its competitor avoid bankruptcy.
Ricoh's deal to buy American office equipment distributor, Ikon Office Solutions, for about $1.62 billion appears to be a win for Warren G. Lichtenstein.

Mike Candrea, the University of Arizona softball coach whose bid to lead the United States to a gold medal ended with a loss to Japan in the title game at the Beijing Olympics, stepped down Wednesday as the coach of the national team. Candrea had guided the Americans since 2002 and went 17-1 in Olympic play. The only defeat was a 3-1 loss to Japan in the gold medal game last week.

Patience paid off for the Colorado Avalanche, who signed their 39-year-old captain, Joe Sakic, to a one-year, $6 million contract after he decided to play a 20th season in the N.H.L. Sakic missed 38 games last season after having a hernia operation.

Officials in Oregon said an autopsy showed that the former Portland Trail Blazers center Kevin Duckworth died when his enlarged heart failed. Duckworth died Monday at 44 on the Oregon coast, where he was on a good-will tour for the team. The Oregon State Police said an autopsy concluded that Duckworth died of “hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with congestive heart failure.”.

The swimmer Eric Shanteau had surgery Wednesday to remove a cancerous testicle after fulfilling his goal of swimming in the Olympics. The 24-year-old Shanteau had the operation at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta, his agent Evan Morgenstein said. Shanteau, who grew up in suburban Atlanta, was found to have cancer in June, shortly before the United States Olympic trials. Manchester, Vt., has long been a favorite escape for holiday travelers looking to beat the summer heat. Drenched in history — and these days in upscale outlet shops — Manchester is also awash in a variety of outdoor pursuits, notably superb fly-fishing and classic mountain golf. Situated in the Green Mountains and just a leisurely four-hour drive from Manhattan and three from Boston, Manchester is ideal for a September weekend golf getaway. Make sure to arrive in advance of the leaf-peepers, however, or your long drives won’t be confined to the golf course.

With 382 miles of paved country roads — and a topography that’s “pastoral and hilly, studden with rock-topped bluffs and cut deep by ravines” — Trempealeau County in Wisconsin is suited perfectly for cycling. Still, it remains off the national radar. In The Times, Stephen Regenold writes about his through the county in the Arcadia Memorial Tour, a noncompetitive group ride: “Tires hummed on the pavement, a gray asphalt with few cracks. The road, narrow and swooping, shouldered by deep ditches of grass, felt like a private bike track, riders shoulder to shoulder across half its width.”.

Charles McGrath experienced many firsts this month — his first visit to Beijing, his first time covering the Olympics, and his first taste of grasshopper and seahorse. (“I steered clear of dog,” he wrote in The Times, “because someone who had tried it told me it could make your nose bleed.”) Now back home after his whirlwind trip, McGrath, a regular contributor to PLAY, talked to us about his experience at the Beijing Games.

Anyone within earshot of Arthur Ashe Tennis Stadium last night was likely to hear the cannon fire that is otherwise known as Andy Roddick’s serve. In a three-set rout of French journeyman Fabrice Santoro, Roddick ripped off a stunning 147-mile-per-hour ace in the first set, the fifth-fastest recorded serve of all time (the first three spots are also occupied by Roddick). Santoro, a finesse player who at age 35 is still ranked 60th in the world, appeared to grow increasingly demoralized as the match wore on. At 30-love in the last game, Roddick served a 140-mile-per-hour ace that nearly struck Santoro in the head as he bent over to protect himself. Santoro walked over to the opposite side of the baseline, gave a facetious round-of-applause for Roddick into his racket, and then pinned his racket against his thigh — giving up on match point. Roddick explained after the match that he had meant to hit the late offending serve on the "T" — the middle line between the service courts — but that the ball got away from him. Santoro wasn’t convinced. "Then it was the biggest mistake of his life," Santoro said. "When he goes on the T, it’s right on the T.".

Barack Hussein Obama, a freshman senator who defeated the first family of Democratic Party politics with a call for a fundamentally new course in politics, was nominated by his party today to be the 44th president of the United States. The unanimous vote made Mr. Obama the first African-American to become a major party nominee for president. It brought to an end an often-bitter, two-year political struggle for the nomination with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who, standing on a packed convention floor electric with anticipation, moved to halt the roll call in progress so that the convention could nominate Mr. Obama by acclamation. That it did with a succession of loud roars, followed by a swirl of dancing, embracing, high-fiving and chants of ''Yes, we can.''

With sympathy, Steve Madden, LTD
