BIONDI--Richard P. The Board of Directors, Management, Volunteers, and Staff of White Plains Hospital Center mourn the loss of Richard P. Biondi, Senior Vice President of Development, Community Relations & Marketing. Rich was truly a giant in the business, civic, and philanthropic communities in Westchester County. He embodied leadership, touching many lives through his involvement with community organizations too numerous to mention. Throughout his illness, Rich gained strength from coming to work, remaining active in the community, and from daily interactions with colleagues and friends. His courage was an inspiration to all of us. He was a man of great compassion and generosity, an outstanding citizen and an extraordinary family man. We extend our deepest sympathies to his bride Maureen, mother Jennie, children Richard P. Biondi II (Kelley) and Jennifer O'Sullivan (Kevin), and his five grandchildren. The entire community has lost a remarkable man who leaves a lasting legacy. Paul M. Weissman Chairman, Board of Directors Jon B. Schandler President and CEO

ELSBREE--Willard H., 87, Athens, OH, professor emeritus of government at Ohio University, died August 19, 2008. Dr. Elsbree had been a professor in the Ohio University Government Department from 1952 until retirement in 1990, serving as chair from 1963 to 1968, and 1975 to 1976. Born Preston Hollow, NY, he attended Dartmouth College and Harvard University, receiving his Bachelor's degree magna cum laude in 1941. He joined the U.S. Navy in 1942 and was sent to its Japanese Language School, where he served as an interpreter in the Pacific, including day three of the Battle of Iwo Jima. Professor Elsbree returned to Harvard where he earned his Ph.D. in government in 1952. His area of expertise was Eastern Asia political science, notably Japan, the Philippines and India. Memorial service will be in Athens, Ohio on September 21, 2008. Online guestbook at jagersfuneralhome.com

Pope Benedict XVI has condemned a sculpture of a crucified frog on display at a museum in Bolzano, Italy, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. Franz Pahl, an official from the Trentino-Alto Adige region in northern Italy, said the pope had written to him to complain about the frog, which was installed in May at Museion, the modern-art museum in Bolzano. In a letter dated Aug. 7, Pope Benedict said that the sculpture ''injured the religious feeling of many people who see in the Cross the symbol of the love of God and of our salvation, which deserves recognition and religious devotion.'' The work, by the German artist Martin Kippenberger, who died in 1997, depicts a frog nailed to a cross with a mug of beer in one hand and an egg in the other. According to ANSA, the museum's curators contend that the work is a self-portrait of the artist ''in a state of profound crisis'' and is not an attack on religion. While they have moved the sculpture away from the museum entrance, they refuse to remove it. Members of the provincial government, who form a majority on the museum's board, said they would ask for the work to be taken down when they meet with museum officials on Thursday.

(TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: CHARLTON HESTONThis all-day tribute shows Heston's range, beginning with ''Bad for Each Other'' (1954), in which a doctor returned from the Korean War must decide whether to set up a glamorous practice or help those in real need. The daytime segment features three epics: ''Khartoum'' (1966), about a British general who fell to the Arabs in 1886, at 10 a.m.; ''The Greatest Story Ever Told'' (1965), at 12:30 p.m.; and ''Ben-Hur'' (1959), above, which earned Heston the best actor Oscar, at 4. The evening segment continues with a western double bill -- ''The Big Country'' (1958) at 8 and ''Major Dundee'' (1965) at 11 -- before time traveling to the year 2022 in the cult favorite ''Soylent Green'' (1973) at 1:30 a.m. ''The Hawaiians'' (1970), based on the novel by James A. Michener and starring Heston as a wayward son who returns to find a ravaged island, wraps up the celebration at 4 a.m. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW The writer Maya Angelou talks about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s ''I Have a Dream'' speech.

GARBER--Sylvia, October 5, 1915-August 26, 2008. Predeceased by her husbands, Julius Hyams and Louis Garber. Survived by her children, Stanley and Joan, Elaine and Alan, Carrie and Ernest, Susan and Jon and their devoted children and grandchildren. Aunt to Rene, Linda and Michael and their families.

SIDNAM--Alan Northcote, longtime Manhattan resident, former advertising executive of Benton & Bowies and Ogilvy & Mather and venture capitalist, died on August 26th at Edgehill Nursing Home in Stamford, CT, at the age of 92. Alan grew up in Kalamazoo, MI, graduating from Kalamazoo College in 1937. He was a member of the Upjohn family of Upjohn Pharmaceuticals. A fighter pilot in WWII, Alan was stationed at Biak in the South Pacific where he flew P-38s with the 475th Fighter Group. Alan once flew as Charles Lindberg's wingman (Tail-end-Charlie). At that time Lindberg was visiting the 475th and, although not trained as a military pilot, was allowed to participate in several combat missions. In a separate incident, Alan crashed into the Pacific testing a P-38 that malfunctioned and suffered burns in the resulting fire. He was rescued hours later by a passing ship and credited his ''Mae West'' with saving his life. Alan moved to Manhattan in 1938. During his tenure as Vice Chairman at Benton & Bowles, his main client was Proctor & Gamble. In the late 1940s and 1950s, the early days of television, P&G was a major advertiser and sponsored the Loretta Young Show. Alan played the dual role of satisfying the needs of both P&G and the show's star, Loretta Young. For the Tide account, Alan's suggestion of the tag line ''when Tide comes in, dirt goes out'' was adopted as ''Tide's in, dirt's out'' and ran for many years, a monumental success. When, in 1962, Alan was asked by David Ogilvy to be a Vice Chairman of Ogilvy & Mather, he took on the management of the General Foods account and acted as Management Supervisor for the Mercedes Benz account. After five successful full-time years at O&M, he transitioned to part-time consultancy to the agency and entered the world of venture capital. As a venture capitalist Alan both raised money for and invested in many existing companies and start-up businesses. He was on the board of Kelley Oil & Gas, an exploration company based in Houston, TX. With his friend, James Gamble Rogers, he was an original board member and investor in Lindblad Travel, one of the first companies to offer exotic expeditions to venues like Antarctica and the Galapagos. Alan was a principal investor and prime mover in V-Band Corporation, which developed specialty telecommunica tions equipment for use in stock and bond trading. Another project of his was National Demographics and Lifestyles, which developed a detailed database of buyers based on known buying habits for use by direct marketing companies. He was involved with Evelyn Wood Reading Dynamics, the world famous speed-reading program. Then-President Jimmy Carter's decision to give Evelyn Wood courses in the White House helped to give a quick lift to this business. Alan assisted with Norman Cousins' purchase of the Saturday Review, saving it from bankruptcy and restoring Cousins to Editor-in-Chief. He also worked with Louis Marx, Jr., at his innovative company, All American Sports, which operated tennis camps, taking advantage of the available off-season facilities at colleges, prep schools and resorts. From 1964 until his death, Alan was a member of the University Club in New York. Although he resigned from the University Club Council at the time of their refusal to admit female members, he continued as a life-long member. He was a member and past President of the Waccabuc Country Club, which he joined in 1956. He had many friends whom he loved and who loved him. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Gloria Wells Sidnam of NYC and Bedford NY, a daughter, Caroline (Coty) Northcote Sidnam, two grandchildren, Emma Pucci of Boulder, CO and Samuel Pucci of NYC, and three stepchildren, Pamela Thye of Greenwich, CT, Robert Meeker of Tar Heel, NC and Greg Ercolano of Pasadena, CA. His sister Jane Heath is presently living in a nursing home in Kalamazoo, MI. A memorial will be held at the University Club, 1 West 54th Street, on Friday, October 10th, 2008 from 2-5pm.

She is survived by her daughter, Elissa Ferretti, son Michael Catania, and sonin-law Joe Ferretti, grandchildren Joseph Ferretti and Diana Ferretti. Visitation will be 5-9pm today, Thursday, August 28, 2008 at Craft Memorial Home, Inc., 40 Leicester St., Port Chester, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be 10am on Friday, August 29, 2008 at Our Lady of Mercy Church, 260 Westchester Ave., Port Chester, NY. Interment to follow at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY.

In her speech Tuesday night at the Democratic National Convention, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton quoted the abolitionist Harriet Tubman as offering this advice: ''If you hear the dogs, keep going. If you see the torches in the woods, keep going. If there's shouting after you, keep going. Don't ever stop. Keep going. If you want a taste of freedom, keep going.'' But in interviews on Wednesday, two scholars say there is no evidence that Tubman, right, the organizer of the Underground Railroad, who died in Auburn, N.Y., in 1913, ever said those words. Instead, the passage appears to be a paraphrase of -- and perhaps an embellishment upon -- a popular expression that has been attributed to Tubman for decades, possibly starting with children's books in the mid-20th century.

FREEMAN--Melvin D. New York Medical College is saddened by the passing of a true humanitarian, our esteemed colleague and friend, Col. Melvin D. Freeman. A trustee of the College since 1993, Col. Freeman holds an honored place as one of the university's most steadfast supporters. We will miss Col. Freeman's optimism, kindness and wise counsel. We extend our heartfelt condolences to daughters Susan and Phyllis and their families. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Karl P. Adler, M.D. President and CEO Ralph A. O' Connell, M.D. Provost and Dean, School of Medicine FREEMAN--Melvin. Col. Melvin D. Freeman, USAF, Retired, of Chappaqua, NY (89), on August 26 from a longterm illness. He was a devoted husband of 63 years to his late wife Helen Yuder Freeman and a beloved father and grandfather. A graduate of St. John's University and New York University, he was a licensed psychologist employed by FEGS for almost 63 years where he was Director of Psychological Services and helped thousands of people find a better life. He and his late wife were lifelong philanthropists and generous benefactors to New York Medical College. Col. Freeman was a member of the Board of Trustees for New York Medical College, Family Services of Westchester and Physicians Home. He is survived by his two daughters, two grandchildren and a brother. Graveside services were held at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. FREEMAN--Melvin. The Board of Directors and Staff of FEGS Health and Human Services System mourn the passing of Melvin Freeman, Director of Psychological Services and member of the FEGS staff for 63 years. Mel joined FES (Federation Employment Service) in 1945. Following his work with returning veterans to help them establish careers, the agency would become FEGS (Federation Employment and Guidance Service). His long, prestigious and invaluable career and his integrity, honor and service will be long remembered. Our deepest sympathies to the entire Freeman family. Stuart Oltchick, President Joseph Stein Jr., Chair Gail Magaliff, CEO Ira Machowsky, EVP Al Miller, Exec. Consultant

COLON--Felix M. Clark & Wilkins mourns the passing of our colleague and friend, Felix M. Colon, who passed away on Friday, August 22, 2008, at 58. Felix joined our firm before he was 21 years old, and stayed his whole life. His hard work and dedication were a proud reflection of the man he was, the faith he possessed, and the responsibilities he assumed. He was a mentor, leader and confidant for our many workers and his skills as estimator and salesman earned him recognition as an officer of the firm and Vice President for Operations. We will miss him dearly. We offer our condolences and prayers to his wife, Alba, their daughters Giselle and Jasmine, and his dear mother. Kenneth F. Flowers, CEO Dennis S. Bogart, COO

ZARET--Sol, died peacefully August 25 in Hospice Care with his wife Mickey and friends by his side. Sol hung in there to celebrate his 91st birthday on August 22. He leaves also his loving family of three sons, David, Joshua and Peter; and three remarkable daughters-in-law, Julie Knost, Elisabeth Karlin and Marilyn Zaret; and two adored grandchildren, Anna and Max Zaret. After serving in the Pentagon with the Signal Corp. during World War II, Sol founded with his partner the Vinytex Co. in Hempstead, NY. A graduate of Brooklyn College with degrees in Physics and Engineering he spent most of his retired life researching and writing papers on the origins of our universe. Sol fought the good fight for all causes demanding civil rights and human dignity. He always practiced love, compassion, generosity and an abiding respect for all people. A memorial service will be held at the Finnerty - Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main St., Great Barrington, MA, Thursday, August 28 at 11:00am.

MILLER--Pearl C. After the sudden passing of her revered uncle Elias A. Cohen, on July 2, 1952, Pearl dedicated over 50 years of her life to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp. Leading by example and putting others before herself, Pearl taught thousands of boys and girls how to live, play and work together. She brought out the best in anyone fortunate enough to meet her. Following Pearl's example, and in the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige,'' her adoring family, the dedicated staff, a grateful alumni and so many loyal friends are all helping to perpetuate Tranquillity Camp as an enduring monument to this great leader. Together, we will do our best to ensure that all generations of Tranquillity's children will mark this day as one to remember our beloved ''Pearl'', the ultimate teacher. The Tranquillity family is proud to announce the successful completion of our 90th Camp season on August 26, 2008. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President Richard Lerner, Director

LeVINE--Jean Bovill, died on August 22, 2008 at the Homewood Residences in Naples, Florida. Jean is the cherished wife of Robert C. LeVine of Naples, Florida and devoted mother to their five children, Jeananne Stine, Robert B. LeVine, Mary LeVine, Ron LeVine, and Jamie LeVine. Born September 5, 1933 to James and Anna Peat Bovill in Avalon, Pennsylvania. Jean graduated from Bethany College in 1955 and was married to Bob LeVine in 1956. The couple moved to Manhattan in 1959, and were longtime residents of New York City and Westchester County, New York. Jean was active in the Hudson River Presbytery for many years. Jean is also survived by three sisters, Elizabeth Steele, Eileen Colburn, Olive Killen and seven adoring grandchildren. She will be remembered joyfully and with gratitude by all of us. Contributions may be made in lieu of flowers to the Grace Church Community Center Summer Camp, 35 Orchard Street, White Plains, New York 10603.

ABRAHAMS--Irving O., M.D. In Memoriam, 1927-2008. The Department of Dermatology at Columbia University mourns the loss of Irving O. Abrahams, M.D., who passed away on August 19 in Burlington, Vermont at the age of 81. Dr. Abrahams, a first generation American of Romanian and Lithuanian heritage, was a distinguished associate clinical professor of dermatology at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeon for forty years. He completed his residency in dermatology at ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center and joined the faculty in 1960. Prior to his tenure at Columbia, Dr. Abrahams was a graduate of New York University, served in the U.S. Navy for four years, and received his M.D. from the State University of New York, Downstate Medical Center. Dr. Abrahams was widely regarded in the medical community as a gifted and compassionate physician and devoted teacher. He was listed in the Best Doctors in New York, received an award as ''Teacher of the Year'' from the residents in the dermatology department, and was selected as the ''Practitioner of the Year'' by the Society of Practitioners at Presbyterian Hospital. Dr. Abrahams and his wife Nancy retired in 2000 and moved to South Burlington, Vermont. In addition to his wife, Dr. Abrahams is survived by six children, Julia Foster, Eve Abrahams Shutt, John and Charles Abrahams, Pamela Mitchell, and Jill Jertson; and by four grandchildren, Kenyon Shutt in California, and Kristen, Jacob, and Annalise Schumacher in Vermont. Dr. Abrahams epitomized the role of physicianeducator and was a great communicator. He made enduring contributions to the teaching programs of this department, was a mentor to many residents and faculty members and was beloved by his patients.

IN addition to fencing and security guards, builders are employing a variety of novel strategies to combat construction site theft. Some said they use deer cameras, which are normally used to monitor wildlife on hunting grounds. These sturdy, waterproof cameras snap pictures when they detect motion. Other builders said they have invested in wireless security systems like the Tattletale (starting at $800), from Tattletale Portable Alarm Systems in Westerville, Ohio. It pages them when thieves cross sensors strategically hidden throughout the job site. Then there are mobile surveillance units, like the $25,000 one at left manufactured by CPS Security Solutions of Gardena, Calif.

BASS--Robert. The New York Choral Consortium mourns the loss of our valued colleague and friend, Robert Bass, longtime conductor of the Collegiate Chorale. BASS--Bob, an incredible visionary with impeccable taste; an absolutely wonderful man who will be dearly missed. Steve Novick Evan Galen BASS--Robert. The musicians, staff, and trustees of the Orchestra of St. Luke's mourn the loss of their long time friend and colleague, Robert Bass. We will always cherish the memories of our long collaboration with him. He had a sense of artistic creativity and a joy of music that made each performance truly special. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. We extend our deep condolences to Juliana, Miranda, Jonathan and the rest of his family. Marianne C. Lockwood, Executive Director and President Orchestra of St. Luke's BASS--Robert. The Board of Directors of The Olga Forrai Foundation, Inc. are deeply saddened by the loss of our great friend and Artistic Advisor, Robert Bass. His courage and grace in facing a terrible illness were formidable, and certainly a bright light in our lives has gone out with his passing. Bob was one of the first grantees of The Foundation in the early nineteeneighties and has served as our Artistic Advisor for the past twenty years. His impeccable musical taste and instincts for realizing the potential for artistic success of opera singers and conductors in the early stages of their professional careers, made his advice to us invaluable in the process of our making decisions in how best to support and nurture these emerging artists. Bob's caring influence carried beyond his professional expertise and as one of our most recent grantees has expressed, ''...though I only knew him briefly, Maestro Bass seemed to me to be an extraordinarily lovely man, leader and musician. The way in which he indicated to me his interest and encouragement for my future career was very genuine and I felt that I had gained a real friend.'' We have no doubt that similar feelings must be shared by all of our grantees of the past two decades. The members of The Board of Directors of The Olga Forrai Foundation send their heartfelt condolences to Bob's wife, Juliana, his two children, Miranda and Jonathan and the rest of his family. His loss is great but his life and career, are an inspiration to us all who love music, those who make it, and the glory of the human voice when raised in song.

San Francisco -- Is Slow Food Nation the Woodstock of food or the Lollapalooza? Locals joke that the city's partying kids have all decamped here for Burning Man in the Nevada desert, replaced by middle-aged Slow Foodies who don't balk at a $4 peach - as long as it's from Frog Hollow Farms.

This week's column recounts an obscure fight involving a company that few people pay attention to anymore, XO Communications. Once a darling of the telecommunications set -- just like its competitors Global Crossing and Level 3 -- XO fell on hard times, just like, well, Global Crossing and Level 3. After filing for bankruptcy protection in 2003 -- a filing that cost Teddy Forstmann's private equity firm its entire $1.5 billion stake in the company -- XO emerged with a new chairman and majority shareholder: none other than Carl Icahn.

Is Argentina just now waking up from a long hangover after celebrating its victory in Olympic soccer? Hardly. The tournament barely made a ripple in Buenos Aires. The contrast is striking, and it says something about the importance of the tournament in countries that really care about soccer.
Admittedly, the summer of 2008 was not as crisis-driven as the summer last.

Religion | The humorist says "science requires more faith than God" because "we don't know what the scientists are talking about." People are "scared silly" by global warming, genetic engineering and nukes. "Religious zealots can't blow up the world the way scientists can." [Science & Spirit]

On and off this summer, between rounds of sudoku, I've worked my way through William Gaddis's third novel, "Carpenter's Gothic." Published in 1985, this book had long been on my list - partly from a simple desire to read everything, and partly from curiosity spurred by the amusing literary spat, a few years ago, between Jonathan Franzen and Ben Marcus. (Long story short: Franzen complained in The New Yorker that Gaddis was too difficult, whereupon Marcus complained in Harper's that Franzen was a sell-out philistine.)

Sarah Palin, who is Senator John McCain's pick for vice president, made an overt grab today for women voters and in particular for disaffected supporters of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who remains a central part of this election drama despite having dropped out of the race in early June.

Jelena Jankovic did not meet the same fate as her Serbian compatriot Ana Ivanovic. A day after the top seed was upset by a qualifier, Jankovic, the second seed, defeated Zheng Jie, the Wimbledon semifinalist, 7-5, 7-5 in a match that lasted 2 hours, 9 minutes.

Dan Schnur, the director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California, was the national communications director for John McCain's presidential campaign in 2000. (Full biography.)

I am the owner of a commercial condominium unit being used as a medical office on the ground floor of a residential co-op. Recently, several of my patients who had arrived before the office was open were ordered by the staff of the building to "go for a walk" or wait outside instead of sitting in the lobby of the building. One person from the building explained that since the owners of the condominiums are not entitled to use the lobby, their patients could not wait there either. As an owner in the building, what are my rights to use the lobby? Are my rights different from those of the co-op owners?

My wife and I are first-time home buyers, and so far we have done all the work ourselves and have not used an agent. Through our own research, we have found a home, and we are preparing to make an offer.

My lease renewal takes effect on Monday. I'm one of the lucky million New York City residents with a stabilized rental. Actually, I'm one of the really lucky ones who knows whether it's better to sign a one-year lease or a two-year lease.That's because my lease date falls in that odd summertime window when you can look ahead and know what the one-year rent increase will be not just for the next year but for the year after that.

A salad of corn, lobster and tomatoes is inevitable in August, and with perfect tomatoes and corn, the lobster can be almost an afterthought. In fact, the salad here is nearly as good with shrimp. But no matter what shellfish you use, the vegetables should steal the show.

Nature | Why do we keep buying new bird and nature field guides? asks an article noting their enduring popularity in a digital age. Because the tension "between the desire to grasp life and its ultimate ungraspability" plays out in their use. And that's a satisfying experience. [The Smart Set]

Aired Thursday night on NBC: Political experts say that John McCain is going to try to steal attention away from the Democrats tonight by leaking the name of his running mate. Experts say there's a pretty good chance that McCain will leak something else too.

Aired Thursday night on CBS: Last night, Barack Obama was officially nominated Democratic candidate for President of the United States. And I want to tell you something. I really think things are starting to look bad for Hillary.

Updated, Aug. 30 | In a few weeks, there will be a concert at Hostos Community College to advance the cause of five Cubans who have been imprisoned in the United States for almost a decade. Their supporters hail them as heroes, fighters against exile groups. Federal prosecutors said the five were spies and won convictions against them for conspiracy to commit crimes against the United States, with one convicted of conspiracy to commit murder.

Aired Thursday night on NBC: Quite a historic day. Barack Obama accepted the Democratic nomination for President of the United States. Barack gave his speech on the historic anniversary of Martin Luther King's "I Have a Dream" speech. And just two days after Hillary Clinton gave her "I Had a Dream" speech.

Let's talk about sex, baby: same-sex sex scenes, sexiness, sexing it up for go-sees. In other words, just another day in the day in the life of an actress - and all kind of awkward, Naomi Watts will have you know. Today in our latest Screen Test video, the ever sensual Academy Award nominee talks dirty with Lynn Hirschberg and calls her love scene with Laura Elena Harring in "Mulholland Drive" "one of the easiest" she's done. And proving that there's nothing sexier than a sense of humor, Watts does a hilarious, Oscar-worthy impersonation of Posh. Major!

In the hotly contested race for a State Senate seat in Brooklyn, Kevin S. Parker, the incumbent, has received the backing of Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization founded more than a century ago to fight the corruption of Tammany Hall.

Phil Hill died of complications from Parkinson's disease at the age of 81 on Thursday, as the obituaries say. Clearly, there was nothing he could do in face of the disease. For given the kind of racing world he survived, it would only be a disease entirely beyond his control that could get him.

Deputy Mayors Edward Skyler, Patricia E. Harris and Kevin Sheekey oppose a third term for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, while business leaders in the city generally support the idea. The debate exposes a crack in the administration's reputation for squabble-free, unified command. The deputy mayors have told associates that any campaign to change term limits, which restrict citywide elected offices to two consecutive four-year terms, could be viewed as an undemocratic end run around voters, who approved the current laws twice, in 1993 and 1996.

Art Official has been listed as the 9-5 favorite for Monday’s $392,850 Cane Pace, the first leg of the pacing Triple Crown for 3-year-olds. Art Official paced a record-setting mile in 1 minute 50 4/5 seconds, breaking the track record at Freehold Raceway in last week’s elimination races. It was also more than 2 seconds faster than the 1:53 clocking of Badlands Nitro, the other elimination winner. The top four finishers in each elimination advanced to the Cane final. Ron Pierce will drive Art Official, who will start from post No. 7. After the Cane moves on to the Little Brown Jug at the Delaware, Ohio, Fairgrounds on Sept. 18 and concludes with the Messenger Stakes at Yonkers Raceway on Oct. 25.
John Ruiz is returning to Berlin in a bid to win the World Boxing Association heavyweight belt for the third time in a bout against Nicolai Valuev on Saturday.

Curlin, the champion 3-year-old of 2007 and horse of the year, drew the No. 5 post in a field of eight Thursday, and was made the 3-5 morning-line favorite for Saturday’s $500,000 Woodward Stakes at Saratoga Race Course. Curlin, a 4-year-old who is regarded as the world’s best horse on dirt, goes for his sixth victory in a row on that surface in the mile-and-an-eighth Woodward. Of the seven challengers to Curlin, Divine Park is the most accomplished. He drew the No. 4 post.

YOUNG--Robert Winthrop Jr . Developed Ajax, Baggies, and Palmolive. Robert Winthrop Young, Jr., 85, the marketing expert who developed the House of Ajax ad its widely successful advertising campaign (the White Knight and the White Tornado), died August 26 after a long battle with cancer. Mr. Young was raised in Greenwich, CT and graduated from the St. Paul's School, Harvard College and Harvard Business School. A veteran of WWII, he joined the army his first year at Harvard. He attended Officer Candidate School in New Orleans, and was stationed in Alaska, where he served as a first lieutenant. Mr. Young was considered one of the leading experts in the development and marketing of new products. An executive with the Colgate-Palmolive company from 1959-1969 (General Manager, Household Product Division; Vice-President and Corporate Director of Marketing-Worldwide), he created a domestic new products development program, and similar programs worldwide. Under his innovative direction, Colgate developed a number of enduring successful product lines, including Ajax, Baggies, Palmolive and Fab. Mr. Young began his career with the Procter & Gamble Company, and then entered the field of advertising. In 1953, as an entrepreneur, and with his brother Andrew Plimpton Young (deceased), he started Golden Gift, Inc., the first company to market orange juice in cartons. The company was sold profitably in 1956 as the product form grew into a significant industry. Mr. Young then served as Vice-President of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising, where he supervised such diverse accounts as Lever Bros., Chase Bank, McKesson & Robbins, and Beecham Ltd. His corporate endeavors also reflected an altruistic and expansive approach to product development and marketing. While at Colgate he used the concept of ''inventing backward'' to invent a hand - operated washing machine for women living without electricity in underdeveloped areas of the world. His long-time collaborator Richard Walton created the machine itself, the ''Walton Washer,'' which was manufactured by Colgate in Mexico and sold for less than $10 throughout Central and South America. He resigned from Colgate in 1969 to pursue a solo career as a marketing and consultant and President of his own company, The Young Group, Inc. He continued to collaborate with Richard Walton on a diverse array of inventions, including a process to substantially decrease the tar inhaled when smoking cigarettes and a plush toy that plays the sound of a beating heart to soothe newborns. His creativity was not confined to the business world and new product development. He enjoyed a lifelong love of singing and performing, beginning as a boy soprano soloist in Greenwich, CT. He went on to sing with the Westminster Choir, in his own radio show as a First Lieutenant in the Army during World War II, as a member of the Hasty Pudding Club at Harvard (performing on stage with Jack Lemmon), then in Gilbert & Sullivan shows produced by the New York based Blue Hill Troupe, of which he became President. One of his favorite shows was the HMS Pinafore, in which he played the leading role. Later in life, after moving to Virginia, he sang baritone with the choir at Trinity Episcopal Church in Upperville, and performed in the two-character play Love Letters. Mr. Young also wrote short stories, poetry, and song lyrics. In his late 70s and early 80s he wrote the book and lyrics, and composer David Oliver wrote the music, for the show ''About Face.'' The show was performed by the Middleburg Players in Middleburg, Virginia, under the guidance of their founder Jean Gold. He was a graduate of the St. Paul's School and of Harvard (1945), where he served as an Editor of the National Lampoon. He was also a member of many clubs throughout his life, including the A.D. Club and Hasty Pudding Club at Harvard, the Racquet and Tennis Club (NYC), the Leash (NYC), the Chatham Yacht Club (Cape Cod, MA), the Piping Rock Country Club (Locust Valley, NY), the Shinnecock Golf Club (South Hampton, NY) and the Army-Navy Club (Washington, DC). He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Margot Airey Young, daughters Marie Bates of Greenwich, CT, Ellen Enns of Seattle, WA and Tracy Wells of Madison, NJ, step-daughter Honore Ryan and stepson Colvin Gregg Ryan, nephew Andrew Young, six grandchildren, two greatgrandchildren, and two grandnieces. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his name to: Blue Ridge Hospice 333 West Cork Street, Winchester, VA 22601.

GANNAWAY--Albert C. Jr. , film and television producer, writer and composer known best for the ''The Grand Ole Opry'' television series dies at age 88. Al Gannaway, a motion picture and television producer, writer, director and songwriter died on Wednesday in Baltimore, Maryland. He was 88. Mr. Gannaway produced several full length feature motion pictures during the 1950s and 1960s but is perhaps best known for his production of the long running weekly television series ''Stars of The Grand Ole Opry'' which featured many legendary country music stars including Chet Atkins, Marty Robbins, Minnie Pearl and many others. Mr. Gannaway was the first to produce a television series using 35mm color film when television broadcasting was exclusively in black and white. As a songwriter he wrote with Johnny Mercer and also wrote songs for Nat King Cole, Bob Hope and Frankie Lane. Mr. Gannaway is survived by his former wife, Dana Gibson Gannaway and his sons, Gary Gannaway, James Gannaway, Tyrone Young, his daughter-in-law, Wendy Gannaway and two granddaughters. A private memorial service will be held in New York City. The family has expressed their wish that gestures of sympathy in lieu of flowers be made by charitable donations to the ''Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine'', 100 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21201 with a note indicating the donation is in memory of Al Gannaway for the benefit of Dr. Marek Mirski Research.

This 5,502-square-foot town house faces Buttermilk Mountain and is about a mile from the center of Aspen. The house, which was built in 1998, is in the Maroon Creek Club, a private golf community. Membership in the club is not included in the price. The house, designed by the architect Robert Trown, has exposed beams, reclaimed wide-plank oak floors, gas fireplaces, cathedral ceilings, and a multi-level, open floor plan. There is a media room with a wet bar, a separate office or den, and an elevator. The bathrooms and kitchen have marble and granite countertops. There are five and a half bathrooms. The house's outdoor features include a deck with mountain views, a large flagstone patio and a waterfall. There is a two-car garage with a golf cart bay. Association fees: $14,000. Taxes: $9,200. Agent: Bob Starodoj, Mason Morse Real Estate, (888) 354-7500; www.masonmorse.com

Riot police officers in Bangkok clashed with protesters early Friday but were forced from a government compound. It was the demonstrators' third night occupying the grounds in an attempt to force Prime Minister Samak Sundaravej from office.

Israel is in the grip of a nightmarish tale of cross-generational infidelity, child abuse and murder. The story is blanketing the news media while police detectives speak of never having been so shaken by a case, and an anguished nation is asking how it could happen here, in a society that considers itself especially caring and intimate. The story centers on the killing of a blue-eyed 4-year-old French girl named Rose, her guileless smile haunting the front page of every newspaper. The police say she was killed by her grandfather, a 45-year-old Israeli who had lured her mother away from his own son, the dead girl's father, to be his lover. They say the man has confessed to having stuffed the child's body into a red suitcase and dumping it into a river. Divers are searching.

A realistic portrayal of New York City's Chinatown can be seen in a new animated movie, ''The Year of The Fish,'' which opens on Friday at the Angelika Film Center. The movie, an adaptation of a Cinderella-like Chinese fable, was shot in live-action, then adapted with rotoscope animation. That digital process allowed the filmmaker, David Kaplan, to create realistic animated scenes -- from the lion dance in the Chinese New Year's parade to senior citizens performing tai chi -- that are instantly recognizable to New Yorkers.

''There's no easy mile when you're hiking the entire length of the trail,'' said Luke Keim, who, as a ridge runner for the Appalachian Trail Conservancy, assists hikers along the Connecticut portion. ''But mile for mile, this state is one of the easiest on the trail.'' That makes it inviting not only for long-distance hikers, but for others who just want to get out for a few hours. There are some short, fairly steep climbs: between Bull's Bridge and the town center of Kent, the hump to 1,138-foot Mount Algo; north of Salisbury, the summit of 2,316-foot Bear Mountain. But most portions in Connecticut are known primarily for their beauty and accessibility.

MORRONE--Armondo Eddie . Mr. Morrone worked for Newark Evening News and NY Times, Armondo Eddie Morrone of Bloomfield passed away on Wednesday, August 27, 2008, at his home. Funeral Mass will be on Saturday at 10am at St. Cassians R.C. Church in Upper Montclair. Interment at Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Upper Montclair, to follow. Visiting is on Friday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm at Caggiano Memorial, 62 Grove St., Montclair. Born in Newark, Mr. Morrone lived in Bloomfield for the past 52 years. He was a World War II Army veteran and worked for the Newark Evening News and the NY Times for over 44 years before retiring in 1980. Mr. Morrone was a member of the Publishers-Newspaper and Mail Union in NYC. He was the devoted husband of the late Ida Edith Morrone (nee Barbarisi); loving father of Delinda Holland and her husband, Jay, Marlene Morrone, Deborah MorroneColella and her husband, Greg; dear brother of the late Thomas, Clara, Henry, Joseph, Lena, Edith and Victor; loving grandfather of seven, Michael, Shannon, Michelle, Christine, Martin, Matthew and Michael, and five cherished great-grandchildren, Gianna, Dominic, Erin, Tyler and Carley. The Danish-Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson has temporarily installed four waterfalls along the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Governors Island waterfronts. Above, the widest fall, and one of the easiest to spot, flows beneath the Brooklyn Bridge.

If the damp smell of offal doesn't do the trick, a hand-painted sign outside Musa's Slaughterhouse warns, ''No Hanging Out.'' This is routinely ignored by the goats who poke their fuzzy brown-and-white noses through the bars of their pen to peer at the passers-by on Third Avenue in the Bronx. After all, what worse punishment can befall these short-timers? On Tuesday, the sidewalk by the Morrisania slaughterhouse looked like a petting zoo for hard hats as construction workers digging a foundation next door strolled over to pet and take pictures of the goats. As one of them returned to his job, he said, ''They like to be petted.''

BASS--Robert . Bob's Thursday morning class mourns his passing. His loss creates a huge hole in all our lives. We are forever grateful that he introduced us to the sublime nuances of the voice with the generosity, humor and gentleness of a master teacher. Our deepest sympathy to the family.
The trumpeter Nicholas Payton, above, joins the guitarist Mark Whitfield and the bassist Christian McBride in a series of performances next week at Jazz Standard.

The seaside town in southwestern France is enjoying a renaissance, as people discover this aristocratic resort where worlds collide and expectations are upended. Once the reigning vacation spot for Europe's noble and gentry classes, Biarritz's golden shores are now shared by everyone from bronze beauties in designer sandals to drop-out surfers in frayed flip-flops. nytimes.com/escapes

DWINDLING VALUE Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac gave hefty servings of stocks and options to employees for decades, but those workers are reeling from falling stock prices. WALL STREET JOB CUTS Lehman Brothers is said to be preparing to lay off up to 1,500 people before the firm reports third-quarter results in mid-September. [C1.]

This condominium is the lowest-priced two-bedroom, two-bath unit currently listed in the heart of downtown Aspen. It is in the Silverglo condominium complex about four blocks from the gondola and within walking distance of downtown. The 698-square-foot unit, which dates from 1970, has been updated and renovated and is being offered fully furnished. The living room has a wood-burning stone-faced fireplace. There is an east-facing balcony with mountain views, and an eat-in kitchen. The condo complex has amenities including a heated outdoor swimming pool, a laundry room, a Jacuzzi and a reception desk. There is a common parking area. The condo has an excellent rental history. Association fees: $7,264. Taxes: $1,107. Agent: Tara Young, BJ Adams and Company- Aspen, (970) 922-2111; www.bjac.net.

HARBURGER--Gladys . Thanks to Patti, Jim and a loving extended family for sharing Gladys Harburger with so many of us. This petite dynamo traveled every subway line and knew more about the people of NYC than any sociologist or ethnographer. She earned immediate respect and credibility from young and old people of all walks of life. She had an unwavering belief in human potential and acted on that conviction. She was a remarkable example of a loving and gracious life. Our consolation is the next generation of son, daughter, nieces, nephews, grandchildren and friends she leaves to carry on what she taught us. Angela HARBURGER--Gladys. Our deepest condolences to Patti and Jim as they mourn the death of their beloved mother and celebrate her extraordinary life. The Flemister Family

THOMS--Charles W. , on August 25 of Delray Beach, Florida, formerly of Garden City. Charles was born on January 9, 1918 to William and Bertha (Chrismer). Predeceased by his loving wives Jane (Jackson), Seneca Maria (Demolat/Pasotti), and Marilyn (Pretch/Altsheler). Loving father of Constance ThomsMazur and son-in-law Leo Mazur. Charles was a graduate of UCLA, Phi Delta Theta, and served in WWII both in Europe and the Pacific earning a Bronze Star. Visiting at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, Franklin Ave and 12th St., Garden City on Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn at 11am on Saturday.

FOR CHILDREN 'ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO' (Friday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series ''Dora the Explorer'' and ''Go, Diego, Go!'' have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, whose new exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego's Animal Rescue Center and Dora's Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., the Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street, (212) 721-1223, cmom.org. Free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members.

Drive-by art appreciation, whizzing by masterpieces, can be a hazard in a city, or a museum, chock full of them. It's Labor Day Weekend. Slow down. Take a closer look. Or if you insist on having a purpose, use this mini-quiz to set your course. In these last weeks of summer the Weekend section has been inviting readers to enjoy a series of details sought and captured by Librado Romero, a staff photographer for The New York Times, and to seek out the works in which they appear. All are now on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Last Friday's images came from tabletops, miniature still lifes in unexpected corners of larger works. This week we offer patterns: the bold or subtle repetitions of strokes or shapes that an artist has chosen as a means of expression. The pieces' titles and artists, along with a fresh set of details, will be printed next Friday; the works that yielded last week's details are identified at right.

Rafael Nadal, playing in his first major as the top-ranked men's player, advanced to the Open's fourth-round on Saturday with a tough 6-4, 6-3, 6-0 victory over Victor Troicki of Serbia. Troicki, ranked 71st, kept close to Nadal for the first set and a half on Ashe Stadium, taking a 3-1 lead in the second set. But he would not win another game. After squandering two break points with Nadal serving at 5-3 in the second, Troicki became deflated and Nadal felt secure for the first time in the match.
What are we to make of this?

Ohio State linebacker James Laurinaitis won the Butkus award last season and the Nagurski award the season before that. He recently spoke to Thayer Evans about why he wanted to play one more year with the Buckeyes, the criticism Ohio State has received for its struggles in the B.C.S. title game and the experience of attending his first concert.

Scornful Chileans laugh. The U.N. doesn't; it has tapped Bolivian boats for Haitian peacekeeping. Nor is Hugo Chávez sniggering. He's paying to overhaul the "toy" navy. [Guardian]

Jimmie Johnson was easily the fastest driver on the two-mile oval at the Auto Club Speedway in Fontana, Calif. He won the pole for the Pepsi 500 on Sunday with a fast lap of 180.397 miles an hour, followed by Jeff Gordon, A. J. Allmendinger and Kasey Kahne.

The National Football League suspended Minnesota Vikings left tackle Bryant McKinnie on Friday for four games without pay for violating the league’s personal conduct policy. He is eligible to return Sept. 29. McKinnie has pleaded not guilty to charges stemming from a street brawl outside a Miami nightclub in February.

The professional golfer Tripp Isenhour pleaded no contest to charges that he killed a protected hawk in Orlando, Fla. His lawyer, David de Armas, said Isenhour agreed to a year of supervised probation, 4 hours of anger management classes and 100 hours of community service. Isenhour was charged with animal cruelty and killing a migratory bird; he was accused of hitting the bird with a golf shot after its chirps interrupted the filming of an instructional video.

The National Basketball Players Association suspended the agent Calvin Andrews for one year. Andrews was accused of recruiting improprieties regarding the former Southern California star O. J. Mayo. Mayo, who played one season at U.S.C. and was drafted third over all by the Memphis Grizzlies, has denied receiving improper funds. Mayo is now represented by Leon Rose, also LeBron James’s agent.

Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel has agreed to contract revisions that will make him the highest-paid football coach in the Big Ten Conference. The university said that the revisions would be phased in this year and that Tressel’s compensation next year would be $3.5 million, an increase of more than $1 million annually.

Pamela Jelimo, an 18-year-old Kenyan, upstaged Usain Bolt and his victory in the 100 meters at the Weltklasse meet in Zurich. Jelimo won the women’s 800 in 1 minute 54.01 seconds, the fastest time in more than two decades and the third fastest in history.

San Antonio Spurs guard Manu Ginóbili, who helped Argentina to a bronze medal at the Beijing Olympics, will need surgery to repair a ligament injury in his left ankle. The Spurs said Ginóbili would have surgery next week, when it would announce a timeline for his return. Ginóbili said a magnetic resonance imaging exam of his ankle showed no improvement from a previous exam two months ago. He led the Spurs in scoring last season with 19.5 points and won the league’s sixth-man award.
Deanna Nolan scored 26 points and Katie Smith added 14 for the Detroit Shock, which clinched a playoff spot with an 83-69 victory over the Liberty in a W.N.B.A. game in Auburn Hills, Mich.

DIAMOND--Joseph Frances , 48, beloved son, brother, uncle, cousin and friend, passed away suddenly on August 28th. His beautiful soul, his loving heart and his wonderful music will always be treasured. Funeral will be Monday, September 1, 10am at Ahavath Israel Synagogue, Chestnut Street, Liberty, NY. www.josephngarlickfuneral home.com

GROSSMAN--Carl , 78, of Woodmere passed away on August 29th, 2008. Carl resided in Woodmere for the past 45 years. He was President of Commercial Trading Co., NYC. He has a lifetime of philanthropic endeavors and was dedicated to many causes. He is survived by his loving wife, Alice; three sons, Scott, Glenn and Peter; and seven grandchildren. He was a dedicated and good friend to many people. The funeral will be held on Sunday, August 31st, 2008 at ''BoulevardRiverside'' Chapels Hewlett, NY at 2pm. Donations may be made to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Woodbury, NY 11797.

FRIEDMAN--Deborah L. , born December 17, 1922, died on August 20, 2008 in New York City, the daughter of the late William Friedman and Stella Oberstein. A lifelong Manhattan resident, Debby was a graduate of Hunter College and the Columbia School of Public Health. She worked as a medical editor, retiring in 1988. She enjoyed photography, swimming, travel and her family. She lived in Israel for a time in the early 1950s and had many friends there. Debby was a founding member of the 1270 Fifth Avenue Cooperative and served the Coop in various capacities. She is survived by her sister Selma Kumin, niece Laura Kumin and nephew David Kumin, and their children and spouses.

(CMT) CMT'S BIGGEST REDNECK WEDDING EVER Elaine and Bruce, a Florida couple, had dreams of a shoes-optional wedding with paper-napkin invitations, a mud-pit ceremony and honor attendants attired in tank tops and cutoffs. But then their caterer fell through. And they couldn't afford real flowers. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: KATHARINE HEPBURN This all-day tribute spans five decades in Hepburn's career, starting with ''Morning Glory'' (1933), about a stage-struck girl determined to make it on Broadway, at 6 a.m., and continuing with ''Mary of Scotland'' (1936) at 7:15; ''Little Women'' (1933) at 12:30 p.m.; and a Cary Grant double bill, ''Bringing Up Baby'' (1938) at 2:30 and ''The Philadelphia Story'' (1940) at 4:15. The evening segment includes ''Woman of the Year'' (1942) at 8; ''The African Queen'' (1951) at 10; and ''On Golden Pond'' (1981) at 2:15 a.m.

STONE--Marlene Lois Singer , loving wife, adoring mother and grandmother, dearest friend to so many people, passed away August 29th, 2008, after battling cancer for over two years. She leaves behind her husband of 51 years, Richard, her children Nancy and Joel Poznansky, Amy Stone, Elliot and Bonnie Stone and her five grandchildren William, David, Deborah Poznansky and Lily and Elizabeth Stone. She was born, January 22, 1936, in Wheeling, West Virginia, but grew up in Miami, Florida, daughter of William D. and Esther Singer. She graduated Valedictorian from Miami Senior High School and received her B.A. from Vanderbilt University, graduating magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa. Marlene Stone was an invaluable companion to her husband Richard, who served his city and state in elected positions as Miami City Attorney, Florida State Senator, Florida Secretary of State, and United States Senator from Florida. Marlene was ''First Lady'' to Richard Stone who served his country as Ambassador at Large to Central America and Ambassador to Denmark. Forty years of public life took the Stones from Miami, to Tallahassee, to Washington, DC and to Denmark. In each of these places, Marlene created a warm, inviting home and made lifelong friends. It was as hostess of her memorable parties and intimate dinners that she connected to people with her sense of style, humor and grace. Marlene was an avid reader, a devotee of duplicate bridge, and a supporter of the arts and many charitable organizations. She enjoyed a close relationship with her sister Dottie Jacobs and her brother Larry Singer and their families Funeral services will be held at Adas Israel Congregation, Sunday, August 31st at 11:00am, 2850 Quebec Street, NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, please honor her memory with contributions to the charity of your choice

MARX--Emilie Hyman , 86, of Naples, Florida died at home with friends and family August 13, 2008. Born August 17, 1921 in Rochester, NY to Alfred H. Hyman and Esther Olson graduated from Vassar College in 1944. Soloed J3 Piper Cub 1945. Ran Old Lyme Book Shop. A life long pacifist. She is survived by son Arthur Marx III, Margaret Gibbons Marx, nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations to Blythedale Children's Hospital Valhalla, NY.

And then on Friday he picked as his running mate a 40-something candidate with two years in major office and no significant foreign policy experience.

COLE--Sylvia Dym , born September 3, 1915, distinguished teacher and author, died at home on August 27, 2008. Valedictorian of her class at Hunter College High School, she was graduated with honors from Hunter College and elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She mesmerized generations of students of English at Bayside High School in New York City; hosted a talk show on WNYC with her husband Abraham Lass, a well-known educator; authored an autobiography, ''Remembering the Bough of Summer and the Winter Branch'', two books on literary allusions and contributed to ''The Family of Man'' photographic collections. Her first husband and father of her two sons, Richard Saunders, a Broadway, radio and television actor, died in 1961. Her second husband, Abraham Lass, died in 2001. She is survived by her loving sons, Stephen Cole and Jonathan R. Cole, by her beloved partner, John Palmer, by her daughters-in-law, Maria and Joanna and by her grandchildren and their spouses and partners, Richard Cole, Daniel Cole and Nicholas Grinder, Robert and Carrie Cole, and Susanna Cole and Gabriel Bach. A memorial service will be held at The Lotos Club, 5 East 66th Street, on Monday, September 15th at 4pm.

FERBER--Fred , on August 27, 97 years. Beloved husband of the late Frances Ferber, loving father of Betty Ferber and Bob Pomerance, Judith Ferber and Gary Altman, devoted grandfather of Laura, Sara, Paula and Aaron. Loving uncle to Joel Einleger and Miriam Westheimer, and devoted Papa Fred to Ari and Leora. Dear uncle to many nieces and nephews and their families. Services Sunday, August 31st, 12 noon, King Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, NJ.

As Hugh described yesterday, Gustav underwent rapid intensification Friday evening through Saturday afternoon. In 24 hours ending Saturday evening, the central pressure fell 34mb, and in 23mb in 12 hours. It strengthened from a 60kt tropical storm to a 130kt CAT4 hurricane in 27 hours. Unfortunately, it accomplished this while heading for, and passing over, western Cuba, causing severe damage.

Hurricane Gustav's approach to the Louisiana coast has been watched with great interest by insurers who are prepared both logistically and financially for the storm. Insurers have been prepositioning resources for days north of the anticipated strike zone. These resources include satellite-linked catastrophe response vehicles, claims adjusters, communications staff and other technical experts. As soon as allowed by local officials, these resources will be deployed into the disaster area to begin the claims settlement process.

Last week the New York Post's Page Six picked up on a story that had been widely circulated on the blogosphere. The magazine Wine Spectator was the victim of a hoax when it came out that its "award of excellence" had been given to a restaurant that did not exist. Robin Goldstein, a wine critic who said that he wanted to expose the lack of any foundation for many food and wine awards, had submitted an application that included the menu and wine list of a fictitious restaurant he named Osteria L'Intrepido. Goldstein revealed the hoax within a week or so of the announced award and declared that what he had done proved that "the level of scrutiny" that accompanies such awards is "insufficient."Stung by the adverse publicity his magazine was receiving, Executive Editor Thomas Matthews fought back with an account of what he termed "the actual facts of the matter" on the Wine Spectator web site. He said that "we do not claim to visit every restaurant in our Awards program" or "review the restaurant as a whole." Rather, "[we evaluate] the content, accuracy and presentation of wine lists."

At 6:00 PM on August 30th, Gustav has been intensifying rapidly all day. "Rapidly intensifying" is one of those meteorological terms of art. In this case it means tropical storm at 2:00 PM yesterday, Category 4 hurricane at 6:00 PM tonight. An eye appeared intermittently yesterday, and we have that beautiful and deadly pattern with cloud bands spiraling inward under a circular, central dense overcast that surrounds a clear eye. In a satellite picture, the dark spot at the center of the eye is blue water. This cloud pattern has been shaping up all day as Gustav slid over warm surface waters of the Caribbean.

A judge in Centre County, Pa., has refused to accept a plea agreement of two years’ probation for a former Penn State receiver accused of threatening a teammate with a knife. The former receiver, Chris Bell, pleaded guilty to making terroristic threats in connection with a confrontation with defensive end Devon Still on April 7. Bell is accused of threatening Still with an eight-inch knife at a dining hall. Bell was kicked off the team after the arrest.

Valuev (49-1) regained the title he lost last year to Ruslan Chagaev. The Quick Bite article on Aug. 17 about Q Restaurant and Bar in Mount Kisco referred incorrectly to the availability of bourbon and beer there. Alcoholic beverages are served at Q’s Port Chester location; its liquor license in Mount Kisco is pending. The article also misstated an offer for children to eat free. The offer applies to one child 12 or under for each adult entree and is good only on Wednesdays. All children 12 and under do not eat free on any day if one adult orders an entree.

WEYMOUTH--Katharine Lewars (duPont), 87, passed away peacefully on Friday August 22, 2008 at her summer home on Fishers Island, NY. She was born in 1921 in Philadelphia, PA and was the daughter of the late Katharine Price Lewars and the late Thomas Belfield Lewars. She attended the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, PA and Lower Merion High School in Ardmore, PA. She graduated from Wheelock College in Boston where she served on their Board of Trustees. Katharine was the widow of State Senator Reynolds duPont of Greenville, DE and Fishers Island, NY and also the widow of George T. Weymouth of Greenville, DE and Boca Grande, FL. Katharine is survived by a wonderfully large family which includes her daughter, Katharine duPont Sanger; son Reynolds duPont, Jr.; son Thomas Lewars duPont and his wife, Ruth; daughter Natalie duPont Lyon and her husband, Frank R. Lyon, Jr.; and son Michael Belfield duPont. Surviving her are a long list of grandchildren including Penn duPont Sanger and his wife, Jennifer; Christopher Durant Sanger and his wife, Nina; Heidi Anne duPont; Reynolds duPont III and his wife, Elizabeth; Jameson Coffey duPont; Jessica duPont Thiel and her husband Eric; Molly Becker duPont and her husband, Trevor Schaffer; Sarah duPont Hendriksen and her husband Edwin; Katharine Lyon Jackson and her husband, Matthew; Brianne Lyon Jarvis and her husband, Benjamin; Kyley Wallace Lyon, Michael Belfield duPont Jr.; Edward Reynolds duPont and Bennett Lammot duPont. Greatgrandchildren include Peter and Cassie Sanger, Eleanor duPont, Tommy, Tyler and Greta Thiel, Teddy and Wilson Schaffer, Sophie and William Hendriksen, Stephen and Connor Jackson and Mason Jarvis. Katharine is also survived by Patricia Weymouth Hobbs, George A. ''Frolic'' Weymouth and Eugene E. Weymouth and their many children and grandchildren. Katharine was predeceased by her brother Thomas Belfield Lewars Jr. and her twin sister Margaret Lewars Ogden. She is survived also by several nieces and nephews and Godchildren to whom she was most deeply devoted. Katharine was predeceased by an infant grandson, Frank R. Lyon IV and a granddaughter, Emily A. duPont. She was also pre-deceased by her son-in-law, Peter Durant Sanger. Katharine's involvement in a myriad of organizations in Wilmington, Boca Grande and Fishers Island left an indelible imprint. Her volunteer service to cultural, medical, historical and educational boards spanned many decades and her roles as both a leader and mentor will long be remembered. Her greatest legacy will remain that of her family. Katharine's generosity and grace, engaging smile and love won her the love and respect of people of many generations. Her gifts of a wonderful sense of humor, undying love of family and loyalty to friends and her willingness to help others will serve as reminders of her wonderful spirit. The family is most grateful to the many years of companionship and friendship offered to her by Kathleen Rupprecht and the compassionate care given to her especially by Josephine Flinn and Ann Egerton over the past two years as well that of many other caregivers in particular East End Hospice of Westhampton Beach, Long Island. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 28, 2008 at St. John's Church, Fishers Island, NY. Interment will be private. A memorial service will also be held in Wilmington, DE at 11am on Friday, September 12, 2008 at Christ Church Christiana Hundred, Greenville, DE. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that gifts in Katharine's memory be made to Christiana Care Health System, Office of Development, P.O. Box 1668, Wilmington, DE 19885-9320 and also St. John's Church/ Sanger Fund, P.O. Box 505, Fishers Island, NY 06390. Services by Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory. www. chandlerfuneralhome.com

KLEIN--Florence Ethel, formerly of Great Neck, NY, passed away at her home in Champaign, IL, August 22. Mother of Rabbi Norman (Dr. Andrea) of Champaign, and David of Marshfield, VT, grandmother of Tessa, Sarah and Samuel. She was an NYC school teacher .

It would be hard to find a team more stunned by a loss than the DALLAS COWBOYS were when they fell to the Giants in the playoffs last season after having secured the N.F.C.'s top seed. The Cowboys are loaded again, so home-field advantage is again in the offing for the best offense in the N.F.C. But going 11 consecutive seasons without a playoff win stings. If that doesn't spur on the Cowboys to a deep playoff run, nothing will. The offense added running back Felix Jones in the draft, and his shiftiness could be a perfect complement to Marion Barber III's power. And if Adam Jones -- formerly Pacman -- can stay on the field, and if the rookie cornerback Michael Jenkins is a hit immediately, the secondary, the only weakness on the defense, should be solved. For good measure, the Cowboys added the veteran linebacker Zach Thomas, who is expected to provide leadership in a locker room full of young guns. In the end, though, the Cowboys' season may come down to Tony Romo. Bill Parcells used to warn him not to become a celebrity quarterback, but with Jessica Simpson hanging around, that's unavoidable. No more trips to Mexico during the bye week, Tony. Buckle down, and Dallas is the favorite to be in the Super Bowl. No Super Bowl champion has ever flown further under the radar than the GIANTS. They had a relatively peaceful training camp that even Plaxico Burress couldn't disrupt with his foot/contract issues. When Brett Favre blew into town to join the Jets, the Giants receded further from the spotlight. Things were going swimmingly until the Pro Bowl defensive end Osi Umenyiora, the Giants' best pass rusher, sustained a season-ending knee injury. The Giants are stocked with pass rushers, but this was a big loss. With Michael Strahan retired and Umenyiora hurt, the team that used its pass rush as a bludgeon on the Patriots in the Super Bowl has gone from a future Hall of Famer and a Pro Bowl player at the ends to having one player who played linebacker last season and another who started only twice. Jeremy Shockey is also gone, and while that removes some of the thrill from the offense, it also removes a lot of headaches from everywhere else. The real question is whether Eli Manning will return as the clutch playoff performer or the inconsistent quarterback of the regular season. If he truly turned the corner in January, the Giants will be a force for years. The defense will still be solid without Umenyiora, and the Giants' offense has loads of young talent, especially if the receivers can regain their health. If Manning's inconsistency returns, the Giants will be in a wild-card fight, because their division is as tough as ever. No matter. Repeating as Super Bowl champs is tough, especially with your best player on injured reserve, but would anyone rule them out after last season?

Steve Warshak, founder of a company accused of cheating customers out of millions of dollars, mainly through sales of so-called male enhancement products, was sentenced last week to 25 years in prison. Mr. Warshak was also fined $93,000 by a federal judge in Cincinnati last week, or $1,000 for each count of fraud, conspiracy and money laundering on which he was convicted in February.

HEROLD--John S. Widely known in the investment community for his company's authoritative reports on the petroleum industry, died at Connecticut Hospice on August 23, 2008 at age 96. He was a resident of New Canaan, CT for 49 years, recently moving to North Branford. He, with his wife of 72 years, the former Peggy Schusser of Greenwich, enjoyed a long and varied career. Graduating from the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University in 1936, he and Peggy moved to the southwestern U.S. where he worked as an explorative geologist for a number of oil companies. His work there was terminated in July 1941 when he was ordered to active duty as an Ensign in the U.S. Navy. Assigned to the U.S.S. William P. Biddle, an amphibious troop transport, he participated in seven amphibious assault operations in the European and Pacific theaters. In late 1944 he returned to the U.S. to commission and assumed command, as a lieutenant commander, of the U.S.S. Waukesha, a 14,000 ton amphibious assault ship. Following various independent operations in the far Pacific, Waukesha joined Task Force 31 to land the first allied seaborne troops on the Japanese homeland on August 30, 1945, followed by occupation of atom-bombed Nagasaki in September. As a civilian John resumed his work as a geologist. In 1948 he organized John S. Herold, Inc., specializing in the preparation and publication of appraisal reports on petroleum companies. He retired in 1984 when he sold his business to Arthur Smith of Houston, TX. He is survived by his wife, Peggy, his children, Susan, John and wife Julie, grandson Christopher and wife Nicole, greatgranddaughters Sadie and Delilah. Sons Robert and David predeceased him. A celebration of John's life will take place at a later time. Memorial donations may be made to: Doctors without Borders USA, Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030 or Waveney Care Center, 3 Farm Road, New Canaan, CT 06840. See obit at http://www.wsclancy.com

A walking tour of three neighborhoods last month offered a glimpse into the spottiness of post-Hurricane Katrina recovery efforts throughout New Orleans. A row of newly built or renovated homes are often juxtaposed with gutted ones or empty lots. Though in some estimates the city may have recovered up to 70 percent of its population, about 65,000 residences -- more than a third of the total -- remain blighted. Rebuilding is far from complete, though two-thirds of the Road Home money has been disbursed.

ALASKANS and Hawaiians make up about 0.7 percent of Americans. As such, they are extremely well represented in national politics this year. Last week, Senator John McCain picked Alaska's governor, Sarah Palin, to be his running mate. ''Barry'' Obama, as he was known in his Honolulu high school, is their Democratic rival. Mr. Obama was born in Hawaii, then spent part of his childhood in Indonesia until returning to Hawaii at age 10. Ms. Palin, who was born in Idaho, moved with her family to Alaska when she was an infant.

MILBURN--Frank Hinckley, 63, died in New York City on August 26, 2008. He was the husband of Maria Vicien-Milburn. Born in Wilmington, DE on June 10, 1945, he was the son of the late Devereux and Elizabeth C. Milburn. He attended St. Pauls' School, the Fay School, and Colorado Academy. After his service in the United States Army, he graduated from Franconia College. Mr. Milburn was the author of the novels The Interloper and Sheltered Lives, and a history of polo entitled Polo: The Emperor of Games. In addition to his wife, he leaves two children, Elizabeth and Alexandra of New York City. He was the brother of Devereux, John, Nancy, and Michael Milburn, and Elizabeth Morris. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to New York Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065, in memory of Frank Hinckley Milburn, to benefit diabetes research.

GANNAWAY--Albert C. Jr., film and television producer, writer and composer known best for the ''The Grand Ole Opry'' television series dies at age 88. Al Gannaway, a motion picture and television producer, writer, director and songwriter died on Wednesday in Baltimore, Maryland. He was 88. Mr. Gannaway produced several full length feature motion pictures during the 1950s and 1960s but is perhaps best known for his production of the long running weekly television series ''Stars of The Grand Ole Opry'' which featured many legendary country music stars including Chet Atkins, Marty Robbins, Minnie Pearl and many others. Mr. Gannaway was the first to produce a television series using 35mm color film when television broadcasting was exclusively in black and white. As a songwriter he wrote with Johnny Mercer and also wrote songs for Nat King Cole, Bob Hope and Frankie Lane. Mr. Gannaway is survived by his former wife, Dana Gibson Gannaway and his sons, Gary Gannaway, James Gannaway, Tyrone Young, his daughter-in-law, Wendy Gannaway and two granddaughters. A private memorial service will be held in New York City. The family has expressed their wish that gestures of sympathy in lieu of flowers be made by charitable donations to the ''Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine'', 100 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21201 with a note indicating the donation is in memory of Al Gannaway for the benefit of Dr. Marek Mirski Research.

10:30 P.M. (13) ATCHAFALAYA HOUSEBOAT In the early 1970s the writer Gwen Carpenter Roland and her childhood companion Calvin Voisin left civilization to live in the Atchafalaya Basin in Louisiana, the nation's largest river swamp, just as their great-grandparents had. They built a floating home by hand (above, with Ms. Roland) and lived in the unspoiled bayou for nearly a decade. Along the way, C. C. Lockwood photographed the couple, who have long since separated, and they appeared in National Geographic magazine in 1978. In this documentary Ms. Roland recounts the days she and Mr. Voisin spent in the imperiled basin, where they caught and grew their own food, sewed clothes, bartered for staples, traded stories and became adults together. 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: SPENCER TRACYFrom 1930 to 1967, the year he died, Tracy filmed more than 70 movies and earned nine Academy Award nominations for best actor. This all-day tribute begins with ''San Francisco'' (1936), the Clark Gable-Jeanette MacDonald gambling-hall romance starring Tracy as a priest, before moving on to two of the nine films he made with his longtime companion, Katharine Hepburn: ''Without Love'' (1945), about a marriage of convenience, at 2:30 p.m., and ''Adam's Rib'' (1949), in which husband-and-wife lawyers argue opposite sides in a women's rights case, at 4:30. The evening segment begins with ''Boys Town'' (1938), his second Oscar-winning role, at 6:15; and ''Captains Courageous'' (1937), his first, at 8.

Wilson's struggles were the result of bone spurs in his elbow, Francisco has closer stuff, as evidenced by his 67 strikeouts in his first 53 1/3 innings. Johan Santana will get a chance to quiet those Mets fans who demand more than just a good season for all of those Wilpon millions. Santana will make two key starts this week: against the Milwaukee ace Ben Sheets and the Philadelphia ace Cole Hamels.
GINGOLD--Jeffrey. Jeff, you are forever in our hearts. We love you, Arl and Bonnie

To the Editor: Re ''The Boy in the Bullpen'' (New York Observed, Aug. 24), about the author's recollection of talking his father into a trip to Yankee Stadium in 1961 and then meeting some of the Yankees:

Paging Peyton Manning. The quarterback was barely seen during the INDIANAPOLIS COLTS' training camp, after having an infected bursa sac removed from his left knee in July. The cloak of secrecy fueled speculation that Manning could be unavailable -- or at least not as good as usual -- when the season starts and that the Colts could slip out of the league's upper echelon. Don't count on it. It's hard to imagine Manning, who has never missed a start, missing the first one in the Colts' new stadium. And a less-than-perfect Manning is still better than most quarterbacks. The Colts are still one of the most loaded, balanced teams in the N.F.L. If receiver Marvin Harrison is back to form after the knee injury that short-circuited most of last season, and defensive end Dwight Freeney comes back from the foot injury that ended his year, the Colts will again battle the Patriots for supremacy in the A.F.C. Incredibly bad health doomed the Colts last season, but this was the only division in the N.F.L. that had three teams with 10 or more victories. As Jacksonville, Tennessee and even Houston close in, the Colts -- and whoever else makes it to the playoffs -- will get beaten up more and more in the division, endangering their chances for a top playoff seed. The JACKSONVILLE JAGUARS were the hottest team entering the playoffs last season, but their loss to the Patriots reflected their biggest problem: no pass rush. They need it to beat Tom Brady, but first they have to get past Manning to secure a home-field postseason game. That was why they went after two of the draft's best rushers: Derrick Harvey and Quentin Groves. It's always dicey to rely on rookies, but just as important may be how well the new receivers Jerry Porter, who is returning from an off-season hamstring injury, and Troy Williamson get up to speed with quarterback David Garrard. This was the first time Garrard had an entire off-season to prepare as the starter -- he was superb last year after winning the job in training camp -- and if the passing game can meld with a superb running attack, the Jaguars may make a deep playoff run.

MARX--Emilie Hyman, 86, of Naples, Florida died at home with friends and family August 13, 2008. Born August 17, 1921 in Rochester, NY to Alfred H. Hyman and Esther Olson graduated from Vassar College in 1944. Soloed J3 Piper Cub 1945. Ran Old Lyme Book Shop. A life long pacifist. She was predeceased by her first husband, Paul Wolf killed in action during WWII, and by her husband of 55 years, Arthur Marx, Jr. and children Alfred and Kathryn. She is survived by son Arthur Marx III, Margaret Gibbons Marx, nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations to Blythedale Children's Hospital Valhalla, NY.

McLain Ward hopped off the jet from humid Hong Kong, where he helped the United States Equestrian Team secure an Olympic gold medal, his second career team gold, and hopped onto Phillipa, the statuesque chestnut mare he rode to an unremarkable 33rd-place finish in a $7,500 Open Jumper event Tuesday afternoon under summer postcard conditions at the Hampton Classic. He did not appear perturbed by the disparity: the gold medal Olympian finishes in the middle of the pack in a small potatoes class back home in New York, where he operates Castle Hill Farm in Brewster, in Putnam County, with his father, Barney.

SEVENTY years ago, death came howling on the ocean. The hurricane of 1938 -- back in the years before the government gave names to storms -- pushed a 15-foot surge and battering waves ahead of it that flooded parts of Westhampton Beach, Southampton and Montauk on Long Island. More than 50 people were killed there, and hundreds of houses were washed away or ruined. The storm hit land at the lightly populated East End on Sept. 21 and then traveled on to do even more damage in New England, and, all told, claimed more than 600 lives.

When Peter Simons, president of La Maison Simons department stores in Quebec, returned from a vacation last Sunday, he had more than the usual backlog of e-mail. About 300 customers had written to complain about the extreme thinness of the adult models featured in the store's 36-page back-to-school clothing catalog. Mr. Simons responded by withdrawing all remaining copies of the catalog, removing the images from the store's Web site and issuing an apology online. The move won praise from public health officials in Quebec.

AT THE WESTERN WALL, JUNE 30, 2008 Jacques Sarfatti, 46, an executive recruiter from São Paulo, Brazil, with his son Michel, 7. ''We were thinking about going to Israel for some years, mainly to show our kids our roots. We're a Jewish family. On my side I'm a son of Egyptians that left Egypt in 1957 and came to Brazil. My wife is the granddaughter of people who left Poland. It's a strong sensation to be part of the large and diverse community praying at the wall: some people talking in Russian, in English, in French, people from all over the world coming and praying and hoping for many things. We even met some Brazilians there that we know. It's a very special place. I would say, yes, Michel understood what he had been learning for so many years in Brazil, about the wall, the history and why we pray in front of it. I have two more kids not in the picture: Raiana, who is 12, and Yuri, who is 15. They study Hebrew and Jewish culture in Brazil, and now they have a real sense of what Israel is like. I think that they saw the contrast that Israel has: Tel Aviv to Jerusalem to Masada. Everyone would like to go back soon. It was not just the history, not just the religion. We had a lot of fun.'' As told to Seth Kugel
