COLE--Sylvia Dym, born September 3, 1915, distinguished teacher and author, died at home on August 27, 2008. Valedictorian of her class at Hunter College High School, she was graduated with honors from Hunter College and elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She mesmerized generations of students of English at Bayside High School in New York City; hosted a talk show on WNYC with her husband Abraham Lass, a well-known educator; authored an autobiography, ''Remembering the Bough of Summer and the Winter Branch'', two books on literary allusions and contributed to ''The Family of Man'' photographic collections. Her first husband and father of her two sons, Richard Saunders, a Broadway, radio and television actor, died in 1961. Her second husband, Abraham Lass, died in 2001. She is survived by her loving sons, Stephen Cole and Jonathan R. Cole, by her beloved partner, John Palmer, by her daughters-in-law, Maria and Joanna and by her grandchildren and their spouses and partners, Richard Cole, Daniel Cole and Nicholas Grinder, Robert and Carrie Cole, and Susanna Cole and Gabriel Bach. A memorial service will be held at The Lotos Club, 5 East 66th Street, on Monday, September 15th at 4pm.

The nomadic linebacker Willie Williams has new home. Less than a week after the N.C.A.A. denied an appeal to restore his eligibility at Division II Glenville State College, he transferred to Union College, an N.A.I.A. school in Kentucky. Williams, a fifth-year senior who is now at his fifth school, is eligible to play this season. On Friday, he practiced with Union for the first time. ''From what I've seen since I've been here, it's amazing,'' Williams said of Union in a telephone interview.

How much of a buzz is there around the MINNESOTA VIKINGS? It's the only team Brett Favre really wanted to play for this year. They didn't land Favre, but when they got defensive end Jared Allen in a trade from the Chiefs, the Vikings instantly became a chic pick to contend. Allen balances a defense that was solid against the run but suspect against the pass. The unit suffered a blow when safety Madieu Williams injured his neck; he could miss almost a month of the regular season. Much of the overall optimism, though, stems from running back Adrian Peterson's breathtaking rookie year, and the acquisition of receiver Bernard Berrian. Still, with all the other parts in place, the Vikings' chances will come down to how well Tarvaris Jackson runs the offense. There is little question Favre would have been an upgrade, but Coach Brad Childress has professed his allegiance to Jackson. If Jackson gets more consistent, the high hopes are justified. One reason the Vikings are considered the top pick in this division is because nobody knows what to expect from the GREEN BAY PACKERS. The defense has looked good in the preseason, but the offense has been suspect. It's impossible to predict how quarterback Aaron Rodgers, perhaps the most unenvied man in the N.F.L. right now, will handle life as Favre's replacement. It won't be easy. The Packers host the Vikings on the opening Monday night of the season, an early litmus test that could prove troublesome if Rodgers doesn't play well. Last year's result -- the Packers nearly won the N.F.C. championship game -- was such a bolt out of the blue that expectations were raised exponentially, until Favre left town. Now the Packers are a great unknown: in an eminently winnable division, but with the biggest question mark in football. No team has gone through a weirder off-season than this one, and how they emerge from the Favre drama will say a lot about the Packers' mental toughness.

The PITTSBURGH STEELERS will always be built around their defense -- it was ranked No. 1 last season -- but this may be the year quarterback Ben Roethlisberger joins Tom Brady and Peyton Manning as the elite at the position. He performed well in spring practices and in training camp, and Santonio Holmes provides a maturing deep threat. The Steelers remain in the top echelon of the A.F.C., and they would seem a lock to make the playoffs, but winning the division could be a struggle against Cleveland. The Steelers and the Browns each went 10-6 last season, but the Steelers went to the playoffs because they beat the Browns twice. The Steelers, who lost the Pro Bowl guard Alan Faneca to the Jets, have a brutal schedule this year, the toughest in the N.F.L. In the first five weeks, they play at Cleveland, at Philadelphia and at Jacksonville. Later, they play the Giants, Colts, Chargers, Patriots and Cowboys -- all playoff teams last season. If the Steelers make the playoffs, they will have earned it. Derek Anderson -- premier quarterback or one-season wonder? If it's the former, the CLEVELAND BROWNS will be a formidable A.F.C. team for quite a few years. This is Anderson's first year as the designated starter -- Charlie Frye started the opener last year, before being quickly replaced by Anderson and then traded -- and a full off-season of preparation should allow him to flourish in the Browns' downfield passing offense. Cleveland signed Donte' Stallworth to be a downfield threat and to take some of the heat off Braylon Edwards. If the Browns can stay healthy, it's hard to imagine them missing the playoffs again, even in a crowded A.F.C. field. But the Steelers have beaten the Browns nine consecutive times, and the Browns cannot go anywhere until they get over that obstacle. They open against the Cowboys and the Steelers, so they should know early if this is their breakthrough year.

Commodore Vanderbilt, below, who knew a thing or two about transportation, would have been amazed at the scene at his bronze feet. Below him, on the elevated roadway, right, that wraps around Grand Central, everything imaginable on wheels -- except cars -- whizzed by. It was a photographer's and dog walker's dream. The opening of the roadway to pedestrians, always off limits before, was the thrill of the day at the last of three temporary closings of a seven-mile stretch from the Brooklyn Bridge up Park Avenue to East 72nd Street.
Dance Jack Anderson

ISRAEL--Lawrence J. You left us and the investment world, and went to your second love, that great big golf course in the sky. I hope each day is perfect and every shot a hole in one. Larry, you left such an indelible impact on so many, many people over your lifetime because there was not one dishonest, mean, or arrogant bone in your body. You will be missed by so many who loved you and knew you so very well and those who knew you just in passing. You also had that proud and marvelous philanthropic side and you gave from the heart, just like all the Israels that came before you. I would like to thank you for being such a wonderful and unforgettable partner, mentor, and friend. Larry, may God bless you and keep a watchful eye on you always. In return, keep Him laughing, like you did me. Bel Miller, VP L.J. Israel & Co.

OLLENDORFF--Anne (nee Riess), 91, died on Saturday, August 23, 2008, peacefully in her sleep, at her home in Englewood, New Jersey. She is survived by her two sons, Stephen and David, three grandchildren, Arthur, Linda and Robert, four greatgrandchildren, Kayla, Holden, Sawyer and Graham and two brothers, Rudi and Stefan Riess. She fled Germany in November, 1938 with her beloved husband, Dr. Ulrich Ollendorff, and her infant son, Stephen. Together, she and her husband established a successful life in America, with her husband becoming a prominent ophthalmologist and she devoting her life to raising her family. In honor of her husband, she helped establish The Ollendorff Diagnostic Center at The Columbia Eye Institute.
A Second Agent At the Last Minute

The Practical Traveler column on Aug. 10, about airlines that are cutting back on routes, referred incorrectly to service to Telluride, Colo. Scheduled seats were expected to drop 26 percent to Telluride Regional Airport -- not to Telluride itself -- in the fourth quarter, according to OAG Back Aviation, an industry consulting firm that tracks such data. (The city also has service through Montrose Regional Airport.)

Once the most competitive division in football, the A.F.C. West has devolved into the SAN DIEGO CHARGERS and everybody else. The Chargers aren't just ahead of the Broncos, the Chiefs and the Raiders, though. They are ahead of almost every other A.F.C. team. This season, they may finally be in position to give New England a run for the conference championship, even if they end up losing the superb pass rusher Shawne Merriman to a knee injury. The Chargers lost to the Patriots in the playoffs last season with running back LaDainian Tomlinson out for most of the game, and with quarterback Philip Rivers gamely playing on a badly injured knee. The Chargers still have one of the most talented and balanced rosters in the N.F.L., but their safety net behind Tomlinson, Michael Turner, left for Altanta. Tomlinson, the game's best runner, enters his eighth season, which means he is probably at the peak of his career. The defense is fantastic, and the offense is multidimensional. Rivers has the respect of his teammates after fighting through the injured knee last season and becoming a team leader. The Chargers should run away with the division, and they could pile up enough victories to beat out the Patriots for home-field advantage. But anything less than a Super Bowl berth with this much talent will be a letdown, and it will raise questions about whether the window is beginning to close on this group. The DENVER BRONCOS are second in this division, which isn't saying much. They dismantled the coaching staff after a losing season, but when receiver Brandon Marshall sustained a serious arm injury in March while wrestling with a family member you had to wonder if the Broncos were doomed. (Marshall will miss one game after being suspended for violating the league's player conduct policy.) The offensive line is in transition, which is a problem for a team that has always had a superb running attack. The defense was a mess last year, too. The good news is that quarterback Jay Cutler is the real thing. The bad news is that there wasn't enough of an overhaul in personnel to make a big difference this season, not when the Broncos were outscored last year by the Chargers, 64-6. A finish above .500 is certainly possible, especially because four of the first six games are at home. The Broncos will need a few breaks to get to 10 wins, which will probably be the minimum for a playoff berth in the A.F.C.

FAIRBRIDGE--Mrs. Dolores G., born May 5, 1922 Rangoon, Burma died August 27, 2008, Stony Brook, NY. Beloved wife of Rhodes W. Fairbridge who preceded her in death in November, 2006. Emeritus professor of Geology at Columbia University. A long time resident of Amagansett and Manhattan. Passionate gardener, cook and interior decorator, supporter of progressive political causes and a critic of the Iraq War. She worked at General Douglas McCarthur's headquarters in Brisban, Australia in WWII where she met her husband who worked on Pacific Theatre Invasion maps. She is survived by one son, Kingsley Carrington Fairbridge of Asheville, NC and one grandson, Sean Hewitt Fairbridge of Sante Fe, NM.

WHITE--Myron Edward. Three Arrows Cooperative Society mourns the passing of Myron Edward White on August 19. An active member of our community for 60 years, he will be greatly missed. Our sympathy is with his loving wife Eleanor Solomon White and their family.
3183 ROCHAMBEAU AVENUE A three-family detached house with a total of six bedrooms and four baths, listed for $599,900.

MORRONE--Armondo Eddie. Mr. Morrone worked for Newark Evening News and NY Times, Armondo Eddie Morrone of Bloomfield passed away on Wednesday, August 27, 2008, at his home. Funeral Mass will be on Saturday at 10am at St. Cassians R.C. Church in Upper Montclair. Interment at Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Upper Montclair, to follow. Visiting is on Friday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm at Caggiano Memorial, 62 Grove St., Montclair. Born in Newark, Mr. Morrone lived in Bloomfield for the past 52 years. He was a World War II Army veteran and worked for the Newark Evening News and the NY Times for over 44 years before retiring in 1980. Mr. Morrone was a member of the Publishers-Newspaper and Mail Union in NYC. He was the devoted husband of the late Ida Edith Morrone (nee Barbarisi); loving father of Delinda Holland and her husband, Jay, Marlene Morrone, Deborah MorroneColella and her husband, Greg; dear brother of the late Thomas, Clara, Henry, Joseph, Lena, Edith and Victor; loving grandfather of seven, Michael, Shannon, Michelle, Christine, Martin, Matthew and Michael, and five cherished great-grandchildren, Gianna, Dominic, Erin, Tyler and Carley. Donations in lieu of flowers to St. Jude Children's Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105, or St. Barnabas Hospice, 95 Old Short Hills Road, West Orange, NJ 07052, would be appreciated.
To the Editor: Re ''Fish and Hips'' (Urban Studies, Aug. 24), about nude models who lie covered with sushi for dining at private parties:

The NEW ORLEANS SAINTS' active off-season make them the division favorites. Drew Brees likes to throw to tight ends, and now he has Jeremy Shockey, who is still dangerous when healthy. The Saints' offense should be explosive, especially if Reggie Bush finally gets somewhere close to the expectations for him. And the defense, which was woeful last year with just 10 interceptions, was shored up by acquiring linebacker Jonathan Vilma, who was miscast by the Jets; signing cornerback Randall Gay; and drafting defensive tackle Sedrick Ellis. Their biggest problem last season was an 0-4 start, which put them in a hole they never escaped. This year's schedule doesn't help much: The Saints host the international game in London, giving them nine trips -- and that game is against San Diego. The Saints clearly have the best offense in the division, and if the defense comes together, they could make a run to the conference championship. Coach Jon Gruden tried to sweet-talk Brett Favre into coming south, mindful that Favre might have been enough to put the TAMPA BAY BUCCANEERS in the N.F.C.'s top tier. They didn't get him, and that leaves the Buccaneers a bit short. Their defense is still top notch, and the addition of the rookie cornerback Aqib Talib won't hurt. But the offense could apply for the senior discount en masse. Quarterback Jeff Garcia performed well last year, and the offense ranked 18th, better than it had been since 2003. But running back Warrick Dunn isn't what he was in his younger days, and receiver Joey Galloway is relatively ancient and missed most of camp with a groin injury. If Galloway gets hurt, the Buccaneers have little punch, as the Giants discovered in the playoffs last season. It's the same as it ever was in Tampa: win with defense or don't win at all.
Film Mike Hale

An article last Sunday about Broadway trivia that is referenced in the musical ''[title of show]'' referred incorrectly to Pia Zadora's appearance in ''Henry, Sweet Henry'' (1967). It was her third role on Broadway, not her first. (She made her Broadway debut in the short-lived 1961 run of ''Midgie Purvis.'')

For the SEATTLE SEAHAWKS, this season will be the Mike Holmgren farewell tour, and the only fitting conclusion to such a great career would be another playoff run. The Seahawks have won four straight division titles, and they are the class of the division again. But in an attempt to get Holmgren a grand finale before he retires, the Seahawks overhauled their running game, signing Julius Jones and T. J. Duckett, acquiring left guard Mike Wahle and hiring a new offensive line coach, Mike Solari. (Has anyone ever dropped from most valuable player to invisible faster than Shaun Alexander last year?) The defense is the strength of the team, though, and the Seahawks will ride that to another division title. That means another home playoff game at Qwest Field, the hardest place for a visitor to win. Don't bet against a deep playoff push for the Seahawks. The ARIZONA CARDINALS lost six games by a touchdown or less last season, which usually suggests that a young, mistake-prone team still has to get its act together. That is why Coach Ken Whisenhunt was not happy to see photos of the supposed franchise quarterback Matt Leinart with a beer bong in hand during the off-season. Things didn't get much better for Leinart once training camp started. He played so poorly that Kurt Warner will start in Week 1. With a receiver tandem as good as any in football with Anquan Boldin and Larry Fitzgerald, the Cardinals should have an explosive offense no matter who the quarterback is. But the receivers must stay healthy, and Boldin, who has demanded a trade, needs to perform despite his publicly stated anger over his contract. The schedule is tough; the Cardinals open at San Francisco, against whom they played poorly last season, and face the Redskins, Jets and Cowboys in the first six weeks. Later there are games against the Giants, Eagles, Vikings and Patriots. It's hard to imagine the Cardinals overtaking the Seahawks this season, but a schedule like that will give a young team plenty of experience to build on.

FREEMAN--Melvin. Col. Melvin D. Freeman, USAF, Retired, of Chappaqua, NY (89), on August 26 from a longterm illness. He was a devoted husband of 63 years to his late wife Helen Yuder Freeman and a beloved father and grandfather. A graduate of St. John's University and New York University, he was a licensed psychologist employed by FEGS for almost 63 years where he was Director of Psychological Services and helped thousands of people find a better life. He and his late wife were lifelong philanthropists and generous benefactors to New York Medical College. Col. Freeman was a member of the Board of Trustees for New York Medical College, Family Services of Westchester and Physicians Home. He is survived by his two daughters, two grandchildren and a brother. Graveside services were held at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

THE NEWS The Russian government announced that it was formally recognizing two breakaway regions of the Republic of Georgia -- Abkhazia and South Ossetia -- as independent states. BEHIND THE NEWS Russia, which has backed separatist movements and had its own troops in the two enclaves for years, sought to turn its recent military successes over Georgian forces into political facts, arguing that what it had done was no different from the West's actions in helping Kosovo break from Serbia. Georgia and its Western friends, including the United States, condemned the step, while anxious eyes turned to other former Soviet republics that have quarreled with Moscow.

Seventeen months after the indictment, a federal judge in New York has set a trial date in the government's fraud case against David A. Stockman, former C.E.O. of Collins & Aikman and once President Ronald Reagan's budget director. A United States District Court judge,Barbara S. Jones, set May 4 of next year to hear claims that Mr. Stockman, along with three co-defendants, defrauded investors in Collins & Aikman in part by painting a too-rosy picture of its finances. The company, an auto parts manufacturer in Southfield, Mich., filed for bankruptcy in 2005 and was liquidated last year.

SEVENTY years ago, death came howling on the ocean. Long Island's hurricane of 1938 -- back in the years before the government gave names to storms -- pushed a 15-foot surge and battering waves ahead of it that flooded parts of Westhampton Beach, Southampton and Montauk. More than 50 people were killed, and hundreds of houses were washed away or ruined. The storm hit land at the lightly populated East End on Sept. 21 and then traveled across Long Island Sound, slamming into Connecticut, near New Haven, about 3 p.m. and then Rhode Island.

Address: 827 East 21st Street (between Farragut and Glenwood Roads) The Property: Near Brooklyn College and a 20-minute subway ride to either the beach or Manhattan, this three-story house was built in 1910 and has an addition with a separate entrance that can be used as a professional office space. The original house has a center staircase, six bedrooms, one full and two half baths, an eat-in kitchen with a six-burner Garland restaurant stove, a pantry, a roof terrace, a backyard deck, a driveway and a two-car garage. Yearly taxes are $2,988.

FREEMAN--Melvin. The Graenum Berger Bronx Jewish Federation Service Center expresses profound sorrow on the passing of one of our founders and officers, Melvin Freeman. He personifies the fundamental Jewish teaching that we are created to do good for others. His commitment to chesed and tzedakah through compassion, diligence and excellence inspires and serves as a role model. May the Almighty comfort his beloved daughters Susan and Phyllis and the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

Aug. 23: Clermont, the country estate established by the Livingston family in 1728, benefited from a picnic on its lawn overlooking the Hudson River in Germantown, N.Y. The Livingston family has long been socially and politically prominent; Robert R. Livingston gave the oath of office to George Washington when he became president. The party celebrated another highlight, the bicentennial of the 1807 launch of Fulton and Livingston's steamboat. The dress was country-western and the theme was the Gold Rush. The event for 350 people was timed to take in the Catskills sunset. The estate, a national landmark, is open to the public (friendsofclermont.org). 1, 2, 3 The river view.

ST. PAUL -- From a distance, the screaming man trapped behind the fence in front of the Holiday Inn on West 7th sounded like he was shouting, "Go home!" at the delegates who were leaving the Xcel Center after a short first-day session. But as the Bagger drew nearer, it was evident the man was shouting - which does not begin to describe the noise he was making - the name of Ron Paul, the libertarian and former presidential candidate.The noise that Jim Westgate of Panama City, Fla., was so comically loud - he would rear back like a banti rooster and hurl himself at the fence and the crowd - that people were reduced to laughing and smiling at the display. It was clear that this was a deeply, deeply held personal vigil and it was tough to discern what good it could possible do given that the people who were leaving were all bent on nominating John McCain later in the week. And then Dr. Jim Taylor, a delegate from the convention from Pinehurst, N.C., came over to the fence and began chatting with Mr. Westgate in between his yelps on behalf of Mr. Paul. "The work you are doing is great and I want you to know that people in the convention are doing lots of talking about Mr. Paul. Keep it up." Not that Mr. Westgate needed the encouragement. As soon as his new friend walked away, he began yelling like crazy, hitting some new and operatic notes on behalf of his guy.

At 9 a.m. Eastern Daylight Time today, Gustav is finally on the Louisiana coast as a strong Category 2 hurricane. The rapid intensification that seemed so likely yesterday (O.K., "inevitable" if you believed my posting) never happened, but the weakening before landfall did. Now the question is what a weaker storm, missing New Orleans by tens of miles to the west, will do to the city and, of course, to the people who are actually in its path. We read yesterday of millions leaving the city. Enough people in the southeastern United States have direct hurricane experience that it isn't an empty platitude to hope that they are safe and that they come back to find their homes and livelihoods still there.

For Hurricane Gustav the steering winds have come from a high-pressure ridge that runs from near the Bahamas and across Florida.
Gov. Sarah Palin owes her selection as Senator John McCain’s running mate in part to an irresistible slogan: the Bridge to Nowhere.
Charles W. Sykes Jr. is expected to become the only federally licensed dealer in Washington to handle the transactions that put guns in the hands of residents.
Agriprocessors, a kosher meat producer, is trying to persuade the Supreme Court to rule that illegal immigrants do not have the right to join labor unions.
Some television networks reassigned many of their stars to a story that they believed had greater news potential than the convention — Hurricane Gustav.
Wounded in a bomb attack, a military translator from Queens is focused on returning to the battlefield.
Record numbers of students turning up for classes this fall are homeless or poor enough to qualify for free meals.
Energy companies shut down production and refining operations throughout the weekend in preparation for an intensifying Hurricane Gustav to hit in the heart of the Gulf of Mexico oil patch.
Volunteers of D’Midas International, a carnival organization in Crown Heights, have been forgoing sleep and social life in recent weeks to prepare for the West Indian American Day Carnival.
Darren Bent delivered Tottenham’s first point of the season in a hard-fought 1-1 draw Sunday at Chelsea, while Liverpool tied, 0-0, at Villa to end its perfect start to the season.

The rookie Justin Wilson won his first IndyCar Series race, edging Hélio Castroneves in the Detroit Indy Grand Prix. Castroneves led for a majority of the road race on the Belle Isle course, but was penalized for blocking Wilson with fewer than 20 laps to go. The series points leader Scott Dixon finished fifth.

Kentucky’s defense looked plenty capable of carrying the Wildcats until the offense caught up. Ashton Cobb returned a Louisville fumble 28 yards for a touchdown and Myron Pryor returned another fumble 72 yards for a score as the Wildcats defeated Louisville, 27-2, in the Governor’s Cup on Sunday in Louisville. Tony Dixon added a 7-yard touchdown run for the Wildcats, who have won two in a row against their rivals for the first time in a decade.

Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh, Olympic beach volleyball champions, lost for the first time in more than a year, dropping a 21-19, 10-21, 25-23 decision to Elaine Youngs and Nicole Branagh on Sunday in Mason, Ohio. The winning streak of May-Treanor and Walsh, the two-time Olympic gold medalists, ended at 112 matches and 19 titles. They last lost on Aug. 19, 2007, also to Branagh and Youngs.

Alejandro Valverde took the overall lead of the Vuelta a España after winning the second stage in Jaen, Spain. Valverde, with the Caisse d’Epargne team, timed his final sprint to distance himself from the pack and finish the 103.9-mile ride from Granada to Jaen in 4 hours 23 minutes. He finished two seconds ahead of the Italians Davide Rebellin of Gerolsteiner and Alessandro Ballan of Lampre. Monday’s third stage is a 105-mile ride from Granada to Cordoba that includes a moderate ascent.

The American midfielder Michael Bradley beat Monday’s midnight transfer deadline in Europe and will move from Heerenveen of the Netherlands to Borussia Mönchengladbach in the German Bundesliga. Details of the transfer were not released. Bradley, 21, who had one year remaining on his contract with Heerenveen, was being pursued by clubs in England, Italy and Germany. He scored 15 league goals for Heerenveen last season.
Senator John McCain called a halt to all but the most essential activities for the Republican convention.
The beaches of Brooklyn, while not among the glitziest, boast a vibrant local economy, whose agents include the unlicensed vendors of beverages and treats.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advisers said they expected she would focus her efforts especially on working women in swing states where she ran strong.
The hurricane’s approach recalled failings of the Bush presidency just as John McCain’s big moment arrived.
Andrea de Mello, who has been training for the past 23 years to regain some of the athletic ability she lost to a stroke as an adolescent, is headed to Beijing.
Ruben Pestano Lavilla Jr., a leader and founder of the Islamic extremist group involved in the 2004 bombing of a passenger ship in the Philippines, was taken into custody there.
Wickham Boyle, a writer and mother of two from New York, has turned her essays on Sept. 11 into an opera, of which she is the librettist, director and co-producer.
Angered by U.S. assertions that cocaine smuggling through Venezuela has surged in recent years, President Hugo Chávez threatened to expel the American ambassador.
INTERNATIONAL.
Vivian Schiller, senior vice president and general manager, NYTimes.com, is answering questions this week.

On a bus taking evacuees from New Orleans, no one seemed to know where they were going or what they would come home to.

A capsule summary on Sunday for an article about Dokdo Island, which Japan calls Takeshima and claims as its own territory, misidentified, in some editions, the country that administers the island and also claims rights to it. As the article correctly noted, it is South Korea — not North Korea.
Representatives of a dozen federal agencies tried to ensure that everyone knew what part to play in the response.

An article on Saturday about “Zen Shaolin,” an extravagant theatrical production in Henan Province, China, with music by the composer Tan Dun, misstated the title of an opera by Mr. Tan that had its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in 2006. It is “The First Emperor,” not “The Last Emperor.”.
At 17-under-par 196, Mike Weir is one stroke clear of Camilo Villegas (63) and three ahead of Sergio García (68) and Vijay Singh (69). in the PGA Tour’s FedEx Cup playoffs.
An article on Tuesday about Lindsay Davenport’s first-round victory at the United States Open misspelled the surname of her husband. He is Jon Leach, not Leech.
John Davidson is preparing for his third season as the president for hockey operations for St. Louis Blues, a departure from his role as a celebrated television analyst.

A Sports of The Times column on Aug. 16 about Nastia Liukin’s gold medal in the gymnastics all-around at the Beijing Olympics — a prize that eluded her father, Valeri Liukin, at the 1988 Summer Games — misidentified the gymnast who narrowly defeated him for the all-around that year. It was Vladimir Artemov — not Vladimir Artemev, another elite gymnast from the same era.
Jayson Werth hit a home run against the Chicago Cubs and Jamie Moyer got his 12th win Sunday, helping Philadelphia reach a 5-3 victory.
Like clockwork, the No. 5 seed Elena Dementieva advanced to the quarterfinals at the United States Open on Sunday night with a 6-4, 6-1 victory against Li Na.

An article on Aug. 23 about the loss of computer records on more than 80,000 British prisoners misidentified a Conservative Party member of Parliament who has opposed collecting large amounts of information about citizens on government computers. He is David Davis — not David Davies, another Conservative Party lawmaker.
The Jets and the Giants are negotiating with Allianz, the financial services giant, to buy the naming rights to their new stadium, said a person with knowledge of the talks.
Information for Labor Day 2008.

Because of an editing error, an article last Monday in the special U.S. Open Preview section about the crowded competition for the No. 1 ranking in women’s tennis misidentified one of the three Russian women to win singles medals at the Beijing Olympics. In addition to Elena Dementieva and Dinara Safina, Vera Zvonareva claimed a medal. Their countrywoman Svetlana Kuznetsova did not.
Andy Roddick completed a straight-sets victory over the 31st seed, Andreas Seppi of Italy, and booked his place in the fourth round.
When a bank robbery saves you from getting a ticket.
Laura, Tami, Debbie and Ella are teeing off in their club’s autumn tournament. Which players proceeded correctly?
Defensive end Jerome McDougle signed with the Giants on Sunday, providing them badly needed depth at a position that had once been their greatest strength.
Israeli and Palestinian officials played down the prospect of any immediate peace deal as Ehud Olmert, Israel’s discredited prime minister, begins his final phase in office.
For the first time since it began 24 years ago, the Brazilian Day festival, a joyous occasion recalling a centuries-old ritual, was held over two days, on Saturday and Sunday.
Asia Muhammad, who lost her first-round match in the main draw, is one of the notable American girls with one foot in the juniors and one in the pros.
Water is one of the few resources the mountainous Central Asian country possesses in great abundance.
Industrial and productivity data will dominate the economic calendar this week.
Hollywood writers and producers are realizing that producing Web content may be easy but profiting from it is hard.
Gilles Muller, who is ranked 130th, smacked 52 unforced errors to Nicolas Almagro’s 31, but the 36 aces coming from his big left-handed serve helped him finally prevail.
Casting long shadows over South Florida’s highways are the billboards advertising “A New Beginning,” featuring those rare stars of sports ad campaigns: the front office.
The juxtaposition between poverty and growing wealth presents an unsavory dilemma for luxury goods makers jumping into India.
Having blundered into a new language policy without thinking it through, the L.P.G.A. is trying to rationalize that it wants its foreign players to speak English.

While Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, stands at the center of Europe’s response to the Russia-Georgia conflict, many of her constituents would like her to put domestic concerns first.
Crimson Tide fans are giddy after a 34-10 drubbing of No. 9 Clemson, but Alabama Coach Nick Saban is not.
The Mets will add at least nine players to their roster, including Jon Niese, a rookie left-handed pitcher, when major league rosters expand.
John McCain enters this year’s Republican convention with the enthusiastic support of nearly 9 in 10 delegates.
The steelworkers union has been negotiating with the company since April on a contract that will cover more than 14,000 workers and tens of thousands of retirees.
An Indian-born doctor arrested in Australia in July 2007 and accused of aiding in bungled bombings in central London and the Glasgow airport has been cleared of any wrongdoing.
A Russian journalist known for his opposition views was arrested in southern Russia on Sunday then fatally shot in the head, suggesting a possible clampdown on domestic dissent.

BRIAN WILSON ''That Lucky Old Sun'' (Capitol) Brian Wilson sings with boundless enthusiasm on ''That Lucky Old Sun,'' his first full album of new songs since 2004. That was when he remade and completed ''Smile,'' the attempted masterpiece he had abandoned amid drug use and mental illness in 1967. In ''Oxygen to the Brain'' on the new album, he sings, ''I wasted a lot of years.''

GROSSMAN--Carl. Our dear friend of 50 years. We are going to miss him terribly, as well as his sense of humor and his sincerity. Massa Family GROSSMAN--Carl, we are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend Carl. We extend our sincere condolences to Alice and the entire Grossman family. Rest in peace. Ralph & Arlene Goffner and family

DOERNBERG--Dudley David, Jr., 95, of Scarsdale, NY, died August 29, 2008. Mr. Doernberg was born March 20, 1913 to the late Dudley David Doernberg and Blanche Heyman Doernberg. Surviving are devoted sons Don (Cyndy Pope) Doernberg, Richard (Nancy) Doernberg, David (Tara) Doernberg and John (Carol Ehrlich) Doernberg. Also survived by loving sister Margery Bruno, nine adoring grandchildren: Doug, Emily, Alison, Sarah, Henry, Ellen, Samuel, Molly and Harry, and many devoted nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Nanette Doernberg, cherished sisters Beatrice Hecht and Natalie Hofheimer and brothers-in-law Joseph Hofheimer and Howard Bruno. Doernberg is best know for heading up the real estate agency founded by his father in 1926 that bears his name. Services will be held at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York, Tuesday, September 2, 2008, at 10am. Interment will follow in the Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contributions may be made to the Westchester Jewish Community Services, 845 North Broadway, Suite 2, White Plains, NY 10603, www.wjcs.com. DOERNBERG--Dudley. Goodbye Dudley dear. We will hold fond memories of both you and Nanette always. God speed. Lynn & Manny Finkelstein

When ''Fine Just the Way It Is: Wyoming Stories 3,'' by Annie Proulx, is released on Sept. 9, it will have a tough time breaking into the top short story rankings, which are dominated by anthologies by multiple authors. The top 100 titles feature many annual roundups as well as genre topics like erotica and mystery. Some gain their standing in sales to students. ''Fifty Great Short Stories,'' released in 1983, includes such required reading as ''The Lottery'' by Shirley Jackson, ''The Jockey'' by Carson McCullers and ''The Catbird Seat'' by James Thurber. SHELLY FREIERMAN
We have double the police force, double the National Guard force that we had for Katrina, and looters will go directly to jail. Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans. [A10]

Apple Imperfect Apple is on a tear like never before. The company, based in Cupertino, Calif., is winning market share from computer makers using Microsoft operating systems. Apple's stock has outpaced Google's, and in the space of a year, the iPhone has turned the telecommunications industry into a knot trying to find a way to respond.
The New Browser From Microsoft Microsoft's new Web browser, Internet Explorer 8, is now available in a beta version meant for ordinary users, and it's a pretty good piece of software.

REILLY--Timothy, 23, of NYC, a computer science student at Binghamton University, died July 28, 2008. He is survived by sister Rebecca, parents Laurence Reilly and Winifred Zubin. Memorial service -September 6, 2008, 1pm at Community Church of NY, 40 East 35th Street.

In the Tajik village of Akjar, the irrigation canal pictured to the left is the only source of water. Tajikistan, the source of more than 40 percent of Central Asia's water, has pinned its economic hopes on its water supply, but a number of sizable hurdles must be surmounted. nytimes.com/world

WINKELRIED--Irwin H., of Maplewood, NJ. Beloved husband of Phyllis (nee Linnett), devoted father of David G. Winkelried and Jon Winkelried, loving father-in-law of Susan and Abby, adored ''Papa'' of Jennifer, Matthew, Jane, Brian and Jack. Funeral services will be held at ''Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman'' 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ, Tuesday, September 2, 2008 at 1:30pm. Please call 1-800-938-6372 for additional information.

AMY MACDONALD ''This Is the Life'' (Melodramatic/Decca) Amy Macdonald, a fresh-faced Scottish singer-songwriter, knows a thing or two about wish fulfillment. On ''This Is the Life,'' her debut album, she sings repeatedly about rock stars and matinee idols, always from the perspective of a fan. Whether she's scathing or adoring in her appraisal, she leaves no doubt about her own aspirations. ''I wish that I was on the stage,'' she cries in ''Barrowland Ballroom,'' a hymn to Glasgow's concert shrine.
PORTER--Lawrence Charles. May 17th, 1932--September 1st, 1978. Dad, in our hearts and minds forever and always. Marjorie, Chip & Carolyn

SILVER-UNGER--Diane, Florida resident formerly of Belle Harbor. Mother of Harold Unger, Ellie and Martin Lifton, beloved nana of Steven and Julie Lifton, Bruce and Danielle Lifton, Judie and Ronald Bobman, adored great grandmother of Jason, Ali, Samantha, Jessica and Miles. Survived by sister Sylvia Cohen. Hunter College graduate, teacher, pianist and avid bridge player. Lived 99 wonderful years. We will all miss you.

DANILO PEREZ ''Across the Crystal Sea'' (Emarcy) The pastel shimmer of ''Across the Crystal Sea'' has no real precedent in the recording history of Danilo Perez, a pianist, composer and educator with active roots in his native Panama. Over the last 20 years Mr. Perez has earned acclaim especially for his rhythmic daring and rigorously playful take on improvisation. Like most jazz musicians, he could have gone an entire career without making a lustrous album with a symphony.

FABRIZIO--Ralph, on August 29, 2008. Retired Superintendent of District 20 Brooklyn. Beloved husband of the late Jean. Cherished father of Karen Spadaro and Ralph Fabrizio Jr. Beloved father-in-law of John Spadaro and Noreen Fabrizio. Devoted grandfather of Jenna Spadaro and Michael, Tommy, Daniel and Julianna Fabrizio. In lieu of flowers, donations to: St. Judes Children's Hospital. Visiting at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons 1305 79th Street, Brooklyn, NY Sunday and Monday, 2-5pm and 7-10pm. Funeral Tuesday St. Ephrem R.C. Church 10:30am. Entombment at St. John's Cloister.

THE VERVE ''Forth'' (On Your Own) In the 1990s a slew of British guitar bands -- including Oasis, Pulp and Blur -- seemed primed for global domination, but very few made good on the promise. The Verve, from Manchester, released two psychedelic rock albums before joining the scrum in 1997 with ''Urban Hymns,'' a luscious pop CD anchored by the hit single ''Bitter Sweet Symphony,'' in which Richard Ashcroft sang of existential anxiety over an orchestral swell snatched from the Rolling Stones.

Amid Colors of Fall, the Greens Still Shine for Golfers This is the last On Par golf feature this year as we will be taking a hiatus and looking forward to next spring. It has been a stirring experience, this weekly conversation about golf in the last 20 weeks. I am heartened to know there are so many golfers and golf-inspired readers who clearly love the game for all its complexities and imponderables.

DONNIE KLANG ''Just a Rolling Stone'' (Bad Boy/Atlantic) In MTV's ''Making the Band 4'' last year Diddy awarded the handsome, slightly awkward Long Island singer Donnie Klang a solo recording contract. In the context of the show -- in which Diddy was forming, through auditions (and attrition), a male R&B group -- he made Mr. Klang's deal seem like an afterthought, maybe because unlike the five singers who ultimately did make the band, African-American all, Mr. Klang is white. Clearly Diddy did not want to tell stories about the one that got away.

Sun Micro Has a Fan in Memphis The short take on the situation at Sun Microsystems is that it's a shame. The company still has plenty of bright people and it's been a wellspring of innovative ideas over the years.

MARX--Angelina Buonamassa, 82, died Friday August 29, 2008. Mrs. Marx was born on January 28, 1926 in New York City, where she spent most of her life. She pursued a career in dance, toured Europe then joined the Metropolitan Opera Ballet. Married to Josef Marx, eminent oboist and musicologist, she ran McGinnis & Marx Music Publishers, completed her college education, became a translator, dance teacher, and raised three children. She was an avid reader, had a great love of literature, opera, dance and music. Mrs. Marx is survived by her three children, Deborah, Alexander and Ida, a stepdaughter Margaret, six grandchildren, Nicolas, Sara, Miles, Milena, Elias, Isaac, and a sister, Filomena. Her presence and words of wisdom will be greatly missed.

8 P.M. (Fox) PRISON BREAK What's harder than breaking out? Breaking in, according to this series's writers, which is what this Season 4 opener, set in Los Angeles and picking up about a month after last season's rushed-by-the-writers-strike finale, has in store. The closely guarded plot supposedly goes something like this: Michael (Wentworth Miller, above right with Dominic Purcell) is trying to avenge the death of Sara (Sarah Wayne Callies) by getting even with Gretchen (Jodi Lyn O'Keefe), who is back to company business with Whistler (Chris Vance) and Mahone (William Fichtner). Lincoln (Mr. Purcell), L. J. (Marshall Allman) and Sofia (Danay Garcia) are playing house. And in Panama Sona has gone up in flames, leaving T-Bag (Robert Knepper), Bellick (Wade Williams) and Sucre (Amaury Nolasco) unaccounted for. But you just know they won't be gone for long. 4 P.M. (Fox) THE PEOPLE'S COURT Order! Judge Marilyn Milian brings down the gavel on a new season of small-claims cases centered on some pretty big problems.

SWIGER--Eli, 89, of Manhattan passed away suddenly at home on August 30, 2008. Beloved husband of Arlene, father of Larry (Amy) Swiger and Karen (James) Lee, and grandfather of Andrew and Jack Swiger. A lifelong member of Lone Star Boat Club. He will be greatly missed.

SCHULZ--Robert, on August 30, 2008. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Marc, Michael and Suzanne. Loving grandfather of Jacob and Sam. Funeral services Tuesday 10am at ''Gutterman's Inc'' 175 Longbeach Rd., Rockville Centre, L.I.

Few immigrant groups are as closely identified with an occupational niche as Koreans with grocery stores. While mom-and-pop produce stores have become an engine of economic mobility and opportunity for some Korean families, Korean produce merchants in New York City have often found themselves in conflict with white wholesale distributors, black customers and labor unions representing Hispanic employees, according to a new book by a Queens College sociologist.

ST. PAUL -- Past the security barricades, inside the convention hall, on the stage of the Republican National Convention, an unlikely species of man stood: a self-described Democrat. As a few conventioneers and members of the media milled around the mostly empty stadium this afternoon, the man, Hank Neimark, strode on and off the stage, shooting off orders and theatrical hand signals.

Against Igor Andreev, Roger Federer was living dangerously. He had been broken in the first game in less than a minute. Then he would drop the first set in a tie breaker. And he was in a second tie breaker when he blasted his way out of trouble. He hit a classic down-the-line backhand for a winner, and then two aces. He would hold on to win the second tie breaker, 7-5, and the match, 6-7 (5), 7-6 (5), 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, at Arthur Ashe Stadium today.

Lieberman, independent of Connecticut, along with board members from the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, one of a handful of private meetings she held on Tuesday in St. Paul.

Most of the time, talk of genetic modification revolves around crops, with claims and counterclaims as to the relative risks and benefits. Such questions are obviously important, but they have been so much discussed I don't want to consider them again here (at least, not at the moment). Instead, I want to spend the next couple of weeks looking at other possible uses of genetic engineering.

As Hurricane Gustav spun ashore yesterday as a Category 2 storm rather than the Category 4 mega-storm that had been predicted just a day earlier, the most recent diaspora of Louisiana evacuees exhaled a collective sigh of relief. The specter of Katrina loomed large over the Labor Day weekend but fortunately there were few true parallels between the storms. Not only was the storm weaker but it cut a slicing path across the state rather than barreling straight into the coast, reducing the magnitude of the storm surge. New Orleans's levees held. Political leaders at all levels of government provided a degree of leadership and coordination that was largely absent when Katrina struck three years earlier.

NEW ORLEANS - When the storm finally passes and the wind ceases to blow, the only evidence of property damage for many blocks around us is in our front yard. A part of my sister's white picket fence has fallen out onto the sidewalk. I call my brother-in-law who says that his fence does that all the time -- he never nailed it back together after Katrina. Give it a nudge and the thing collapses. A few hours later, a video crew from "The NewsHour" with Jim Lehrer is marching one of Gustav's victims back and forth in front of my sister's fence. My brother-in-law asks me to go prop it back up, so that the neighbors won't take offense, but I leave it down, as other TV crews may need it. There's precious little else that might serve as a Backdrop to a Catastrophe. The city looks too good.

An article on Sunday about the reaction of women to Senator John McCain’s choice of Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska as his running mate misidentified the 50th state to enter the union in some editions. It was Hawaii — not Alaska, which was the 49th. The article also misspelled, in some editions, the name of a woman who said the choice of Ms. Palin made her less likely to support Mr. McCain. She is Sue Angers, not Angiers.

An article on Friday about Kelly Bruno, an amputee who competes in triathlons and who is a ball girl at the United States Open, referred incorrectly to her finish this year at the International Triathlon Union World Championships. She was third in her category for athletes with a disability, not third over all.

A picture caption in some editions on Thursday with coverage of the United States Open misstated, in some copies, the round to which Lindsay Davenport advanced by defeating Alisa Kleybanova. Davenport, shown in action, advanced to the third round — not the second.

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Julie Coin’s upset of top-seeded Ana Ivanovic, the world’s No. 1-ranked player, at the United States Open misstated, in some editions, the rankings for three other women. Serena Williams is third, not fourth; Elena Dementieva is sixth, not fifth; and Dinara Safina is seventh, not sixth. (The article used their tournament seeds, not their world rankings.).

An article on Monday about the financial problems that many schools are having at the same time that some of their students’ families are struggling economically omitted the names of three contributing reporters. Tom Collins reported from Florida, Joel Elliott from Maine and Sean D. Hamill from Pennsylvania.

A Sports of The Times column last Tuesday, about great moments at Yankee Stadium involving the Red Sox and the Yankees, referred incorrectly to the 1949 season. The Boston pitcher who gave up an eighth-inning home run to Tommy Henrich on the way to a pennant-clinching victory by the Yankees on the final day of the 1949 season was Mel Parnell — not Ellis Kinder, who had been lifted for a pinch-hitter in the top of the inning. And Joe McCarthy, who was Boston’s manager that season, won seven — not eight — World Series titles when he was the Yankees’ manager.

O'Brien and Helen Costello, a graduate of Brown University and Fordham Law School, he served in the U.S. Marine Corps and retired as Chief Trademark Counsel, Bristol-Myers Squibb. LOVE--Lee. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime and cherished member, Lee Love. To her family we express our sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to all who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Marcia Waxman, President Robert A. Calinoff, Secretary LOVE--Lee Morse, a pioneer in reporting on United Nations efforts to ensure the peaceful uses of outer space for over 40 years, passed away Sunday August 31. She wrote about the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space from its early days, and her personal relations were so close with committee members that during the Cold War years she was one of the very few people who was able to entertain delegates from both the United Sates and the former Soviet Union at the same occasion. By the time she left the U.N., only a few months prior to her illness, Lee had covered man's flights into space and the moon and reported on arguments over who owned the rights to outer space, seas and satellites orbits. She attended the annual International Aeronautical Congress all over the world and was elected to membership in the International Institute of Space Law in recognition of her work in the area of space law and policy. Lee was also hired by the United States Agency for International Development to go to places like Truk in Micronesia, to see if and how satellites could help its many islands to better communicate. Her generosity and warmth were eclipsed only by her beauty. A former model and actress, she studied at the Pasadena Playhouse in California. She grew up in Los Angeles, moved to New York and opened her heart and home to the world. In a world of givers and takers, she was a giver with no boundaries. Lee's love and devotion to the United Nations and its diplomatic concepts brought people together from all over the world regardless of race, religion or political beliefs. With her boundless energy, Lee touched and brought joy to so many people. She will be missed by all her family, friends and anyone fortunate to have been in her company. ''Lee Lee'', as she was known, by those closest to her, leaves behind her loving husband of sixty years, Matthew; her children, Wendy Barnard and Gregory Love and his fiance Nipa; and her grandchildren, Lance, Alessandra, Samantha and Anouchka and many loving nephews and nieces. The family would like to thank her loving caregivers, Alicia and Adja for their companionship and compassion in her final days. One of Lee Lee's favorite expressions was: Age is a number and mine is unlisted, and it will remain so as per her wishes. New York services will be held on Wednesday, 10:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam and 91st, Manhattan. Funeral Services will be held on Friday at 2pm at Hillside Memorial Park in Los Angeles, 6001 W Centinela Ave., where she will rejoin her mother, father, and loving sister Florence. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lee and Matthew Love Foundation (a charitable foundation) (860 UN Plaza Apt. 23A, NYC, NY 10017) for the funding of the Lee Love Award for members of the winning team at the International Institute of Space Laws annual Moot Court Competition.

COHEN--Joyce, 69, August 30, 2008 after a sudden illness. Devoted wife of Martin Cohen, beloved mother of Melissa Brown-Bornstein, Meridith Brown and Scott Brown, mother-in-law of Dr. Harold Bornstein, Neri Tannenbaum and Nicole Brown, adoring grandmother of Robyn, Joseph, Alix, Jeremee, Jackson and Eliot, sister of Stewart Shapiro. Shiva Thursday evening and Sunday at Dr. and Melissa Bornstein's in Scarsdale. She was loved profoundly and will be enormously missed forever.

HATVARY--George Egon, died suddenly on August 30th, at Saint Vincent's Hospital, at the age of 87. Son of the late tenor, Carlo Hatvary, and Magda Hatvary, he was born in Budapest and came to the United States as a child. A specialist in 19th-century American literature, Professor Hatvary taught at Saint John's University for over 40 years, until his retirement in 1992. A prolific writer and scholar, Professor Hatvary was best known for his scholarship on Poe and Horace Binney Wallace, whose major influence on Poe he discovered, and for his novels: The Suitor (1981), The Murder of Edgar Allan Poe (1997), and his recent book The Slap and Other Stories (2007). He is survived by his wife, Laurel T. Hatvary, Professor Emerita of Yeshiva University, and their daughter, Maura Hatvary, a photographer. The funeral will be held Wednesday, September 3rd, at 2:30pm, at the Riverside Funeral Home at 77th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

WOLKENBERG--Gilbert G., 85 of Lido Beach, NY. An epic man in every sense of the word. Beloved husband of Edith, father of Beth and Bruce Kaplan, Richard and Karen Wolkenberg, Rusty Primeau and Michael Primeau, grandfather to Joshua, Andrew, Adrianne, Jeremy, Rachel, Justin, Steven, Casey, Logan and Corey, greatgrandfather to Jacob, adored brother of Alfred, Joan Biller, baby sister Barbara Solomon and cherished brother in-law Jack Solomon. Gilbert was a pillar of wisdom and kindness. His warmth and stoic strength were guideposts and inspirations to all who were lucky enough to be touched by his love. Gilbert, affectionately known as ''Pop-Pop'' by his grandchildren, was a mortgage banker for over 40 years, growing his father's business, G&M Wolkenberg, into one of the premier mortgage banking firms in New York, continuing today under the leadership of his son Richard. Gilbert leaves behind a legacy as grand as his personality and a lifetime of laughter. An endless source of advice, he counseled many and above all, lived a breathlessly romantic life with his magnificent wife, Edith for 57 years. Together they built a family and instilled traditions and values that will live on for generations. Services, Wednesday September 3, 2008, 11:30am Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, NY. Donations may be made to The Center for Discovery, P.O. Box 840, Harris, NY 12742.

8 P.M. (CW) 90210 They're not in Kansas anymore. In this new version of ''Beverly Hills, 90210'' Rob Estes and Lori Loughlin play Harry and Debbie Wilson, who depart rural America for California with their teenage children, Annie (Shenae Grimes) and Dixon (Tristan Wilds) -- the better to care for a boozy grandmother (Jessica Walters). Enter West Beverly Hills High School, where Harry has become the new principal; Jennie Garth, reprising her role as Kelly Taylor from the original series, is a guidance counselor; and Shannen Doherty, resurrected as Brenda Walsh, is directing the school play. In the premiere episode classmates of the Wilson children, including Adrianna and Naomi (above, from left, Jessica Lowndes and AnnaLynne McCord), are introduced, after which, at 8:30, Dixon tries out for the lacrosse team, and Annie is flown to dinner in San Francisco on a student's private jet but neglects to tell her parents. 5 P.M. CONCERNS ABOUT ZETIA The anticholesterol drug Zetia and the combination drug Vytorin, which contains Zetia, were approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 2002 despite clinical trials that showed they did not help patients live longer or avoid heart attacks. Now, scientists are debating whether there is a link between the two drugs, bestsellers used by three million people, and cancer. GOOGLE INTRODUCING BROWSER Google plans to begin distributing its own Web browser, called Chrome, on Tuesday as its rivalry with Microsoft, the maker of the Internet Explorer browser, escalates. [C1.]

BRIMMER--Brenda, August 30, New York. Brenda's loving friends mourn her death following her heroic struggle to overcome complications of heart surgery. Her outstanding work as Project Director of Policy Studies at UNAUSA, Executive Director of Joint Foundation Support, founding Director, Ms. Foundation for Women, and award winning Vice President of American Express was a source of pride and accomplishment throughout her life. Her homes brought her great joy, for the opportunity to experience the glories of nature, and as a place her devoted friends gathered to exchange ideas and benefit from her wisdom and love. We all cherish our special memories and will hold Brenda in our hearts, always. Thank you Brenda for so enriching our lives. A memorial will be held at a later date. Contributions in her honor may be sent to the charity of your choice. On behalf of all of Brenda's friends who have sustained her as family, we offer this tribute. Barbara, David, Linda, Patricia and Dale

The women's world championship tournament in Nalchik, a Russian city in the Caucasus, got off to a rocky start when 11 of the 64 participants did not show up for the first matches, most, if not all, protesting Russia's military action in Georgia earlier this month. The boycott wreaked havoc on the pairings as two first-round matches were not played because neither participant showed up and two players in the second round, Humpy Koneru of India and Aleksandra Kosteniuk of Russia, had walkovers because those earlier matches produced no opponents for them. Still, the tournament proceeded and, after the first two rounds, there are now 16 women left, including most of the top seeds. Results, photographs, information about the players and games are on the championship's Web site.

The hour of the Kurds has come round again. They are the great success story of the Iraq war, what the Bush administration always hoped for across the entire country. They have a functioning, popularly supported regional government. Their economy is booming. Religion has little retrograde or divisive influence on their public institutions. Women are respected (there have been many important female leaders in Kurdish history) and Israel is viewed approvingly. Terrorism is generally unknown in the Kurdish areas of Iraq. What's more, the Kurds are ready to defend themselves and what they have achieved. Anyone who wants to understand the future of Iraq and the Middle East in general has to take them into account.

Jersey barriers, sidewalk vendors, honor boxes, traffic cones, double-parked cars, unloading trucks and ice-cream-wielding tourists constitute the day-to-day obstacles that usually block pedestrian progress in New York. But a Sunday stroll along the Brooklyn waterfront could not advance many yards without running into one wedding party photo-op after the other. These three pictures were taken 28 minutes apart, for an average speed of 6.43 m.p.h. (marriages per hour). As if the bustles of bridal gowns did not take up enough square footage on the sidewalk, swarms of hired photographers and videographers behaved with paparazzi-grade determination to catch their subjects, at one point briefly blocking the pedestrian access to the Brooklyn Bridge to frame a newlywed couple. Who could begrudge them that backdrop, though?

From Floyd Norris at Notions on High and Low Finance:
Wolters Kluwer said it agreed to buy UpToDate, an online resource for doctors on how to diagnose and treat patients.
Do Lazard bankers see trouble on the horizon? That's what Breakingviews is pondering after the advisory firm's executives filed to sell more than $300 million of stock in a secondary offering.
From our colleagues at Bits:
Atticus Capital and the Children's Investment Fund are teaming up again to take on Deutsche Börse, warning the stock exchange operator on Tuesday to take urgent action to improve shareholder value.
HSBC and an unidentified Chinese bank are among potential buyers of Lehman Brothers, South Korea's Chosun Ilbo newspaper reported on Wednesday, citing a financial industry source.

High-ranking bankers at Dresdner Kleinwort are said to be considering a management buyout of the London investment bank after Commerzbank agreed to buy its parent, Dresdner Bank, for 9.8 billion euros from Allianz ($14.2 billion), The Deal reported.
Rupert Murdoch, who last December won control of The Wall Street Journal, seemingly yearns for another sacred cow of the journalism world: The New York Times.

Last September, Abu Dhabi Media Company, an arm of the government in the city-state capital of the United Arab Emirates, reached a $1 billion deal to make movies and video games with Warner Brothers, the big Hollywood studio owned by Time Warner.

Claremont Creek Ventures, a venture capital firm that targets early-stage information technology and life science start-ups, has raised almost $115 million towards its second fund, VentureWire reported, citing a regulatory filing.

The hedge fund manager Ospraie Management will close its flagship fund after it fell 27 percent in August on losses in energy, mining and natural resources equity holdings, in one of the biggest ever closures of a commodities-focused hedge fund.

Merrill Lynch, battered by more than $40 billion of write-downs tied largely to mortgages, said on Tuesday it hired Michael Nierenberg from JPMorgan Chase to head its mortgage and securitization businesses.

Archaeology | Papyrus scrolls from the only library to survive from classical antiquity are stoking a revival of scholarly interest in Epicureanism, "Europe's first green philosophy." The library of the Villa of the Papyri was buried by lava in Vesuvius's eruption in the year 79. Technology is now helping to reveal works of Epicurus and his disciples. [The Australian]
A former portfolio manager at Contrarian Capital Management is gearing up to raise about $1 billion to start his own fund, The New York Post reported.

Morgan Stanley is raising $10 billion for a global property fund and plans to put $1.5 billion or more of that into China, shrugging off concern about a property market downturn, according to Reuters.

Lawyers for imprisoned former Tyco International chief executive Dennis Kozlowski and ex-financial chief Mark Swartz on Tuesday asked New York's highest court to throw out their convictions, saying a jury had insufficient evidence when it found them guilty.

After paying $250 million in late 2005 for a drab 12-story building in Washington, built in 1968 a few blocks from the White House, Marshall Allan knew he needed to improve the appearance of the facade. Belgian brewer InBev is planning to put its Korean beer business up for sale, in an effort to shed a noncore asset and raise what could be approximately $2 billion for its purchase of U.S. brewer Anheuser-Busch, according to Reuters.

Science | Better luck next summer: new research affirms it's best not to swat at a fly's starting position; rather, aim for its escape route. At a dead start, a fly takes like 200 milliseconds to reposition its legs and wings and bolt from a threat. Meaning you and your newspaper. But you knew that. [Reuters]

Energy | Plug-in hybrids? Right. They're still a ways off, so automakers are scraping for every possible mile per gallon now. Look for less dramatic changes in the short run: direct-injection gasoline engines; the return of fuel-efficient diesels; low-rolling resistance tires. And weight loss: Ford has a per-vehicle target of 250 to 750 pounds. [Business Week]
Giorgio Armani's next project with Emaar Properties will be the Armani Residences in Marassi, the Dubai-based developer's massive master-planned project in Egypt.

Dario Franchitti will leave Nascar and return to IndyCar in 2009 as the replacement driver for Dan Wheldon at Chip Ganassi Racing. The move was announced by Ganassi, who also signed a multiyear sponsorship extension with Target for his open-wheel and Nascar programs. Franchitti won the 2007 IndyCar Series title and the Indianapolis 500 but left open-wheel for Nascar at the end of the season to drive Ganassi’s No. 40 Dodge in the Sprint Cup Series. Ganassi never secured sponsorship for that team and was forced to shutter it in July. At the time, Franchitti said that returning to IndyCar was not an option.

Guard Keon Lawrence has transferred from Missouri to play at Seton Hall. He can practice with the Pirates this season but cannot play in games until the 2009-10 season. Lawrence played in all 32 games at Missouri last season, averaging a team-high 29.2 minutes and leading the Tigers in field-goal attempts. He averaged 11 points, 3.3 rebounds and 2.4 assists. Lawrence averaged 31.2 points as a senior at Weequahic High School in Newark.

Usain Bolt of Jamaica won the 200 meters in 19.63 seconds, easing up before the finish, at the Athletissima Grand Prix in Lausanne, Switzerland. He had not run a 200 since the Olympics, where he won the gold medal with a world-record 19.30. This was the second-fastest time in the world this year. In the 100, Asafa Powell of Jamaica ran the second-fastest time ever, 9.72, which equals the time Bolt ran in New York in May; at the time, it was a world record. Bolt lowered it to 9.69 in winning gold in Beijing.

Janel McCarville scored a career-high 34 points and Lisa Willis added a career-high 19 on Tuesday night to help the Liberty beat the Houston Comets, 90-87, in overtime in a W.N.B.A. game. The Liberty snapped the Comets’ eight-game home winning streak and completed a sweep of their two-game season series.

CHESTER--Pauline , 95, loving mother of Susan Sokol and Bill Shurr, adoring mother-inlaw and grandmother to Michael and Jake Sokol. We will forever remember your goodness and grace. Rest peacefully, and know that we will miss you deeply every day of our lives. All our love, Susan, Michael, Bill and Jake CHESTER--Pauline. To my Loving Mother, Pauline Chester, who passed away on August 31st, 2008, close to her 96th birthday, You gave me nothing but love, encouragement, admiration, support and strength throughout my entire life. Words could never express the adoration and gratitude I feel for you. I will think of you every day and hear your loving voice in my heart forever. With all my love and devotion, Susan CHESTER--Pauline. It is the end of an era, so many years and wonderful memories. Our deepest love goes to Susan, Michael and Jake. Joel, Maura, Eric, Glen and Juliet

9 P.M. (BBC America) COCAINE DIARIES: ALEX JAMES IN COLOMBIA Alex James, the bass player for the band Blur, once bragged that he had spent more than a million British pounds on cocaine. In this documentary the now reformed Mr. James travels to Colombia at the invitation of its president to see where his money went. He rides shotgun with a drug kingpin's assassin and goes into the rainforest to watch as coca leaves are harvested and turned into narcotics. He also discovers that cocaine and violence are inextricably linked. ''It's a long way from a cheeky line at a dinner party,'' Mr. James says. ''It's terrifying.'' Above, he watches as a drug dealer lays out his wares. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Segments include reports from the Republican National Convention; an interview with the psychologist Phil McGraw; preparing for a baby; and what not to wear after you've turned 50.

T HE OAK ROOM of the Plaza hotel, built in 1907, originally opened as a bar for men only. Closed during Prohibition, it re-emerged as a restaurant in 1934. Since then, miscellaneous additions and subtractions, not to mention decades of tobacco smoke, took some of the luster off the room and its adjoining Oak Bar, both closed since the Plaza began its massive renovation in 2005. This summer, teams of artists, artisans and laborers have been bringing the place back to life, working on a painstaking floor-to-ceiling restoration, guided by historic photos. The Oak Room's majority owner and managing partner, Joey Allaham, who also owns several kosher restaurants, has lured Joël Antunès to New York to serve as chef. Mr. Antunès, who has left his restaurant, Joël, in Atlanta, brings along a collection of 24,384 recipes he has gathered over 25 years behind the stove.

A front-page article on Sunday reported that a legal dispute might prevent a $10 million-plus racing yacht built for Lawrence J. Ellison, chief of the Oracle Corporation, from participating in the next America's Cup, but the details of the legal dispute were deleted during the editing process. Lawyers for the Golden Gate Yacht Club, for which Mr. Ellison's team races, have argued that the rules that govern the next race, which will exclude his trimaran, unfairly handicap challengers. The terms, which require 90-foot keel yachts, were negotiated last year for all competitors by the club behind the team of Ernesto Bertarelli, the defending cup winner, and the Spanish yacht club that officially challenged him. Lawyers for Golden Gate also argued that it, not the Spanish yacht club, should have been the official challenger with the right to negotiate terms of the next race, and that the Spanish club was not qualified to challenge for the cup. A trial court judge agreed with those arguments, prompting Mr. Ellison's team to start building the three-hulled yacht. An appeals court reversed the decision, however, and reinstated the Spanish club as challenger, effectively blocking Mr. Ellison's trimaran.

WALZER--Richard A. , M.D. The Department of Dermatology at Columbia University mourns the loss of Richard A. Walzer, M.D., who passed away on August 4 in Boston, MA at the age of 78. Dr. Walzer was a distinguished faculty member and associate clinical professor of dermatology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He completed his residency in dermatology at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and joined the faculty in 1961. Prior to his tenure at Columbia, Dr. Walzer was a graduate of Harvard College, received his medical degree from Columbia University, served as a general medical officer in the United States Air Force, and was a research fellow at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. He was interested in autoimmunity and the skin and published several important publications in this area. Dr. Walzer was widely regarded by the dermatological community as a gifted and compassionate physician and a dedicated teacher. He was a prolific writer including three books, Healthy Skin, Treating Acne, and Skintelligence. Dr. Walzer and his wife Joyce retired in 1993 and moved from Wayne, NJ to Cape Neddick, ME in 1996. Dr. Walzer is survived by his wife, and his children Susan, Andrew, and Janet.

DRIVER--Phoebe Washburn , longtime resident of Westwood, Massachusetts and North Haven, Maine, died peacefully on August 22, 2008 at age 100. Born in Worcester, Massachusetts, she was married for 51 years to Charles Benjamin Barnes, who died in 1980. In 1987, she married William K. Driver who predeceased her after 14 years of marriage. She is survived by her daughter, Phoebe Caner and son-in-law, John E. Z. Caner of Seattle, daughters, Josephine Lea Iselin and Cornelia B. Barnes both of New York City, and her son, Charles Benjamin Barnes Jr. and daughter-in-law Connie Thomson Barnes of Medfield, as well as 12 grandchildren and 17 great-grandchildren. Also surviving are her stepchildren, Sally Anderson of Roswell, New Mexico, William R. Driver of Ottawa, Ontario, Senta Driver and Mary Driver, both of New York City, and Emily Moore of Albuquerque, New Mexico. Mrs. Driver was an accomplished author and poet, having published three books of poetry and an oral history with artist Gardiner Cox, painter of some of the great figures of the mid-20th century. She was an avid sailor in the waters off her beloved island, North Haven, and a life-long salmon fisherwoman who captured the essence of fishing the great rivers of Norway, Scotland, Iceland and the Gaspe Peninsula in her 2002 book, A Salmon Fishing Journey. A funeral service will be held at St. Paul's Church in Dedham MA at 12 noon on Saturday, September 13, 2008. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Mrs. Driver's honor to the North Haven Library. J.S. Waterman & Sons & Waring Wellesley 781-235-4110.

WASILLA, Alaska -- The world arrived here more than a century ago with the gold rush and later the railroad. Yet one aspect of American life did not come to town until 1996, the year Sarah Palin ran for mayor and Wasilla got its first local lesson in wedge politics. The traditional turning points that had decided municipal elections in this town of less than 7,000 people -- Should we pave the dirt roads? Put in sewers? Which candidate is your hunting buddy? -- seemed all but obsolete the year Ms. Palin, then 32, challenged the three-term incumbent, John C. Stein.

Jewel Kahn, The Melchners, The Millers, The Robinsons, The Rubins, The Sandlers, and The Siskinds DIRECTOR--Gerald, of Boca Raton, FL. With profound sadness we announce the untimely passing of our beloved husband, father and grandfather on September 2, 2008. As the heart, soul and spirit of our family, he was our guiding light. His wisdom, integrity, eloquence, humor, grace, humility and compassion were surpassed only by his immeasurable love and devotion to each of us. He shared a lifetime with his true love, who completed him in every way. His many significant professional, charitable and civic accomplishments spanned half a century and included innumerable achievments in the legal profession and dedicated service to his synagogue and to a range of charities. He was widely respected and admired for his professionalism, character and unparalleled skills as a trial lawyer and trusted counselor by his colleagues, clients and friends. Words cannot adequately express how much we will miss him, but his legacy and the lifetime of memories that he created for us all will remain in our hearts and souls forever. Survived by his loving wife Tamara, devoted children Mark, Shari, Stacy and David and his treasured grandchildren Brittani, Alexa, Chelsea and Carly. Memorial service Thursday, September 4, 2008 at 10am at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY 10606, followed by interment service Friday, September 5, 2008, at The Gardens, 4103 N. Military Trail, Boca Raton, FL 33431, In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to the American Liver Foundation, New York Chapter, 50 Broadway, Suite 1504, New York, NY 10004, or www.liverfoundation.org.

I applied directly to a lender for a mortgage to purchase a condominium. The closing has been delayed several times because the lender had to clear up issue after issue. Fearing that I might lose my financing at the last minute, I decided to go through a second application with a second mortgage broker, just to be on the safe side. In the event I am approved by both of them, am I free to pick the loan with the better terms? Do I owe anything to either?

How does the New York mortgage tax work when you are refinancing a property and are not getting any cash out? I owe $350,000 on my current mortgage on a New York City property. All I want to do is refinance the existing mortgage and get enough extra to cover closing costs, a total of $360,000. Do I have to pay the mortgage tax on the whole $360,000 or only on the $10,000 difference between the old loan and the new loan?

New Orleans may have been spared the worst of Hurricane Gustav. But the hurricane season has been terrible so far for some of the big Caribbean islands. Haiti has suffered the most. But Cuba has also had a rough time. And deaths have also been reported on other islands. More than 70 people have died in Haiti, mostly from flooding. The Miami Herald reported on Thursday that in scenes that recalled New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina three years ago, some people were left stranded on their roofs after Tropical Storm Hanna had moved on. The SunSentinel, published in Fort Lauderdale, showed Haitians wading chest-deep in a flooded town. After decades of abuse by Haitians cutting down trees to use for fire wood and charcoal, the mountains of the country have become raw dirt ramps that funnel rainwater into the low-lying towns and farm fields. Any heavy rain is bad for Haiti. And the latest run of storms, including Tropical Storms Fay and Hanna and Hurricane Gustav, left some places 12-feet deep in water, according to news reports.
