City Councilman G. Oliver Koppell said on Thursday that he would introduce legislation "within weeks" that would allow the city's elected officials to serve three full terms instead of the current two.

Leander Paes has been around long enough to have won a bronze medal in singles at the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. He has had many doubles partners, so playing with someone for the first time was not a challenge, especially when that partner is part of the top-ranked women's doubles team.

ST. PAUL -- "Palin Power" may represent conservative principles and women's ascension, but it could just as well mean purchasing power. After Gov. Sarah Palin's acceptance speech last night, merchandise with her name or likeness is super hot.

New York City's political landscape has long been filled with officials who are related: parents in elective office alongside their children; siblings serving simultaneously in political office. Some suggest that it is now for more married couples to serve in office at the same time.
The actor Javier Bardem, one of the stars of "Vicky Cristina Barcelona," talks to Lynn Hirschberg about that film, the origins of his love of acting and more.

As expected, Dell has joined the netbook party. On Thursday, the company unveiled the Mini 9, a $349 portable computer that weighs 2.28 pounds, has an 8.9-inch screen and is tailored for Internet-centric tasks, like surfing, chatting, uploading photos, blogging, watching videos and listening to music.
Scenes from "Little Big Planet," a new video game from Sony Playstation.

For those of us still recovering from the sturm und drang of the Olympics, well, the time for recovery is over, because the Paralympics Games are just about ready to begin. And just as the Beijing organizers didn't skimp on the pageantry for the Olympics opening ceremony, it seems as if the Paralympic opening ceremony will also feature its share of mind-boggling spectacle.

Politics | An actuarial analysis suggests John McCain has 1 in 3 chance (or worse, given his cancer history) of dying before the end of a second term. But the chance of a guy his age dying before the end of one term is roughly 15 percent. Disclaimer: because mortality statistics describe broad population trends, it's dicey to apply them to any individual. [Politico]

Following is the second set of answers from Frances R. Sheridan, the writer and photographer of "Unleashed: The Dog Runs of New York City" (Prestel, 2005). This week, she answered City Room readers' questions about New York's dogs and dog runs and offering suggestions to readers on how to improve their pet portraits. We are no longer taking questions for this feature.
In a year or so, it may not be necessary to move all the way to Dubai to own a piece of the emirate's ostentatious man-made, palm-shaped islands.

Dianne Brill -- fashion icon-cum-queen of 80's New York nightlife -- has created a makeup collection and, now, a fragrance. Perhaps the best way to describe the surprisingly good Dianne Brill Eau de Parfum, which launches this month, is to let Ms. Brill do the job herself:

Dan Schnur, the director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California, was the national communications director for John McCain's presidential campaign in 2000. (Full biography.)
Alex Beam reveals the mysteries of the legendary New Yorker squash ladder.

Last week I asked for ways humans could fend off obsolescence by working with smart machines. If you watch these videos of a robotic helicopter at Stanford University doing stunts, you'll see a fine example of human-machine cooperation -- but I'll leave it to you to decide whether it's good news for us or for the machine.
Natural gas is a cleaner burning fuel than coal and oil, and so companies invested in natural gas like to advertise that fact. But some may be exaggerating the benefits to the climate.

In the race to create the highest-quality television image with the deepest blacks, plasma has always stood out as the technology of choice. But on Wednesday evening at the CEDIA trade show, Sharp introduced a series of new L.C.D. TVs that could change that equation.

As a freshman last season, Michael Crabtree was an all-everything receiver for Texas Tech. He led the nation in receptions (134), receiving yards (1,962) and touchdowns (22) - all N.C.A.A. freshman records. In Tech's season-opening 49-24 victory against Eastern Washington, he was back at it with nine catches, including one for a touchdown. Michael is going to be contributing a diary to The Quad during the season. In this first installment, he talks about his return to school, getting ready to visit Reno and his love of fashion.

Electronics industry press conferences are usually pretty staid affairs. After the lights and music die down, the industry "suits" come out on stage to announce their new offerings and tell the press why their company is perfectly positioned to forge ahead and capture the public's imagination in the new year.
The cast discuss their show.

The Milwaukee Brewers came into their series with the Mets, a potential postseason opponent, feeling good after winning eight of their last nine games in August and capping the month with a near no-hitter by C.C. Sabathia against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

Michael A. Cohen is a senior research fellow at the New America Foundation and the author of "Live From the Campaign Trail: The Greatest Presidential Campaign Speeches of the 20th Century and How They Shaped Modern America." (Full biography.)

Culture | In the 1920s, Emanuel Haldeman-Julius was a mail-order publisher whose "Little Blue Books" brought self-education (sex) and literature (Shakespeare) to millions of Americans. He's forgotten now. But until the Internet, "no single venture brought so much information across such great distance to so many Americans at so little expense." [Believer]
Eggplant is particularly good in this sweet-and-sour Sicilian version of ratatouille.

Jarett Dillard is a senior receiver at Rice. He holds almost every Rice career receiving record and leads all active N.C.A.A. receivers in receptions, receiving yardage and touchdown receptions. He also graduated with a degree in political science. Jarett will be checking in with The Quad from time to time to give readers an inside look at his season. Here he writes about the Owls' season-opening 56-27 victory over Southern Methodist in which he had three touchdown catches, as well as the impact that Hurricane Gustav has had on the team.

Talk about love amid the ruins. When the Bronx was burning, a romance sparked between John Reilly and Lois Harr. They were young and idealistic. They were determined to put into practice the lessons they learned at Catholic colleges about their faith, their neighbors and responsibility. They were community organizers.

Every now and then a bit of technology wanders onto my computer screen that makes me want to pull someone over and say, "Isn't it amazing that you can do this?" Flying around on Google Earth was like that. And so is the new face recognition system on Google's photo sharing site, Picasa Web Albums. (Microsoft's PhotoSynth system, which creates 3D spaces from a stack of digital snapshots, also had a jaw-dropping demo, but its first release is too hard to use.)
Ramsey County prosecutors filed charges against a protest group, saying members conspired to disrupt the National Republican Convention and discussed violent crimes, including kidnapping.

The virtualization software market just got even more crowded, thanks to Red Hat's $107 million acquisition Thursday of Qumranet. Red Hat will now compete head-to-head against the likes of VMware, Microsoft, Citrix Systems and Sun Microsystems.

I'm happy to report that I solved the odor problem, thanks to helpful comments from readers and consulting some of the materials on this site -- which, I should point out, are extremely helpful. (And yes, my wife is grateful the odor has been abated.)

Brooklyn voters packed the auditorium at St. Francis College Wednesday night to hear a spirited -- at times, testy -- debate between a longtime incumbent state senator, Martin Connor, and his challenger, Daniel L. Squadron, a former aide to United States Senator Charles E. Schumer.

Health | And you thought the Barbarians were the bane of civilization: French researchers say the spread of the Roman Empire could have left European countries more vulnerable to HIV. They say people in countries once ruled by Rome -- England, France, Greece and Spain -- are less likely to have a gene variant that protects against the virus. [New Scientist, BBC]

So writes John Gapper, the fine columnist for The Financial Times in today's paper. Chrome, of course, is Google's new browser, which is pretty explicitly designed to be a Windows killer. As Mr. Gapper notes, that precise fear -- that an Internet browser could become such a powerful platform for applications software that it would effectively take over the function of the operating system -- is what caused Microsoft to start the browser wars in the 1990s, effectively putting Netscape out of business.

About 21.5 million viewers watched the first full night of the Republican National Convention on Tuesday, the night before Governor Sarah Palin gave her address, Nielsen estimated. The convention was not broadcast on television Monday due to the landfall of Hurricane Gustav, but the Tuesday session featured Senator Joseph I. Lieberman speaking during prime time.

Over the last year, Citigroup has added many c-suite positions, so named for the word chief in their titles. Some of these are common positions: chief financial officer, chief administrative officer, chief risk officer and, of course, chief executive, meaning Vikram S. Pandit.

LVMH has announced that Phoebe Philo will be the creative director of Celine, beginning in October. Marco Gobbetti, the president of Givenchy, will now manage Celine. There's been a ton of speculation that Philo, who left Chloe nearly two years ago, would return to the fashion fold, and of course it would have to be to a big brand in need of a contemporary look. Fashion is sort of desperate for girlish clothes done with a knowing eye, and it will be interesting to see what Philo makes of classic, friendly Celine. She has a clean slate, really. Balmain, in a limited way, has sexy clothes. Chloe has a new designer, Hannah Macgibbon. Suddenly, there are different players at the French table.
Samak Sundaravej has again rejected calls to quit and announced plans to hold a national referendum to defuse the crisis.

Updated, 4:30 p.m. | A worker fell 48 stories to his death -- about 500 feet -- at 9:29 a.m. Thursday from a movable walkway at a construction site at West 41st Street and 11th Avenue, on the Far West Side of Manhattan, according to city officials.Officials initially looked into the possibility that the worker, identified by the authorities as Anthony Esposito, may have been involved with the operation of a construction crane at the site, but later said the crane was not involved in the accident. "There was no crane collapse here," said Kate Lindquist, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Buildings. "The tower is structurally sound."

The Automotive X Prize has a rich $10 million purse, and that may be a powerful draw for many of the entrants, some of whom appear to be operating on a shoestring. All they have to do is come up with something that has so far eluded all the major automakers - a vehicle that can achieve the equivalent of 100 miles a gallon. Then they simply need to make their car or truck safe and low-emission, and devise a business plan so it can be "production capable."

Rafael Nadal's four-set victory over Mardy Fish ended after 2 o'clock this morning, its start delayed by Andy Murray's four-set victory in almost four hours and Serena Williams's triumph over her sister in two long sets. Fish won the first set but, as Lynn Zinser pointed out in The Times, could not sustain his high level of aggressive play:

With the impending claustrophobia and frivolity of New York Fashion Week only hours away, sometimes you just need to get away from it all. No one understands this better than the designer Adam Kimmel who, despite his reputation as a darling of the New York men's wear scene, prefers the rugged nature of California skate culture to the straight-and-narrow catwalk. A collaboration between Kimmel and the Sonoma-based artist (and pal of the designer) Ari Marcopoulos, "Claremont" (above) is a must-see exercise in stomach-dropping exhibitionism. While the swashbuckling stuntmen Noah Sakamoto and Patrick Rizzo are dressed in Kimmel's baby-blue suits for Spring '09 -- apparently, the best way to bomb an open road is with a '70s open collar -- this ten minute movie is less about the threads and more about the mind-boggling joy of watching a bearded guy in a suit doing 60 down a highway on a skateboard with more grace than any model wobbling down a runway in a pair of six-inch heels.

Netflix, the DVD rental company, has long spoken of its belief that its business would eventually move from the shipping of DVD discs to electronic downloads. The company offers 12,000 titles now for instant viewing on personal computer or a TV equipped with Roku, a $100 intermediary device introduced last Spring. And soon, Xbox 360 owners will also be able to stream Netflix titles to the TV.

Now it's Senator John McCain's turn.

Stephen A. Feinberg, one of the country's most powerful and secretive financiers, hoped to make a fortune out of the detritus of the American auto industry. Instead, The New York Times' Michael J. de la Merced and Vikas Bajaj say, he seems to be losing one.

Internet | It seems fitting: use an online, graphic-novel style narrative to tell the gestational backstory of Google's new open-source Web browser, Chrome. [Innovation, Google]
Vibes Media, a mobile marketing company, will announce on Thursday that it has raised $15 million from Fidelity Ventures in its first round of fund-raising, mocoNews reported.

A.I.G., the troubled insurance giant, is working with JPMorgan Chase as it considers a possible plan to put billions of dollars of its most toxic assets into a separate company, The New York Post reported, citing undisclosed sources.
Merrill Lynch's efforts to sell a large number of mortgages to state-run Korea Asset Management have stalled over pricing issues, the Korean firm's chief executive told Bloomberg News.
Raptr, an online social gaming start-up, has received $12 million in its first round of funding, PaidContent.org reported.

Oracle's chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, failed to turn over evidence that may have proved relevant in a shareholder lawsuit against the tech giant, a federal judge in San Francisco ruled on Wednesday.

RAB Capital is removing its co-founder, Philip Richards, from his role as chief executive, as the British hedge fund faces shrinking profits after a series of wrong bets, including an investment in the troubled British lender Northern Rock, which was ultimately nationalized.

M&G, one of the biggest shareholders in British Energy, sought to damp down speculation that it had reached agreement with Électricité de France over an improved offer for the British nuclear power generator.
The Blackstone Group has joined a consortium bidding for Informa, but Reuters reported that the group was no longer prepared to pay its original price for the British publishing firm.

New York's attorney general is issuing subpoenas to several Bank of America executives to gain more information about the firm's marketing of auction-rate securities, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.
Herley Industries may have just put itself up for sale, The Deal says, after the defense electronics maker said it had hired Jefferies Quarterdeck to help it consider strategic alternatives.
The broker said the securities were as safe as cash. After all, he claimed, the outfit that issued them, Glacier Education Loan, bought student loans guaranteed by the federal government.
General Motors plans to have inked a deal to sell its Hummer brand by early 2009, the automaker's chief operating officer Fritz Henderson said Wednesday.
Procter & Gamble announced Wednesday that it has snapped up Nioxin Research Laboratories, a maker of products to help combat thinning hair.

The New York Sun, a daily newspaper launched six years ago as an often conservative-leaning alternative to The New York Times, may stop publishing by the end of September unless it gets additional financial backing.

Ivory Tower | Cambridge University wants to shed its elitist image by planting plot lines on British TV soaps like "EastEnders" and "Coronation Street." The idea: show the hoi polloi gaining admission, not just prep-school swells. A blog says that unlike Ivy League colleges, "Oxford and Cambridge are officially public institutions, so the expectation of public access is higher." [Brainiac, Guardian]

Cities | A study says British towns and cities are designed mainly for men. Take travel: while men just travel to and from work, women face urban-planning obstacles in their complex journeys to school with the kids, then work, then shopping. And women depend more on public transport. Then there's the issue of toilets ... [BBC]
The Blackstone Group has hired technology banker Ivan Brockman to launch its an M&A advisory office in Menlo Park, Calif., as the firm seeks to build out its advisory business.

Mervyn's, the lower-cost retail chain, is accusing its private equity owners of essentially pilfering the company's resources in a suit against the three private buyout shops and former parent Target.
Jefferies Group said Tuesday that it has hired 25 former Bear Stearns executives for its equities division.
Real-estate developer Harry Macklowe's woes deepened this week, as the credit squeeze continues to unravel leveraged deals he inked during the credit boom.
David Carr cleans himself up before Gov. Palin's acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention.

BP is close to a deal with its oligarch co-owners of TNK-BP that would see board changes at the Russian oil major, the departure of TNK-BP's BP-nominated chief executive, and which could lead to 20 percent of TNK-BP being floated, according to Reuters.

Billionaire Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda investment firm settled a regulator's allegations that it was misleading about its plan to cut its stake in General Motors , the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday.
Telephone and Data Systems Inc. and its majority-owned U.S. Cellular are planning to dump their listings on the American Stock Exchange in favor of the New York Stock Exchange.

State regulators approved a deal on Wednesday that will allow the construction of hundreds of new wind turbines in New York, doubling the amount of wind power capacity within a few years, Nicholas Confessore wrote in today's New York Times.

Novolipetsk Steel, the Russian steel maker owned by billionaire Vladimir Lisin, has agreed to pay $400 million in cash to acquire U.S. hot-rolled steel maker Beta Steel and expand its presence in North America.
The California State Teachers' Retirement System, the nation's second-largest pension fund, isn't feeling as optimistic about its investments in the Blackstone Group, it seems.
Vignette's software sales are slowing and its stock is slumping, a situation that The 451 Group thinks could make the Web content-management company ripe for a takeover.

We neither resented nor calculated what we spent during those years and, indeed, would have spent more but for worries about our own retirements and old age, a worry that Anne shares. Underoath, which played Irving Plaza last week, has regrouped after past problems but can still sound frighteningly bleak.

Long before the slogan known to 48-hour libertines -- What happens in Vegas, stays in Vegas - became commonplace, I heard a variant of that in Alaska, and not just at closing time in fishermen's bars.

It’s a long way from tonight’s season opener to the Super Bowl in Tampa next February. But as you make your prediction on which two teams will be there, consider the Super Bowl-winning coaches from this decade: Tom Coughlin, Bill Belichick, Bill Cowher and Tony Dungy are all defensive minds. And even the ”offensive geniuses” who won it, Brian Billick and Jon Gruden, did so by riding two of the most menacing defensive units of recent vintage: the 2000 Baltimore Ravens and the 2002 Tampa Bay Buccaneers, respectively. We all know the latter also owed a debt to Dungy, Gruden’s predecessor in Tampa. It’s not that offensive minds have completely failed. Joe Gibbs, Norv Turner and Mike McCarthy all led their teams deep into the playoffs last season. But the difference between a good team and a championship team is the difference between the lightning bug and the lightning. So why can’t offensive coaches get over the Super Hump?.

If you’re planning to exercise outside in the heat and drenching humidity of the final dog days of summer, get cool first. That’s the unsurprising but still consequential finding of a new study published this month in the journal “Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise.” The study, conducted by researchers at Loughborough University in England, sent eight fit young men into a climate-controlled chamber, with the temperature set at a sweltering 97 degrees and 20 percent humidity. There, the men rode exercise bikes at a hard, steady pace until they were too tired to turn the pedals anymore.
Inevitability is out; unpredictability is in.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Friday about Wellesley College’s loss of a painting by Fernand Léger, using information from Reuters, omitted credit for the first report of the lost painting. It was in The Boston Globe.

The Copenhagen Journal article on Aug. 19, about Omar Marzouk, a Danish comedian who is trying to use comedy to combat prejudice about Islam, misstated the class background of the main characters in a former British sitcom, “The Young Ones,” which Mr. Marzouk said was a source of inspiration. Of the four principal characters, at least two were middle class or upper middle class. They were not all working class.
An article on Tuesday about online serials sponsored by television networks misstated the premiere date of “Sorority Forever,” a serial on thewb.com. It is Monday, not Tuesday.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the singer Michael Feinstein omitted part of the title of a song on his new album, “The Sinatra Project.” The song, introduced by Joan Crawford in the 1931 film “Possessed” and recorded by Sinatra in the 1940s, is “How Long Will It Last?” not “How Will It Last?”.

A picture caption on Aug. 26 with the New DVDs column, using information provided by Warner Brothers, misidentified the film in which Errol Flynn, four of whose westerns have recently been issued on DVD by Warner Home Video, was shown with Alexis Smith. It was “San Antonio,” not “Montana.”.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about Andrei Loshak, a Russian filmmaker whose documentary on the demolition of Moscow’s historic buildings was spiked by a local television station, may have left an incorrect impression about the location of the photograph showing Mr. Loshak on a city street. He was in St. Petersburg at the time, not Moscow.

An article on Tuesday about a new computer game, Spore, referred incorrectly to the popularity of The Sims, an earlier game from the same designer. The Sims is the best-selling computer game franchise ever, not the best-selling video game franchise.

An article on Tuesday about the role of nitrogen in global warming misstated the effect of one nitrogen compound. Emissions of nitrogen triflouride contribute more to global warming than carbon dioxide emissions from any one of the largest coal-fired power plants, not more than all coal-fired power plants.

Because of an editing error, the Front Row column last Thursday, about an iPhone application offered by Style.com that will allow users to watch the runway shows from New York Fashion Week, referred incompletely to its availability. It can be seen on the iPod Touch, not just the iPhone.
An article last Thursday about the fashion designer Michael Kors misstated the year he made his debut as a “Project Runway” judge. It was 2004, not 2006.
Serena Williams fought back from what looked like near-defeat in both sets to grab a riveting 7-6 (6), 7-6 (7) quarterfinal victory from Venus Williams at the United States Open.
The contrast in racial and ethnic demographics is perhaps the most visible difference between the Republican convention and last week’s Democratic conclave.
Recollections from Republicans on past conventions and vice-presidential selection process.
By his own admission, Representative Edolphus Towns is campaigning as if he were in the fight of his political life.
A subway motorman who was mugged in January chased a bystander down a Harlem block and stabbed him, then misled the police by saying he acted in self-defense, prosecutors said.
Fort Ticonderoga’s caretakers are struggling to keep the historic site open after a breach between the fort’s greatest benefactor and its executive director.
A lawsuit against the governing body of chess in the United States and some of its members was dismissed last week, but the dispute is not about to go away.
Financial documents suggest that after seven years of rule by a billionaire, control of City Hall is likely to go to a person of far humbler means.
A home run protested by the Tampa Bay Rays was the 549th of Rodriguez’s career, and it punctuated a victory, the Yankees’ third win in three games this month.
INTERNATIONAL.

The American Todd Hays’s hopes of competing in one more Olympics got a boost when he officially returned to national-level sliding by winning the drivers’ competition at the United States Bobsled Push Championships in Calgary, Alberta. Hays was the 2002 Olympic silver medalist but retired after failing to reach the medal podium at the 2006 Turin Games in Italy. Hays, already a three-time Olympian, announced late last year that he was making a comeback attempt.

The National Stock Car Racing Commission, Nascar’s rules appeal body, overturned probation penalties for Tony Stewart and Joey Logano, drivers for Joe Gibbs Racing, in the league’s second-tier Nationwide Series. The commission “unanimously decided to amend the penalties assessed by Nascar, removing the probation portions of both driver penalties,” it said in a statement. The drivers were docked 150 points in the Nationwide standings after postrace inspections at Michigan International Speedway last month. That part of the penalty will stand, the commission said.

A federal grand jury issued new indictments against two part-owners of the 2007 Horse of the Year Curlin. The owners, William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham Jr., are accused of defrauding clients of $94 million after winning a settlement from manufacturers of the diet drug fen-phen. A jury could not reach a verdict against them in July during a trial on charges of conspiracy to commit wire fraud. The new indictment charges the men with eight counts of wire fraud. Cunningham’s lawyer, Steven Dobson, questioned whether the newest indictment was a result of vindictiveness from prosecutors who failed to get a conviction. The two defendants bought Curlin, winner of last year’s Preakness, in 2004 before selling an 80 percent interest.

After weeks of speculation, Oklahoma City’s new N.B.A. franchise revealed that the team would be called the Thunder. A group of children and team members pulled down a curtain at a news conference to reveal a large team banner as the AC/DC song “Thunderstruck” was played. Clay Bennett, the team chairman, said the team colors would be blue, red and orange.

GOODMAN--Linda Berg . We are saddened to learn that Linda Berg Goodman's valiant battle against pancreatic cancer ended early on September 2, and wish to extend our deepest condolences to her family and friends. Sylvia & David Ehrlich

FORD--Gerard William , died in Morristown, New Jersey on Sunday, August 24th. Jerry was the beloved husband of Eileen Otte Ford for nearly 64 years, devoted father of Jamie Ford Craft; Gerard William Ford, Jr.; Katie Ford; and Lacey Ford Williams. He was also a much-loved grandfather of eight grandchildren and great-grandfather of three. His family treasures the example he set for them of kindness, wisdom, responsibility, integrity, and humor. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Church, 1 West 53rd Street on Thursday, September 4th at 2:00pm. The family requests that no flowers be sent. Those who wish to remember him may send donations in his honor to Citymeals-on-Wheels, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

REYNIAK--J. Victor , 1936-2008. Beloved husband of Sibylle, father of Andrew and Stefan, and grandfather of August and Fergus. Devoted educator; innovative researcher; compassionate physician; skler; opera patron; oenophile: Victor was happiest when he could share his spirit and passion with others. As Clinical and Research Professor of Obstetrics, Gynecology, and Reproductive Science and in private practice, he affected the lives of his patients and students in a unique, profound, and lasting way. At his request, services were private.

RABIN--Arthur . The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Arthur Rabin, beloved husband of Rita, father of Cindy Golub and Elliott Rabin, and fatherin-law of Bennet Golub and Adele Rabin. The Rabin and Golub families have long expressed their love of the Jewish community and devotion to social and humanitarian causes through their exceptional philanthropy and leadership. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Rita; to Cindy and Ben; to Elliott and Adele; to his grandchildren, Alexandra, Phillip, Jill and Batya; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO RABIN--Arthur. Beloved husband of Rita for 59 years. Cherished father of Cindy and Elliott and adored grandfather of Alex, Phillip, Jill and Batia. Funeral will take place at Pelham Jewish Center, 9am on Thursday. Shiva at home. Donations in his memory can be sent to UJA Federation of NY, Pelham Jewish Center or a charity of your choice.

Palin-palooza hit the floor of the Xcel Energy Center on Wednesday night, and the shock waves were felt as far away as the Virgin Islands. Actually, it wasn't that far away at all: the Virgin Islands delegation was situated just next to the Palin Procession that took over a cluster of seats just a few steps up from the floor (eschewing the customary family box in the rafters). Lens magnet that they are, the Palin family caused a bottleneck of photographers who crowded near the small island delegation for about 10 minutes of the vice-presidential nominee's speech.

BENBASSET--Celia , on September 3, 2008. A century of loving and giving. Beloved wife of the late Joseph M. Benbasset. Cherished mother of Susan and Stanley, Annette and Morty, Murray and Merri, Sally and Steve. Adored grandmother of Liz and Harold, Margie and Sandy, Joe and Nancy, Michelle and Dan, Jonathan and Stephanie, Jason and Melissa, Andrew, Corey, and Cari. Amazing Nona to six great-grandchildren. She taught her family how to live, always united. Leticia Chua took care of her to the end. Services today, 9am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Shiva will be at 555 North Ave, Fort Lee, NJ.

SHAFFER--Stanley . Devoted and beloved husband of Rosalie. Cherished father of Jon (Ivone), Burt, and Marjorie. Adored grandfather of Louis, Audrey, and Daniel. Winner of D.F.C Award in WWII. Services today, 1pm at ''Guttermans'', 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, L.I.

CHESTER--Pauline , 95, loving mother of Susan Sokol and Bill Shurr, adoring mother-inlaw and grandmother to Michael and Jake Sokol. We will forever remember your goodness and grace. Rest peacefully, and know that we will miss you deeply every day of our lives. All our love, Susan, Michael, Bill and Jake CHESTER--Pauline. To my Loving Mother, Pauline Chester, who passed away on August 31st, 2008, close to her 96th birthday, You gave me nothing but love, encouragement, admiration, support and strength throughout my entire life. Words could never express the adoration and gratitude I feel for you. I will think of you every day and hear your loving voice in my heart forever. With all my love and devotion, Susan

Calvin L. Beale, a government demographer who was among the first to recognize the transformation of America's rural landscape from farms to a mixture of farms, industry and vacation homes, died on Tuesday in Washington. He was 85. A niece, Carol Rudolph, said the cause was colon cancer.
COHEN--Paul , loving husband, father and grandfather died peacefully, September 2nd, 2008 in Port Orange, Florida surrounded by his family.

OSTROFF--William . Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime, devoted member. Nyren, president OSTROFF--William L., on September 2nd, 2008. Beloved husband of Carole. Devoted father of Gregg, Jeffrey and Jonathan. CATES--Ethel , ''Essie'' died peacefully on September 1, 2008 after a brief illness at home in Old Lyme, CT. She graduated from the Chapin School (1932). GALLAND--Helen . An elegant, brilliant and dignified woman who paves the way for other women. She loved life and people. She will definitely be missed. Muriel ''Mickie'' Siebert GALLAND--Helen. It is with deep sadness that we mourn your sudden passing. You were, without doubt, one of New York's most admired and inspirational women. We will sorely miss your unfailing friendship, indomitable tenacity in the face of personal adversity, incalculable wisdom and unending kindnesses. We are grateful to have been included in your circle of love. Your glowing spirit will continue to soar in our hearts forevermore. We send heartfelt condolences to your children -Judy, Susan and David. Funeral will be held Thursday, September 4, 2008 11:45am at Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions can be made to New York City Meals on Wheels, City of Hope and the Helen Galland Loewus Scholarship Fund at FIT. Your close friends GALLAND--Helen Loewus, on September 1, 2008. Hunter College graduate and pioneer in the fashion industry. Former President of Bonwit Teller. Survived by her children, David Frishberg, Susan Frishberg, Judy Schoenig and sonin-law Robert Schoenig, and their wonderful children. We will never forget her -she will be in our hearts forever. Services Thursday 11:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. GALLAND--Helen. The Women's Forum records with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Helen Galland. A universally respected leader in the retail industry, Helen inspired us all with her strength and determination. Judith D. Fryer, President, Women's Forum, Inc. GALLAND--Helen. The Hunter College community mourns the loss of a dear friend, loyal alumna and generous benefactor. A founding member of the Hunter College Foundation, Helen contributed her time and extraordinary service to Hunter and especially enjoyed her interactions with students. We will sorely miss her presence on our campus. Contributions in her name may be made to the Helen Galland Internship Fund, Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, NY, NY 10065. Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College GALLAND--Helen. The Fashion Institute of Technology's Educational Foundation for the Fashion Industries notes with sorrow the death of our distinguished member Helen Galland. A towering figure in retail, she was a longtime friend and generous supporter of the college. As we mourn her passing, we celebrate her achievements and remember her with admiration and gratitude. Joyce F. Brown, CEO Gilbert W. Harrison and John J. Pomerantz, Co-chairmen

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: KAY FRANCIS She was the most popular actress at Warner Brothers before Bette Davis came along. This month Turner Classic Movies pays tribute each Thursday to Francis, an Oklahoma girl whose dark, statuesque beauty -- at 5 feet 9 inches she was the tallest leading lady in 1930s Hollywood -- and velvety voice helped make her a star. The 42-film salute features several of Francis's pre-code hits, beginning tonight with ''Raffles'' (1930), starring Ronald Colman as a British charmer who turns jewel thief by night but vows to change his ways for the love of a beautiful socialite (Francis). The evening continues with -- is there a theme here? -- ''Jewel Robbery'' (1932), at 9:15, with William Powell (above, with Francis); and ''One Way Passage'' (1932), at 10:30, about a shipboard romance between a man (also Powell) condemned to be executed and a woman (Francis) doomed to an early death. The vampish ''Divorce'' (1945), at 11:45, was one of three films Francis made for Monogram in an attempt to regain her lost stardom. 6 A.M. (FNC); 5 P.M. (C-Span); 6 P.M. (CNN); 7 P.M. (MSNBC); 8 P.M. (13, 49, TV One); 10 P.M. GORDON--June . August 6, 2008. June was a dazzling jewel who shed light, warmth and humor on every facet of our lives. Dedicated psychotherapist, caring family member, loyal friend, she nourished all. Vibrant, creative and beautiful, June epitomized the Yves St. Laurent saying: ''Fashion fades, but style is eternal.'' June, you will live eternally in our hearts. Mary Wallach

WEBBER--Richard Howard , passed away on August 31, in Branford, CT. He was born in 1939, the son of Harry G. and Anne Webber. After graduating from Yale University in 1961, he joined the U.S. Navy and served aboard the USS Bache. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 1968 and practiced in New York and Connecticut specializing in admiralty and international trade law. He recently retired as a partner with the law firm of Hill Rivkins and Hayden. He served the First Presbyterian Church in New York City as an elder and trustee. He leaves his mother; wife, Mary Patterson Webber; son, Frank Patterson Webber and his wife Kara; son, Robert Lawther Webber and his wife Safia; and granddaughters Alexandra and Anya. Friends may call Friday, September 5 from 4 to 6pm at Hawley Lincoln Memorial, 493 Whitney Ave. in New Haven, Connecticut. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church, 12 W 12th St., New York City, Monday, September 8 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Richard Webber's memory may be made to Maine Maritime Academy, Development Office, 101 Leavitt Hall, Castine, ME 04420.

COLCHAMIRO--Leon , on August 31st, 2008 after a short illness. Beloved husband of Connie. He loved her and was in love with her for their entire 52 year marriage. Loving father and friend of Charles, David (Sharon) and Paul (Veronica). Adored grandpa of Lauren, Sara, Lindsay, Jillian, Emma, Colin and Evan. A memorial will be held at 4:30pm on September 14th, 2008 at Kehila Kedosha Janina, 280 Broome St., NYC.

FELDBAUM--Laura . Our dear Laura passed away on Wednesday, August 27 surrounded by family, at home in Ketchum, Idaho and at peace. Laura lived out her lives as daughter, sister, wife, mother, grandmother, aunt, friend and professional colleague exquisitely to the end. She fully realized her character and individuality in a way that was and always will be inspirational. Our family is grateful for having shared Laura's 62 years of love, laughter, learning and wisdom, and so thankful to you who gave your caring and powerful support over these four years while she battled brain cancer. After graduation from Vassar College, Laura was program officer at the Eisenhower Exchange Fellowship in Philadelphia, and was director of the Marshall Memorial Fellowship Program of the German Marshall Fund in Washington, DC. She served on the board of the Ketchum Community Library and recently received her Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology. She is survived by her husband Carl, her sister Susan Klein, her children Harley and Mia, daughter-in-law Nicole Fraser, and grandchildren Maddox and Nora. Memorial services and receptions have been set for 2pm Sunday, September 7th, in Washington, DC, and 2pm Sunday, September 21st in Ketchum, Idaho. For more information, contact: wrchapel@aol.com

MALONEY--William H., Jr. , age 92, passed on September 1, 2008. Born in New York, NY on February 13, 1916 to Elizabeth and William H. Maloney, Sr. He served his country as a Lieutenant Colonel in the United States Army. He is survived by his wife, Irene T. Maloney of Austin, TX; sister, Margaret Malone of Hamilton Square, NJ; sons, William Maloney of Bridgeport, WV and Patrick Maloney of San Francisco, CA; daughters, Janine Ray of Austin, TX, Michele Maloney of Henderson, NV, Nicole Maloney of Le Val Andr, France, eight granddaughters, and six great-grandchildren. RICHTER--Dr. Peter , a long time resident of Garrison, NY and New York City, passed away on Monday, September 1, 2008. Dr. Richter was born on May 16, 1922 in Baltimore, Maryland, to Dr. Curt Paul Richter and Dr. Phyllis Greenacre. During World War II, Dr. Richter served as a Naval Pilot, receiving an honorable discharge and the rank of ensign. Dr. Richter graduated from Yale University in 1946, and Cornell Medical School in 1950. He completed his internship and residency in internal medicine at New York Hospital. For almost 40 years, Dr. Richter practiced as a psychoanalyst in New York City. He was a member of the faculty of the New York Psychoanlytic Institute and also served as the institute's Vice President from 1975 to 1978, and chair of the Education Committee from 1972-1975. Dr. Richter was an avid gardener, fisherman, golfer and woodworker. He leaves behind Patricia, his wife of 59 years, his sons Eric of Garrison, NY, Peter of Garrison, NY and Curt of Helsinki, Finland. He is also survived by his four grandchildren, for whom he was a devoted grandfather. Services entrusted to E.O. Curry Funeral Home, Inc., Peekskill.

I recently moved to a co-op that does not allow washers or dryers in individual apartments (except for those installed before this restriction was enacted). Since moving in, I've had hives and rashes wherever my clothes or bedding rub my skin. After some sleuthing, my physician confirmed that I'm having an allergic response to detergent residues in the communal washing machines. The problem is very uncomfortable, and the antihistamines to reduce itching cause extreme drowsiness, which interferes with my work.

The new men's issue of T Magazine, starring the Spanish star Javier Bardem, proves that true style has global appeal. Anglo Cool is the dominant force in fall men's wear, but Japanese labels like Number (N)ine are giving Americana a fresh new spin, while Berlin-based artists are keeping international galleries on their toes. Frenchman Bernard-Henri Lévy reveals the intellectual underpinnings of hiswardrobe, and Italian "paninari" make an unexpected comeback; Mark Segal highlights fashion's Soviet influence as Stephen Bayley pays tribute to the eccentric Italian architect Carlo Mollino. Back in the USA, Justin Timberlake shares insights on his budding fashion career, and the collector, publishing mogul and all-around bon vivant Peter Brant shows off his new toys. It's enough cultural multilateralism to put the U.N. to shame.

And while Saturday's schedule seems somewhat weak on paper, last season taught us to never underestimate the power of top teams to completely collapse. With that in mind here are this week's picks from our esteemed panel.

Tlayuda, a specialty in Oaxaca, Mexico, is a baked flatbread, its base a large tortilla, usually corn. I've seen the tortilla topped with pork fat, thin-sliced roasted pork or crumbled or sliced chorizo, but the topping you see on almost every tlayuda is a black bean purée.

Fox's crime drama "Bones" delivered solid ratings with its fourth-season premiere on Wednesday, earning 9.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates. It was the show's best season debut since its first episode, in 2005.

In these tight economic times, with transportation costs rising, how far will people go to save a few dollars on their commute? For the last 11 years, on Staten Island, the answer appears to be about half a mile -- the distance some riders of the local commuter train walk every day to avoid the system's $2 fare.By this time next year, we'll know if they are willing to trek six-tenths of a mile on top of that.

Glater reported, citing a senior official in the office.

Phillip Bennett, the former chief executive of collapsed commodities broker Refco, reported to prison on Thursday to serve a 16-year sentence for fraud, a spokeswoman for the Federal Bureau of Prisons said.
Already struggling with an economy on the brink of recession and a record budget deficit, Britain is facing a potential new problem: an exodus of British companies fleeing the tax system.

Lexicon | Vet, as in checking out someone's background (like Sarah Palin's), is a "figurative contraction of veterinarian" dating to the 1860's and used in horse-racing. ("He vetted the stallion before the race.") First a Britishism and used by Kipling, vet gained traction in America in the middle of last century. It figures: The Times's William Safire has vetted "vet" before. [Slate, New York Times]
Banks and businesses are still having trouble raising money, according to data on Thursday that reinforced the prospect that the year-long U.S. credit crisis will persist for the foreseeable future.
Square Enix, the Japanese video-game maker, scrapped a takeover bid for software developer Tecmo after its offer was rebuffed.

American private equity firm Lone Star is seriously considering suing the South Korean government if it delays approval beyond September of the firm's $6.3 billion sale of shares in a local bank, according to The Korea Times.
Dell is trying to sell computer factories around the world in efforts to cut cost and improve profitability, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Exelon's board of directors approved a plan to buy back as much as $1.5 billion of the company's common stock, the utility company said Thursday.

Eli and Edythe Broad, who are giving away a multibillion-dollar fortune made in real estate and insurance, announced on Thursday their biggest gift so far, a $400 million donation to the Broad Institute of M.I.T. and Harvard, The New York Times' Stephanie Strom reported.

Pacific Investment Management Company, the manager of the world's biggest bond fund, named Mohamed El-Erian as its sole chief executive. The move gives him full control of a role he had shared with Bill Thompson, who will retire at the end of the year.
Shares of Informa, the London-based publisher of Lloyd's List maritime newspaper, fell 6 percent on Friday after the company rejected a reduced takeover bid from a private equity consortium.

An indicted former Credit Suisse broker was in custody Thursday to face charges over deceptive sales of subprime-related auction-rate debt, the F.B.I. said.

SemantiNet, a Tel Aviv-based developer of semantic Internet browsing tools, has raised $3.4 million in a first round of funding, led by Giza Ventures.

Greetings, fantasy football fans. At long last Week 1 of the season has arrived. Many of us have been thinking about this week for the past eight months - perhaps wondering if we could defend our league title or maybe just crawl out of the league's basement. Personally the past eight months have only persuaded me to fall deeper into this crazy fantasy football world: I am now in seven fantasy football leagues. Yes, that's one league for each day of the week. There are doubts that I'll surface with my sanity intact come January. Now a quick introduction might be in order for those of you who haven't been to my blog before, Fantasy Football Librarian.

Tyson Gay has pulled out of Friday’s 100-meter showdown with Usain Bolt and Asafa Powell at the Golden League meet in Brussels. Gay, who has been dogged by hamstring troubles since the United States Olympic trials, said he withdrew because he did not want to risk further damage.

Power forward Herb Pope has transferred to Seton Hall from New Mexico State. The 6-foot-8 Pope will be eligible to practice with the Pirates this season, but will not play until 2009-10. Pope played in 16 games at New Mexico State last season, averaging 11.1 points and 6.8 rebounds.

Still hesitant to race Curlin in the Breeders’ Cup Classic, the owner Jess Jackson announced Thursday that the immediate goal for the horse was the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park on Sept. 27. With a win in the $750,000 race, Curlin, the 4-year-old horse of the year, would become the sport’s top money-earner and the first horse to top $10 million. The announcement made no mention of the Breeders’ Cup, where Curlin could meet the top 3-year-old, Big Brown. When reached, Jackson did not rule out a Breeders’ Cup start. He was concerned that the race would be run on a synthetic surface at Santa Anita, something Curlin had never raced on.

The silver and bronze medalists in the hammer throw at the Beijing Olympics are being investigated for doping offenses by the International Olympic Committee. The medalists, Vadim Devyatovskiy and Ivan Tsikhan, both of Belarus, tested positive for traces of testosterone after the final on Aug. 17, the Russian news agency Allsport said. An I.O.C. disciplinary commission will meet at the end of the month to hear the case, an I.O.C. spokeswoman said.

A newly formed Russian hockey league accused the N.H.L. of poaching two of its players when the Los Angeles Kings agreed to terms with two draft prospects last week. As a result, the Continental Hockey League announced that it was no longer obligated to abide by a moratorium reached in July, when the leagues agreed against signing players who were under contract.

KENT--Raymond K., Ph.D . June 14, 1929-August 13, 2008. Dr. Raymond K. Kent, a scholar of world renowned and universal erudition, emeritus professor of African history at the University of California, Berkeley has passed away on August 13, 2008. His distinguished academic career, including many books, articles, years of field work and public lectures, deals primarily with the turbulent and complex history of the peoples and cultures of the great island of Madagascar and their struggle for independence. Professor Kent was born in Belgrade, Serbia and worked tirelessly and knowledgeably in the defense of the Serbian people during the tragic years of the disintegration of Yugoslavia and its aftermath. A Memorial Service will be held on September 7, 2008 at 10:30am in Holy Trinity Serbian Orthodox Church (address: 1700 School St., Moraga, CA 94556; Phone: (925) 376 - 5982; www.htsoc.org), followed by a reception. A commemoration honoring Prof. Kents life and academic achievements will be held at UC Berkeley Womens Faculty Club on September 9, between 5pm7pm (address: University of California, Berkeley, Phone: (510) 642-4175, womensfacultyclub.com). He will be sadly missed by his bereaved wife Estelle, numerous academic colleagues and many friends in the American and Serbian communities.

Few immigrant groups are as closely identified with an occupational niche as Koreans with grocery stores. A new book, ''Ethnic Solidarity for Economic Survival: Korean Greengrocers in New York City,'' offers a look at the complex role that ethnicity plays in those mom-and-pop businesses, which have been engines of economic mobility and opportunity for some Korean families.

ARNOLD--Donna M . A long time resident of Old Greenwich and Charlestown, Rhode Island died peacefully in her home, August 29th, after an 8th month struggle with CJD. Donna was born September 20, 1954 to Tom and Rosa Arnold. She graduated Classical High School a Merit Scholar in 1972 and attended The University of Rhode Island. Donna earned a BA in 1976 and MBA in 1978 graduating Beta Gamma Sigma. After graduation she moved to New York City to pursue a career on Wall Street. Her academic success and fluent German earned her a position at Swiss Bank where she worked her way into the trading room. Known for her brilliance, hard work, ethical behavior and attention to detail, Donna was recruited by JP Morgan, promoted to VP and worked on the F/X and Bond trading floors. With the arrival of her second son, Donna decided it was time to put her career on hold. After a decade of success in the financial markets she redirected full attention to her sons, Dominic and Victor. The love and devotion to her boys was immeasurable. An active alumni of URI she served on the URI Trustee Foundation Committee, Branding Steering Committee, Alumni Ram Fund Advisory Board, Communications Advisory Council, was the Alumni Winter Gala Host Chair 2004 -2005 and helped manage the investment portfolio for the grad students. An amazing wife for 29 years and best friend for 35, she is my inspiration and one true love.....the boys and I will miss her terribly every minute of every day. Donna is survived by her husband, Tom Cerio, her two sons, Dominic and Victor, her parents, Tom and Rosa Arnold, two brothers Tom and Leo Arnold and her sister Linda Arnold. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated Saturday September 6, 2008 at 10am in St. Catherine of Siena Church, 4 Riverside Ave., Riverside, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly ask you send donations to: Institute for Neurodegenerative Diseases, University of California, San Francisco, Attn: Stanley B. Prusiner, M.D. Box 0518, San Francisco, CA 94143-0518.

Gov. Sarah Palin's vice-presidential acceptance speech Wednesday night swept in 37,244,000 television viewers, as measured by Nielsen Media Research. That was about 13 million more than those who last week watched her Democratic counterpart, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., and, most remarkably, was just shy of the 38.4 million who saw Senator Barack Obama's speech from Invesco Field. In a further measure of the curiosity about Ms. Palin, her near-match of Mr. Obama's record-setting viewership for a convention was achieved even though her speech was carried live on just six cable and broadcast networks, compared with 10 for Mr. Obama's speech.

Viewers of the convention Wednesday night might have been startled by Gov. Sarah Palin's sudden appearance on the stage. It was not planned that way; she was supposed to have been introduced by a short video. Republicans skipped the video because Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, who preceded Ms. Palin, was loving every minute on the stage and ran about 13 minutes longer than he was supposed to.

The words that speakers use at the two political conventions show the themes that the parties have highlighted. Republican speakers have talked about reform and character far more frequently than the Democrats. And Republicans were more likely to talk about businesses and taxes, while Democrats were more likely to mention jobs or the economy. Unlike in 2004, this year the Republicans mentioned the opposing candidate less frequently than the Democrats, mentioning Senator Barack Obama about a third as often as the Democrats mentioned Senator John McCain. The Democrats also pushed a couple catch phrases of the Obama campaign in their speeches: the need for ''change'' and that the country doesn't need ''four more years'' of a Republican administration. And the nomination of Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska as the Republican vice-presidential candidate brought a new term into the convention vocabulary, ''hockey mom,'' which popped up in several speeches.

OMORI, Japan -- Home to a silver mine whose production peaked nearly four centuries ago and finally closed in 1923, this tiny rural town in western Japan once seemed doomed to suffer the fate of so many former boomtowns. Perhaps one day, after the last of the die-hards had moved away and the town's abandoned wooden houses had been ground to dust, the surrounding thick forests would have simply swallowed up Omori. But after intense lobbying by Japan, the Iwami Silver Mine here, which many Japanese had never heard of, was improbably named a Unesco World Heritage site last year. Having joined the ranks of the Pyramids, the Taj Mahal and Angkor Wat, Omori -- population 413 -- has been flooded with hundreds of thousands of tourists.

RICHTER--Dr. Peter , a long time resident of Garrison, NY and New York City, passed away on Monday, September 1, 2008. Dr. Richter was born on May 16, 1922 in Baltimore, Maryland, to Dr. Curt Paul Richter and Dr. Phyllis Greenacre. During World War II, Dr. Richter served as a Naval Pilot, receiving an honorable discharge and the rank of ensign. Dr. Richter graduated from Yale University in 1946, and Cornell Medical School in 1950. He completed his internship and residency in internal medicine at New York Hospital. For almost 40 years, Dr. Richter practiced as a psychoanalyst in New York City. He was a member of the faculty of the New York Psychoanlytic Institute and also served as the institute's Vice President from 1975 to 1978, and chair of the Education Committee from 1972-1975. Dr. Richter was an avid gardener, fisherman, golfer and woodworker. He leaves behind Patricia, his wife of 59 years, his sons Eric of Garrison, NY, Peter of Garrison, NY and Curt of Helsinki, Finland. He is also survived by his four grandchildren, for whom he was a devoted grandfather. Services will be held in Sorrento, ME.

The delegates to the Democratic and Republican conventions, generally representing the extreme wings of their parties, do not agree on much, but one belief they have in common: Nominating conventions are important. The New York Times/CBS News polls of delegates to each convention found that 9 out of 10 of each party's delegates said the conventions were necessary to show the public who the party leaders were and what they stood for. Only 56 percent of the electorate feels the same way.

He left the ministry to serve as Assistant to Mitchell Sviridoff, Administrator of NYC's Human Resources Administration and later to Henry Cohen, Director of The New School's Urban Studies program. [UPDATE 6:54 PM- A later version of the Tennessean story quoted below includes a crucial sentence not in the first version, which seems to change the meaning of the NHL's response to the IIHF proposal. That sentence appears to provide hope that the NHL is not flatly rejecting the proposal. The sentence reads, "NHL deputy commissioner Bill Daly said on Saturday the league would consider having the Radulov matter decided by an arbitrator, one agreed upon by both the NHL and KHL." John Glennon, the Tennessean writer, then adds "But Daly was angry that the IIHF didn't take a stronger stance against the KHL," and he goes on to quote from Daly's email referenced below.UPDATE 8:08 PM - In an email to Ken Campbell of The Hockey News, Daly sounded even more supportive of arbitration, but skeptical it would ever come to pass, saying, "We're happy to submit the Radulov matter to binding arbitration, but I sincerely doubt we would ever get the agreement of the KHL or Ufa to do so. They have no case to present, and no justification whatsoever for their lawless actions."]

United States Coach Dan Campbell retired Friday after his attempt to remake the team backfired in Beijing with its worst showing in Olympic history. Campbell, 65, a veteran of the amateur boxing ranks in Virginia Beach, Va., had been the national director of coaching for USA Boxing since 2005. The United States team had not left the Olympics with fewer than two medals since 1948, when it won one silver. The heavyweight Deontay Wilder’s bronze was the only prize for the Americans, who have won just one gold medal in the last three Olympics.

LIU--Joan (born Joan Brown Harrop), died peacefully in Chestnut Hill, MA, on August 28, 2008. Born in Manchester, England in 1923, she attended London University, and began working for the United Nations in 1945. Previously of New Rochelle and Bronxville, she was the wife of the late F.T. Liu. She will be missed by her sister Margaret Morris, of Chester, England, by her son and daughter-in-law, Michael and Karen Liu, and their children John and Mark, and by her daughter and sonin-law, Margaret and Scott McConnell, and their children Neil, Anna and Kristen, and by her great-granddaughter Ruby Weg McConnell. A memorial service will be held in Trinity Episcopal Church, 11 Homer St., Newton Centre, MA, at 1pm on Saturday September 13.

PESKOE--Judge Florence Ring, 78, of Shrewsbury died Thursday, September 4, 2008 at Riverview Medical Center, Red Bank, NJ. Judge Peskoe was the daughter of the late Irving and Anna Ring. A lifelong resident of New Jersey, she was born in Newark and grew up in Irvington. Judge Peskoe and her late husband, Lloyd Peskoe, lived in Roselle and Tinton Falls for 16 years and Colts Neck for 30 years before moving to Shrewsbury 5 years ago. Judge Peskoe was a retired New Jersey Superior Court Judge. A proud honors graduate of Wellesley College and Rutgers Law School, Judge Peskoe served the State of New Jersey in several court-related administrative positions, including service as The Clerk of the New Jersey Supreme Court and culminating in her appointment as Deputy Director of the Administrative Office of the Courts. In 1980, she was first appointed to the Superior Court bench by Governor Brendan Byrne and later was re-appointed with tenure. Judge Peskoe was active in many local charitable causes and Democratic political organizations prior to her judicial appointment. She served as chairperson of a number of committees of the national American Bar Association both prior to her appointment and later as a Judge. She was a nationally recognized expert in court administration and judicial ethics. Judge Peskoe was predeceased by her beloved husband of 56 years, Lloyd, in February 2007. She is survived by her two loving sons and daughters-in-law, Stuart Peskoe and Barbara Wolfinger of North Andover, MA and Andrew and Julie Peskoe of Briarcliff Manor, NY; her devoted daughter, Nina Peskoe Peyser of South Orange; and her cherished grandchildren Benjamin, Sarah, Madeline, Jacob and Anna. Florence Peskoe will be remembered as a trailblazer for women entering law school and in the judiciary. She was a staunch advocate for civil rights and womens rights, and a community leader throughout her life. Services are 12:30 Sunday at Bloomfield - Cooper Jewish Chapels, 2130 Hwy. 35, Ocean Twp., NJ. Donations can be made to the Florence Ring Peskoe Fund at Planned Parenthood of Central NJ, 69 Newman Springs Road, PO Box 95, Shrewsbury, NJ 07702; or the Florence Ring Peskoe Fund at Literacy Volunteers, C/O LVA of Essex/Passaic Counties NJ, Bloomfield College, 467 Franklin Street, Bloomfield, NJ 07003. Shiva will be observed at the Peskoe residence in Shrewsbury on Sunday, at Ninas residence in South Orange, NJ from 3pm-8pm on Monday and at Andrews residence in Briarcliff, NY from 3pm-9pm Tuesday through Thursday. Bloomfield - Cooper Jewish Chapels, Ocean Twp. is in charge of services.

BALTIMORE One weekday morning in 1981, when he was new to Baltimore, Arnold Graf descended into the basement of the Enon Baptist Church. The steps took him into the midst of 60 skeptics. They were the black ministers whom Mr. Graf, a white Jew, was trying to persuade to join him in community organizing.

JAMES--Sheila McBride. It is with deep sadness that the Lee family mourns the loss of your passing, a life taken all too soon. With such a generous and warm spirit, you were not only a fabulous mother to your own family, great wife to David and only daughter to Babby and Joe, but also a sister to three special boys -and an older sister to me. A dynamo on the golf course, you were a terrific partner -and my ultimate match. As the ultimate allstar, you touched all of those around with your selfless passion for friends and family. We celebrate your achievements and remember you with admiration and gratitude. You made the world a better place. James B. Lee Jr.

Tel +44 20 7352 0008.

Toll Brothers, the largest United States luxury homebuilder, lost a bid to have a shareholders' securities-fraud lawsuit against it dismissed. Investors who bought shares in the company from December 2004 to November 2005 made claims specific enough in their complaint to survive Toll Brothers' motion to dismiss it, a United States District Court judge in Philadelphia, James T. Giles, said in his order. He did not rule on the merits of the claims. The plaintiffs alleged that the company and individual defendants misrepresented or omitted facts ''regarding, but not limited to, traffic, demand and defendants' ability to add new selling communities in fiscal year 2005,'' the judge wrote.

DWORNICK--George. Be loved husband to Martha, father to Gail, Arlene and Gary and grandfather to Billy, A.J., Rachel and Megan. Passed away on September 5. His love, warmth and wit will be missed by all. We love you Dad.

TRAKTMAN--Esther (Katz). Suddenly, on September 4, 2008, at 86 years of age, while recuperating from a broken hip. Devoted and adoring wife of 66 years of Mortimer Traktman. Loving, caring mother of David and Paula (Stephen Duncan). Proud, doting grandmother of Samantha and Cameron Duncan. Fond sister of Florence Katz. A women of incisive intelligence, passionate in her beliefs and fiercely loyal to those she cared about, she was a true idealist in an age of relativism. She was much loved and will be sorely missed. Contributions in her memory to UJA-Federation or Planned Parenthood are welcome. Graveside service Sunday, September 7 at 11:30 am. Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York

CURRAN--Paul J. The Council, Past Presidents and members of The University Club mourn the passing of our esteemed friend and beloved former president Pual J. Curran, Esq., Georgetown '53. A giant of the legal profession, Paul was our leader and confidant, a gentleman, raconteur, patriot, sportsman and friend. A man of great generosity, devoted to his extended family and church, he now has a commanding view of the track from above. Our most heartfelt condolences to his wife Barbara, and fine family. Ave atque vale. The University Club CURRAN--Paul J., February 21st, 1933 to September 4th, 2008. Beloved husband of Barbara Ann (nee Frank). Loving father of Mark I., Mary Louise Kingsbery (Clay), Catherine Souther (Thomas), Barbara Susanin (Timothy), Thomas J., II (Deirdre), Paul J., Jr. (Wendy) and Elizabeth Stockton (Richard, Jr.). Cherished grandfather of Ann, Lucy, James, Paul, Ted, Caroline, William, Caitlin, Christopher, Margaret, Jack, Annabel, Barbara Ann, Thomas III, Lucie, Matthew, Claire, Paul III, Catherine, Curran, Richard III and Libby. Devoted son of the late Thomas J. and Margaret Farley Curran. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Monday, September 8th, 2-7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, September 9th, 10:30 am at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Paul J. Curran Fund, 645 5th Avenue, Suite 703, NY, NY 10022, which provides assistance to schools servicing New York City's less advantaged children.

General Electric said the Securities and Exchange Commission planned to recommend a civil complaint against the company in a three-year-old inquiry into the way it recognizes revenue and presents cash flow. The S.E.C. staff issued a so-called Wells notice, G.E. said in a regulatory filing after the close of markets on Friday. Wells notices typically give the recipient an opportunity to dissuade the S.E.C. from proceeding. G.E. is in preliminary settlement discussions with the agency, Russell Wilkerson, a company spokesman, said. The S.E.C. inquiry and internal investigations have involved G.E.'s finance, aviation, health-care and energy units, and ''a few'' workers at the locomotive unit were fired as a result, G.E. said in July 2007.

The chess column for Sunday, Sept. 7, is about Greg Chamitoff, an American astronaut aboard the International Space Station, who has been playing chess games with mission control. As the column mentions, this is not the first Earth vs. space chess match. In June 1970, Soviet astronauts Andrian Nikolayev and Vitaly Sevastyanov, who were aboard the Soyuz 9 spacecraft, played a consultation game against the earthbound Viktor Gorbatko, another astronaut, and Nikolai P. Kamanin, a Soviet general who was the head of the astronaut training program. Miron Sher, a grandmaster and coach who lives in New York City, dug up the score of the game. It can be replayed below.

As I predicted some time ago, all it took was for Formula One to have one race with very little action - the European Grand Prix in Valencia two weeks ago - for all sorts of people to start talking about Formula One being boring. An article on Aug. 24 about the actor Terrence Howard’s debut album, using information from his record label, Columbia, referred incorrectly to the premiere of the video for his song “Sanctuary.” It was first available on Essence.com, the Web site for Essence magazine, not on the television show “Extra.”.

An article last Sunday about Christopher Plummer’s portrayal of Caesar in Bernard Shaw’s “Caesar and Cleopatra,” at the Stratford Festival, misidentified the plot turn that inspired Caesar to say, “And so, to the end of history, murder shall breed murder, always in the name of right and honor and peace, until the gods are tired of blood and create a race that can understand.” Caesar’s line is in response to Pompey’s death, not Ptolemy’s. And a subheading misidentified the playwrights of the works in which Brian Dennehy appeared at the festival. He was in “Hughie” by Eugene O’Neill and also appeared in “Krapp’s Last Tape” by Samuel Beckett; he did not appear in any plays by Shaw.

Assuming all goes well with his bullpen session later today, Billy Wagner hopes to receive medical clearance Monday to face hitters, the last thing he needs to do before the team deems him ready to return. With Class A Brooklyn's season over, Wagner's options for pitching against live competition are limited to a simulated game, which would likely come Tuesday. Look for him to be activated for next weekend's series against the Braves.

The Treasury Department seized control of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the giant quasi-public mortgage finance companies, on Sunday and announced a four-part rescue plan that included an open-ended guarantee to provide as much capital as they need to stave off insolvency, according to The New York Times's Edmund Andrews.

Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. talked on Sunday about the inherent conflicts of interest in the way the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were run, as he put the government-sponsored enterprises into conservatorship. But his various comments made it clear that the conflicts remain.

Cooler-lugging guys in Mets T-shirts, flip-flop Asia girls, couple pushing Burberry fake-plaid stroller, blonde girl in skinny jeans and black halter top, aging Wheaten terrier, slow-moving grannies, tourists looking up: I got off the train this afternoon at Grand Cen and headed down 42nd Street, to rejoin, as it were, the fashion crowd for another season. The day is impossibly gorgeous. I found in the back of my closet, the way back, a black Comme des Garcons jacket from 20 year ago with slit sleeves. I thought this glorious day called for denim shorts and a little something extra. Hence the faithful CdG jacket. Yesterday's monsoon was a trial to the fashion goer. I opted for the navy trench coat, Balenciaga boots, and a baseball cap in lieu of an umbrella. Outside the Canal Street subway, on my way to see the guys at Proenza Schouler, a Niagara was in progress. Girls in cotton minidresses were scampering and whimpering through sudden puddles.

NORMAN, Okla. - Oklahoma wide receiver Ryan Broyles definitely lived up to the hype surrounding his debut.In the Sooners' 52-26 victory against Cincinnati on Saturday, Broyles had seven catches for a game-high 141 yards and a touchdown. His receiving yardage was the most by a player in his Sooners debut."If Ryan keeps doing the things he's been doing lately, he has a chance to be a special player here," Oklahoma Coach Bob Stoops said.Excitement about Broyles, a 5-foot-11, 175-pound redshirt freshman from Norman High School, had been building for more than a year.He missed Oklahoma's season-opening victory last week against Tennessee-Chattanooga while serving a one-game suspension. (The reason for the penalty was not disclosed.)Last season, Broyles was arrested the day before Oklahoma's opener for allegedly stealing gasoline from a Norman convenience store. The police said he was in possession of a gas-pump key and override codes.Broyles later pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor count of attempted petty larceny and was suspended for the season."It was definitely worth the wait," Broyles said of his debut. "I would have loved to play last year, but I have to take it one game at a time and be thankful for the opportunity I have now."

As Barack Obama hones his economic policy (David Leonhardt, Aug. 24), he should include a historian among his advisers to counterbalance advice he receives from free-market economists. Free-market laissez-faire economics is based on the faulty notion that corporate owners, workers and consumers have equal power and influence within the economic sphere. History teaches otherwise. Obama should study America’s Gilded Age, and the difficult times that followed, to see why it is important for government to regulate business and provide necessary support for workers. The titans of industry have disproportionate power that must be held in check by government to make our economic system work for everyone.

Non-tennis players usually do not understand the real problem withMcEnroe’s behavior on the tennis court (Nicholas Dawidoff, Aug. 24). His temper tantrums and tirades are often attributed to his perfectionism, his antiestablishmentism or his good guy-bad brat personality. In fact, this was gamesmanship in an attempt to get the psychological advantage over his opponents and, in some cases, the line judges. There are countless examples of his timely tirades to upset the opponent— not to beat the opponent physically through better play. None of the great champs (Laver, Borg, Evert, Navratilova, the Williams sisters, Federer, Nadal) behaved this way; it’s a form of cheating.

Alessandro Ballan of Italy won the seventh stage of the Vuelta a España and took the overall lead in the race. Ballan, a 28-year-old rider for Lampre, won the first major mountain stage — a 139-mile leg from Barbastro to La Rabassa in Andorra — in 6 hours 15 minutes 51 seconds. He finished ahead of the Spaniards Ezequiel Mosquera, riding for Xacobeo Galicia, and Alberto Contador of Astana.

Rory McIlroy shot a five-under 66 to take a four-stroke lead after the third round of the European Masters in Crans-sur-Sierre, Switzerland. McIlroy, a 19-year-old from Northern Ireland, is chasing his first European Tour victory.

Tampa Bay third baseman Evan Longoria was activated off the 15-day disabled list Saturday after he said he felt “almost 100 percent” following 30 swings with a regular bat. The French national team was humbled, 3-1, by Austria as Europe’s big guns began their 2010 World Cup qualifying campaigns. The British lightweight hope Amir Khan received the first loss of his professional career when he was knocked out in 54 seconds by Breidis Prescott of Colombia in Manchester, England. An article last Sunday about relatively inexpensive ways that co-ops and condominiums can improve the quality of life for their residents misstated the cost of an online service, BuildingLink.com, that enables residents to communicate with staff members and with one another. It is $13 per apartment per year, not per month.
