Gas is reaching heights of $4 a gallon, the Dow is on a roller coaster, and the housing market is as anemic as a runway model. In other words, what better time to drop $30,000 on a straight razor? In November, Hommage is introducing the limited-edition Damascene, conceived by Wolfgang Joensson, an industrial and product designer who co-founded the company after stints at renowned shops like Pentagram and frog design. The blade, made of pure Damascus steel, a hot-forged metal that is legendary for its strength, has a pedigree stretching back nearly a dozen centuries to ancient sword makers. A platinum-plated sheath houses the blade when it’s not in use, and each of the 15 razors in the first edition comes with a certificate of authenticity. For the shaving cream, you’re on your own. [?][?][?]ETHAN HAUSER.
“My label is for R.O.M.’s: rich old men,” says Jean Pigozzi, who knows whereof he speaks.

Since Jonathan Meese, above right, exploded on the scene at the Berlin Biennale in 1998 with his exhaustive mix of painting, sculpture and performance — he’s been known to goose-step in his underwear and bring his mother onstage — he has galvanized international audiences. Is he an art-world star, a charlatan or both? “Berlin will be the place for the revolution of art in 2023,” announces the baby-faced Meese (shown here with the artist Daniel Richter). Revolution or not, his installations shake up the system, bursting with playful Meesian mythologies about individuals as varied as Scarlett Johansson, Joseph Stalin and Richard Wagner. Richter, left, wears an Inhabit sweater. Meese wears a Giorgio Armani trench coat and shirt.

What do Beau Brummell, Malcolm McLaren and Ralph Lauren have in common? They have all been obsessed, in one way or another, with the tug of war between self-conscious historicism and cutting-edge avant-gardism that has always defined British fashion. Using clothes as shorthand for social posturing, subcultures ranging from Regency fops to ’60s Mods and Thatcher punks have both asserted and subverted the traditions of polite English society.

Naming your brand AAAAAAAAAA is a bit like having a band called !!! Confusing, yet strangely memorable. Daria Dazzan, an Italian-born 24-year-old former student at Antwerp’s Royal Academy of Fine Arts, and her boyfriend, the product designer Matteo Cibic, unveiled their clothing line with the sly moniker at the spring Milan Furniture Fair. (Why they avoided fashion week is a long, unfathomable story.) Having moved most of their production to Vicenza, the headquarters of Italian houses like Bottega Veneta, they wished to design something honoring the classic tailoring traditions of the area, but with a twist. The result is a single trouser style and matching suspenders reproduced in seemingly endless colors and linings. The fabrics, including everything from fine Italian wool to denim, are off cuts from neighboring ateliers; they are used only once, so no two pairs are alike. The cut is slim and low-rise, with a slightly tapered leg, and the suspenders fasten in the back via small buttons of corozo nut. “They’re very elegant trousers to wear to a party,” Cibic says, “or to work as a mechanic.” [?][?][?]JILL SINGER.

The romantic ideal of the tortured artiste is always in fashion — even so, the Number (N)ine designer Takahiro Miyashita seems to take special pains to suffer for his craft. When planning the portrait that accompanies this article, he asked that his face be obscured, perhaps fearing that the gigantic frames he wears wouldn’t provide sufficient cover. During our interview, he fielded several questions with enigmatic pronouncements like “You would have to ask my brain” and “I am a shadow.” At times, he simply stared into space, as if submerged in an autistic trance. Thus the sobriquet “Taka the oyster.”.
Marky Ramone of the Ramones goes way back with his Converse All Stars.

At the 53-acre Greenwich, Conn., estate that Peter Brant shares with his wife, the supermodel Stephanie Seymour Brant, and their children, a crew of gardeners on a hill crest was inserting tens of thousands of annual flowering plants into the stocky flanks and adorably snub snout of one of the most recognizable sculptures of our time: Jeff Koons’s “Puppy,” a 40-foot-tall Westie that is shaped from living blooms. Every spring, the reinstallation of “Puppy” requires 10 men to labor for 12 days. Somehow “Puppy” seems emblematic of Brant’s lifetime engagement as a collector. Many wealthy businessmen collect contemporary art, but for Brant, merely buying the work can feel insufficient. If possible, he wants to put some more work into it.

You should be dancing, yeah! And listening to the latest arbiters of disco — Hercules and Love Affair, Holy Ghost!, Glass Candy (whose album “Beatbox” is at left) and Horsemeat Disco, to name a few — who have updated the beat (and the genre’s transcendent lyrics) for a new generation of dance-floor dandies. “Disco never died,” says Michel Gaubert, the French D.J. who has used the sound for several runway shows. “It has only become more acceptable.” So acceptable, in fact, that LCD Soundsystem’s James Murphy and Pat Mahoney are bringing their “Special Disco Version,” an international D.J. tour of obscure vintage nightclub gems, to Manhattan’s Santos Party House every other Wednesday starting Sept. 10. [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.

Everyone has heard of Neapolitan tailors and London’s Savile Row, but few are in the know about Vienna’s rigorous suit makers. Knize, a haberdasher that has been in business since 1858, greatly influenced Helmut Lang’s streamlined silhouettes; when Lang was a professor at the University of Applied Arts Vienna, he would take his students there to acquaint them with the art of tailoring. Lang eventually hired Bernhard Niedersuesz, the owner’s son, to work with him in New York. Now Niedersuesz has opened his own Viennese atelier: his signature, a narrow three-button suit with double vents, soft shoulders and a high waistline, has found a strong fan base in Eastern Europe. It makes sense, then, that Niedersuesz is planning to open a shop in Moscow. That doesn’t mean he has no interest in America: a New York outpost is also in the works, and he says his dream assignment would be to make a loden suit for Arnold Schwarzenegger. So much for that famed narrow silhouette. Go to www.niedersuesz.com. [?][?][?]MARKUS EBNER.

The French designer Romain Kremer (center) knows how to create a fashion moment. At his debut three years ago at the Hyères International Fashion and Photography Festival, one judge, the retailer Maria Luisa Poumaillou, invented a prize on the spot so that Kremer’s work, including a printed anorak of André Leon Talleyish proportions, wouldn’t go unheralded. Though Kremer’s suits, knits and outerwear have grown up since then, he doesn’t shy away from challenging pieces: for fall, he offers extravagant outfits in retina-searing hues. He finds constant inspiration from Tecktonik dance — picture amped-up voguing with a dash of pop-lock — as performed by white working-class youths from Parisian suburbs. “The first time I saw these kids dancing in eyeliner and fluoro, I had a shock like I’ve never had before,” says the 26-year-old Kremer, who had a group of boys perform at his fashion show after-party. “The only shame is that at least for now, they can’t afford my line.” At Seven New York. [?][?][?]ALEXANDRA MARSHALL.

Something may finally be coming between Calvin and his monopoly on underwear. Acne (below) is introducing a line of briefs, undershirts, boxers and pajamas; Kris Van Assche has tapped Sunspel, the manufacturer of British skivvies, to create a tank top and briefs set that has a twisted shoulder strap. Meanwhile, aussieBum has introduced tighty whities dipped in stress-busting elixirs of either ginseng or vitamin C; after 15 washes, the briefs must be resoaked in the special solution, also sold by aussieBum. 2(x)ist’s Liquid Cotton line is made of a superfine stretch fiber that ostensibly offers four times as much support as spandex. And the Japanese firm Wacoal claims that its Cross Walker underwear develops the abs: the cross-design on the thigh area allegedly forces the wearer to take wider steps, which in turn tweaks flabby stomachs. Sadly for Hanes-wearing couch potatoes, no American on-sale date has been announced. [?][?][?]MARK ELLWOOD.

Sometimes a white shirt is just a white shirt. Just ask the French author and philosopher Bernard-Henri Lévy, who has no interest in discussing the suavely unbuttoned garment that for his fans and detractors alike has become synonymous with his name. According to Lévy, colloquially known as B.H.L., he wears his signature chemises open to his tanned, flat abdomen for functional reasons only. “I’m constitutionally incapable of wearing a tie,” he says with a shrug. “They strangle me.” Beyond that, “my clothing has no importance whatsoever.” Or rather it is beside the point, since he cares not about fashion but about “trying to draw the world’s attention to wars and sufferings and problems that people might otherwise ignore.” “So that when an article begins with ‘his white shirt unbuttoned down to his navel,’ ” Lévy concludes, his you-know-what unbuttoned down to you-know-where, “I think, What a pity the journalist didn’t read ‘Le Lys et la Cendre’!”.

Mention the word “poster,” and most of us drift back to our teens, to our adolescent bedrooms, where the walls were papered with images that reflected our obsessions just as eloquently as our favorite music and the clothes strewn on the floor.
Picture This.

There’s little doubt that Jérôme Coste’s calling is protective headgear. Fascinated by two-wheel racers since childhood, he has survived six different accidents involving trauma to the head and worked with the famed motocross equipment brand JT Racing. His Ruby motorcycle helmets, made of ultralight carbon fiber, are celebrated for their glossy candy colors; inspired by Steve McQueen and Japanese motorcycle gangs, Coste’s first helmet, the Pavillon (right), which was edged in chrome and lined with red nappa lambskin, was snapped up by the Parisian store Colette. Coste has also produced matching silk scarfs and is about to introduce a limited-edition helmet in partnership with the English design team Eley Kishimoto. Guaranteed to get your engine going. Go to ateliersruby.com. [?][?][?]REBECCA VOIGHT.
Almost 60 years after their introduction, creeper shoes are back in style, thanks to designers like Raf Simons and Stefano Pilati.
Soon, all riders on the Staten Island Railway will have to pay $2 to get both on and off trains.
An investment in the fast-disappearing art of shoemaking.

Tim Barber, the photographer, curator and publisher who started the online gallery Tinyvices, has assembled a five-volume set of eclectic monographs (Aperture) from rising art stars like Jason Nocito, Robin Schwartz and Kenneth Cappello (below). The site’s success has shown how the Web can be essential for a young artist’s career. Yet Barber, who has also created an on-demand publishing house called TV Books, happily concedes that the printed page is not quite dead. “There is something fundamental about a book,” he says. “It’s permanent; it lasts; it exists.” For now, at least. [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD.

amekaji / (a/m^ e ka/^ je\) / adj. / Short for “amerikan kajiaru,” a Japlish contraction of “American casual” that was popular in the 1980s among Tokyo preppies, as in, “Before he was a salaryman, he was a pill-popping, Polo-wearing amekaji club kid”; a modifier that’s ripe for rehabilitation now that influential Japanese designers like Takahiro Miyashita are mining the America of the imagination, e.g., “There were so many Northwest amekaji looks on the Number (N)ine runway, it looked like a Japanese remake of ‘Kurt & Courtney.’ ”.

Deviled eggs are the latest suburban staple to find new life with chefs who mine their childhoods for their menus. They may never become a headliner like mac and cheese, but they are perfect in their supporting role of bar snack. As anybody who has been to the Spotted Pig, Smith’s or the Pegu Club knows, an egg or three is the perfect foil for a Manhattan or a Brooklyn Pennant Ale.
THE WONDER YEARS.

Aviator, architect, race car driver, wizard, ski instructor, fabulist, photographer and erotomaniac, Carlo Mollino designed furniture, cars, buildings and dresses. He could sometimes be abrasive, blasphemous and disturbed, even according to his friends. The only category he belongs to is the uncategorizable, although La Repubblica was surely right to call his style “troppo sexy.”.
The recently opened Harley-Davidson Museum, near downtown Milwaukee, is a 130,00-square-foot steel-and-glass shrine to the iconic bikemaker.

Kim Jones, Dunhill’s newly appointed creative director, will show his debut collection this January; in the meantime, fans of the label can head to Bourdon House, the Georgian mansion in the Mayfair section of London that was the home of the second Duke of Westminster. It now houses Dunhill’s members-only club, which includes a restaurant with a resident sommelier, a bar and four luxury bedrooms. For the general public, there is a screening room, a spa and a store with a barbershop, bespoke leather service and collectible vintage luggage. The idea is to pay tribute to the world of Alfred Dunhill, who created refined and cutting-edge accessories, like the first lighter that could be used with one hand. [?][?][?]REBECCA VOIGHT.

The dry world of cerebral magazines just got a little stickier with the release of Tar, a biannual title from the nascent New York publishing, film and advertising collective of the same name. Not surprising for an enterprise whose name is an anagram of “art,” Tar is heavy on visual culture, with contributions from Ed Ruscha, Juergen Teller, Ryan McGinley and Julian Schnabel, who photographed and interviewed Benicio Del Toro for the cover. Which is not to say the text is shortchanged. Matthew Barney and David Cronenberg rhapsodize about their new operas (Barney’s is based on Norman Mailer’s “Ancient Evenings”; Cronenberg’s is an adaptation of his 1986 film, “The Fly”); Dave Hickey, the art critic and author of “Air Guitar: Essays on Art and Democracy,” riffs on his former drug-fueled sexcapades; and in a heated exchange between the writer Naomi Wolf and the performance artist Coco Fusco that could get them both tarred and feathered on the Hill, Condoleezza Rice is branded a “global sex criminal.” Smoking! [?][?][?]HORACIO SILVA.
Sean Avery: hockey star, former Vogue intern.

Rad PadYou know you’re really rock ’n’ roll when your bed is dressed in more denim than you are. Diesel’s newest venture is, ahem, a home décor line featuring duvets with lightning bolts and techno graphics, studded hand towels and throw pillows made from actual Diesel jeans — ironic machine-made holes and all. “The trompe l’oeil, stud-printed sheets are already in my bedroom,” affirms Diesel’s president and founder, Renzo Rosso, who teamed up with the Italian textile manufacturer Gruppo Zucchi to produce the designs. (They are available in Europe and will make their way to the States next spring.) Rosso is also trying his hand at making actual furniture in the near future; that may explain some of the collection’s more unexpected offerings, like the Chesterfaux sofa cover (above) with photo-realistic tufting. [?][?][?]MONICA KHEMSUROV.

If you were to draw a Venn diagram charting the intersection of accessories designers and Ultimate Fighting Championship fans, there might well be a single name in the overlap: Reed Krakoff, the president and creative director of Coach. Krakoff’s photographic portraits of 34 mixed martial arts stars are collected in “Fighter: The Fighters of the UFC,” which will be published in October by Viking Studio. The photos reveal the requisite icy stares, chiseled physiques and menacing tattoos of men who step into a ring with minimal rules (no biting, eye gouging or fish hooking), but more gripping are the moments of goofiness and vulnerability that Krakoff captures. Each fighter also offers a few words of wisdom, ranging from the slightly alarming (“When I’m training I’m just having fun, thinking about punching somebody in the face”) to the unexpectedly eloquent (“Right before I enter the Octagon, I feel almost like I did a bunch of practice paintings and now I have this empty canvas and I can create this picture in front of everyone and make it beautiful”). Monet be damned. [?][?][?]ETHAN HAUSER.
1. Trophy Bar.
Where seldom is seen a casual jean.

The thrust of the throat was the last thing I expected to see on a men’s runway. The male torso may have been a focus of attention since Adonis and the Olympics, when Greeks, rather than geeks, ruled the world. But those bodies were about rippling muscles, heaving pectorals and sporty might. At Prada’s spring 2009 show, I was apparently viewing sweet and gentle exposure, with blouson jackets hanging from lean straps on bared shoulders and scoop-neck sweaters that fixed my eyes on the Adam’s apple. Then I looked down at the feet. Normal shoes — except for a fetish strap across the instep. By the time the shows closed, I’d seen more clavicles and weirdo shoes (toe spats at Vuitton, winged flaps at Raf Simons) and fewer ties than in living memory. Finally it dawned on me: I’d witnessed the search for a new male erogenous zone.

The disappointments among scents marketed to men are greater than the number of atoms in the universe. Masculines — the industry term — are generally defined by the vast creativity, beauty, elegance and innovation that have not been put into them. Those qualities are usually reserved for feminines, though men who know scent just wear what’s great and ignore the gender distinctions. Marketers be damned.

The Brooklyn-based designer Kiel Mead is something of a whiz kid. Before his graduation from the Pratt Institute two years ago, the Cooper-Hewitt museum shop had already picked up his clever Forget-Me-Not ring, modeled on a piece of tied string. Unsurprisingly for such a young upstart, Mead’s work often refers to youthful rites of passage: he has made rings out of old bent car keys and hung castings of chewed gum and his brother’s retainer from silver chains. His new collection — sold at John Bartlett — features money clips based on sailors’ knots and belt buckles with large fishhooks.

Who would ever imagine that an Italian fast-food joint could spawn a subculture that would alter the fortunes of a fashion label? In the early 1980s, affluent teenagers from well-to-do Milanese families — Milano bene — used to hang out at a small snack bar called Il Panino, listening to New Wave music. When Burghy, the Italian equivalent of McDonald’s, opened on the nearby Piazza San Babila, the kids rode over in their Vespas and made that bigger joint their official hangout. In a matter of months, the “paninari” (the term is literally derived from panino, the Italian word for sandwich) were known all over Italy.

1. Armand Hadidahas more than lived up to the name of his cult Paris and Tokyo stores, L’Eclaireur. (“It means ‘pathfinder,’ ” he says.) Over the past 28 years, he’s helped introduce shoppers to Prada, John Galliano, Helmut Lang, Ann Demeulemeester and Vivienne Westwood. And L’Eclaireur is still the only game in town if you’re looking for under-the-radar talents like Carol Christian Poell, Gianni Guaglianone and Paul Harnden. “I’ve always liked to focus on designers with strong personalities and even stronger attitudes,” he says. Go to leclaireur.com for information.

It was one thing when the cellphone replaced the cigarette. But now killer apps have replaced killer abs, and the chicest parties throng with guys showing how they can make their iPhones look like Magic 8 Balls. It’s enough to make a man long for the days when all you heard from even the costliest accessory was the faint tick of a sleek watch.

Gone are the days when important collectors were content to merely donate their treasures to public museums. In today’s art market, German heavyweights are leaving their art to their own eponymous institutions. In Düsseldorf, the Julia Stoschek Collection, which shows mostly video art, opened in June 2007; the fashionable Sammlung Boros, with its Reyles and Eliassons, followed last April in Berlin; and, most recently, the Sammlung Falckenberg (above), the largest and most impressive of the three, had its debut in Hamburg. The 67,000-square-foot space, which used to be a rubber factory, has become a multilevel playing field for its contemporary-art-obsessed founder, Harald Falckenberg. “If I really wanted to find out what made me do this, I would probably have to see a psychiatrist,” says the 64-year-old businessman. Falckenberg, who was one of Jonathan Meese’s earliest patrons, loves to take visitors on detailed tours of the premises, and he’s confident enough to admit that his Sammlung is a bit of a vanity project: “Of course there is an element of that to it — the more one were to deny it, the truer it would be.’ [?][?][?]FELIX BURRICHTER.

ORNSTEIN--Barbara Holly, 80, an editor and longtime Connecticut resident, died at Rosenthal Hospice Residences on Saturday, August 16, 2008, following a three-month struggle with leukemia. Born November 11, 1927 in New York City to the late Charles George Muller and Georgia Lydia Stanbrough, she grew up and lived most of her life in Greenwich, CT. She began her publishing career at Time, Inc. From 1952 to 1961 Barbara worked at National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in New York as a producer in news and public affairs and as an assistant to legendary Frank McGee. In 1962 she married the late Peter Ornstein. They moved to Greenwich into a 200-year-old farmhouse. In 1975 she became the editor-in-chief of the Friends of Greenwich Library Oral History Project, a job she held until 2003. She also chaired the Greenwich Fresh Air Fund and was a board member for the Greenwich Library. Barbara was a devoted genealogist as befits a 10th generation decedent of Mayflower settlers. She was related to George Washington and Alexander Hamilton. She was an avid sailor and an enthusiastic gardener, who could name virtually every flower she came upon in both English and Latin. She attended Swarthmore College, where she graduated in 1949 with a major in Latin and minors in Greek and Fine Arts. She later told her children, ''I studied all of this so that I could be sure to teach you to speak English properly.'' Surviving are her daughter, Holly Ornstein Carter and her husband, Robert of New York City; her son, David Stanbrough Ornstein and his wife, Alexandra of Greenwich; and five grandchildren. She is also survived by her half-sister, Jenny Muller Coons of Sedona, AZ. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 13 at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich at 1pm. Barbara's family is asking that donations in her honor and memory be made in her name to Swarthmore College or to the Greenwich Library.

ELETTRA WIEDEMANN, model, activist, student of biomedicine research, daughter of Isabella Rossellini. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW The pants are No. 6, from their fall collection. I'm trying to get into new silhouettes -- slouchier, not so tight. I love a cute-cut jean, but I started to feel like I was wearing the same thing every day. The shoes are Christian Louboutin, the belt is vintage -- it's a lion, I'm a Leo -- and the T-shirt is for a charity I started with friends called jofd.org. We're raising half a million dollars to build a solar electric hospital in Burundi, which is a tiny country next door to Rwanda.

DIVERSITY rules this season in the outstanding array of exhibitions at art museums in the suburbs of New York City. After a couple of years in which contemporary art has dominated, modern and historical art are now receiving equal billing, with several shows of old master prints and paintings. There are also half a dozen decorative arts, fashion, folk art and architecture shows in the eclectic mix this fall. Several exhibitions are touring, an indicator that the role of regional museums in a national museum network has expanded. There is a touring show of modern photographs at the Parrish Art Museum, on Long Island, for example, while the Princeton University Art Museum will be the first stop for a national show of the early work of Jasper Johns.

APPLING --William T. Renowned conductor, pianist, and educator William Appling passed away on Friday, August 29, 2008. He was 75 and lived in Poughkeepsie, NY. In 1979, Mr. Appling founded William Appling Singers & Orchestra (WASO) in Cleveland, Ohio, a professional ensemble dedicated to performing music of all periods, and particularly the works of American composers. WASO released four critically acclaimed recordings on the New World and Albany record labels and premiered numerous contemporary works. While in Ohio, WASO presented many concerts and performed at venues including Severance Hall and the Blossom Music Center. Relocating to Poughkeepsie in 1989 when Mr. Appling was appointed Director of Choral Activities at Vassar College, WASO presented concerts at Lincoln Center, Bard College and many other venues, both as its own entity and under the auspices of the Bard Music Festival and American Symphony Orchestra. In 1996, WASO was one of the only professional musical organizations in the United States to present concerts celebrating the 250th anniversary of the birth of American composer William Billings. Early in his career as educator in the Cleveland area, Mr. Appling was Choral Director for Glenville High School where under his direction the choir received widespread acclaim and was invited to sing at the the Ohio Music Education Association in Columbus, Ohio, and the New York World's Fair. The choir also sang a sold-out recital in Severance Hall in 1965. At Case Institute of Technology, he conducted the Men's Glee Club, which toured Europe and gave concerts in Germany, Switzerland, France and Luxembourg. While in Ohio, he was also Music Director of the West Shore Chorale and the Cleveland Philharmonic Chorus. He served on the faculty for 25 years at Western Reserve Academy in Hudson, Ohio, and was Director of Music there for many years. While at WRA, Mr. Appling founded and directed Summer Music Experience, an international six-week program offering intensive music training and performance experience to gifted students of high school age. The music camp/festival involved members of the Cleveland Orchestra and included visiting artists and master classes with Robert Shaw, Andre Watts, Janos Starker, Lynn Harrell and Lorin Maazel. William Appling received numerous honors during his career, including the first Kulas Foundation Fellowship Award for Choral Conducting with the Cleveland Orchestra, during which time he assisted George Szell and Robert Shaw. He also enjoyed an active career as a pianist, appearing in solo recital at Town Hall, New York City, concerto performances with the Cleveland Orchestra, at the Aspen Festival under Darius Milhaud, and in duo recital with tenor Seth McCoy. Mr. Appling most recently recorded the complete piano works of Scott Joplin. A celebration of William Appling's life will take place in 2009. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Henry Street Settlement, 265 Henry St., New York, NY 10002. Further information is available at WASO's web site: www.muzen.com/waso.html.

FRIEDMAN--Ross Mandel, 55, a former staff attorney for the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, died Sunday, August 31st at The Village of Laurel Lakes Assisted Living Center in Lee, MA, after suffering from Huntington's Disease for more than 20 years. Friedman, a life-long environmentalist, spent a majority of his legal career involved with complex acid rain litigation in order to protect the Catskill Watershed area of New York City. He played a significant role in the construction of Manhattan's North River waste water treatment plant. This public works project integrates 28-acre Riverbank State Park atop one of the world's largest sewage treatment facilities. Born February 21, 1953 in Oakland, California, Friedman was the son of the late Julian Richard Friedman, a University of California at Berkeley political science professor, and the late Marian Nieder Friedman, a social worker and civil rights activist. He attended elementary school in Berkeley before living in Kenya, East Africa where he attended Greenland School for a year, and then moving permanently to Syracuse, New York. He was an honors graduate of Syracuse's Nottingham High School, where he served as school vice president, and a graduate of University of Wisconsin at Madison, where he studied economics. He received his doctorate of law from Syracuse University School of Law. Friedman was deeply committed to environmental issues. While studying law, he served as a summer intern at the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation in Albany. Following law school, he was a fulltime volunteer for the Environmental Defense League and Sierra Club, and served as a field coordinator for Presidential Candidate Mo Udall, the former Arizona Congressman who was a strong environmental advocate. A lifelong sports enthusiast, he was a highly ranked junior tennis player in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, captain of the perennial state powerhouse Nottingham High School Tennis Team and played on the Division One varsity tennis team at the University of Wisconsin. In his mid-20s, he became an avid marathon runner and finished several New York City Marathons in less than 3 hours. He was a serious skier, who frequented North America's most challenging ski mountains such as Whistler Mountain in British Columbia, Taos in New Mexico and Jackson Hole in Wyoming. While stricken with Huntington's Disease, a progressive neurological illness, Friedman became an accomplished therapeutic horseback rider. He is survived by his uncle, Bailey Nieder of Seattle, WA; his brothers, Clark Arnold Friedman of Needham, MA, and Thomas Harold Friedman, Newton, MA; and two nieces and a nephew. Memorial services will be announced by the family. Donations should be sent to Blue Rider Stable, P.O. Box 924, Great Barrington, MA 01230.

Kat Dennings has an odd, arresting beauty: sleepy blue-green eyes, por-celain-pale oval face -- and lips so red and juicy they look like the prototype for the wax ones little girls used to wear at Halloween. Along with the slight space between her perfect teeth, the effect is sexy and slightly comic. Enjoying her first leading role, Ms. Dennings makes the most of it in ''Nick & Norah's Infinite Playlist'' (Oct. 3). ''Nick & Norah'' is a romantic comedy about two smart, oddball high school seniors with a shared taste for arcane pop who fall for each other while tangling with their awful exes and chasing a mysterious band called Fluffy over a long New York night. The director, Peter Sollett, made the Lower East Side charmer ''Raising Victor Vargas'' and knows something about screen chemistry. Who better than the nerd du jour Michael Cera to play the anti-Bogey to Ms. Dennings's neo-Bacall?

If No. 15 Brigham Young is vying for a spot in the Bowl Championship Series at season's end, the Cougars can thank an exuberant Jake Locker. Locker, Washington's quarterback, scored with two seconds remaining Saturday to trim B.Y.U.'s lead to 28-27. Locker threw the ball in the air and hugged a teammate. The toss was deemed excessive, and the Huskies were penalized 15 yards. The longer extra-point attempt was blocked. If B.Y.U. can beat No. 23 U.C.L.A. next week, it will have wins over two Pac-10 teams, providing legitimacy to its B.C.S. argument. And that will have the Cougars celebrating. 9 P.M. (HBO) TRUE BLOOD ''You know how many people are having sex with vampires these days?'' This new genre-bending series from Alan Ball (''Six Feet Under'') imagines a world in which the advent of synthetic human blood has allowed vampires to get their fix without breaking laws (or skin). Sadly, there's still some stigma associated with the bloodsuckers -- after all, they hang out at a biker bar called Fangtasia -- but that doesn't stop Sookie Stackhouse (Anna Paquin), a mind-reading waitress, from falling for the incisive Bill Compton (Stephen Moyer, above with Ms. Paquin), who looks good for 173. 10 A.M. Months after the announcement of curved TVs comes the DVD release of the Cinerama spectacle ''How the West Was Won'' (Tuesday). Can in-home Sensurround be far behind? Sept. 16 brings a bushel of special editions, including ''An American in Paris'' and ''Beetlejuice,'' as well as the second volume of Warner Brothers' ''Busby Berkeley Collection.'' In addition Criterion fills a hole in DVD libraries with three films by the peerless Max Ophüls: ''La Ronde,'' ''Le Plaisir'' and his masterpiece, ''The Earrings of Madame de ... '' Also the young Diane Lane stars with members of the Clash in ''Ladies and Gentlemen, the Fabulous Stains,'' one of the few films to get the punk scene right. Criterion will release the Finnish filmmaker Aki Kaurismaki's ''Proletariat Trilogy'' (Sept. 23). That same day the ''Godfather'' trilogy arrives with a frame-by-frame restoration supervised by the director, Francis Ford Coppola. There is the Italian horrormeister Dario Argento's delirious ''Mother of Tears,'' which begins with strangulation by intestine and gets nuttier. The most beguiling of this year's superhero movies, ''Iron Man,'' makes it to DVD on Sept. 30, the same day that ''Daughters of Darkness,'' a cult favorite, lesbian-vampire division, arrives.

EICHEL--Simon, Holocaust survivor and author of The Family Whistle: A Holocaust Memoir of Loss and Survival passed away peacefully August 26th, 2008 at the age of 84. In his book he left a charge to his survivors ''Value your family. Never lose hope''. He grew up in Poland and immigrated to the United States in 1949. Starting as a stock clerk in a retail company, he lived the American dream and retired as vice president of the same company. He is survived by Mary his beloved wife of sixty years, his daughters Margaret Liu and Evelyn Rogers, their husbands Dr. David Liu and Charles Rogers and his grandchildren: Jessica Rogers, Erica Liu, Nicole Rogers and Sara Liu. Donations can be made in his memory to NYU Faculty and Friends Campaign, 1 Park Avenue, 10th Floor, New York, NY 10015 in memory of Simon Eichel, in honor of Dr. Joseph Weisstuch.

WRIGGINS--W. Howard, former U.S. Ambassador to Sri Lanka, and Director of the Southern Asian Institute at Columbia University died in Hanover, New Hampshire on August 30 at age 90. He is survived by his wife Sally Hovey Wriggins, of Hanover, three children, Diana Cundy of Paris, Maine, Chris Wriggins of Yarmouth, Maine, and Jennifer B. Wriggins of Portland, Maine, and six grandchildren.

CURRAN--Paul J. It is with deep sorrow that Kaye Scholer LLP mourns the passing of our friend and esteemed colleague, Paul J. Curran. Paul was a giant at the firm and in the legal community and was recognized as one of the leading trial lawyers in the country. Paul's contributions to the firm have spanned nearly a half century. He joined the firm in 1961 and became a partner in 1969. Aside from the years when he served as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York (1973-1975), Paul remained a partner at the firm until 1996, when he became a Special Counsel to the firm. Paul headed the firm's Litigation Department for more than a decade and served as a member of the firm's Executive Committee. In addition to serving as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Paul also held a number of important governmental positions throughout his career, including his appointment as Special Counsel, United States Department of Justice to investigate President Jimmy Carter (1979); Special Consultant to the Secretary of Defense on Intelligence Matters (1976); and Chairman (1969-1973) of the New York State Commission of Investigation. Paul was New York City's Legislative Representative to Albany (1967) and served three terms as a Member of the New York State Assembly, representing the Lower East Side of Manhattan district (1963-1966). Paul held numerous pro bono positions, including, most recently, serving as a member of the Judicial Election Qualification Commission (2007). From 1956-1958, Paul served as First Lieutenant, United States Air Force. He gave generously of his time and expertise, serving as the Chair and/or President of many professional and charitable organizations at the national, state and local levels, including Director and Past President, Fordham Law Alumni Association; Past President of the University Club; and the Cardinal's Committee for Charity. He received his LL.B. from Fordham University Law School and his A.B. from Georgetown University. We extend our deepest condolences to Paul's wife Barbara, their seven children and 22 grandchildren, and the rest of their wonderful family. Visitation will be on Monday, September 8, from 2:00-7:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel (Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Manhattan). A funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, September 9, at 10:30am at St. Patrick's Cathedral (Fifth Avenue at 50th Street, Manhattan). CURRAN--Paul J. Fordham Law School records with profound sorrow the passing of Paul J. Curran '56, a devoted graduate, a gifted lawyer, the former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and a past president of the Fordham Law Alumni Association. A dedicated public servant, in 1979 Mr. Curran served by appointment of the Attorney General as Special Counsel to the United States Department of Justice to conduct an investigation of President Jimmy Carter. William M. Treanor, Dean CURRAN--Paul J. The Justices of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department mark with sadness the passing of a distinguished public servant and friend of the Court who, as member and past Chairman of the Departmental Disciplinary Committee, served the New York legal community with unflagging commitment and dedication for many years. Jonathan Lippman Presiding Justice CURRAN--Paul J., February 21st, 1933 to September 4th, 2008. Beloved husband of Barbara Ann (nee Frank). Loving father of Mark I., Mary Louise Kingsbery (Clay), Catherine Souther (Thomas), Barbara Susanin (Timothy), Thomas J., II (Deirdre), Paul J., Jr. (Wendy) and Elizabeth Stockton (Richard, Jr.). Cherished grandfather of Ann, Lucy, James, Paul, Ted, Caroline, William, Caitlin, Christopher, Margaret, Jack, Annabel, Barbara Ann, Thomas III, Lucie, Matthew, Claire, Paul III, Catherine, Curran, Richard III and Libby. Devoted son of the late Thomas J. and Margaret Farley Curran. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Monday, September 8th, 2-7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, September 9th, 10:30 am at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Paul J. Curran Fund, 645 5th Avenue, Suite 703, NY, NY 10022, which provides assistance to schools servicing New York City's less advantaged children.

An interactive map with audio and photos of Iowa farms is the latest installment of ''Going Down the Road,'' a series on communities once documented in the 1930s by writers for the Works Progress Administration. Farming, a staple in Iowa then and now, has changed markedly since those writers drove through. In many cases, what was once an ordinary farm is today far bigger and more specialized. Left, Brice and Melanie Hundling of Breda, Iowa, bring a bale of dried cornstalks to the hog barn. nytimes.com/wpa

ZENKO--Russell Scott. Scottie 36 year old son of John and Jere Scott Zenko, brother of Starrett and Sallyan Zenko and godfather to Brooks Pearce, passed away on August 22, 2008 while climbing his favorite mountain in Alta, Utah. Scottie attended The Hotchkiss School and was a graduate of Hobart College where he was a member of the Kappa Alpha Society, and past President of the Hobart chapter. Additionally he was a member of the Kappa Alpha Executive Council. Professionally, Scottie was an independent auction consultant. He was an avid golfer and expert skier who raced for the Pink Taco Team in Alta, Utah. He was a member of the Onwentsia Club in Lake Forest, IL and a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club in New York, NY. We plan to go to Argentina for three weeks in October and visit only the north part of the country, and maybe spend some days in Bolivia and Chile. Any advice on cities to visit and transportation? Dangte Nguyen, Montreal My advice comes via Ian Mount, who has written for the Travel section about South America, including ''36 Hours in Buenos Aires'' (Feb. 4, 2007). ''My favorite part of Argentina is the northwest corridor, from Mendoza at the southern end up north through the town of Salta and Jujuy province (on the Bolivia border),'' he wrote in an e-mail message from Buenos Aires. Mendoza, which Ann Marie Gardner wrote about in ''Napa Valley Meets the Wild West'' (Dec. 10, 2006), is the wine capital, has a ''burgeoning gourmet food scene'' and offers ''outdoor options like rafting, horseback riding and hiking,'' he said.

DUNN--Mary Palmer. With great sadness, the teachers, Board of Directors, staff and members of the Iyengar Yoga Association of Greater New York mourn the passing of our beloved founder and Senior Teacher, Mary Dunn. Mary began her study of yoga with B.K.S. Iyengar in 1974, and became one of the most significant teachers of Iyengar Yoga in the United States, building a devoted following. Her intelligent study and infectious humor created demand for her teaching throughout the world. She reached out to all students, sharing her love and knowledge of the art of yoga with clarity, dynamism and generosity. She helped establish vibrant centers for the study of Iyengar yoga in San Francisco, Southern California and New York, touched the lives of thousands of students, and trained countless teachers. Mary faced her cancer diagnosis with wisdom and courage, and continued to teach and inspire others, communicating with her students and friends about her illness and how it informed her magnificent life. We are profoundly grateful for Mary's passion and gift for teaching, and extend our deepest sympathies to her daughters Elizabeth and Louise and their families. A celebration of Mary's life is planned for early 2009 in New York. For details, contact the IYAGNY at: www.iyengarnyc.org

Some people know how to live very well. David Tanis certainly does -- though it has to be said that he has had the consummate mentor and friend in the improvisational journey of life: Alice Waters. In 2001, when Tanis was in about his 20th year cooking at Waters's legendary Berkeley restaurant, Chez Panisse, he was vacationing in Paris when a friend told him about a lovely 17th-century apartment for rent in the Fifth Arrondissement. He wasn't really in the market, but he was already in love with Paris and fell instantly in love with the apartment too. Tanis loved it so much, in fact, that he decided to make his home there. As he explained, ''Every time I go traveling, I think, Oh, I think I'll move here. And sometimes I do.'' Deciding to live in Paris was easy; the hard part was telling Waters that he wouldn't be returning to Chez Panisse, as he did in the '90s, when he opened a restaurant in Santa Fe. Waters later surprised him with a plan. Before he left for Paris, Tanis was sharing head-chef duties with Jean-Pierre Moullé, dividing the workweek. Moulle missed his summer house in Bordeaux. Tanis wanted to move to Paris. Instead of splitting the week, Waters suggested that they split the year. Everyone was happy.

''It would instill a huge amount of confidence.'' John E. Lekas, chief executive of Leader Capital, an investment firm, on a notion that has been quietly floating around: to merge Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

SEMINAL rock star that she is, Kim Gordon still has some rather common clothing issues. Like finding chic everyday pieces that work as well in New York as they do at her home in Northampton, Mass. ''There's a need for clothes for cool moms,'' Ms. Gordon said. To fill the gap, she has started a clothing line called Mirror/Dash with her friends Melinda Wansbrough and Jeffrey Monteiro. The name is taken from her experimental music project with her husband and Sonic Youth bandmate, Thurston Moore. Their first piece: a military-style wool jacket inspired by Françoise Hardy. ''I know, every designer says they're inspired by Françoise Hardy,'' Ms. Gordon said. ''But I've been listening to her records for 15 years.'' Additional designs will be offered throughout the year. For now, just 50 of the jackets will be sold. ''Some people make limited-edition records -- we're making a limited-edition jacket,'' she joked.

New York Fashion Week opened this weekend on the runways in the tents in Bryant Park and at other locations around Manhattan. But there is another runway -- the streets of the city, which many people use as a personal red carpet. This 24-hour display of style makes the city a center of fashion. Often, the street parade is more original and exuberant than anything in the tents. For an informed opinion about style, you must first see the designer shows, live or on television. Second, see what buyers have bought for the stores. And third, what people actually choose and how they wear it. The public becomes the arbiter of fashion, not the designers.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Negotiations With Allianz on Naming of Stadium'' Sept. 1: My family and I recently visited Auschwitz-Birkenau, the Nazi extermination camps. We were surprised to see pools of water inside Birkenau. Our guide told us that because most of the prison barracks were made of wood, the Nazis' insurance company required an on-site firewater supply. The name of that insurance company? Allianz, the same Allianz to whom the Giants and Jets want to sell naming rights to their new stadium.

IT started last fall at Lanvin: exposed zippers, running down the back of silk blouses and the front of fitted dresses, cutting a sleek, sexy line through very chic clothing. This season, with the shift toward a harder brand of elegance, they seem to be everywhere: slinking around Balmain's skinny rocker dresses, zigzagging across a sculptured Yves Saint Laurent skirt. Rick Owens used them as liberally as leather. ''They just add an element of intrigue,'' said the Sophomore designer Chrissie Miller, who ran an exposed zipper down the front of a high-waisted miniskirt. ''Mostly because they undo so quickly.'' Sophomore cotton jersey skirt, $104 at Opening Ceremony; sophomorenyc.com.

FOOD WHERE IT'S NEEDED When David P. Kirchhoff, chief executive of Weight Watchers International, was making some of his rounds of local operations late last year, he was impressed with something one of his group leaders in Seattle was doing to motivate customers to lose weight. The leader ''was asking people to put aside one pound of food for every pound of weight they lost,'' Mr. Kirchhoff said in a recent phone conversation. ''Then she asked them to bring in the food to build a shrine, and they donated all the food -- 2,000 pounds -- to local food banks.''

The Boeing Company, whose order books are bulging with demand for its planes, was hit by its second major strike in three years early Saturday, when the union that represents 27,000 machinists in Washington State, Oregon and Kansas walked off the job. The union, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, said its members struck at 3:01 a.m. Eastern time after last-minute talks failed to bring an accord. No new talks were scheduled.

FERGIE'S SHADE The singer known as Fergie, a spokeswoman for the AIDS-related fund-raising efforts of MAC Cosmetics, said she actually studied with the company when she was younger. ''When I was about 19 years old and I was in a group called Wild Orchid, we didn't have makeup artists or anything and we didn't know really how to do stage makeup,'' Fergie, now 33, said during a visit to New York last week. ''So we went and took these MAC makeup classes, and the record company paid for it so that we could do our own makeup on tour. So that's how I learned to do makeup.''

FROM a soft-focus silhouette of a woman behind a shower door to an eye-popping close-up of a finger awash in acid-orange powder, Michael Thompson's photos, which have appeared in French Vogue, Vanity Fair and often on the cover of W, are, as he put it, ''all over the place'' in terms of light and subject matter. Yet they are consistently striking. ''I like things very strong and graphic,'' said Mr. Thompson, whose first solo show in the United States opened earlier this week. ''And the simpler, the better.'' It's an aesthetic learned from his mentor Irving Penn, whom he assisted in the late '80s. ''Mr. Penn's eye for simplicity and impact is unmatched,'' he said. Indeed, Mr. Thompson's comes close.

BEFORE she was the Republican nominee for No. 2, Sarah Palin wondered aloud in a television interview: ''What is it exactly that the V.P. does every day?'' If fate intervenes, plenty. Of the last 19 presidential administrations, about half have had occasions when the vice president was forced to assume presidential responsibilities (or perhaps should have, in the case of President Woodrow Wilson). Four of those vice presidents took over when the president died (as did four others in the 19th century: John Tyler, Millard Fillmore, Andrew Johnson and Chester A. Arthur).

For the French director Jean-Pierre Melville the world consisted of hideouts. There was the hothouse fantasy domain of his film of Cocteau's novel ''Les Enfants Terribles,'' the safe houses used by the Resistance in his masterpiece ''Army of Shadows'' and the shabby apartments and back rooms frequented by the crooks in the genre thrillers that make up most of his filmography. Two of his movies, ''Le Doulos'' (1962), which means ''The Stool Pigeon,'' and ''Le Deuxième Souffle'' (1966), or ''The Second Wind,'' both arriving in fine new transfers from Criterion, are essentially heist-gone-wrong stories. Both are also reminders that Melville, who died at 55 in 1973, was a singular sensibility. A spiritual godfather to the New Wave filmmakers, his carefully calibrated style was markedly different from their caught-on-the-fly approach. But though Melville made crime thrillers, he was also out of step with conventional commercial filmmaking. Tense and involving, his dour, deliberately paced thrillers nonetheless contain little visceral charge. And while the stories are all satisfyingly worked out, he seems much more interested in investigating the ethics of fringe existence.

Nicholas Meyer's 1979 time-travel fantasy has a terrific premise. An English surgeon discovered to be Jack the Ripper (David Warner, glowering scarily) escapes to late-1970s San Francisco in a time machine built by his friend H. G. Wells (Malcolm McDowell, right, with Mary Steenburgen). Wells, the fervent socialist who believes that a future utopia is inevitable, follows and falls in love with a modern woman (Ms. Steenburgen) who embodies all the notions he holds about female emancipation. Mr. Meyer directs the movie, from a story by Karl Alexander and Steve Hayes, in a luxe '40s studio style. The painted backdrops of Big Ben, the sets of London streets with fog machines working overtime to make everything look gloomy and mysterious, all have a quaintness that's very pleasing. (The same can't be said of Miklos Rozsa's score, which nearly steamrolls the film each time the composer stages one of his D-Day landings on your eardrums.)

Dashingly undead young men are popping their coffins in Alan Ball's new HBO series ''True Blood'' and Catherine Hardwicke's November movie, ''Twilight.'' But the most appealing vampire of the new season may well be the girl with the blood-smeared chin in Tomas Alfredson's award-winning film ''Let the Right One In'' (Oct. 24). As played by a 12-year-old tyro named Lina Leandersson, she looks about as predatory as a kid who got into the jam jar again. Set in a wintry Stockholm suburb where even the drunks look slightly marooned, ''Let the Right One In'' revolves around the budding attraction between a slender boy named Oskar, who is savagely bullied at school, and Ms. Leandersson's Eli, his new neighbor in the apartment next door. Eli (pronounced Ellie) has some decidedly supernatural characteristics: She can scoot up the side of a multistory building in no time and appear and disappear with the suddenness of teleportation. She doesn't feel the cold, so when she first turns up outdoors as Oskar works his Rubik's Cube (she wants to work it too), she's coatless and barefoot.

McREYNOLDS--Dr. Kathryn Baker, 52, a prominent writer on youth and educational issues, died on September 5, 2008, after a year-long battle with lung cancer. McReynolds was a regular contributor to the journal, Encounter: Education for Meaning and Social Justice, writing on issues such as free schools, homeschooling, and children's right to a happy childhood. She was named the journal's Associate Editor in 2006. McReynolds was sharply critical of test-driven education and the No Child Left Behind Act, which she saw as cramping children's full development. Dr. McReynolds was born in Kansas City, Missouri, attended high school in Scottsdale, Arizona, and graduated from Columbia University School of General Studies in 1983, Magna cum laude. She also was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received a Ph.D. in clinical psychology from the City University of New York in 2004. While working on her graduate degree, she taught numerous undergraduates courses, and was widely regarded as one of the most inspiring teachers in the department and college, according to the department's former chairperson, Dr. William Crain. From 2005 to 2006, she served as the interim director of The City College Gateway Academy, the college orientation and advisement center for new and continuing students. Dr. McReynolds, is survived by her husband, Pinchas Ben-Or, her children, Lilith Helen Ben-Or and Asher Jacob Ben-Or, her mother, Helen Jarvis McReynolds, her brothers Steven Martin and Andrew Claxon McReynolds, and her sister Billie J. McReynolds. The wake will be held at the Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway (West 214 Street) New York, NY 10034 on Sunday, September 7th, 57pm. The funeral service will be at the Holy Trinity Church, located at 20 Cumming Street off Seaman Avenue, New York, NY 10034, on Monday, September 8th, 7:30pm. Donations, in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Holy Trinity Food Pantry or the Pied Piper Children's Theater.

STEUBER--Charles P. (Chuck). Shipping Pioneer and Founder of the National Croquet Center, Dies...Charles P. (Chuck) Steuber died at home, surrounded by his family, the morning of Wednesday, August 27, 2008. He was 87. Born December 26, 1920 in Milwaukee, WI, he was the son of Charles H. Steuber and Alma Paul Steuber. He was educated at Hartford and Riverside schools in Milwaukee and majored in chemical engineering at the University of Wisconsin where he was also a member of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity. Chuck started his career with Union Carbide and by 1947 was marketing director for Union Carbide's European sales and instrumental in establishing their European headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. In 1949 Chuck married Margaret (Peggy) Morris, also from Milwaukee, and the newlywed couple lived in Geneva until Chuck finished his career with Carbide and returned to New York to start his own company, while Peggy raised their eventual family of three children. In 1951 Chuck founded a company that became a pioneering merchant firm in the transportation, storage and distribution of petrochemicals. At that time, all chemicals were transported around the world in 55 gallon drums. In the 1950s a few companies experimented with modifying existing plain steel petroleum tankers to transport some chemicals in bulk. Then, in 1961, Chuck built the world's first tanker with individual pumps and lines to an array of specialized tanks designed to maintain the high quality specifications of most products in the petrochemical industry. The ship was christened the S/S Alchemist and was the progenitor of all the ships that service the global industry of today. Chuck was also a pioneer in the bulk storage of petrochemicals. He built several facilities around the world, the largest of which was Eurotank in Antwerp, Belgium and became the largest such facility in Continental Europe. The Steuber Group of companies were also involved in the marketing and distribution of chemicals with firms located throughout Europe, the United States, Asia and Australia. After living in Pelham, NY for 27 years, Chuck and Peggy moved to Boca Raton, FL in 1983, but kept a summer home in Rye, NY. By then Chuck had retired, but his venture capitalist and visionary spirit kept him busy with several projects. He funded what has become a very successful internet fulfillment company, Dotcom Distribution, which, in a way, aspires to the pioneering storage and shipping success in the cyber world that Chuck achieved in the chemical industry. He also became very involved in his chosen sport of competitive croquet. At that time any substantial tournament play involved organizing a patchwork of courts at local estates or area Country Clubs and resorts. The croquet world dreamed of having their own dedicated center for the greater enjoyment and promotion of the sport. In 2000-2001 Chuck purchased land, funded and built what became the Charles P. Steuber National Croquet Center. It is comprised of 12 laserleveled courts, a 18,000 square foot club house on 10 acres of land in West Palm Beach and is today the jewel of the croquet community at large. Chuck was also a member of the U.S. Croquet Association Hall of Fame. Chuck is survived by his sisters Marion of Paw Paw, MI and Ruth of Milwaukee, WI; sons Charlie of Lighthouse Point, FL and Victor of Eugene, OR; daughter Midge of Jerome, AZ and two grandchildren; Lucas of Portland, OR and Robyn of Eugene, OR. He was predeceased by his wife of 57 years, Peggy. A private ceremony will be held at the Forest Home Cemetery in Milwaukee, WI. In lieu of flowers, the family requests those so inclined make a donation in Chuck's name to the charity of their choice appreciated.
Film Stephen Holden

Indian villagers in the northeastern state of Bihar ran Saturday to retrieve aid that was dropped by the Indian Air Force. Indian officials said about one million people had been evacuated since the flooding began on Aug. 18, Bloomberg News reported. Rising waters inundated parts of Bihar, one of India's poorest states, after the Kosi River burst a dam in neighboring Nepal.

HILL--Dorothy R., passed away on September 4 after a long illness. Noted medical librarian and co-author of the Brandon/Hill Selected Lists of Books and Journals for the Small Medical Library; Nursing; and Allied Health, her work influenced the development of medical library collections Worldwide. Daughter of the late Arthur T. and Ruth Hill, Dorothy received numerous awards for her work with medical libraries and had a long career building medical library collections at the University of Kentucky, Johns Hopkins, and Mount Sinai School of Medicine where she spent the last 33 years of her career. A gathering in her honor will be held on Friday, September 12 at 11:00am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment will be Saturday, September 13 in Springfield, MA.

MASSEY--Joyce (Jody) Bousley, 82. Raised in Ipswich, MA on a simple homestead with well, bucket and outhouse. High School valedictorian, Smith College class of 1947, Magna Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa. Masters degrees from Columbia and Brooklyn College, Ph.D. candidate in English literature. Deferred academic career to attend to special needs child. Raised family of five in Brooklyn. Beloved, and highly esteemed for her pure soul, sterling character, selflessness, giving nature, and intellect. Mourned by husband David; children Sydney (Chris), Joshua, Joseph, Carla and Jonathan; grandsons Mateo and Jonah; and many nieces and nephews.

Like a particularly subtle sleight-of-hand trick Gillian Armstrong's ''Death Defying Acts'' slipped into -- and out of -- a small number of American theaters this summer, before anyone could see it. Now on DVD, it has a chance at last to find its audience. Catherine Zeta-Jones (below, with Guy Pearce) plays Mary, a luscious con artist in 1920s Scotland who gets by on her charm, her smarts and her sex. But she also relies on the help and companionship of her precocious daughter, Benji (Saoirse Ronan, the striking young actress from ''Atonement''). The two scrape together a living as a performing duo, of which Mary is the star. She uses her ''clairvoyant'' powers to wow audiences, although her spangly, skimpy dancing-girl costume sure doesn't hurt.

PLANTING AN IDEA In the competition among businesses to ''go green,'' it may no longer be enough to use paper that is simply recycled. At the Green Field Paper Company in San Diego, requests for seed-embedded business cards -- which actually sprout if planted -- have more than doubled over the last year, said Shari Smith, who owns the company along with her husband, Rick. Of the Earth, a handmade-paper company in Seattle owned by Kevin and Lori Graham, says it gets several requests a week for its flower-seeded business cards. (If someone gives you one of these cards, just be sure to save the information on it before you plant.) Coming for the holidays: plantable wrapping paper and gift tags. JULIE BICK

MARIANI--Celeste. Sister, aunt, friend to many and world traveler died peacefully on Thursday, September 4, 2008 at her home in New York City at age 81 surrounded by her loving family. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer. Beloved sister of Peter R. Mariani, his wife Rita (Noblesville, IN) and the late Donald J. Mariani, her sister-inlaw Jeanette L. Mariani (Dallas, TX) and ''Aunt Cess'' to 12 nieces and nephews, their husbands, wives and children. Born in Chicago, IL on January 15, 1927, Celeste joined TWA in 1949 in the early days of commercial flying as a flight attendant and then served as purser for the airlines, flying internationally, until her retirement in 1987. Celeste was adored and admired by hundreds of friends and colleagues whom she met throughout the world during 40 years of flying and during her subsequent 20 years of travel while in retirement. She was selected to join the flight crew that served Lyndon Johnson during a Presidential World Tour and had the privilege of escorting many troops to and from Vietnam. THE NEWS Improperly maintained utility lines were responsible for three devastating wildfires that killed 2 people, destroyed 1,141 homes and scorched 207,000 acres of land near San Diego last year, state utility regulators reported. BEHIND THE NEWS Downed power lines cause only a small percentage of California wildfires, but they tend to be big ones because the lines generally traverse remote, windy terrain on high towers. The two utilities involved, San Diego Gas & Electric and Cox Communications, denied that their lines were badly maintained and said unusually fierce winds were to blame. Some elected officials want the lines put underground, but the utilities balk at the cost.

THE Automotive X Prize has a rich $10 million purse, and that may be a powerful draw for many entrants, some of whom appear to be operating on a shoestring. All they have to do is come up with something that has eluded the major automakers -- a vehicle that can achieve the equivalent of 100 miles a gallon. Then they simply need to make their car or truck safe, low-emission and ''production capable.''

STOOKEY--Lyman, 77, former minister at First Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, died August 29th at his home in Boston. He left the ministry to serve as Assistant to Mitchell Sviridoff, Administrator of NYC's Human Resources Administration and later to Henry Cohen, Director of The New School's Urban Studies program. He taught for 20 years at Brandeis University, directing its Law, Medicine and Health Policy program, and was about to start his second year as volunteer tutor at Codman Academy, a charter school in Dorchester, MA. He is survived by his daughters, Meg Stookey, Caroline Dennis and Hoyt Bingham, by his son, John Stookey, and by his former wife, Dorothy and many grandchildren, nieces and nephews. He leaves his brothers John and Byron and his first wife, Shirley. A service will be held in the fall. Donations may be made to Codman Academy Foundation, POB 240906, Dorchester, MA 02124.

FAY--Sylvia, of New York City, passed away peacefully in the early morning hours of August 22, 2008. In the later 1960s, Ms. Fay was one of the first women in New York to open her own Background Casting Company for film and television where she cast thousands of actors in some of the most memorable films ever made. She launched some actors into stardom and helped sustain the dream for others. To actors, Ms. Fay was known to be tough but fair. She was legendary to some, respected within the entertainment industry by most, and will be forgotten by none. In her honor the company she started will continue to use the name it has been operating under for several years, ''Sylvia Fay/Lee Genick & Associates Casting.'' A memorial service will be held in her honor on Sunday, October 5, 2008 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to ''The Actors Fund'' or to ''The American Cancer Society.''

Orson Welles's 1958 ''Touch of Evil'' is a work of slippery precision, a picture whose seductiveness is only enhanced by its refusal to surrender fully to our grasp. Charlton Heston (below, with Janet Leigh), in dark makeup, is Mike Vargas, the upstanding Mexican narcotics agent who becomes involved in a murder case that straddles the Mexico-United States border. Leigh is his feisty new bride, whose reward for her pluck is to be chained to a bed and drugged; and Welles is the corrupt American fat-cat cop Hank Quinlan, looming over the picture like a scowling parade balloon. In ''Touch of Evil'' important plot points and crucial dialogue come at you sideways and from behind in slithery sections, like the vertebrae of a snake. Blink and you might miss something. But you won't miss Welles.

GOLDBERG--William Eric. January 2, 1971 to September 7, 2000. Today marks 8 years since you left us. We miss your smile, your laughter, and your unending support. TRAKTMAN--Esther (Katz). Suddenly, on September 4, 2008, at 86 years of age, while recuperating from a broken hip. Devoted and adoring wife of 66 years of Mortimer Traktman. Loving, caring mother of David and Paula (Stephen Duncan). Proud, doting grandmother of Samantha and Cameron Duncan. Fond sister of Florence Katz. A women of incisive intelligence, passionate in her beliefs and fiercely loyal to those she cared about, she was a true idealist in an age of relativism. She was much loved and will be sorely missed. Contributions in her memory to UJA-Federation or Planned Parenthood are welcome. Graveside service Sunday, September 7 at 11:30 am. Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

EVERY week of the Grand Tour, I signed off on my travel videos with a standard line: ''For The New York Times, this is Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler.'' This sentence was so simple, and yet it gave me no end of headaches. The problem? I was trying to say it in French, in Romanian, in Lithuanian -- in the local language of every country I visited. The issue was never ''The New York Times,'' nor my name, which swings easily from Mathieu to Mateo to Matthias. No, the troublesome word was ''frugal'' -- it's a concept that just doesn't translate easily. Often, my local friends explained, its closest analogue was ''cheap,'' which can have a negative connotation of stinginess. And even if we came up with the right word -- ''rhis'' in Maltese, ''prijsbewuste'' in Dutch -- there was still one last challenge: How the heck do I pronounce this stuff? (Answer: poorly.)

Pedro Castaneda was installing wireless computer networks in San Antonio when he met a young filmmaker named Chris Eska, who asked him to be in his first movie, ''August Evening'' (Sept. 5). Mr. Castaneda hesitated, but after reading the script and consulting his family, he said yes. Considering that Mr. Eska was offering the leading role to a novice in his 50s, it's hard to say who was taking the greater chance. But no matter -- their gamble has paid off handsomely. ''August Evening'' is a deceptively quiet, Ozu-like drama set in southwest Texas, near the Mexican border. Mr. Castaneda plays Jaime, an illegal immigrant and father who has lost one son and whose other children are embarrassed by him. When the movie begins, he's living with his wife and his son's devoted young widow of four years in a small house on the chicken farm where he works. As Mr. Castaneda goes about Jaime's chores in the heat and mess of the overcrowded chicken barn, his silent performance becomes remarkably eloquent.

BILANDER--Rose, died September 3, 2008 at age 90. A social activist, wife, mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. She was a true pistol. We already miss her fighting spirit. Memorial at a later date. In her memory donate to the Obama Campaign and vote.

KEENAN--William Michael, 70, Boulder, Colorado, passed away Thursday, August 21, 2008. He was born in Robinson, Illinois, to Paul Eugene Keenan and Frances Pauline Stansfield on July 1, 1938. Mike obtained a B.S. from Case Institute of Technology, and M.S. and Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon Institute. He was a professor and Deputy Chairman of Finance at New York University Stern Business School, retiring in 2004. Mike authored numerous papers, books, and edited works. He served as an officer in several financial professional societies including The American Finance Association, Eastern Finance Association, Financial Management Association and New York Society of Security Analysts. He was an ex-trustee of the Collegiate Church Corporation and Collegiate School of Boys. A devoted member of his church, Mike has served as Churchmaster, Treasurer, Elder, and Board Member for Marble Collegiate Church, New York City. After retiring to Boulder, CO, he served on the board of the Boulder Public Library for one year. He is survived by his sister, Laura Jean (Henry) Pietrzak; niece, Julie Jean (Keith) Moore, a great-niece and great-nephew. Mike was preceded in death by his parents and nephew, Michael Henry Pietrzak. Services will be held Sunday, September 14, 2008, 2:00pm at Marble Collegiate Church, 1 West 29th St., New York. The family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the American Heart Association or charity of your choice.

IN FRONT OF BENRATH CASTLE, DÜSSELDORF, JULY 12, 2008 Irina Chernuskina, 44, at left in background, a librarian from Moscow. ''I'd been planning to spend a weeklong vacation with my friends in Konstanz, Germany. But completely out of the blue, old college friends I had lost touch with almost 20 years ago found me through a Russian schoolmate social-networking site. I couldn't afford to be in Germany and not to see them in Düsseldorf, where they've lived since 1999, so I rebooked my tickets to include a stopover there. We had lived in the same dorm at Kiev University -- at that time it was the Soviet Union. They got married probably after the third year in the university; I went to their native town in Moldova for their wedding party. After university each of us got busy with our own lives. We spent time talking a lot about our old friends, walking in the city in Düsseldorf, drinking beer. I was surprised to see how many German people, senior people, were on the street drinking and talking to each other; it's a different culture. You'll never see in Moscow such kind of people who spend time on the street drinking beer.'' As told toSeth Kugel

Now that we know that Robert Downey Jr. can play pretty much anything -- from a captain-of-industry superhero with a soul (''Iron Man'') to a self-absorbed Australian actor who undergoes a ''pigmentation-alteration procedure'' so he can play a black man (''Tropic Thunder'') -- his performance in the 1992 ''Chaplin'' should not seem so astonishing. But to watch the picture again, in this digitally remastered 15th-anniversary edition, is to be reminded that even before he hit 30, Mr. Downey had the ability to burrow more deeply into a character than most actors can manage after a lifetime in the business. He plays Charlie Chaplin as a figure who is both larger than life and deeply unknowable, a fragile human being locked inside the bold, decisive strokes of a caricature. Mr. Downey doesn't just recreate Chaplin's physical genius, he suggests that that famous balletic, bowlegged walk might have been one man's way of staying safely balanced on the knife edge of emotional anguish.

THREE HUNDRED years ago, wealthy young Englishmen began taking a post-Oxbridge trek through France and Italy in search of art, culture and the roots of Western civilization. With nearly unlimited funds, aristocratic connections and months (or years) to roam, they commissioned paintings, perfected their language skills and mingled with the upper crust of the Continent. No one knows who came up with it, but their adventures soon had a perfectly appropriate name: the Grand Tour. This summer, I embarked on a Grand Tour of my own, reinventing the classic European journey as a budget-minded, modern-day jaunt. Where the original Grand Tourists carried letters of credit granting them access to riches, and letters of introduction to society figures, I had just 100 euros a day (about $160 when I began, but more like $150 today) and the e-mail addresses of several friends of friends. As I faced 13 weeks of travel, I was feeling somewhat less than grand.
CURCIO--Frank. The longer you are away, the more I realize that I am just like you. I love you and miss you terribly. Paola

MILLER--Sylvia Rogers, Rhythms Teacher. Sylvia Rogers Miller, a long time resident of Stamford, Connecticut passed away July 10, 2008 peacefully in her sleep at age 96 of natural causes. She was bom on July 22, 1911 in Hartford, Connecticut, the daughter of Julia Erwin Miller and Martin Peck Miller, the later a graduate of Yale Class of 1902. As a young woman, she lived for many years in Monmouth County, New Jersey and was a graduate of Red Bank High School, Class of 1928. Ms. Miller was a lifelong artist and skilled in many disciplines but especially dance. She studied dance in New Jersey and New York and at the Alexander Volinine studios in Paris. Her experience in dance spanned a wide range of forms, including performance with the Garrick Gaieties Revue in a chorus line with the renowned actress Rosalind Russell. The Revue started on Broadway, in 1925, and Ms. Miller joined it in later years, performing on Broadway, and on a tour which included the United States and Canada. Beginning in 1935, she also performed and taught a form of dance set to music called ''Rhythms'', originated by Miss Ruth Doing with whom she studied, Sylvia taught Rhythms to children and adults and continued to do so for adults into her nineties. She also excelled at wood carving, drawing and painting and was still carving wood in her late nineties. Sylvia taught dance and other subjects at the City and Country School, 146 West 13th Street New York City for almost 40 years from the Fall of 1939 until her retirement in 1976. In the summers, beginning in 1932, she taught similar subjects at a camp in the Adirondacks on Upper St. Regis Lake, Paul Smiths, known for many years as the GardnerDoing Camp. Sylvia continued to visit the Camp and enjoyed swimming in the lake and boating until very recently. She is survived by her longtime companion Patricia Panasuk, her brother, William C. Miller and his wife Hannelore Miller of Sausalito, California, a nephew, grandnephews and grandnieces. Family services will be private. A memorial gathering and celebration of Sylvia's life and work is to be held October 25th, 2008 at the City and Country School, 146 West 13th Street, NYC.

In an interview posted on YouTube the character actor Omar Benson Miller talks about his roles in two back-to-back high-profile movies coming out this fall. ''I'm turning it up,'' he says. ''It's time to explode!'' Given Mr. Miller's outstanding work in the earlier film, Spike Lee's World War II drama, ''Miracle at St. Anna'' (Sept. 26), he may not have to wait until the second -- Gary Fleder's ''Express'' (Oct. 3), about Ernie Davis, the first black football player to win the Heisman Trophy -- for his career to become airborne. The first World War II feature film devoted to the experience of some of the 900,000 or so black military personnel who served, Mr. Lee's ''Miracle'' follows four soldiers from the all-black 92nd Division who become separated from their company and hole up in a partisan-controlled Italian village behind German lines. Along the way and under mortar fire, Mr. Miller's Pvt. Sam Train laboriously rescues a small, injured Italian boy who, gazing at him in wonder, calls him ''the chocolate giant.''

Burial will be immediately after at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the diabetes foundation.

If you had time to visit just one museum in Rome's Villa Borghese (the city's Central Park) it would of course be the Galleria Borghese, filled with Renaissance masterpieces by Titian, Bernini and Caravaggio to name a few. But if you have an extra hour, or want a second culture stop on your walk down through the park back to the center of town...Well then, you should really stop in at the Museo Carlo Bilotti

Updated and corrected, 9:20 p.m. |New York City Transit officials unveiled a new behemoth double-decker bus today that will cruise city streets in a 30-day trial run. The two-story vehicles have not been in wide use for everyday public transit since 1953, although they did make a brief, limited return in the 1970s.Beginning on Thursday, the 13-foot-tall, 45-foot-long, 81-seat bus will alternate service on local and express bus routes: BxM3 from Yonkers to Manhattan, the X17J between Staten Island and Manhattan, the M15 limited on First and Second Avenues, and possibly the M5 along Fifth Avenue (if the tree pruning along the bus lane goes well).

Instead of "Monday Night Football," the buzz in New York is the Roger Federer-Andy Murray championship match, starting at 5 p.m. at Arthur Ashe Stadium. By the way, one reason the final starts at 5 p.m. instead of later is perhaps to avoid direct competition from the two National Football League games tonight; another, given by Open officials in a Saturday news conference, is a nod to European broadcasters and fans.

Energy | An article asks how we can square the Iran issue with a revived interest in nuclear power to reduce carbon emissions: "After Iran's recent behavior, should the United States continue to act as though all states have a right per se to make nuclear fuel and thus come withing days of possessing a nuclear bomb?" [The New Atlantis]

About two months after Italy hoisted the World Cup in 2006 in a game watched by more than a billion people around the world, 48 teams gathered in Cape Town, South Africa, for a tournament that had little glitz or cache - the fourth Homeless World Cup.
