After successfully rebuffing the overtures of some very pushy corporate raiders over the years, the Gehl Company is finally being acquired -- willingly.

By and large, it is safe to assume, there's nothing quite like it back home.Take this cigar-chomping, money-bag-clutching behemoth, stationed last week in front of the Lincoln Building, across East 42nd Street from Grand Central Terminal.

The Mets' worst fears were confirmed today when MRI testing revealed that Billy Wagner will be out for a year after tearing the medial collateral ligament and the flexor pronator in his left elbow. Wagner will have surgery this week. With the recovery time expected to be a full year, it is possible that Wagner, whose four-year contract expires after next season, has thrown his last pitch as a Met.

Barack Obama is right: if John McCain comes out on top in November, it will be more of the same. For almost eight years we've had a president who pronounces "nuclear" the way Homer Simpson does; if the Republicans win, we'll have a president who rails against "Warshington" and a vice president who rails against "the pundints."

Silicon Valley's entrepreneurial energy is being served up in highly concentrated form this week, at a San Francisco conference called the TechCrunch50, sponsored by the technology blog TechCrunch. Over the next three days, the bright-eyed founders of some four dozen brand new start-ups will take the stage to describe how they plan to make money from a connective, online future.

Wealthy parents in New York City raise money -- a lot of it -- to buy their children's schools all kinds of extras, including assistant teachers hired on the side. It has become so accepted that it could hardly seem shocking. But when the mayor and the schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, incessantly speak of equality and fairness in the schools, money raised by outside groups raises interesting questions.Over the weekend, The New York Post reported that some parent-teacher association groups in the city's wealthiest neighborhoods raise hundreds of thousands of dollars to hire assistant teachers for $12 an hour.
While the United States appears to be on track to play in its sixth straight World Cup, the game north of the border in Canada experienced the good, the bad, but mostly the ugly this past week.

Back in 2001, when Bill Miller was viewed as one of the world's greatest investors, I edited a story about him at Fortune magazine. Mr. Miller, of course, is the manager of the Legg Mason Value Trust mutual fund, whose claim to fame is that he beat the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for 15 years straight. (It was 10 straight when Fortune published its story.) In the last few years, however, his fund has stumbled badly. Indeed, there are those in the investment community who whisper that Mr. Miller was never really a truly great investor. Rather, he was akin to the guy who flips a coin and it comes up heads 15 straight times -- a product, that is, of randomness rather than skill.

The bailout of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will post big consequences in yet another corner of the financial markets: contracts that protect $1.47 billion of the mortgage finance giants' bonds against default.

Today is the big day: The Huntsman-Hexion trial is upon us. This is a rare example of a collapsed buyout deal from the recent boom that is actually going to trial, and I'll be live-blogging the opening arguments.

Think Tank Central | In an article written before the Sarah Palin nomination, the feminist critic Christina Hoff Sommers makes a case for "classical" feminism over more recent "radical" feminism. Classical feminism had two wellsprings: egalitarian feminists like Mary Wollstonecraft, and conservative feminists like Hannah More and Frances Willard. The latter, she says, have "vanished from the official 'herstorical' record." [American Enterprise Institute]

With the presidential campaign now in full swing, Congress returns today for a September stretch that will be more about politics than policy as the two parties maneuver for full advantage in both Congressional contests and the race for the White House.

ROME - Vice President Dick Cheney, not surprisingly, endorsed Gov. Sarah Palin as the Republican candidate to replace him, but the man who reshaped the office as much as other vice president in history suggested she would not necessarily replicate the role he has played under President Bush.
Given a ticket for drinking a beer on his stoop, a Brooklyn resident is contesting his summons, questioning whether a stoop can be considered "a public place."

Cars | The 2009 Fiesta ECOnetic gets 65 miles per gallon, but Ford will sell it only in Europe. Reason: it runs on diesel, which (1) costs way more than gasoline in America because of taxes aimed at trucks; and (2) is thought by American consumers to be smelly, dirty and "old-tech," even though it's now cleaner than gasoline. So they go for the Prius instead. [Business Week]

It wasn't quite a wipe-out. In the end, and like all bailouts, the Freddie Mac/Fannie Mae weekend affair was imperfect. The result is that today the government sponsored entities' common and preferred shares are trading in the market and will continue to do so for the time being. They have been spared from total eradication.

Altria Group said Monday it reached an agreement to buy UST, the maker of Skoal and Copenhagen smokeless tobacco, for about $10.4 billion. Altria will pay $69.50 per share in cash for each UST share, a premium of nearly 29 percent above UST's closing price on Thursday, the day before The New York Times reported that the companies were in negotiations.

Over the years, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac showered riches on many winners: their executives, Wall Street bankers and Washington lobbyists. Now the foundering mortgage giants are leaving some losers in their wake, notably their shareholders, rank-and-file employees and, in the worst case, American taxpayers.

As part of its rescue plan for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government has dismissed to the current chief executives of the mortgage giants and replaced them with two veterans of the financial world.

Environment | Scientists with the Royal Society are hard at work on "planetary engineering" to fight global warming, and one idea is: more pollution! That is, "deliberately polluting the stratosphere with sulphate in order to reflect solar heat back into space" -- by burning "high-sulphur aviation fuel" on civilian flights. Al Gore's private jet explained? [Economist]

The president of China Eastern Airlines said on Sunday that the airline is actively considering a merger with Shanghai Airlines, its smaller rival carrier in eastern China, according to The Financial Times.

A financial firm borrows billions of dollars to make big bets on esoteric securities. Markets turn and the bets go sour. Overnight, the firm loses most of its money, and Wall Street suddenly shuns it. Fearing that its collapse could set off a full-scale market meltdown, the government intervenes and encourages private interests to bail it out.

Investors around the world breathed a sigh of relief on Monday after the federal government took over and backed Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, assuring a continued flow of credit through America's wounded mortgage system, The New York Times' Vikas Bajaj and Keith Bradsher reported.
Can Senator John McCain prevail without offering more for those voters’ pocketbooks?

As rivals seem to be struggling to meet their fundraising targets, TPG has quietly raised a fresh $30 billion war chest to target deals across a broad range of spectrum, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Royal Bank of Canada considered buying Lehman Brothers in July, but decided against the move because it doubted the bank's ability to shore up its balance sheet, The Financial Times reported.
Paulson & Company, a prominent New York hedge fund, will weigh buying shares or convertible bonds in banks and other financial institutions that need capital, according to The Financial Times.

Why does Henry R. Kravis, the co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, want to take the storied private equity firm public now, given the poor performance of rival Blackstone Group's stock and mounting concern that the credit crisis may suffocate deals inked during the preceding boom?
The longtime chief executive of Washington Mutual, the country's biggest savings and loan, has been forced out because of the company's mounting losses, The New York Times' Eric Dash reported.

Americans call the economy the top issue of the 2008 election, and both presidential candidates agree on the target voters: the ones Gov. Sarah Palin says "do some of the hardest work in America - who grow our food, run our factories and fight our wars."

Sam Bronfman, the older brother of Edgar Bronfman Jr., has returned to his roots with a new financing vehicle that provides mezzanine loans for wine and spirit deals.
Eco-Products, a maker of compostable food service supplies, such as cups and plates, has raised $2 million in first round funding from Greenmont Capital Partners.

Alitalia's adviser will soon present its rescue plan for the airline to British Airways, considered by Italy as a possible foreign partner for the bankrupt airline, an executive told business daily Il Sole 24 Ore.

Origin Energy, fending off an $11 billion hostile bid from Britain's BG Group, is to spin off its coalbed methane assets into a joint venture with U.S. oil major ConocoPhillips.

Apparently, this is not genetic, but cultural, to judge from the "clear difference" between Asians newly arrived in the West and those here some time. [Wired]

Headlines from the world of property:

The Olympic gold medalists Misty May-Treanor and Kerri Walsh lost for the second time since the Beijing Games and missed their first tour final since April 2007, falling to Jen Boss and April Ross, 21-18, 15-21, 20-18, in the semifinals of the AVP Crocs Cup Shootout in Santa Barbara, Calif.

John Skelton threw touchdown passes of 87 and 50 yards to lead host Fordham to a 16-0 victory against Rhode Island. Xavier Martin led the Rams with 169 yards on 29 carries. Rain and wind forced a postponement Saturday.

Janel McCarville had 16 points before leaving with an injury and Essence Carson had 10 to lead the Liberty (18-12) to a 69-61 victory against the Chicago Sky in a W.N.B.A. game at Madison Square Garden.

Levi Leipheimer of the United States took the overall lead of the Vuelta a España after an eighth stage won by David Moncoutie of France in Salardu. Moncoutie completed the 94-mile stage in the Pyrenees in 4 hours 24 minutes 58 seconds. Leipheimer, of Astana, is 21 seconds ahead of his teammate Alberto Contador.

Hélio Castroneves won the PEAK Indy 300 in the second-closest finish in IndyCar Series history, but it was not enough to keep Scott Dixon from his second championship. Castroneves came from last place to win in Joliet, Ill., but Dixon, who knew he had to finish eighth or better to win the title, took the lead with a perfect late pit stop and nearly held off Castroneves, crossing the line inches behind the winner. After nearly 30 minutes, official timing and scoring called the margin of victory 0.0033 of a second.

Asafa Powell won the 100 meters at the Rieti (Italy) Grand Prix in 9.82 seconds. Powell, who set a world record of 9.74 on the same track a year ago, clocked 9.77 in his semifinal heat, well off the world record of 9.69 set by his fellow Jamaican Usain Bolt at the Beijing Olympics.

Felipe Massa became the winner of the Belgian Grand Prix after Lewis Hamilton was penalized for cutting a corner in a late duel with the world champion Kimi Raikkonen on Sunday in Spa-Francorchamps. Hamilton, of McLaren, crossed the line 14.4 seconds ahead of Ferrari’s Massa during a finish in which Raikkonen crashed into a barrier, but Hamilton was penalized 25 seconds for an illegal maneuver.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday about Muriel Kallis Steinberg Newman, who gave a major gift of modern art to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misstated the timing of the gift. She completed the transaction before she died; she did not delay completion until her death. The obituary also omitted a survivor — her stepdaughter from her second marriage, Estelle Newman Tanner.

Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 29 about the Yankees’ 3-2 victory over the Red Sox in the final scheduled game between the teams at Yankee Stadium described incorrectly a ninth-inning play that put the winning run in scoring position. Brett Gardner, pinch-running for the Yankees, stole second base — not third.

Because of a production error, the State of the Art column on Thursday, about a service that can scan incoming postal service mail and display it on a private Web page, was less than state of the art in some copies. The word “Years” mistakenly appeared as the name of the column instead of as the first word of the column. The opening sentence should have begun, “Years ago” — not simply “ago.”.

A credit for a picture in some editions on Friday with an article about the death of a construction worker who fell 400 feet from a Manhattan high-rise misspelled the photographer’s surname. The photograph of the scene of the fall was by Dan Alcalde — not Alcade — of The New York Times.

The Beachwood Journal article on Aug. 29, about a controversy ensnaring Mayor Ronald W. Jones Jr. of Beachwood, N.J., whose 24-year-old son is a registered sex offender, misstated the son’s given name at one point in some copies. He is Ronald W. Jones III, not Robert.

An article on Friday about a $400 million gift to the Broad Institute of M.I.T. and Harvard, by Eli and Edythe Broad, described the Starr Foundation, another donor to the institute, incorrectly. It is a private foundation, not the philanthropic arm of the insurance company American International Group. (The Starr Foundation was created by Cornelius Vander Starr, the founder of A.I.G., and the foundation’s chairman is Maurice Greenberg, the former chairman and chief executive of A.I.G.).

LEEDS--Gloria, at age 82 of Delray Beach, Florida and Southbury, CT passed away September 6, 2008. Born in Brooklyn, NY on August 20, 1926, she was an elementary school teacher, loving wife, mother and grandmother. She shared 51 years of marriage with her beloved Alfred, who passed away in 1999. She served as President of the Eastern Long Island Branch of Womens League of Conservative Judaism and President of the Plainview Jewish Center Sisterhood. She is survived by son, Alan, daughter, Barbara, and four grandchildren, Mark, Shanna, Paige and Benjamin. Her life was a treasure. The work of her hands and heart made the world a measurably richer, kinder place. She leaves a host of friends and family who loved her dearly. She showed us all that a life is not measured as one big thing; it is a million little things, all of them precious. Services will take place on Tuesday, September 9, 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

With the presidential campaign now in full swing, Congress returns today for a September stretch that will be more about politics than policy as the two parties maneuver for full advantage in both Congressional contests and the race for the White House. The first issue on the Congressional plate will be higher energy prices as House Democrats could move as early as this week to bring to the floor a broad energy plan that would open up some areas to coastal drilling while providing incentives for alternative energy and reducing subsidies for oil companies. Democrats were still assembling the measure over the weekend, and Republicans were set to portray it as a sham, particularly if Democrats do not allow them any opportunity to amend it on the floor. But the measure is expected to open the door to new drilling in coastal waters now off limits, potentially depriving Republicans of the ability to keep hammering Democrats for blocking an offshore drilling vote. The Senate, where a growing bipartisan group is pushing its own version of a comprehensive measure, could have more success in finding a consensus, one that includes some financial aid for the nation's auto industry, throwing the lobbying muscle of automakers behind the plan. Senate Republicans may cite the need to keep focused on energy if they block a Democratic attempt later Monday to vote to take up the annual Pentagon policy bill. Democrats will also be pushing for a second economic stimulus package headed into the fall, arguing that the government takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and rising unemployment are clear evidence that the economy is still in turmoil and average Americans need help as much as the mortgage giants and automakers. ''This situation is yet another stark reminder that we live in difficult economic times and we must do more to help struggling families reach the American dream,'' said Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, the majority leader. ''That is why I urge President Bush, Senator McCain and other Republicans to work with Democrats in the immediate days ahead to enact an economic recovery package.'' The one thing Congress must do before the end of the month is pass a stop-gap financing bill for the federal government after Sept. 30, but even that seemingly simple action is fraught with politics. Such a bill would typically include an extension of the annual ban on drilling off much of the nation's coast, and Republicans may try to block the funding bill over the ban, raising the prospect of a government shutdown just a few weeks before the November elections. Lawmakers will also have to decide whether any interim spending measure expires later this year, forcing a post-election lame-duck session, or extends into early 2009 after the inauguration of a new president. With some states still cleaning up from Hurricane Gustav and a more menacing hurricane approaching, Congress will also likely provide significant disaster relief before leaving town to campaign. Lawmakers will also try to deal with a rapidly depleting highway fund that is threatening to shut down road and bridge projects around the nation.

ORNSTEIN--Barbara Holly, 80, an editor and longtime Connecticut resident, died at Rosenthal Hospice Residences on Saturday, August 16, 2008, following a three-month struggle with leukemia. Born November 11, 1927 in New York City to the late Charles George Muller and Georgia Lydia Stanbrough, she grew up and lived most of her life in Greenwich, CT. She began her publishing career at Time, Inc. From 1952 to 1961 Barbara worked at National Broadcasting Company (NBC) in New York as a producer in news and public affairs and as an assistant to legendary Frank McGee. In 1962 she married the late Peter Ornstein. They moved to Greenwich into a 200-year-old farmhouse. In 1975 she became the editor-in-chief of the Friends of Greenwich Library Oral History Project, a job she held until 2003. She also chaired the Greenwich Fresh Air Fund and was a board member for the Greenwich Library. Barbara was a devoted genealogist as befits a 10th generation decedent of Mayflower settlers. She was related to George Washington and Alexander Hamilton. She was an avid sailor and an enthusiastic gardener, who could name virtually every flower she came upon in both English and Latin. She attended Swarthmore College, where she graduated in 1949 with a major in Latin and minors in Greek and Fine Arts. She later told her children, ''I studied all of this so that I could be sure to teach you to speak English properly.'' Surviving are her daughter, Holly Ornstein Carter and her husband, Robert of New York City; her son, David Stanbrough Ornstein and his wife, Alexandra of Greenwich; and five grandchildren. She is also survived by her half-sister, Jenny Muller Coons of Sedona, AZ. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 13 at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich at 1pm. Barbara's family is asking that donations in her honor and memory be made in her name to Swarthmore College or to the Greenwich Library.

CURRAN--Paul J. It is with deep sorrow that Kaye Scholer LLP mourns the passing of our friend and esteemed colleague, Paul J. Curran. Paul was a giant at the firm and in the legal community and was recognized as one of the leading trial lawyers in the country. Paul's contributions to the firm have spanned nearly a half century. He joined the firm in 1961 and became a partner in 1969. Aside from the years when he served as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York (1973-1975), Paul remained a partner at the firm until 1996, when he became a Special Counsel to the firm. Paul headed the firm's Litigation Department for more than a decade and served as a member of the firm's Executive Committee. In addition to serving as the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, Paul also held a number of important governmental positions throughout his career, including his appointment as Special Counsel, United States Department of Justice to investigate President Jimmy Carter (1979); Special Consultant to the Secretary of Defense on Intelligence Matters (1976); and Chairman (1969-1973) of the New York State Commission of Investigation. Paul was New York City's Legislative Representative to Albany (1967) and served three terms as a Member of the New York State Assembly, representing the Lower East Side of Manhattan district (1963-1966). Paul held numerous pro bono positions, including, most recently, serving as a member of the Judicial Election Qualification Commission (2007). From 1956-1958, Paul served as First Lieutenant, United States Air Force. He gave generously of his time and expertise, serving as the Chair and/or President of many professional and charitable organizations at the national, state and local levels, including Director and Past President, Fordham Law Alumni Association; Past President of the University Club; and the Cardinal's Committee for Charity. He received his LL.B. from Fordham University Law School and his A.B. from Georgetown University. We extend our deepest condolences to Paul's wife Barbara, their seven children and 22 grandchildren, and the rest of their wonderful family. Visitation will be on Monday, September 8, from 2:00-7:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel (Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Manhattan). A funeral mass will be held on Tuesday, September 9, at 10:30am at St. Patrick's Cathedral (Fifth Avenue at 50th Street, Manhattan). CURRAN--Paul J., February 21st, 1933 to September 4th, 2008. Beloved husband of Barbara Ann (nee Frank). Loving father of Mark I., Mary Louise Kingsbery (Clay), Catherine Souther (Thomas), Barbara Susanin (Timothy), Thomas J., II (Deirdre), Paul J., Jr. (Wendy) and Elizabeth Stockton (Richard, Jr.). Cherished grandfather of Ann, Lucy, James, Paul, Ted, Caroline, William, Caitlin, Christopher, Margaret, Jack, Annabel, Barbara Ann, Thomas III, Lucie, Matthew, Claire, Paul III, Catherine, Curran, Richard III and Libby. Devoted son of the late Thomas J. and Margaret Farley Curran. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Monday, September 8th, 2-7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, September 9th, 10:30 am at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Paul J. Curran Fund, 645 5th Avenue, Suite 703, NY, NY 10022, which provides assistance to schools servicing New York City's less advantaged children.

EMILíANA TORRINI ''Me and Armini'' (Rough Trade) On her enchanting 2005 album ''Fisherman's Woman,'' the singer-songwriter Emilíana Torrini sang small, ruminative songs in an intimate hush. She seemed watchful and a bit careful, with the stir of stringed instruments framing her voice like a cushion beneath a gem. So it's no surprise that Ms. Torrini begins a song on ''Me and Armini'' with an airy suggestion -- ''Let's stay awake/And listen to the dark'' -- against a fingerpicked acoustic guitar. The sound, like the image, feels right.

THE FINANCIAL RESCUE Capping months of uncertainty, the federal takeover of the mortgage finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Sunday was met with a sigh of relief from investors around the globe. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were intended to serve at least two masters -- the investors who put up capital and a government that wanted to help the housing industry and extend home ownership. In the end, they failed to serve either one very well. [C1.]

BOBO STENSON TRIO ''Cantando'' (ECM) This record, by the Swedish pianist Bobo Stenson, embodies two qualities that usually don't go together: extreme breadth and extreme humility. Often when a jazz bandleader serves up a program as mixed as ''Cantando'' -- folk song, an Ornette Coleman jazz tune, lieder, tango, free improvisation -- he wants to show you that he has a battling spirit: he can't be classified; he hasn't bought into any particular aesthetic. An assertiveness of touch tends to go along with that. But Mr. Stenson makes fairly sublime piano-trio records without over-arranging, over-playing or over-bandleading. In his mid-60s now, he's the repository of half a century of the development of free jazz, in particular the European post-'60s kind, with its folk and classical leanings. Yet he wears it all lightly. In his recent records you don't hear strategies or contentions, but a natural working flow.

OKKERVIL RIVER ''The Stand Ins'' (Jagjaguwar) Every song is a short story for Will Sheff, the songwriter and singer of the Austin, Tex., band Okkervil River. Usually his stories are first-person monologues, their drama stoked by Mr. Sheff's fearlessly disheveled voice: crooning like Morrissey, quavering like David Byrne, cracking, aching. The band matches his mood swings and eggs him on, harking back to the 1960s and '70s with folk-rock, new wave, country and an occasional stately ballad, sometimes sprinkled with mariachi horns or sleigh bells or banjo.

McREYNOLDS--Dr. Kathryn Baker, 52, a prominent writer on youth and educational issues, died on September 5, 2008, after a year-long battle with lung cancer. McReynolds was a regular contributor to the journal, Encounter: Education for Meaning and Social Justice, writing on issues such as free schools, homeschooling, and children's right to a happy childhood. She was named the journal's Associate Editor in 2006. McReynolds was sharply critical of test-driven education and the No Child Left Behind Act, which she saw as cramping children's full development. Dr. McReynolds was born in Kansas City, Missouri, attended high school in Scottsdale, Arizona, and graduated from Columbia University School of General Studies in 1983, Magna cum laude. She also was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received a Ph.D. in clinical psychology from the City University of New York in 2004. While working on her graduate degree, she taught numerous undergraduates courses, and was widely regarded as one of the most inspiring teachers in the department and college, according to the department's former chairperson, Dr. William Crain. From 2005 to 2006, she served as the interim director of The City College Gateway Academy, the college orientation and advisement center for new and continuing students. Dr. McReynolds, is survived by her husband, Pinchas Ben-Or, her children, Lilith Helen Ben-Or and Asher Jacob Ben-Or, her mother, Helen Jarvis McReynolds, her brothers Steven Martin and Andrew Claxon McReynolds, and her sister Billie J. McReynolds. The wake will be held at the Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway (West 214 Street) New York, NY 10034 on Sunday, September 7th, 57pm. The funeral service will be at the Holy Trinity Church, located at 20 Cumming Street off Seaman Avenue, New York, NY 10034, on Monday, September 8th, 7:30pm. Donations, in lieu of flowers, can be made to the Holy Trinity Food Pantry or the Pied Piper Children's Theater.

The New Chamber Ballet exudes an impressive atmosphere of serious endeavor. The music is played live, and this is plainly a point of principle for the company. Nothing superfluous intervenes. On Friday in Studio 4 of New York City Center, where I saw the ensemble for the first time, costumes were simple and mainly minimal. There were just five dancers. Not only did the artistic director, Miro Magloire, give brief, sensible, unpretentious spoken introductions to each work and tell the audience where to go for refreshments and purchases at intermission, he even helped to shift a grand piano. Though it's evident that music is the basis of most of his work, he's not a zealot about it. In an act of happy in-house heresy, one of his works, ''Dreams,'' was performed in silence, aside from the murmurs and isolated words uttered by its three dancers.

KELL--Yetta ''The Great Lady'' September 8th marks 22 years that she passed away, but her wisdom and kindness has never been forgotten by all who knew her. ''Rest in peace mom'' Your children, Joseph Kell and Ethel Kell-Davis

HETTINGER--Albert John III, died peacefully at home in Pawling, New Jersey on September 6, 2008 after a long illness. Devoted husband of Betty, father of William and James, father-in-law of Corinna and Leanna, grandfather of Caroline, Charles and Lily. Member of The Jockey Club, Trustee of The New York Racing Association and Chairman Emeritus of the Grayson Jockey Club Research Foundation. Trusted and dear friend to all who knew him. Will be greatly missed by all especially the employees and horses at Akindale Farm, a major thoroughbred facility in Pawling, New York. Substantial involvement in the transformation of Fasig-Tipton, a horse auction company, to its status as a major player in the thoroughbred industry. Extraordinary humanitarian and philanthropist whose passion for saving throroughbred racehorses from slaughter will live on long after his death through the dedication of his farm in perpetuity as a facility for horse rescue and ongoing horse care. There will be a private mass. A future celebration of his life will be planned. In lieu of flowers, donations to Akindale Thoroughbred Rescue, a Section 501(c)(3) organization, is requested --see www.akindale horserescue.org

ROSENBERG--Adrienne, died peacefully at home at age 97, surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of the late David, treasured and wonderful mother of Stephanie and Larry Levy and Janet Catalina. Adoring ''nana'' to Jennifer, Allison and Mark. Darling great-grandmother of Talia, Gabriel, Julia and Cate. A woman of impeccable grace, beauty and warmth, always with a smile on her face and in her heart. She will be missed so very much. Graveside family service in Florida. Donations in her memory may be made to Hospice By The Sea, 1531 W. Palmetto Rd., Boca Raton, FL 33486.

SAFFIOTTI--Paola Amman, 83, died peacefully at home in Bethesda, MD, on September 5th, 2008, following a year's journey with lung cancer. Beloved and devoted wife of 50 years of Umberto Saffiotti, loving mother of Luisa Saffiotti and Maria Saffiotti Dale, affectionate mother-in-law of Thomas Dale, adoring grandmother of Francesco Dale, cherished sister of Zaira Semenza (Fabio), Fernando Amman (Margherita) and Sofia Amman. She will be greatly missed by beloved relatives and friends all over the world. Her devotion to music and musicians has touched the lives of many. Born August 19, 1925, in Milan, Italy, she earned a piano diploma at the Conservatorio G. Verdi in 1948 and was assistant manager of the Organizzazione Internazionale Concerti in Milan (1952-60). After emigrating to the United States in 1960, she worked as personal assistant to the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra (196668). Saffiotti moved with her family to Bethesda, MD, in 1968, and contributed significantly to the cultural life of the Washington area for 40 years as co-founder and organizer of the Chamber Music Series of the Foundation for Advanced Education in the Sciences, National Institutes of Health. At Rudolf Serkin's urging, she became Administrative Coordinator of the Marlboro Recording Society in 1971, and oversaw the Library of Congress Marlboro Archives from 1974. She served on the Board of Trustees of the Marlboro Music School and Festival from 1991. Since 1993, she volunteered for the Recording for the Blind & Dyslexic. A Mass of Resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, September 13, 2008, 1:00pm, at The Church of the Little Flower, 5607 Massachusetts Ave., Bethesda, MD 20816. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Marlboro Music, 1616 Walnut Street, Suite 1600, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

''Burn After Reading,'' which opens on Friday, is the 14th movie written and directed by the Joel and Ethan Coen. The Coen brothers, who have won four Oscars, including best picture and direction for ''No Country for Old Men,'' have always been critical darlings. The box-office success of their films, however, hinges in part on the draw of their stars, like George Clooney in ''O Brother,'' Tom Hanks in ''Ladykillers'' and Tommy Lee Jones in ''No Country.'' ''Burn After Reading'' stars Mr. Clooney, as well as John Malkovich, Frances McDormand and Brad Pitt, above. SHELLY FREIERMAN

From Greenwich in the east to Hampton Court in the west the meandering River Thames is one of London's finest assets. On 13th and 14th September, the Thames Festival will celebrate the river with an annual event, which has grown over the last 10 years into one of Europe's largest street festivals. A mixture of arts, spectacle and entertainment will take place along a 2-mile stretch between Westminster Bridge and Tower Bridge, on the South Bank. Unusual spaces on and around the river will be transformed with a mixture of street arts, music, pyrotechnics, art installations, and performances, culminating with an illuminated night carnival and fireworks.

As societies modernize and sexual barriers crumble, do the personalities of men and women really become more different? Yes, if you believe the international comparisons showing that the gender gap in personality is larger in more progressive Western countries than in traditional cultures. In my Findings column I describe these counter-intuitive results and an explanation from the psychologist David Schmitt. I'm curious to hear Lab readers' thoughts on this. But first let me delve into the debate among researchers over this personality gap.

At the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, they call it "The Hawk," driving buses from 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. The yardmaster juggling maintenance schedules for Metro-North trains refers to it as "The Trick," as in "Night Trick." It is known nearly universally as the third shift - third chronologically, and most people's third choice.The guy hosing down Dumpsters, the bus boy at the all-night diner, the vendor hawking hot dogs as the bars close in the meatpacking district: they work midnights because, well, at least it's work. But others, part vampire, perhaps, prefer the wee hours. No bosses around. No office politics. The air a little lighter, the light, when it comes, a little brighter. Alone with the work, alone except for Champaine, the night disc jockey at WBLS, who talks to everyone else out there who works when much of the city that never sleeps is sleeping.

The architect Craig Dykers has been working since 2004 on the design of a museum building for the World Trade Center site. In the end, he realized there could be no more powerful a centerpiece than something Minoru Yamasaki designed 45 years ago.To an otherwise Spartan design for the twin towers, Mr. Yamasaki, the original architect, added one instantly recognizable flourish: trident shaped columns at the base of the buildings, which created an arcade of almost Gothic proportion. Enough of these enormous steel tridents survived the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001, that their familiar silhouettes came to symbolize endurance in the face of catastrophe.

New Yorkers may have been surprised to learn that sitting on a stoop and drinking a glass of wine or a bottle of beer is illegal. We reported Monday on the tale of a Brooklyn man who was handed a $25 summons from a police officer for sipping a bottle of Sierra Nevada beer on his stoop, in violation of the city's open container law.
Fears that the world might end because of a grand scientific experiment that begins on Wednesday have given way to something less urgent: Stephen Hawking may lose $100, or gain a Nobel Prize.

A recent "Vows'' column in The New York Times recounts the magical reunion and marriage of Amy Dickinson, the syndicated advice columnist for the Chicago Tribune, and Bruno Schickel, the older brother of a childhood friend in the Finger Lakes town of Freeville, N.Y. (population 505), where they both grew up.

"Wilma Jennings Bryan"? Jim Manzi, writing at The American Scene, compares Sarah Palin's acceptance speech at the Republican convention in St. Paul to William Jennings Bryan's "Cross of Gold" speech to the 1896 Democratic convention in Chicago.

The Obama campaign is framing a day of contrasts with the Republican ticket on the issue of public education as Senator Barack Obama prepares to deliver a speech about how to "modernize and strengthen our education system."
Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of former Pakistani prime minister Benazir Bhutto, has been sworn in as president.

History | A history podcaster notes that John McCain shows no sign of heart disease, the No. 1 shortener of life for men his age. Also, Bob Dole, 85 -- he's still alive and kicking. "Had he won the election in '96 he would have lived -- if what's occurred is any indication -- well past his second term." [My History Can Beat Up Your Politics, Sept. 6 podcast]

Last week, we solicited questions for Gordon Murray, the engineer behind the McLaren F1, who is at work on a green city car called the Type 25. Your queries touched on topics from turbines to high-tech materials to, yes, the F1.
The New York Civil Liberties Union has filed a suit seeking information about the Police Department's proposed Lower Manhattan Security Initiative.

Ivory Tower | An article says the start-up of the Large Hadron Collider in Geneva this week marks America's decline in particle physics and, perhaps, science in general. The loss of the collider for Texas in the 1990s demoralized American scientists, and a study says physics is now as unpopular among university students as it was when the Soviets launched Sputnik in 1957. [Newsweek]
This is part of a week-long series of blog posts on the debate among ordinary Iraqis over the presence of American troops.

Language | A British paper says a casualty of the Georgian war is the French language. The truce that was supposed to get the Russians out of disputed areas was written in French before being translated into English and then Russian. Problematic prepositions crept in, allowing Russia to say it could stay. And so much for French as a lingua franca. [London Telegraph]
Expect a lot of socks at Apple's event Tuesday. IPod Socks are the sort of brand building fluff that Apple talks about when it isn't changing the fate of humanity.
Atticus Capital is so tired of the market speculation about its health that it is clamming up.

Barclays' global build-out of its investment banking business could continue for as much as four more years, as the British bank seeks a bigger presence in the United States, the Mideast and Asia. That's what Robert E. Diamond Jr., the president of Barclays and its chief executive of investment banking, told Investment Dealers' Digest for its recent cover story.
O.K., we get it, Tiger. You're good.
As the old saw goes, no risk, no reward. But in turbulent times, that may also mean no meltdown.

Napster, the one-time leader in digital music downloads, received support on Monday from two proxy advisory firms as it seeks to stave off an attack by three dissident shareholders, according to The Los Angeles Times's Technology blog.
More of your "late night" humor (use the comment link below):

A day after the government seized control of the nation's two largest mortgage finance companies, policy makers and Congress began what promises to be an epic political fight over how to revamp the companies once the current crisis ends, Stephen Labaton and Edmund L. Andrews wrote in The New York Times.

Environment | Meat pollutes more than planes, trains and automobiles, United Nations figures suggest. So eat less meat, its climate chief urges this week. Meat production accounts for about 18 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions, versus 13 percent from transportation. This would make the drive-thru at McDonald's practically a mortal sin. [BBC, Times of India]

President Bush may be the nation's first M.B.A. president, but when Mr. Bush and a small coterie of advisers met in the Oval Office last week to complete their plan to rescue the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, there was no question who was in charge, The New York Times' Sheryl Gay Stolberg reports.
Is the definition of companies that are "too big to fail" getting broader? Or are some industries simply more important than others?
Why did Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson pull the trigger on a government takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac when he did?

Raffaello Follieri, the Italian businessman who was accused last year by the entrepreneur Ron Burkle of misusing more than $1 million he had put up for investments, is near an agreement to plead guilty to fraud and money-laundering charges in his federal criminal case, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Financial services companies have long sought to associate themselves with athletes who represent the best of their profession. Think of Yao Ming and Visa, or Tiger Woods and American Express.

In what may gall some Wall Streeters, London will share the title of the most developed financial system with the Big Apple in a new study to be released by the World Economic Forum Tuesday, The Financial Times reported.
Michael Dell shelled about $100 million for a swath of his company's stock last week, following a drop in the computer firm's shares after it reported disappointing earnings.
Evercore Partners announced Monday that it was starting an investment group, along with other investors, to take minority stakes in independent alternative asset managers.
Bank of America is close to signing a deal to become the biggest sponsor of the new Yankee Stadium, in a pact that could fetch the stadium as much as $20 million a year, according to press reports.
A federal judge rejected a proposed plea agreement sentence of probation and a fine for Broadcom co-founder Henry Samueli as too lenient, and postponed his sentencing, Reuters reported.

Nokia's Internet offering is far from ready and the world's top cellphone maker is seeking further acquisitions to speed up the roll out of new services, Niklas Savander, the head of the unit, told Reuters.

In the summer of 2007, Diane Greene was lauded as a business hero for leading VMware, a maker of business software, to the hottest stock debut since Google. But, The New York Times' Ashlee Vance says, in the ensuing year, despite her popularity with employees and on Wall Street, her relationship with her directors, and especially VMware's chairman, Joseph M. Tucci, grew increasingly chilly.

A start-up with the goal of bring high-speed Internet access to poor countries around the world via satellite is prepping for takeoff, after snagging funding from heavy hitters, including Google, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Shares in German drugs and chemicals group Bayer rose on market talk of takeover interest from U.S. rival Pfizer, traders told Reuters Tuesday.

The Justice Department laid out a broad policy on antitrust enforcement on Monday that drew an unusually sharp rebuke from three federal trade commissioners, who said it would protect monopolies from prosecution, according to The New York Times' Eric Lichtblau.

The London Stock Exchange suffered its worst breakdown in eight years Monday as a computer problem prevented traders from participating in a worldwide market rally after the American government's takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, The New York Times' Julia Werdigier reported.

Pakistan plans to sell valuable energy assets, beginning with a major gas field, as it tries to reap billions of dollars from deals with investors in industries like banking and farming, The New York Times' Heather Timmons reported.

Franklin Templeton Investments has appointed an executive to spearhead efforts to improve ties with sovereign wealth funds in a bid to manage more of the $2-3 trillion controlled by these state-owned entities.

The Justice Department has hired Sandy Litvack, who was its former antitrust chief and the Walt Disney Company's former vice chairman, to consult on its probe of Google's search advertising deal with Yahoo, according to press reports.

BG Group, the British gas producer, admitted defeat in its hostile bid for Australian coal-bed methane producer Origin Energy, but analysts said BG may shift its focus to another target or become a target itself.

Lone Star Funds has submitted documents requested by South Korean authorities that could help the private equity house avoid sanctions including the forced sale of its shares in Korea Exchange Bank, already offered to HSBC.

Ivory Tower | Law-school students come to class expecting to be grilled in the manner of Professor Kingsfield in "The Paper Chase," by brilliant professors who teach them "to think like lawyers." But a U.C.L.A. law professor says most teachers are lousy at this so-called Socratic method and it doesn't work. Socrates winds up doing most of the talking. [BusinessAssociationsBlog]

Music | Using Google Maps, a music magazine has begun mapping where album cover photographs were taken. You can browse by album title or by clicking markers on the map that pop up album details. Add your own favorites or (for the true obsessive) submit your quibbles. [Word]

Economy | An effect of the downturn you may not have considered: the tooth fairy gives less. A British survey says the average amount left under a pillow for a tooth has dropped from just over $2 to about $1.50 in the past six months. More than a third of British kids get nothing. [London Telegraph]

The Olympic champion Usain Bolt pointed to the sky in his signature victory pose as he returned to his native Jamaica. Fans crowded the international airport to welcome Bolt, who won three gold medals at the Beijing Games. He was also greeted by dignitaries including Prime Minister Bruce Golding.

A horse that did not sell upstaged the ones that did at Keeneland’s September yearling sale. Although the bidding reached $7.7 million for Vallenzeri, an A. P. Indy colt and the first foal out of the former Breeders Cup Distaff champion Azeri, that amount was not enough to pry the horse from the owner Michael Paulson. It was the highest price refused for a horse at a Keeneland sale. Azeri won Horse of the Year honors in 2002 while racing for Paulson’s father, Allen.

The Knicks are exploring trades involving Zach Randolph, but a proposed deal with the Memphis Grizzlies has been dormant for weeks and may never be revived, according to Knicks officials. “There was a discussion about different formats, and it never got anywhere,” Donnie Walsh, the Knicks’ president, said Monday.

There have been so many snapshots during this Yankees season that defy all sense.
Win
The Yankees’ season has become a theater of the hopeless. So it was in the sixth inning, when the fourth-place Yankees brawled with the Los Angeles Angels.

Photos of a stone and stucco tri-level house in Malviera da Serra, Portugal.
Properties on the market in Florida, Utah and Pennsylvania.
The most important thing the next president must do is prevent terrorist groups from executing a nuclear attack in America. Which candidate will deter an attack?

Congress should resist the pressure from the Bush administration to approve a nuclear deal with India.

You could argue which team looked the best on Sunday; you could argue which team had the most surprising loss or win. (And feel free to argue those things, nicely, in comments.) But there can't be much debate about which team looked the worst.
The movie “Kicking It” chronicles the Homeless World Cup through the eyes of seven players in the competition.
One of the leaders in the new field of consumer genetic information, is expected to announce on Tuesday that it is cutting the price of its service deeply, to $399, down from $999.
In the wake of Diane Greene’s departure, three other key executives have left, and competitors are readying fresh assaults on VMware’s dominant position in the virtualization software market.
Pakistan plans to sell valuable energy assets, beginning with a major gas field, as it tries to reap billions of dollars from deals with investors in industries like banking and farming.

Under pressure from regulators, policymakers and privacy advocates around the world, Google said late Monday that it would further tighten its data retention policy. In its official blog, the company said it would "anonymize" search records after 9 months, rather than the current 18 months.
Big technology companies are seeing their prized customers in the financial services sector pull way back on existing and new I.T. projects, according to recent data issued by Forrester Research.

The Abroad column on Monday, about an exhibition of the work of the caricaturist Arthur Szyk at a museum in Berlin, rendered part of the museum’s name incorrectly. It is the Deutsches Historisches Museum, not the Deutsche Historisches Museum. The error also appeared in an accompanying picture caption.

An article on Monday about the potential winners and losers among investors after the federal rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac erroneously included one major Wall Street investor on a list of value-oriented money managers who invested in the mortgage companies. The investor, Martin Whitman, of Third Avenue Management, has made large investments in other distressed financials, including MBIA and Ambac, but his fund does not own shares of Freddie or Fannie. The article also misstated the date that the contract of Richard F. Syron, the chief executive of Freddie Mac, was extended and amended to increase his potential severance package. It was November 2007, not July 2008.

An obituary on Friday about the financial writer Michael Hammer, using information from a family spokesman, misstated his middle name and misidentified his father’s profession. It was Martin, not Gartner, and his father was a cantor, not a rabbi.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the major role of music in some films at the Toronto International Film Festival misidentified the member of U2 who is featured in “It Might Get Loud,” a documentary about the electric guitar. He is the Edge, not Bono.

An article in some copies on Monday about Serena Williams’s United States Open championship misstated the name of a recent HBO documentary that included her among its portraits of fascinating and influential black Americans. It is “The Black List,” not “The Color List.”.

An article on Saturday about contestants on the Bravo reality show “Top Design” gathering to watch the second-season premiere referred incorrectly to the business owned by Ondine Karady, a contestant. It is a boutique interior design studio, not a boutique.
This list summarizes our recommendations for some of the most contested races in the Democratic primary election today.

Polls for Tuesday’s primary election open at 6 a.m. and close at 9 p.m. in New York City and in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam and Erie Counties. In all other counties the polls open at noon and close at 9 p.m.
BUSINESS DAY.

FREDDIE'S AND FANNIE'S FUTURE What will the two mortgage financing giants look like in the future? Three camps are forming in what will be a major battle in the next Congress. MR. The older a man is, the more likely he is to father children who develop bipolar disorder as adults, a large Swedish study reports. Previous studies have found an association between paternal age and both autism and schizophrenia, but this is the first time a connection with bipolar illness has been suggested. The study appears in the September issue of The Archives of General Psychiatry.

KOHN--Henry . The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn with a heavy heart the passing of Henry Kohn, past president and our beloved Board member of 40 years. Henry's warmth, care, generosity and humanity will long be remembered. The loss of Henry's deep devotion to the Jewish community and the world-at-large will be felt for many years. Henry shared with the world the importance of giving back, an admirable and essential legacy. Our hearts and prayers are with his family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Fredric Mack, President Michael Goldstein, Chair Sol Adler, Executive Director KOHN--Henry. The Board of Directors of the American Jewish Society for Service mourns the passing of its founder and longtime leader, Henry Kohn. It was Henry's vision that established the AJSS in 1951 to provide an opportunity for Jewish teenagers to work in underprivileged communities throughout the U.S. and put their Jewish values into action to serve others. To date AJSS has sent close to 2500 volunteers to more than 140 communities making lasting contributions to the betterment of society. The Board expresses its deepest sympathy to Henry's family. May his life's work and a life well lived be a blessing and a comfort to us all. Board of Directors, AJSS Lawrence G. Green, Chair Rena Convissor, Executive Director KOHN--Henry. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with deep sadness the passing of Henry Kohn, whose longstanding generosity strengthened our ability to care for those in need. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Kohn family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Hurricane Ike hit eastern Cuba on Monday, causing damage in the city of Holguín, near right, while Cubans sought refuge in temporary shelters across the island, above. SIFFERT--Miriam Sand , 90, passed away peacefully in her home in New York City on September 7, 2008. She was the beloved wife of Dr. Robert S. Siffert for 67 years, loving mother of Joan Siffert and John Siffert, mother-inlaw of Goldie Alfasi-Siffert and grandmother of Molly Kochan Ouanes (Alexx), David Siffert and Matthew Siffert. Mrs. Siffert was born and educated in Brooklyn at James Madison High School, where she met and then later married her high school sweetheart, Robert S. Siffert, M.D., former Chairman of the Department of Orthopedics at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. She went on to attend Brooklyn College, while actively taking part in the American Student Union and World Youth Congress. She worked as assistant to Dr. Alvin Johnson, the first President of the New School. Miriam later served on the Board and as Chair of both the Wiltwyck School for Dependent and Neglected Children and the Hillcrest Center for Children in Bedford, New York. She dedicated much of her life to the work of Citizens' Committee for Children, where she served on the Board as Vice President, Treasurer, and Honorary Member. She received the first Eleanor Roosevelt Award for her contribution to the creation of the Leadership Institute at CCC. Mimi also served on the Board of The Hudson River Museum. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Services will be private. Donations in memory of Miriam Siffert may be made to Citizens' Committee for Children at 105 E. 22nd St., NYC 10010.

GOLDEN--Helen Kross, Ph.D. , at age 80, on September 6, 2008, after a long battle with lung cancer. Beloved and devoted wife of 55 years of the late Howard N. Golden. Loving mother of Eve, Jonathan, and David, and devoted mother-in-law of Ellen Golden and Kenneth Kronenberg. Adoring grandmother of Sarah and Daniel. Loving sister of the late Alice K. Frankel, M.D. and aunt of Anita, Jane, David, Ellen, Mara, and Eleanor. A strong and elegant woman of impeccable style, beauty, and warmth, Helen trained first as a clinical psychologist and then as a psychoanalyst. She was instrumental in the struggle to open psychoanalysis to nonM.D.s. She was honored last year for her lifetime contribution to the Westchester Center for the Study of Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy. She will be greatly missed by the many whose lives she touched. The family will receive friends and colleagues from 1pm to 7pm on Friday, September 12, 2008 at 19 Mayhew Avenue, Larchmont, NY. We will gather to share memories of Helen's life at 4pm. Donations in Helen's memory may be made to Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care, Development Dept, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

WELCH--Stuart Cary . The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art deeply mourn the loss of colleague and friend Stuart Cary Welch, who served as special consultant to the Department of Islamic Art from 1979 to 1987. He helped nurture the collection--considered the most comprehensive permanent installation of Islamic art on view in the world--during a period of rapid growth. Concurrent with his work at the Metropolitan, he held various curatorial and teaching positions at Harvard University. A pioneer in the study of Indian and Islamic art, he was also a groundbreaking scholar, passionate collector, and connoisseur of great discernment, who influenced countless students, many of whom now hold leadership positions in American museums. We extend condolences to his entire family. Philippe de Montebello, Dir.

Don Haskins, the Hall of Fame coach who helped change the face of college basketball when he started five black players on his Texas Western team, which went on to defeat an all-white University of Kentucky squad for the 1966 N.C.A.A. championship, died Sunday in El Paso. He was 78. The cause was congestive heart failure, Haskins's physician, Dr. Dwayne Aboud, told The El Paso Times.

Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell on September 10 at 11:30am. 1076 Madison Avenue.

SIFFERT--Miriam . The Board of Directors and Staff of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourn the passing of Miriam Siffert and extend our condolences to her family, friends and the colleagues who share our deep respect for her lifelong commitment to child advocacy. Mrs. Siffert was involved in CCC as a volunteer since 1949; became a Board Member in 1956; Honorary Director in 1995; and received the Eleanor Roosevelt Award in 1997. In 1961 she played a key role in instituting the CCC Community Leadership Course, an experiential training program that has graduated over a thousand New Yorkers. Mimi was a fearless and tenacious advocate and friend who met every challenge head-on with her trademark sense of humor. She never stopped believing in the importance of making NYC a better place for all children and families. She will be greatly missed. Maryann Marston, Chairman Marcy Sandler, President Jennifer March-Joly, Executive Director SIFFERT--Miriam. May your memories be an everlasting source of comfort. President Bush has accepted the recommendation of his senior civilian and military advisers to reduce the number of American troops in Iraq by 8,000 in the early months of next year. AVERILL--William J. , age 95, of Hampton, NJ died Wednesday, September 10, 2008. Bill was born March 15, 1913 in Brooklyn, NY. He retired as a Deputy Chief Inspector from the NYPD. Contact Martin Funeral Home in Clinton, NJ at 908-735-7180 or www.martinfh.com for Service Information.

MILLS--Warren Edward , died peacefully at home after a courageous battle with cancer on September 3, 2008 in New Port Richey, FL. He was born in New York City on April 7, 1941. Always the ambitious person, Warren started his career at Washington and Lee University with a degree in accounting and began working with the Wasserman & Tate accounting firm. He then went on to become controller at Hugo P. Keller and then onto President of General Ruby in 1974. Throughout his long career he strived to become the best at what he does, and earned his MBA at Hofstra University in 1974, his CPA in 1968 and Law Degree at New York University in 1977. He was a member of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Maria Parascandolo Mills, and 3 sons; Edward, Foy and Joseph. He was also the honorary father to Teddy Moustakopulos and Paula Bamis. He will be missed by relatives, friends and many others. Funeral services will be held in New Port Richey, FL on September 9, 2008 at North / Meadowlawn Funeral Home (727)8498281.

MURPHY--Dr. Austin S. , of Rye, NY passed away on September 9, 2008. He was an economist, educator and banker. Born in New York, on November 20, 1917, the son of Daniel J. Murphy and Marie Austin Murphy. He received his BA, St. Francis College in Brooklyn in 1938, MA (Hayden fellow 1938-1940) Fordham University 1940 Ph.D. He was an instructor at Canisius College 1986, Fordham University 1938-1941, economics instructor Georgetown University 1941-1942, Fordham University School of Education 1946-1955, dean of school of business administration Seton Hall University 1950-1955, dean of school of business administration Canisius College Buffalo 1955-1962. Chairman and President of River Bank America, (formerly East River Savings Bank) 1970-1989. He was married to the former Mary Patricia Halpin who predeceased him in May 1974. He remarried the former Lee Chilton Romero who also predeceased him in February 2007. He is survived by his children Austin Joseph and Owen Gerard, his grandchildren Rachel, Gerrit and Lizzie Murphy, Tessa and Katie Romero. Friends may call at the Graham Funeral Home on Friday from 2-4 to 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday at Resurrection Church 10am.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc. and Young Judaea, The Zionist youth movement of Hadassah, expresses its deepest sorrow at the passing of Professor David Diamond, beloved husband of Shelley Sherman, Hadassah National Board member, loving father of Daniel and Hannah. David was devoted to his family, and carried this passion to his work as a Professor of Law at Hofstra University, teaching both procedure and trial practice in areas concerned with families and children. Prior to Hofstra School of Law, Professor Diamond taught at Syracuse Law School and had been an associate at Hughes, Hubbard and Reed in New York. David and Shelley were dedicated supporters of Zionism, Israel and Young Judaea. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his loved ones. May his memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Nancy Falchuk, National President Morlie Levin, National Executive Director Rabbi Ramie Arian, National Director Young Judaea

When Lehman Brothers officially unveiled its “bad bank” strategy on Wednesday, the investment bank’s rationale was that spinning off $25 billion to $35 billion worth of commercial mortgages would protect the firm’s good assets.

Lehman Brothers‘ surprise conference call Wednesday morning, in which the firm confirmed that it was spinning off parts of the company and posting a big loss for the fiscal third quarter, seemed to leave analysts less than satisfied. The steps that Lehman is taking to reduce its exposure to risky assets lacked many specifics, inducing a deluge of questions on subjects including tax considerations and employee morale.

I’ve been teaching in Fairbanks, Alaska’s second largest city, for 25 years. I moved here in my late 20’s after dropping out of college and working a long series of seasonal jobs, one of which was as a farm laborer in a Wenatchee, Wash., apple orchard. I met a Mexican family there, kids and all, living in their car as the October weather grew colder, with fewer hours to work each day. I realized that my educational background, truncated though it was, gave me a foundation I could build on to secure my future in ways that people with less schooling might never pull off. I decided then that I should be a teacher, and maybe spread the wealth a little farther and wider.

There are a couple of interesting (and very different) developments related to China:Raised Earthquake Risk The devastating earthquake that shattered a wide swath of Sichuan Province on May 12 has significantly increased the likelihood of big quakes on nearby faults. In a paper calculating new Chinese earthquake risks in Geophysical Research Letters, a team led by Japanese and American geophysicists analyzed shifts in stress along several faults around the area where a magnitude 7.9 temblor killed nearly 70,000 people and drew rare citizen protests because so many schools crumbled. The scientists found substantial increases along the surrounding strike-slip faults, in which abutting plates in the earth's crust -- as in the San Andreas fault -- get stuck and can generate destructive shaking when they lurch free. Over all, the scientists say there is now a 57 to 71 percent chance of a temblor of magnitude 6 or greater within a decade, and about a one-in-four chance of a quake greater than 7.0 within 30 years.

Ironically, the relatively peaceful, mixed election outcomes in Angolalook pretty promising, when set against the disturbingly violent anddestabilizing outcomes seen in the last year in Zimbabwe and Kenya, andnot so long ago in Nigeria and Ethiopia. When elections were lastattempted in Angola in 1992, the results were a shock and a disaster.Razor-thin margins, in a winner-take-all competition, led the losingside -- UNITA, led by its president Jonas Savimbi -- to plunge Angolaback into a war that swiftly reignited violence across the country. Thistime around, there was never any serious question of the ruling MPLA'sability to win decisively, and never any question that UNITA wouldacquiesce to defeat but still retain a foothold in the political system.Angola today, by comparison with other African countries, appears farbetter able to navigate electoral tests. It is beginning to look like anormal country, which is something Angola's leaders have aspired toachieve since Savimbi was killed in February 2002.

I've always been a fan of Alain de Botton's "How Proust Can Change Your Life" - beginning with the title. De Botton was out to de-monumentalize Proust, to bring him down to earth, make him accessible in a human way. If your reason for reading Proust was because he's there, like Everest, and you wanted to be able to say you had climbed one of culture's tallest mountains, then, de Botton suggests, you probably shouldn't bother. You can no doubt find more productive ways to spend your time. "In Search of Lost Time" is among other things a catalog of snobbery, but one snob Proust never encountered is the person who pridefully announces that he has finished Proust.

The Washington Post has an interesting article on a global forecast being drafted by the intelligence agencies for the next president (and presumably vice president). In a world of declining American influence, according to the article, the assessment foresees unavoidable social disruption, particularly in developing countries, from the effects of climate shifts driven by accumulating greenhouse gases. The imbalance of impacts from climate extremes was the focus of our "Climate Divide" series last year. The wealthy world is already insulating itself from such hazards with its wealth and technology, and emissions associated with building that wealth are likely to add to stresses in the poor world.

Robot developers fall into two camps: those trying to make their machines as anthropomorphic as possible and those favoring sheer utility. Humanoids may be a better sell, research shows. Move over, Roomba; make way for "Einstein." [Economist]

Fisker Automotive, a maker of electric sports cars, said it received an additional $65 million in funding, led by the Qatar Investment Authority.

Dan Johnson was sleeping in a hotel room in Scranton, Pa., when his phone rang at about 9 a.m. on Tuesday. Johnson, who was playing for Class AAA Durham, was told that the Tampa Bay Rays had recalled him and that he needed to get on a 12:45 P.M. flight to Boston. The Rays and Red Sox were playing on Tuesday night.

Merger talks between Britain's Tullett Prebon and U.S. rival GFI Group to create one of largest global interdealer brokers fell apart on Tuesday, as both companies announced they had been unable to agree on terms of the deal.

Deloitte confirmed that it dismissed about 800 professionals and staff in the United States, amid speculation that the Big Four accounting firms are cutting back because of the slowing economy and relaxed compliance rules.

RAB Capital, which recently removed its chief executive from his post, announced Wednesday that it wanted to freeze redemptions in an effort to restructure its flagship hedge fund, which has plunged in value by nearly half this year, with a 22 percent drop in August alone.
Stocks tumbled Tuesday after fresh concerns about the stability of Lehman Brothers touched off renewed jitters about the overall financial sector.
After Bear Stearns was taken over by JPMorgan Chase in a government-brokered deal, there was much speculation about where the bank's former chieftain, Alan D. Schwartz, would end up.

Environment | There's a conservative case for going green, even without embracing the left's view of global warming, an article argues. Is suburban sprawl the American dream? Some Republicans doubt it: "fiscal conservatism and localism, both key to Republican ideology, can be better realized through population-dense development." [American Prospect]
Former New York Govenor George Pataki has joined the executive board of MidOcean Partners, a private-equity firm run by a one-time Deutsche Bank executive, Ted Virtue.

The Echo Nest, an enhanced music Web site, said it has raised first round of financing, which was led by Commonwealth Capital Ventures. The amount raised in the round, which also included with participation from angel investors, was not disclosed.
From Joe Nocera at Executive Suite:

The Giants and the Jets face moral and public-relations questions as they negotiate the possible sale of the naming rights to their new stadium with Allianz, a Munich-based insurer and financial services company with disturbing connections to Nazi Germany, The New York Times's Richard Sandomir reports.

Shares of American International Group, the world's biggest insurer, fell 16 percent on Tuesday on fears that the company's large exposure to the mortgage markets could trigger the need to raise fresh capital.

The government's takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, The New York Times's Eric Dash writes, is training a spotlight on a part of American financial system that rarely gets much attention: the vast network of federal agencies and quasi-governmental lenders that helps keep credit flowing through the economy.

Senator Barack Obama and two other prominent Democrats urged federal housing regulators on Tuesday to cut the golden parachutes of the ousted leaders of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, another sign that the government bailout of those mortgage giants could reverberate through the presidential campaign, The New York Times's Eric Dash reported.
The United States' current reliance on foreign governments for financing represents a strategic vulnerability, according to a report by the Council of Foreign Relations released on Tuesday.
Lawyers for investors in Enron will get $688 million in fees for recovering more than $7.2 billion from its lenders, auditors and directors, a judge ruled.

Bear Stearns and its mortgage servicing unit agreed to pay $28 million to settle federal charges it had deceived subprime borrowers and had engaged in abusive loan practices before the investment bank's collapse.
Russian investigators raided the Moscow offices of Rupert Murdoch's outdoor advertising firm, News Outdoor, the largest in Russia, the company said.

Education | Can poetry incite violence? Some in Britain think so. That's why "Education for Leisure" by Carol Ann Duffy -- which begins with, "Today I am going to kill something" and alludes to knifeplay -- has been banned from secondary schools. Poets and educators are up in arms. But there's been a spate of knife crimes; people are on edge. [Guardian, Brainiac]

As fears of further bank failures continue to rock the markets, Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has told one of its units to stop insuring bank deposits above the amount guaranteed by the U.S. federal government, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The Coca-Cola Company plans to seek approval under China's antitrust law for its $2.5 billion bid for top domestic juice-maker China Huiyuan Juice Group, the final obstacle to what would be the largest foreign takeover of a local firm, Huiyuan said on Wednesday.
British insurer Old Mutual said on Wednesday Chief Executive Jim Sutcliffe would resign with immediate effect, and would be replaced by Julian Roberts, the former head of Skandia.

Unable to earn her tour card through sponsor exemptions, Michelle Wie has entered the L.P.G.A. Tour qualifying school. The first stage will be at Mission Hills in Rancho Mirage, Calif., site of the Kraft Nabisco Championship, where Wie played in the final group of the L.P.G.A.’s first major when she was in the eighth grade.

The Hall of Fame jockey Braulio Baeza and the former racing official Mario Sclafani filed a $100 million civil suit against former Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the New York Racing Association and several others. The suit, filed in United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, claims the defendants participated in a conspiracy to violate the civil rights of Baeza and Sclafani and includes accusations of false arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, defamation and a conspiracy in violation of constitutional rights. Baeza and Sclafani were racing officials working in the jockeys’ quarters at Belmont Park when they were arrested Sept. 21, 2005, and charged with falsely reporting the weights of several riders and, therefore, defrauding the betting public. The case was thrown out in September 2007. ¶A sluggish market continued through the second session of Keeneland’s September yearling sale, with fewer horses than usual fetching high prices. For the second consecutive day, a sheik paid the session’s high price for a yearling by the leading sire A. P. Indy. Sheik Hamdan bin Rashid al Maktoum’s Shadwell Stable spent the session’s high of $1.5 million for a bay colt out of Taegu. A day earlier, his brother, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al Maktoum — the ruler of Dubai — spent $3.1 million on a filly, also by A. P. Indy.keeneland (AP).

Evan Tanner, an Ultimate Fighting Championship star, was found dead in the desert east of San Diego, possibly a victim of heat exposure. Sheriff’s Lt. George Moreno said Tanner, 37, was found Monday about two miles from his campsite in the Palo Verdes Mountains, where temperatures reached 110 degrees.Spike.com.

Unable to earn her card through sponsor exemptions, Michelle Wie has entered the L.P.G.A. Tour qualifying school and will play the first stage next week on the California course where she first rose to fame at 13. Her father, B. J. Wie, had said at the United States Women’s Open that Wie had “no other options” but Q-school if she did not make enough money to finish the equivalent of 80th on the L.P.G.A. Tour money list. The first stage will be at Mission Hills in Rancho Mirage, Calif., site of the Kraft Nabisco Championship, where Wie played in the final group of the L.P.G.A.’s first major when she was in the eighth grade.

The former Liberty star Becky Hammon scored 23 of her season-high 30 points in the second half to lead the visiting San Antonio Silver Stars to an 82-76 victory against her former W.N.B.A. team. Shameka Christon and Jessica Davenport scored 15 points each for the Liberty (18-13).

Africa | Tensions over Africa's now highly valued farmland: Western companies seek vast stretches to meet the world's biofuel needs, and are making lots of promises to the locals. Is this another form of economic colonialism? On the other hand, are green do-gooders holding Africa back by promoting traditional farming? [Spiegel, Times of London]

And that seems like a good excuse to review the nooks and crannies of the bike racing legend's home in Texas, courtesy of a recent feature in Architectural Digest.

Society | A book excerpt describes the "Peter Pan mindset" typical of males between 16 and 26 - more than 15 percent of the total American male population. "Guyland" is a stage of life "between adolescence and adulthood that can often stretch for a decade or more." Women compete with them in the workplace, and these guys get drunk and post porn. [New York Post]

Energy | Amory Lovins, the eco-comeback kid. For years a "lonely voice in the wilderness" in pleading for resource efficiency, he has been "proved right" by history. But he's worried that, like in the 1970s, efficiency will bring down oil prices and wipe out gains in alternatives. [Economist]

Derek Jeter tied Babe Ruth in championships with the Yankees back in 2000, when he won his fourth World Series ring. For all of Ruth's greatness, he led the Yankees to only four titles (1923, 1927, 1928 and 1932) -- as many as Jeter.
