An article on Aug. 18 about the boom in American exports described those exports imprecisely. Commodities exports can include items like flour and beverages and industrial supplies like chemicals, metals and paperboard; they are not limited to raw materials like grains and ores.

An article on Friday about administrative changes at some of the 52 New York City schools that received a grade of F on their first report cards last fall misidentified the Manhattan neighborhood that includes the Muscota School, one of those named as failing. It is in Inwood, not Washington Heights.

An article on Tuesday about the New Museum of Contemporary Art’s acquisition of an adjacent building on the Bowery misstated the number of stories in that building. As an accompanying picture showed, it has six stories, not five.

An article on Saturday about the variety of fashion choices made by New York City’s judges misstated the title once held by two former United States Supreme Court justices — John Jay, who was often pictured wearing a scarlet and black robe with silver trim, and John Marshall, who departed from tradition by wearing a plain silk black robe. They were chief justices of the United States — there is no such title as chief justice of the Supreme Court.

The Findings column on Tuesday, about gender gaps, misidentified the educational affiliation of Robert Deaner, a psychologist who analyzed competitive runners. He is at Grand Valley State University, in Michigan — not Colgate University, where he received his bachelor’s degree.

An article on Monday about a four-story brownstone that is the first Manhattan outpost for the City University of New York’s Macaulay Honors College, whose 1,300 students are spread across 7 of the 22 other CUNY institutions, misspelled the surname of the Honors College dean at one point. She is Ann Kirschner, not Kirchner.

A report in the Bats baseball notebook on Sunday about the Colorado Rockies, who have been playing better baseball after a terrible start this season, misstated the number of games the team won late last season to force a one-game playoff with the San Diego Padres for a National League postseason berth. It was 13 of 14 — not 14 of 15.

A picture caption on Tuesday with the DealBook column, about Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr.’s decision to use his authority to order a federal rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, misidentified the agency of James Lockhart, shown accompanying Mr. Paulson to a news conference on Sunday. Mr. Lockhart is with the Federal Housing Finance Agency, not the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight. (He was director of the oversight office until it was merged with another housing program in July to create the Federal Housing Finance Agency.).

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the actor Viggo Mortensen’s apology to Canadians for saying “in this country” when he was criticizing American political leaders in a panel discussion at the Toronto International Film Festival misspelled the given name of the festival’s documentary programmer, who moderated the discussion. He is Thom Powers, not Tom.

Republicans swarmed Senator Joseph I. Lieberman after he cast his lot with Senator John McCain at the Republican convention, but Democrats all but ignored their former vice-presidential nominee.

The federal government will run a deficit of $407 billion this fiscal year, according to the latest Capitol Hill estimates. The Congressional Budget Office also predicted that the deficit would reach a record $438 billion in the next fiscal year, and could go even higher if Congress adjusts the alternative minimum tax and the government takes over the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The budget office figures for this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, are slightly worse than the White House predictions released in July. The White House foresees a $389 billion deficit for 2008, growing to $482 billion in 2009.
Texas Instruments said that earnings and revenue for the current quarter were on track, sending shares up 6 percent.
The bill would make it harder to protect federal workers, residents and the president, city and federal officials said Tuesday at a House oversight hearing.
Shopping mall owners are facing mounting challenges these days as a growing number of established chains have filed for bankruptcy protection and others are scaling back.

A judge has ruled that the mass murderer George Banks was too mentally ill to be executed. Mr. Banks killed 13 people in a 1982 shooting rampage in northeastern Pennsylvania. Five of the victims were his own children. Judge Michael Conahan ruled Monday that he agreed with defense lawyers that Mr. Banks was psychotic and unable to comprehend his death sentence or participate in his defense.
The Nationals overcame deficits of two and three runs but were not able to contain Carlos Delgado, who hit two homers for the second consecutive game.
A conspiracy to cover up the intended recipient of a suitcase filled with $800,000 in cash found in Argentina last year reached the highest levels of Venezuela’s government.
A Democratic county election commissioner sued the state’s Republican governor for putting the special election for Trent Lott’s Senate seat near the bottom of this fall’s ballot.
FedEx said it would report a profit of $1.23 a share for the quarter ended Aug. 31, beating its forecast as fuel costs fell.

In a peaceful end to a treetop standoff, four protesters descended from a redwood at the University at California, Berkeley, after 21 months of occupying a contested campus grove. Protesters had hoped to stop the construction of a $124 million athletic center, but a court order blocking the construction had recently been lifted. A final protester, wearing a backpack and waving to a large crowd on onlookers below, crawled down from a rickety crow’s nest just hours after campus workers erected a scaffolding around one of the grove’s two remaining trees. All four tree-sitters were arrested, though campus officials said no felony charges were expected to be filed. Dan Mogulof, a university spokesman, expressed relief that the lengthy protest was over. “We look forward to beginning construction,” he said.

Hurricane Gustav caused an estimated $372 million in crop damage, dumping as many as 20 inches of rain, agriculture officials said. The storm also caused crawfish and catfish ponds to overflow, causing an estimated $46 million in damages to fisheries, according to estimates by the Louisiana State University AgCenter. Among hardest-hit crops were cotton, sweet potatoes, soybeans and sugar cane. More than 47 percent of the cotton crop is estimated to be destroyed, a $112 million loss in what was expected to be a $237 million crop.
Senator John McCain’s daughter Meghan is on a tear of television and radio appearances this week to publicize her children’s book, but like Gov. Sarah Palin, she is largely avoiding the print press.
Barack Obama is going after John McCain more aggressively than at any other point in the campaign, with a professorial tone giving way to one of prosecution.

The hiring of a veteran antitrust lawyer represents the clearest indication that the Justice Department could be planning to mount a legal challenge to the deal, some analysts said.

COLLINS--John Joseph, formerly of Roslyn Harbor, NY, and Highland Beach, Fl, passed away Mars, PA, September 6, 2008, age 86. Loving husband of the late Phyllis Reed Collins & brother of the late Jean A. Robinson. Beloved father of Priscilla Collins (Dr. Kevin Robert) O'Hara of Wexford, PA, & Cynthia Collins Peters of Slingerlands, NY. Grand ''Furrie'' to Catherine, Kimberly, & Marguerite O'Hara and Carolyn Peters. Uncle Jack to Jill Anne, Jeffrey, and James Robinson. Graduated from the US Naval Academy (1946). Jack worked for NY Telephone Co. for 38 years rising to Exec. GUILDERLAND--Roman S. (Ray) Lapinski, 86 died Monday, September 8 at home. Born in Middle Village, Queens NY, the son of two Polish immigrants. The first in his family to go to college, he attended St. John's University. Afterwards he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and served as a 2nd Lieutenant as a navigator on B-29 airplanes. His service included flying missions over Japan and the South Pacific in the final year of WWII. He returned home and married Blanche (Bronislas) Lipko in 1947 and raised 4 children with her. He took great pride in all of his children and grandchildren and used every opportunity to brag about their accomplishments. Ray loved his family and spent much of his life dedicated to being a caring and nurturing dad and grandpa. He was active in the Polish community of New York City his whole life, including being a member of the first NYC Pulaski Day Parade Committee and being named Citizen of the Year by the Polish American World in 1979. He spent much of his working career in public service and most of it at the NYS Liquor Authority where he served as a Deputy Commissioner from 1959 until his retirement in 1983. For over 40 years he served as a director and then Chair of the Board of the Atlas Savings and Loan Association in Brooklyn NY. The family invites relatives and friends to attend his funeral 10am at St. John's St. Ann's Church of Albany, New York where the Liturgy of Christian Death and Burial will be celebrated. Friends may call in the funeral home on Thursday from 5-8pm. An interment ceremony will take place at Calvary Cemetery, 4902 Laurel Hill Blvd, Flushing, NY on Saturday, September 13 at 11am with a luncheon to follow. (Please call Rockefeller for details.) In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Community Hospice of Albany County, 445 New Karner Road, Albany, NY 12205.

Merrill Lynch & Company is expected to announce on Wednesday that it has hired George H. Young III, a veteran Wall Street banker, to run its technology, media and telecommunications investment banking practice. Mr. Young, known as Woody, had previously led the communications group at Lehman Brothers, and was that firm's biggest rainmaker. He advised AT&T, Verizon and Sprint on some of their biggest deals during the wave of telecommunication mergers that swept that industry over the last decade.

At the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, they call it ''the Hawk,'' driving buses from 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. The yardmaster juggling maintenance schedules for Metro-North trains refers to it as ''the Trick,'' as in, ''Night Trick.'' It is known nearly universally as the third shift -- third chronologically, and most people's third choice. The guy hosing down Dumpsters, the busboy at the all-night diner, the vendor hawking hot dogs as the bars close in the meatpacking district: They work midnights because, well, at least it's work. But others, part vampire, perhaps, prefer the wee hours. No bosses around. No office politics. The air a little lighter, the light, when it comes, a little brighter. Alone with the work, alone except for Champaine, the night disc jockey at WBLS, who talks to everyone else out there who works when much of the city that never sleeps is sleeping.

GOLDEN--Helen Kross, Ph.D., at age 80, on September 6, 2008, after a long battle with lung cancer. Beloved and devoted wife of 55 years of the late Howard N. Golden. Loving mother of Eve, Jonathan, and David, and devoted mother-in-law of Ellen Golden and Kenneth Kronenberg. Adoring grandmother of Sarah and Daniel. Loving sister of the late Alice K. Frankel, M.D. and aunt of Anita, Jane, David, Ellen, Mara, and Eleanor. A strong and elegant woman of impeccable style, beauty, and warmth, Helen trained first as a clinical psychologist and then as a psychoanalyst. She was instrumental in the struggle to open psychoanalysis to nonM.D.s. She was honored last year for her lifetime contribution to the Westchester Center for the Study of Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy. She will be greatly missed by the many whose lives she touched. The family will receive friends and colleagues from 1pm to 7pm on Friday, September 12, 2008 at 19 Mayhew Avenue, Larchmont, NY. We will gather to share memories of Helen's life at 4pm. Donations in Helen's memory may be made to Jansen Hospice and Palliative Care, Development Dept, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

PAUL--Jean Lithgow. The family mourns the death of their beloved mother and grandmother on September 7, 2008, in Westwood, MA, at age 89. Born on October 4, 1918, she was the daughter of Leslie and Kate Lithgow of New York City. She attended the Brearley School and Vassar College. In June 1940 she married Rev. James A. Paul, who took up the post of vicar (later rector) of The Church of the Holy Trinity (Episcopal) in New York. After the untimely death of her husband in 1957, she raised her three children, served as President of the Ladies' Christian Union and continued to be active in the Episcopal Church. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and spent many summers in Wianno on Cape Cod. In January 1981 she married Dr. Oglesby Paul (no relation to her first husband). He was then Professor of Cardiology and Dean of Admissions at the Harvard Medical School. They lived in Dedham, Massachusetts, and later at Fox Hill Village in nearby Westwood. Dr. Paul died December 22, 2007. She had a wide circle of cherished friends with whom she kept in close touch. She leaves three children and their spouses, James and Susanne Paul, Douglas and Elizabeth Paul, and Patricia and John Olive (of New York City), as well as two stepchildren and spouse, Rodman and Roberta Paul and Marguerite Paul (of Atlanta). She also leaves four grandchildren, Timothy and Jonathan Paul, Nicholas Paul and Elizabeth Olive and two step - grandchildren, David and Andrew Paul. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Dedham. A memorial service will be announced later.

Haiti has been hit by four heavy storms in less than a month, and Port-de-Paix, above, remained flooded on Tuesday. The storms have killed more than 300 people in Haiti. The region's latest, Hurricane Ike, has killed at least 80 people, including 4 in Cuba.

In a peaceful end to a treetop standoff, four protesters descended from a redwood at the University at California, Berkeley, after 21 months in a contested campus grove. Protesters had hoped to stop the construction of a $124 million athletic center, but a court order blocking the construction had recently been lifted. A final protester, wearing a backpack and waving to a large crowd on onlookers below, crawled down from a rickety crow's nest just hours after campus workers erected a scaffolding around one of the grove's two remaining trees. All four tree-sitters were arrested, though campus officials said no felony charges were expected to be filed. Dan Mogulof, a university spokesman, expressed relief that the lengthy protest was over. ''We look forward to beginning construction,'' he said. The tree was cut down late Tuesday.

KATZ--Jerome, 80 years old, died on September 9th, 2008. Beloved and devoted husband of Doris Katz. Loving father of Andrea Katz and Susan Chin, and Patricia Katz and Eileen Birns. Cherished grandfather of Harrison Katz. Devoted and giving brother of Melvin Katz and his wife Judy. Loving uncle of Melissa Katz Kane, John Katz, Steve Sackin, Ken Sackin, and Nancy Oiler and brother-in-law of Marjorie Sackin. Services Wednesday, 12 noon at ''Riverside - Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

GERST-KATZ--Carole, nee Granat, 67, on July 28, 2008. Today would have been her 68th birthday. Carole was an accomplished artist and Administrative Assistant at Small Property Owners of New York (S.P.O.N.Y.). Although Carole's special gifts of color and design grace countless homes and offices, her art is but a small portion of her legacy. Though blessed with beauty, talent, and style, she was never filled with herself. Polite, considerate, devoted to family, and fiercely loyal, she would never gossip or betray a confidence. One could not have a better or more thoughtful friend. And yet Carole was playful, with a keen sense of humor, marvelous laugh and beguiling charm. She was also strong, with a determination and courage that let a younger Carole overcome obstacles that most young mothers would have found insurmountable. Raising two little girls on her own, she built a career as an artist that provided the secure home her children needed to become successful and independent adults. Because Carole never dwelt in the past, her friends of later years had no inkling of how hard she had battled. And that was the way Carole wanted it. She was always positive, looking forward, never back. Carole always intended the world to see her at her best, and succeeded, even to the very end when cancer began to overpower her. Deeply loved by family and friends, Carole had all the virtues and more. She will remain treasured in our hearts forever.
BEDDARD--Anita. We miss, honor and love you every day. Michael, Fred and Devon

PATRIOTS MOVE ON WITH CASSEL The Patriots, sifting through their quarterback options after Tom Brady's season-ending knee injury, sent the free agents Chris Simms and Tim Rattay home Monday without working them out, Coach Bill Belichick said. That means the Patriots will prepare for the Jets with Matt Cassel, who last started in high school, as their No. 1 quarterback and the rookie Kevin O'Connell as their backup.

He served the Five Towns area for 34 years as an OB/GYN and was loved by his patients and colleagues.

Lehman Brothers’ chairman and chief executive, Richard S. Fuld Jr., has stepped up efforts in the last 24 hours to sell the investment bank, as confidence in the firm has spiraled downward, taking its stock along with it

Lehman Brothers is having a tough time convincing the public markets that it can survive the credit crunch. Shares of the investment bank were down about 40 percent Thursday morning, after analysts gave lukewarm reviews to its turnaround plan.

So far, Richard S. Fuld Jr. has avoided the fate of E. Stanley O’Neal and Charles O. Prince III, two other Wall Street chiefs shown the door after their firms posted huge losses. But as shares of Lehman Brothers continued to swoon on Thursday, it was clearly a make-or-break moment in his long tenure as Lehman’s chief.
Richard S. Fuld Jr. may have hoped that Wednesday’s conference call would stem the sell-off in Lehman Brothers‘ stock, but Wall Street is still running scared.

For the first time in my six-year teaching career, I am not completely freaked out by going back to school. I have, however, more than paid my dues to reach this stage of teacher emotional stability. In my first year of teaching, I freaked out not only in September, but pretty much every day (and well into every night) of the school year. At the time, I taught teenagers with learning disabilities in the South Bronx, including many emotionally disturbed students. I somehow managed to stick it out, and the next year, I met a Bronx teenager who would change my life and set me on my current career path.

Fascinating, ambitious Calvin Klein show this afternoon from Francisco Costa. Done predominately in shades of white with silver and crystal accents, it was based on a cube and prism shapes. Fabrics looked technical and were hard to identify without the press notes. Such as: "A talc brushed latex hand interlock seamless shift." There were moments of awkwardness but in the main the collection worked, and maybe was clearest and best in the finale dresses-strapless works of geometry in luscious shades of lavender, periwinkle and deep blue silk. I liked that Costa opened the door, as he can, to something different. And it was the right door in the context of Fashion Week. I'd love to hear what you all think.

The online used-book collective AbeBooks.com has released a list of its best-selling signed books for August. It includes Michael Phelps's autobiography, David Wroblewski's "Story of Edgar Sawtelle" and two volumes from Stephenie Meyer's "Twilight" series. What stopped me, though, was the book at No. 10: an autographed copy of "Dean Koontz's 2003 foray into poetry." ("Believe it or not," the press release says.) Titled "The Book of Counted Sorrows," the collection was apparently printed in a limited edition of 1,250 copies by an outfit called Charnel House. The cheapest copy currently on sale at AbeBooks is listed at $800. Koontz describes his book this way, according to the title page: "Being the mind bending, heart stopping, bowel freezing , spleen tickling history of the most dangerous book of poetry ever written including the text of that cursed book itself, with the prayer that God will protect you from a spontaneous head explosion (and even worse potential fates) if you dare read it."

Language | How do Americans in different parts of the country refer to their fizzy drinks? "Soda," "pop" or "coke"? A 1996 linguistics study (first page here) inspired a map that remains popular on the Web, showing "soda" (green and yellow on the map) prevalent on the coasts, while "pop" (blue) held sway in the Northwest and Midwest, and the generic "coke" (red) took the South. There must be some electoral significance to this. [Strange Maps]

Accel-KKR, the joint venture involving the venture capital firm Accel and the buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, said that it had raised $600 million for its third-private equity fund, a third more than it had initially hoped to raise.

Three members of Congress, armed with a new report that they say proves that excessive oil speculation is distorting consumer energy prices, are renewing their efforts to exclude many institutional investors from the nation's commodity markets, according to The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques.

The U.S. government's pension insurance agency has told bankrupt auto parts maker Delphi it would go to court on Friday to secure a claim on an additional $900 million in Delphi assets, The Wall Street Journal reported.

An Italian businessman who parlayed claims of Vatican ties into financial backing from the billionaire Ron Burkle, social links to former President Bill Clinton and a highly publicized romance with the movie actress Anne Hathaway, watched his ambitions come to an end on Wednesday when he pleaded guilty to fraud, The New York Times's Christine Haughney reported.

A proposed $25 billion federal loan program to help retool the American auto industry would speed the development of electric cars and other alternative-fuel vehicles, a Chrysler executive said Wednesday.
Deutsche Bank, confirming market rumors and conjecture, said that it is in what it called advanced talks with Deutsche Post about taking a stake in Postbank, Germany's largest consumer retail bank.

ImClone Systems' announcement Wednesday that it was entertaining a preliminary offer from a new unnamed suitor that topped a $4.5 billion bid by Bristol-Myers Squibb, had industry watchers predicting a bidding war.

Vishay Intertechnology, a maker of semiconductors and other electronic components, on Wednesday went hostile with a sweetened bid for International Rectifier, after its California rival rebuffed an earlier $1.6 billion offer.

U.S. miner Cleveland-Cliffs made a friendly 560 million Australian dollar ($450.5 million) offer to buy out Australian iron miner Portman Ltd. on Thursday, and is seeking a 30 percent stake in a second Australian miner.
The Boston Globe, citing N.F.L. sources as confirmation, reported that Tom Brady tore anterior cruciate and medial collateral ligaments in his left knee.
Deutsche Bank's U.S. investment banking arm has agreed to pay a $575,000 fine for short-selling violations in the largest penalty to date from NYSE Regulation.

Home | The confluence of the Great Housing Bust with our current rude energy awakening seems a good bet to become a turning point in the history of the American home, especially with the Baby Boom growing frail and downsizing. Is your home pre-bust or post-bust (whenever that happens)? It might be easy to tell, given design trends. [Economist, Mental Floss]

Wall Street investment banks are marketing and selling complex schemes meant to allow foreign investors, including offshore hedge funds, to avoid paying billions of dollars in dividend taxes illegally, according to a Senate subcommittee report released Wednesday.

McClatchy's chief executive, Gary Pruitt, said his resignation as a co-trustee of trusts held by the U.S. newspaper publisher's controlling family should not be read as a prelude to the company going private or changing its capital structure, despite speculation to the contrary.

A federal judge in San Jose has given preliminary approval to a $14 million settlement of shareholder claims over backdating of stock options against current and former Apple executives, court documents showed.

Bank of America said Wednesday that it would buy back about $4.5 billion in auction-rate securities held by roughly 5,500 customers nationwide as part of a settlement agreement with Massachusetts regulators.
A former chief executive of the UnitedHealth Group, William W. McGuire, will pay $30 million and return stock options representing more than three million shares to settle a class-action lawsuit.

Advertising | With all the fuss over Sarah Palin, moose hunter, it's easy to forget that the ranks of hunters are shrinking. So the No. 1 ammo maker, Black Cloud, keeps its edge by branding its rounds as a deadlier shot. A cable TV ad: ducks in the sky ... heavy metal riffs ... then shotgun blasts punctuating words on the screen: "Drop. Ducks. Like. Rain." [Business Week]

Arts | An art review says the interior designers Thomas Hope and Jean-Michel Frank had "a largeness of ambition more naturally associated with the history of ideas." They were like writers weaving "a sort of fiction out of curtains and rugs and chairs and couches--a fiction in which people then proceed to live their real lives." Rather like Balzac. [New Republic]

Fred J. DeVito, 55, sees the World Trade Center wherever he looks. This has nothing to do with illusions or phantasms. Rather, it has to do with the keen eye he has developed over 20 years as an art director and graphic designer in Manhattan.

Blockages in the heart's arteries commonly cause chest pains called angina. Cardiologists possess ever-improving invasive tools for restoring blood flow, including angioplasty (blowing up balloons to expand the artery at sites of plaque), stenting (insertion of cylindrical props of metal mesh), and bypass surgery, increasingly through very small incisions.

World | This intelligence forecast will greet the next president: a steady decline in American dominance as the world is transformed by globalization, climate change, and regional upheavals over scarce food, water and energy. And American military superiority won't do much good because "nobody is going to attack us with massive conventional force." [Washington Post]

History | An essay paints Benjamin Franklin as America's first city slicker. Sure, he played the bumpkin bewildered in the big city. But "Franklin made his way by means of book learning, wit, social savvy, and ability to hobnob with the rich, famous, and powerful-all assets valued in urban society." And he had his own Giuliani-esque urban leadership moment. [City Journal]

Se Ri Pak of South Korea defended the L.P.G.A. Tour in the wake of its short-lived plan to suspend players who do not speak English well enough to satisfy sponsors, saying Wednesday that learning the language can benefit rising international stars. Others at the Bell Micro Classic in Mobile, Ala., the first L.P.G.A. tournament since the controversy surfaced, also supported the goal of improving the English skills of international players. But they disliked the idea of suspending non-English speakers — which was proposed and quickly shelved.

The Chinese Football Association announced that its chairman, Xie Yalong, was taking a leave to attend government management school. The move came in the face of widespread criticism of Xie, who is often blamed by fans for the dismal performance of the Chinese men’s national and Olympic teams. Soccer is the favorite sport in China, but the men’s teams continue to disappoint fans, who say the association is awash in corruption. On its Web site, the association on Wednesday said Nan Yong, the vice chairman and the association’s Communist Party secretary, would take Xie’s place while he was away.

The university police chief at East Carolina said the university would use only local officers following complaints of excessive force after fans charged the field to celebrate the Pirates’ upset of West Virginia. Scott Shelton, the chief, said the department had completed an initial inquiry and identified police officers and sheriff’s deputies from various agencies shown in video clips of incidents after the game.

Pity poor Minoru Mori, the Japanese developer of the Shanghai World Financial Centre. The building was billed as the world's tallest building when it was first announced in 1994, designed to dominate the ongoing game of my-tower-is-bigger-than-yours.

Michael Bradley and Clint Dempsey scored first-half goals eight minutes apart and Brian Ching added a goal early in the second half as the United States defeated Trinidad and Tobago, 3-0, in a regional World Cup qualifier in Bridgeview, Ill., on Wednesday night. The United States has won all three games in the semifinal round in the Concacaf region. The American team, with Tim Howard in goal, had also shut out Guatemala and Cuba.

A convicted sex offender who enrolled in Arizona public schools posing as a 12-year-old boy has pleaded guilty to six felony accounts, including the exploitation of a minor.

Moschino is young, fun and flirtatious. The cheerful light hip-hop music immediately makes you feel as if you are lounging next to the water slide at a happy under-age casino.
Have you heard? It's "silly season in politics."
As fashion brands continue to emphasize luxury handbags and shoes, the perfectly groomed extremity is becoming the ultimate marketing tool. I decided it was time to investigate.

Injured feet have an ignoble status among athletes, writes Gretchen Reynolds in her Phys Ed column (“Unhappy Feet”) in the current issue of Play. Foot pain is common, but often ignored, she says, because it doesn’t have, well, “glamour,” for lack of a better word (knee, shoulder and back injuries have all the sex appeal). This is odd, Reynolds writes, because feet are the foundation of the body and elemental to everything we do, athletically and otherwise. But if you choose to pay attention there are many ways to prevent foot injuries, or to treat them when they occur.

He had the best curveball in the game, but somehow he lost it. As Pat Jordan writes, what went wrong remains a mystery, and Barry Zito, baseball’s high-priced prince of confusion, remains in an ongoing metaphysical crisis. Jordan writes that Zito “has assumed a new persona: the abused guy who can no longer be himself with people. ‘But it requires so much energy to be inauthentic,’ Zito said. Which is the point. Zito was never truly ‘authentic.’ ”.

What happens when a 12-year-old girl is just a little too good on the court? Ask Jaime Nared. As Elizabeth Weil explains in PLAY, Nared has found herself at the center of a controversy about sports and gender after being kicked off a boy’s team for her superior skills. Jaime dominates girls her age and she can’t play with boys her age. What is she supposed to do?.

How did a relentless pass rush produce an unexpected championship? In The Fine Points, former Giants defensive end Michael Strahan dissects some of the plays that put the Patriots’ Tom Brady on his back and produced a shocking upset in last season’s Super Bowl.

Even among the N.F.L.’s eccentric group of wide receivers, Chad Johnson of the Cincinnati Bengals stands apart. That’s why PLAY asked him to appear on the cover of its football issue, as a visiting professor for the magazine’s “N.F.L. 2008: Big Brain Edition.” The issue appears in print in The Sunday Times this weekend.

Bet you didn’t learn from the N.F.L. studio shows that good-looking quarterbacks get bigger bucks in the N.F.L. No, you need Play’s “Football for Smarties” guide to tell you stuff like that. When Dave Berri, a professor of economics at Southern Utah University, floated the theory to us, we encouraged him to check into it. Berri did the math. He and his colleagues had already done research on what factors determine a quarterback’s pay; so they added a component based on findings that showed people equate the symmetry of a face to good looks. In the end, Berri postulated that a pretty boy QB may earn about $300,000 extra in his annual paycheck. “It fits into a lot of research that says that people who are more attractive get more of what they want in life,” Berri told us. “How you look makes a difference. And you find that in a very odd place — on a football field.”.

The Personal Best column last Thursday, about athletes who overtrain, included an incorrect Web address for a listing of sports-medicine doctors. It is amssm.org, the site of the American Medical Society for Sports Medicine — not acsm.org, the site for the American College of Sports Medicine.

Kara Goucher, the bronze medalist in the 5,000 meters at the 2007 world championships, said Wednesday she would run in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 2. Goucher has never run a marathon. In addition to her performance at the world championships, she finished 10th in the 10,000 and ninth in the 5,000 at the Beijing Olympics. ''I'm not afraid to do the marathon and see how my body takes it,'' she said. More at nytimes.com/sports

Thousands of people fled coastal areas of Texas on Wednesday as Hurricane Ike, having spun away from Cuba and roared into the Gulf of Mexico, moved toward the state with growing strength. After pummeling Haiti, Cuba and other parts of the Caribbean, the storm refueled in the gulf and headed toward landfall somewhere from Corpus Christi northeastward to Galveston. It is expected to arrive early Saturday as a Category 4 hurricane, that is, one with maximum sustained winds of at least 131 miles per hour.

Militants armed with guns and grenades attacked villagers praying at a mosque, killing at least 20 and injuring about 50 others in a village in the North-West Frontier Province on Wednesday, local residents said. According to witnesses, the attackers, whom they identified as Taliban, threw grenades into the mosque and shot people as they fled the building. The village is near the tribal area of Bajaur, where the Pakistani Army has been fighting the Taliban.

Maybe he should have spoken up sooner. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, said Wednesday that perhaps Senator Barack Obama should have chosen someone else as his running mate.
Who knew? Even as Senator Barack Obama has tried to overcome skepticism by some Jewish voters, he has been keeping a little family secret. Turns out that a member of the Obama clan is a rabbi.

Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday accused his Republican rivals of stirring ''phony outrage'' over a comment he made a day earlier about putting ''lipstick on a pig,'' which he said was a clear reference to Senator John McCain's policies, not a derogatory comment about Mr. McCain's running mate. ''Enough!'' Mr. Obama said, interrupting a speech in Norfolk, Va., on education to address the latest controversy in the heated presidential campaign. ''I don't care what they say about me, but I love this country too much to let them take over another election with lies and phony outrage and Swift Boat politics. Enough is enough.''

UNDER the tents during Fashion Week, designers labored strenuously to give the crowds a show of eccentricity. But their efforts paled alongside those of the spectators, for whom fanning out one's feathers has become a fiercely competitive sport. In an exhibition that made some people nostalgic for the days before fashion became mass entertainment, Shail Upadhya (right), a stylist, showed off the polka-dot suit that is his workday uniform. Dexter Ivy (second from left, below), who teaches models to prance, experienced a Scarlett O'Hara moment, stitching up his fuchsia wrap at home from a stray swag of fabric. And Rosemary Ponzo, a costume stylist (second from right, below), wore her plumage as a crown -- the perfectly toned-in complement to her parrot-colored dress.

Sarah Palin of Alaska and the potential ''second gentleman,'' attended the Hay Days Grass Drags in Forest Lake, Minn., where he signed autographs on behalf of Arctic Cat snowmobiles. Mr. Palin, a champion snowmobile racer who is sponsored by Arctic Cat, spent the weekend after the convention at the company's booth signing autographs and greeting the crowd while wearing a shirt with the company's logo. He has taken part in the 2,000-mile Tesoro Iron Dog snowmobile race in Alaska every year since 1993 and, with a teammate, Scott Davis, has won the race four times.

BROFFMAN--Charles , 87, loving husband, brother, father, uncle, grandfather and friend died suddenly September 7, 2008. Chuck was a partner in the firm HDC Publications, responsible for the trade magazine ''The Designer''. In his retirement years he worked passionately to bring the musicals he co-wrote with Phil Freedman to the theatre. These musicals included the ''Song of the Medics'' performed at the time of WWII during his years of service as a medic in the Bronx.

MURPHY--Dr. Austin S. , of Rye, NY passed away on September 9, 2008. He was an economist, educator and banker. Born in New York, on November 20, 1917, the son of Daniel J. Murphy and Marie Austin Murphy. He received his BA, St. Francis College in Brooklyn in 1938, MA (Hayden fellow 1938-1940) Fordham University 1940 Ph.D. He was an instructor at Canisius College 1986, Fordham University 1938-1941, economics instructor Georgetown University 1941-1942, Fordham University School of Education 1946-1955, dean of school of business administration Seton Hall University 1950-1955, dean of school of business administration Canisius College Buffalo 1955-1962. Chairman and President of River Bank America, (formerly East River Savings Bank) 1970-1989. He was married to the former Mary Patricia Halpin who predeceased him in May 1974. He remarried the former Lee Chilton Romero who also predeceased him in February 2007. He is survived by his children Austin Joseph and Owen Gerard, his grandchildren Rachel, Gerrit and Lizzie Murphy, Tessa and Katie Romero. Friends may call at the Graham Funeral Home on Friday from 2-4 to 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday at Resurrection Church 10am.

SIFFERT--Miriam Sand , 90, passed away peacefully in her home in New York City on September 7, 2008. She was the beloved wife of Dr. Robert S. Siffert for 67 years, loving mother of Joan Siffert and John Siffert, mother-inlaw of Goldie Alfasi-Siffert and grandmother of Molly Kochan Ouanes (Alexx), David Siffert and Matthew Siffert. Mrs. Siffert was born and educated in Brooklyn at James Madison High School, where she met and then later married her high school sweetheart, Robert S. Siffert, M.D., former Chairman of the Department of Orthopedics at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. She went on to attend Brooklyn College, while actively taking part in the American Student Union and World Youth Congress. She worked as assistant to Dr. Alvin Johnson, the first President of the New School. Miriam later served on the Board and as Chair of both the Wiltwyck School for Dependent and Neglected Children and the Hillcrest Center for Children in Bedford, New York. She dedicated much of her life to the work of Citizens' Committee for Children, where she served on the Board as Vice President, Treasurer, and Honorary Member. She received the first Eleanor Roosevelt Award for her contribution to the creation of the Leadership Institute at CCC. Mimi also served on the Board of The Hudson River Museum. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Services will be private. Donations in memory of Miriam Siffert may be made to Citizens' Committee for Children at 105 E. 22nd St., NYC 10010.

GAL--Bertha . On September 8th, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Harold and Robert and mother-in-law of Irma. Dear sister of Beatrice Dallin. Cherished grandmother of Peter, Steven and Lisa and great-grandmother of Charlie and Sam.

The Carolina Hurricanes signed center Eric Staal to a seven-year contract extension worth $57.75 million. Staal, 23, will earn an average of $8.25 million starting in 2009-10 through the 2015-16 season. A two-time All-Star and the most valuable player of last year’s All-Star Game, Staal had 100 points three seasons ago in leading Carolina to its first Stanley Cup title. He bounced back from a subpar 2006-7 season with 38 goals and 44 assists last season.

Every two years, September in Paris takes on a special air of refinement with the arrival of the Biennale des Antiquaires, the gold standard of the global antiques industry, which is currently celebrating its 24th edition at the Grand Palais.  Built to house the 1900 Universal Exhibition, the Grand Palais is a marvel of soaring steel and glass construction and is the perfect backdrop for what experts consider some of the finest antiques and artworks on the market today.
Lifetime’s “Coco Chanel,” which stars Shirley MacLaine and airs Saturday, is a loopy work of hagiography that never gets its subject right.

No doubt much more will be said about the spring collections in the coming days, but I had the thought as I slogged back to the Times tonight from the tents-rained on again!-that some of the best shows came at the end of the week, as if in a rush. Today saw Ralph Lauren's deluxe expedition clothes, L'Wren Scott's ultra-feminine dresses and a lofty, jazzy feather cape, and Ralph Rucci at his most relaxed and refined. People are still talking about Francisco Costa's Calvin Klein cubes. Clearly we have a group of designers, including Costa and Raf Simons, who are attracted to new materials and ideas related to contemporary art and architecture, and are eager to express themselves in that direction. It can be argued that the things Costa personally accomplished with this collection will lead him to other designs. Just as in engineering, lots of things come from experiment and risk.

1. Terrelle Pryor, the nation's top quarterback recruit, got just 28 snaps in the first two games and didn't attempt a pass longer than 10 yards. Not exactly the type of resume that makes you think he'll tear up the Coliseum. Todd Boeckman has played terribly in his past four games against top division competition. He's thrown two touchdowns and six interceptions. He has also looked as mobile as a fire hydrant. But by not giving Pryor more live-ammo snaps in the first two games, Ohio State looks as if it will use Pryor sparingly against the Trojans. And that may greatly decrease Ohio State's chances to win.

Dear Reader: It may be time to give up on writing about current events in this space. When you think how news travel time has been telescoped, it's dizzying. It took days for even the rumors of Custer's annihilation at Little Big Horn to reach the east. Now any news over two hours old isn't news - it's "olds." Anything from the day before is virtually archaeology.

The new particle collider in Europe hasn't hurt anyone there yet, but all the talk about a "doomsday machine" seems to be taking a toll elsewhere, according to Reuters (hat tip: Charles Mann). It reports from Bhopal that Indians were so alarmed by reports that the Large Hadron Collider could destroy the world that they flocked to temples to pray and fast. One teenage girl traumatized by the warnings on television committed suicide, according to Reuters, which quoted her father: "We tried to divert her attention and told her she should not worry about such things, but to no avail."

As Fox's Geraldo Rivera stood along the sea wall in Galveston, Texas and watched Hurricane Ike pummel the coastline Friday morning, the graphic on the bottom of the TV screen could not be more ominous.

Without any doubt Hurricane Ike will be the most destructive hurricane to strike the United States since Hurricane Wilma caused $10 billion in insured losses arising from some one million claims in October 2005. The track, size and strength of this storm at midday Thursday­ -- about 12 hours before landfall­all -- put Ike on a collision course with one of the country's largest and most industrialized metropolitan areas­, Houston. At the same time, Ike will deliver Category 4 or 5 storm surge to low-lying coastal despite the fact that the storm is expected to make landfall as a Category 2 storm. Resident of these areas have been advised that they face "certain death" by drowning if they stay behind. Damage will not be limited to the coast. Inland tropical storm warnings extend as far away as Dallas­, 250 miles to the northwest.

And here's what I don't understand: why the shows that don't need to be in high definition (evening news, late-night talk shows, "Face the Nation"-type shows) usually are, and shows that cry out to be in high definition ("Survivor," "The Amazing Race") generally aren't.

Richard B. Alley of Penn State has long been a source I call on when I'm puzzling over the latest study of ice trends in the Arctic or Antarctica. Besides being a lead author on several reports from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Dr. Alley led one of the groups that first discerned in Greenland's ice layers how the climate has seen extraordinary jogs in temperature, particularly shortly after the end of the last ice age. He's considered a master teacher, and if you've seen him do a little bobbing, tilting, rotating dance to imitate the Milankovitch Cycle through which the orbital variations of Earth influence climate, you know why. Now he's moving into multimedia communication on climate, and earth sciences more generally, not just with video, but with a guitar. (I've been known to do the same thing; video evidence of my guitar picking here.)

What happens when a school that you deemed "very successful" less than two months ago is labeled with an F? With the news that Public School 8 in Brooklyn had received an F on the city's report cards, Chancellor Joel I. Klein was asked if he could explain the discrepancy between his praise and the letter grade. "It's just new information, that's all," he said.As they did last year, the grades are likely to provoke plenty of controversy when they are released next week. And Friday's exchange with a few reporters who pressed Mr. Klein about the grade was illuminating in part because of his unshakable faith that the grading system is the right way to judge schools.

This is the weekend that has been looked forward to by every college football fan since the final seconds of the B.C.S. title game ticked away back in January. Even with the team away for most of the last two weeks, the fans have been getting to Yankee Stadium early - some of them arriving, one ticket agent said, at 7:30 a.m. to get in line for tickets to the stadium tour. Besides going to a game, there aren't many other ways to get a glimpse of the historic ballpark before it closes down next weekend after a night game on Sept. 21 between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles.You can peer through the gate that opens behind home plate to let the tour groups in, and get a clear look at the 385-foot sign on the right-field fence, a small patch of green grass, and a Budweiser sign nearby. Another gate, in left field, functions as a loading dock, flanked by parked forklifts and stacks of wooden pallets. It also offered the best free view into the stadium on Wednesday afternoon, and a steady stream of tourists gathered there to take pictures, gazing past the Yankees bullpen toward the soaring arc of seats behind home plate.

Brooklyn will weather the current economic downturn better than the rest of New York City, but it will suffer more than it did during the last recession, according to a report commissioned by the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce.The report, conducted by the Fiscal Policy Institute, projects that Brooklyn will lose about 6,000 private-sector jobs through the first half of next year. That would amount to about one of every 70 jobs in the borough and less than one-tenth of the 80,000 jobs expected to be lost across the entire city, the report says.

Bristol-Myers Squibb stood by its $60-a-share offer for ImClone Systems, a day after the biotechnology company spurned Bristol's offer and said it had another bid at $70 a share.

Deutsche Bank, which spent the last decade building a global brand in the high-powered world of investment banking, said Friday it would buy a minority stake in Postbank, a relatively modest but profitable German institution. It also secured a right of first refusal to buy the remaining shares.

Internet | An article says the future of the Web is in developing countries, which seem likely to bypass the PC and go straight to mobile. China just surpassed the United States with the most Internet users -- more than 250 million -- and already has 600 million mobile-phone subscribers. So do the math: "the potential for the mobile Internet is enormous." [Economist]

Energy | At the new "human-powered" Green Microgym in Portland, Ore., people pedal furiously to create enough energy to power the TV, stereo and lights. But savings are hard to come by -- only "about a penny's worth of electricity an hour" per person on one new machine. Maybe they should harness the jaws of people who go to the gym just to gab. [ABC News]

Nakheel, the government-backed developer of several of Dubai's iconic coastal projects, says sales have tripled in the last year, with more than 6,100 units sold so far in 2008. An increase in buyers from India, Russia, Iran and Pakistan, as well as a jump in domestic buyers, has helped boost sales, said Manal Shaheen, Nakheel's director of sales and marketing, in an interview earlier this week.

Environment | A law professor describes a new legal strategy to force the government to reduce carbon emissions -- based on a centuries-old "public trust doctrine." That precept says it's the government's duty to maintain certain natural resources for the benefit of its citizens. And lawsuits would establish the atmosphere as one of those resources. [Utne Reader]

Steve Wilson of Ocean Springs, Miss., defeated Todd Mitchell of Bloomington, Ind., 5 and 4, in the 36-hole finale of the United States Mid-Amateur Championship to earn an invitation to next year’s Masters. Wilson, 38, one-putted nine times in the first 18 holes to take a 2-up lead into the afternoon session in River Hills, Wis. He finished with 14 one-putts in 32 holes.

Patrick Roy will have his No. 33 retired by the Montreal Canadiens, ending a bitter falling out. Roy, a Hall of Fame goaltender, played 11 seasons in Montreal, leading the Canadiens to Stanley Cup titles in 1986 and 1993. In 1995, he allowed nine goals before being pulled in a 12-1 loss to Detroit. Believing he had been left in to be humiliated by Coach Mario Tremblay, Roy said he would never play for the Canadiens again. A few days later he was traded to the Avalanche. Roy’s jersey will be raised to the rafters on Nov. 22 when the Canadiens host the Bruins.

The Carolina Hurricanes signed center Eric Staal to a seven-year contract extension worth $57.75 million. Staal, 23, will earn an average of $8.25 million starting in 2009-10 through the 2015-16 season. A two-time All-Star and the most valuable player of last year’s All-Star Game, Staal had 100 points three seasons ago in leading Carolina to its first Stanley Cup title. He bounced back from a subpar 2006-7 season with 38 goals and 44 assists last season.

In speech after speech to crowds in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Virginia in recent days, Gov. Sarah Palin, the Republican nominee for vice president, has made sure to mention the so-called Bridge to Nowhere, the Alaska project that has become the symbol of earmarks, and what she portrays as her ''thanks but no thanks'' position on it. When she landed in Fairbanks on Wednesday night, though, the bridge was notably absent from an otherwise mostly similar speech she made inside an airplane hangar before her home-state crowd.

Hundreds of eager Harlemites flocked to the State Office Building on 125th Street on Thursday, and many waited hours hoping to get a glimpse of Senator Barack Obama, who was scheduled to meet there with former President Bill Clinton. Among them were a dozen women of West African descent who work at the Unity African Hair Braiding salon, which is next door to the building. The women, dressed in colorful robes and headdresses, discussed Mr. Obama and his Kenyan lineage and declared their support for him. ''I'm not voting for him because of his color or his African background,'' said Masa Doukoure, who emigrated from Liberia 10 years ago. ''I'm voting for change. The dollar here is so weak that when we send money back to Africa, it's worth nothing.''

SIFFERT--Miriam Sand, 90, passed away peacefully in her home in New York City on September 7, 2008. She was the beloved wife of Dr. Robert S. Siffert for 67 years, loving mother of Joan Siffert and John Siffert, mother-inlaw of Goldie Alfasi-Siffert and grandmother of Molly Kochan Ouanes (Alexx), David Siffert and Matthew Siffert. Mrs. Siffert was born and educated in Brooklyn at James Madison High School, where she met and then later married her high school sweetheart, Robert S. Siffert, M.D., former Chairman of the Department of Orthopedics at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. She went on to attend Brooklyn College, while actively taking part in the American Student Union and World Youth Congress. She worked as assistant to Dr. Alvin Johnson, the first President of the New School. Miriam later served on the Board and as Chair of both the Wiltwyck School for Dependent and Neglected Children and the Hillcrest Center for Children in Bedford, New York. She dedicated much of her life to the work of Citizens' Committee for Children, where she served on the Board as Vice President, Treasurer, and Honorary Member. She received the first Eleanor Roosevelt Award for her contribution to the creation of the Leadership Institute at CCC. Mimi also served on the Board of The Hudson River Museum. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. Services will be private. Donations in memory of Miriam Siffert may be made to Citizens' Committee for Children at 105 E. 22nd St., NYC 10010.

Government officials in Argentina suggested to an executive at Venezuela's state oil company that charges could be dropped against a man discovered with a suitcase filled with $800,000 in cash, apparently to head off disclosure that the money was intended for an Argentine presidential candidate, according to a secretly recorded conversation played in federal court here on Thursday. Officials at Argentina's Justice Ministry told the oil executive, Ángel Morales, that charges in Argentina would be dropped against Guido Alejandro Antonini Wilson, the man found with the suitcase at a Buenos Aires airport, if he signed over power of attorney and got a lawyer to represent him in Argentina, a Venezuelan lawyer, Moisés Maionica, said in the taped conversation.

Sarah Obama, the elderly Kenyan stepgrandmother of Senator Barack Obama, does not have much, but what little she has was nearly stolen on Wednesday. She woke up early that morning to people stomping on her roof, according to a Kenyan police spokesman, Eric Kiraithe. Apparently some young men from her village in rural western Kenya were trying to pry off her solar panel, one of her prized possessions. Ms. Obama, about 86, and some other relatives chased the burglars away and the police later arrested four men.

I must admit I couldn't resist watching a bit more of the Huntsman-Hexion trial Tuesday, courtesy of the Courtroom View Network. (Huntsman International filed the suit in Delaware Court of Chancery, to prevent Hexion Specialty Chemicals from pulling out of a proposed $10.6 billion merger of the two chemical companies.) My timing was good; when I logged in that morning, it was right at the start of Andy Nussbaum's testimony. Mr. Nussbaum is the lawyer at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz who negotiated the merger agreement on behalf of Hexion. He was called to the stand by Hexion, with Hexion partly waiving its attorney-client privilege to do so.

CURRAN--Paul J. The Federal Bar Council notes with sadness the passing of Paul J. Curran, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and a distinguished lawyer in both public and private service. He was a selfless mentor and friend to many of our members. Most of all, he will be remembered for his civility and kindness in all of his endeavors, and he set an example that was an inspiration to every lawyer who knew him. We extend our condolences to his entire family. Mark C. Zauderer, President Federal Bar Council

BROOKLYN BOOK FESTIVAL Tucked within the list of events planned for the more than 140 authors appearing at this Sunday's book festival is a little reading called ''Brooklyn's Own,'' featuring three authors who call the borough home. It is a testament to the vitality of the Brooklyn literary scene that the reading is not the signature event of the day. The festival is not just a breeding ground for local authors, it has also become a destination for those who arrive via plane rather than subway. And that's no accident.

AXELROD--Allan. Professor Allan Axelrod, the William J. Brennan, Jr. Professor Emeritus of Law at Rutgers School of Law--Newark and a legendary figure in the history of the law school, died on August 9, 2008, at his home in Hoboken, NJ. He was 85 years old. On Sunday, September 21, 2008, at 1:00pm, a memorial tribute to Professor Axelrod will be held at Rutgers Law School, 123 Washington St., Newark, NJ. Professor Axelrod was one of the ablest, most penetrating, and most exciting law teachers of his--or indeed of any-era. For 59 years, from 1948 to 2007, Professor Axelrod employed brilliance, verbal artistry, colorful anecdotes (some with a basis in fact), and bursts of humor to bring tens of thousands of students to thoughtful understanding of legal doctrine and the underlying tensions of policy. His fields of special interest were Contracts, Property, Commercial Law and Bankruptcy but he was equally at home teaching Antitrust, Oil and Gas, and Local Government. Another of his pedagogical interests was the Law of Gambling, a seminar he particularly enjoyed researching and teaching. Professor Axelrod was born in Detroit in 1922. As an undergraduate he attended the University of Michigan, graduating with a B.A. in 1943. During World War II he worked for the War Labor Board. In 1946 he matriculated at Yale Law School, earning his LL.B. in 1948. Two weeks before graduating, he commenced his teaching career as an Instructor at the University of Nebraska Law School. In 1960 Professor Axelrod shifted his academic base to Rutgers School of Law--Newark, where he was a beloved teacher for 47 years. In 1978 he received the Lindback Prize, Rutgers University's highest teaching award. Professor Axelrod's prowess as a law teacher was reflected in the roster of law schools at which he was a Visiting Professor: Berkeley, University of Chicago, Georgetown, Harvard, Hastings, University of Pennsylvania, Southern California, Stanford and Yale. The Law School is establishing the Allan Axelrod Memorial Fund to support the creation of an Axelrod Professorship as well as the existing Axelrod Library Endowment. Donations to the Memorial Fund should be made out to the Rutgers University Foundation, with a notation that it is for the Allan Axelrod Memorial Fund and should be mailed to the Dean's Office, Rutgers Law School--Newark, 123 Washington St., Newark, NJ 07102.

BOOTH--John E. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund are deeply saddened by the passing of one of our founding members and our first Chairman. As Chair from 1967 -1970, John was an instrumental force in the defining TDF and it's mission. He remained an active Trustee until he moved to New Mexico in 2004. John's passion for the theatre and new plays, and his commitment to the American playwrights were unparalleled. That passion and commitment lives on in the study currently underway, ''TDF New Plays and Playwrights Projects'' which he spearheaded and for which he was a tireless advocate. We will miss his vigor, humor and passion. Our condolences to his family. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Victoria Bailey, Exec. Dir.

Hurricane Ike cut its path of destruction across the Texas coast and points northward and early estimates of insured losses are beginning to flow in. According to catastrophe modeling firm AIR Worldwide, insured losses will total between $8 billion to $12 billion, with an expectedloss of $10 billion. If the $10 billion estimate holds, Ike will rank as the fourth most expensive hurricane in United States history, just behind Hurricane Wilma with $10.9 billion which struck Florida in 2005.Storms of this magnitude typically generate hundreds of thousands of claims. Wilma produced one million claims. Another catastrophe modeler, Eqecat, estimates that insured losses could range somewhat higher, with total losses coming in somewhere between $8 billion and $18 billion. These figures do not include flood damage covered through the National Flood Insurance Program or losses to offshore oil facilities.

The Irish managed on 11 first downs, but the convincing win was much-needed for the struggling program.

EDINBURGH, SCOTLAND -- This modern Parnassus, Robert Louis Stevenson maintained, was a city that has many admirers but few true lovers. He may have made his remarks in a feuillton of a guide written in the 1890s, but I'm with him on that - and I have the Jekyll/Hyde thing as well. Mostly, I like to admire Edinburgh from afar; although there are those legions of admirers, personally I find a certain frigidity to the elegance of the New Town, a sense that these superb townhouses were built to be the stalls of enlightened horses, who clopped over the cobbles ruminating on the reconciliation of faith and reason.

The mooncakes eaten during Mid-Autumn Festival, which takes place this long weekend, are not dissimilar to Christmas fruitcakes: leaden, sticky, obligatory gifts made from recipes that became outdated generations ago. They make the rounds at family functions not because they taste good, but because you can't show up at Grandma's without them. Like the nighttime dragon dance or lanterns carried by children, they are an integral part of the second most important Chinese festival after the Lunar New Year.

As forecast, Hurricane Ike passed onshore early Saturday morning over Houston and Galveston as a CAT-2 hurricane. Any time a hurricaneaffects Galveston, we think about the 1900 catastrophe, but accurate modern forecasts and 2 categories less wind mean that Ike was not a repeat.According to CNN, waves breaking over the seawall in Galveston caused up to 7 feet of flooding. As horrendous as 7 feet of salt water in your neighborhood seems, it's very different from what happened that on windy Saturday night 108 years (and 5 days) ago. Then mighty waves swept away all the houses and people from the seaward third of the island. Since many structures in eastTexas today (how to up this delicately?) do not incorporate every imaginable wind-resistant design feature, we may see a surprising amount of roof, door, and window failures.Ike's huge wind circulation raised a powerful sea with potential to damage offshore petroleum production. Nonetheless, there is reason to hope that the damage will be manageable.

Behavior | A British psychiatrist makes a case for moral performance enhancers. In a way, such drugs are already in use, he says. Take the man with "antisocial personality disorder" who seeks medication to prevent himself from harming a girlfriend. He's using pharmacology as "moral agency." [British Journal of Psychiatry, Wired]

Religion | Today's theological question: If there is a God, would He put a merciful halt to the God vs. atheism debate, or let it drag on interminably? Such are the imponderables. Anyway, there's yet another addition to the pile of tomes on the issue, raising the related question of how many trees have to die. This one's from the former bishop of Edinburgh. [New Statesman]

Sport | A new book explores how rugby helped defeat apartheid in South Africa. That is, how Nelson Mandela's effort to understand a sport at the heart of Afrikaner identity formed a "bridge across the racial chasm." The end of apartheid became not just a defeat of racism but a victory for cultural amity. They're all rugby fans now. [Economist]

The Bryant lacrosse coach Mike Pressler will coach the United States men’s lacrosse team in the 2010 world championship in England. Pressler, who is his third season at Bryant, led Duke to 10 N.C.A.A. tournaments but was forced to resign after rape allegations were leveled against three players. State prosecutors later determined that the accusations were false.

USA Taekwondo filed a protest Friday with the Court of Arbitration for Sport, seeking changes in the sport’s judging protocols after Steven Lopez’s disputed quarterfinal loss in the Beijing Olympics. Lopez was a two-time defending Olympic champion heading into Beijing and a favorite to win a third gold medal. He wound up with a bronze after he had a point deducted because of a series of penalties.

An article on Thursday about the scientific debate over a past examination of the cyclist Lance Armstrong’s muscle efficiency misidentified the publication that presented both the original research and new information about an error in the study. It is the Journal of Applied Physiology, not the Journal of Physiology.

An article on Friday about quarterback Todd Reesing’s academic and athletic success at Kansas omitted a passage at the continuation in some copies. It should have read, “It did not matter that as a junior, he was named the Texas 4A offensive player of the year over Matthew Stafford, who then was considered the No. 1 quarterback prospect in the nation and now leads No. 2 Georgia.” The article also misspelled the surname of a fellow quarterback in the Big 12 Conference. He is Missouri’s Chase Daniel, not Daniels. (The full article is at nytimes.com/sports.).

BARTOLINI--Leonardo . The officers and staff of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York mourn the loss of their colleague and friend Leonardo Bartolini, senior vice president in the International Research division of the Bank's Research and Statistics Group. Leonardo was one of the Bank's most respected analysts of global macroeconomic and monetary policy issues. His research and policy work centered on monetary policy execution, interbank markets, central bank intervention, exchange rate regimes, and capital controls. Most recently, he had been studying cross-country differences in monetary policy implementation and the behavior of the money markets. Leonardo came to the United States from Italy to pursue a graduate education in economics. He received a Ph.D. from Princeton University in 1991 after completing his dissertation, ''Essays on International Capital Markets under Uncertainty.'' Leonardo joined the New York Fed in 1995 as an economist in the Foreign Research department and held various positions before being made a senior vice president in 2002. From 2000 to 2004, he served as head of the International Research division. For two periods in the 1990s-1990-95 and 1998-Leonardo worked as an economist at the International Monetary Fund. During his years at the IMF, he made significant contributions to the institution's work agenda, particularly in the area of exchange rate analysis, and published extensively in leading economics and policy journals. Leonardo was very modest about his own professional accomplishments, but he was quick to support and encourage younger economists beginning their careers. He inspired all of his colleagues at the IMF and the New York Fed with his integrity, intelligence, and quiet authority, and he was loved as a warm and generous friend. We extend our deepest condolences to Leonardo's wife, Jin, and his young son, Lorenzo. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, September 13, at the Tillman Chapel, Church Center for the United Nations, 1st Avenue and 44th Street, New York City. Donations may be made to the All Things Project of the Neighborhood Church of Greenwich Village, 269 Bleecker Street, New York, NY 10014. Timothy F. Geithner, President and Chief Executive Officer

HOROWITZ--Richard F . Heller, Horowitz & Feit, P.C. mourns the passing of its founding partner, mentor and friend Richard F. Horowitz who died on September 11th, 2008. Richard was a graduate of Columbia College (A.B. 1961) and Columbia University Law School (LL.B 1964). In 1979, Richard, along with Jacob Heller and Eli Feit founded Heller, Horowitz & Feit, P.C. For nearly thirty years at HH&F Richard served his clients with intellectual brilliance, passion and integrity and formed a special bond and working relationships with his partners, associates and staff that will never be forgotten. Richard was an active member of Temple Ner Tamid, Broad Street in Bloomfield, NJ. As well as being one of the original members of this community, he has served in various capacities, including Trustee. Richard is survived by his wife of forty-one years, Diane Horowitz nee Ascione, his son David Alfred Horowitz and daughter-in-law Bonnie, his daughter Dr. Deborah Horowitz Salanon and son-inlaw David Salanon, brother Michael Horowitz, and sisterin-law, Judge Arlene Hahn, his grandchildren Daniel and Eric Frey, Michelle Salanon, Ariella and Ryan Laszlo. Richard was the son of the late Sidney and Mathilda Horowitz and son-in-law of New York State Justice Alfred Ascione and his wife Joan, all whom predeceased him. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 14th at 1:00pm at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ. 973 - 779 - 3048. Please No Flowers. Contributions can be sent to the Foundation Fighting Blindness, 11435 Cronhill Drive, Owings Mills, MD 21117-2220.

CARROLL--Thomas J. , 81, a Wall Street veteran, formerly of Unionville, PA, died September 11 at his farm in Middleburg, VA surrounded by his family. Carroll, the son of the late Harry Joseph and Kathryn (McLaughlin) Carroll was born and raised in Philadelphia, PA. He left high school prior to graduation in 1945 to serve in the United States Army until the end of World War II. Carroll began his professional career in 1947 at the investment firm of Cartwright and Parmelee, in New York City. In December of 1969 he founded Carroll, McEntee & McGinley, a primary government bond dealer, now part of HSBC. He was an Emeritus Trustee of The Foxcroft School in Middleburg, VA. He started the Christopher T. Carroll Foundation, which donates money to cancer research grants across the U.S. A lifelong horseman, he was involved in foxhunting, steeplechase and flat racing. His wife Joan preceded him in death in 2003. They mourned the death of their son Christopher Carroll of Chicago, IL in 2001. He is survived by Margaret Eldridge of San Diego, CA, Cornelius X. Carroll (Sally), of Windmere, FL, Michael Carroll (Lori) of Glenview, IL, Joann Linden (Lindsey) of Reston, VA, Thomas J., Jr. (Margaret) of Rectortown, VA and Moira Carroll of Chicago, IL; two sisters, Mary Nicholson and Regina Lauria; and grandchildren Leah, Christopher, Corey, Michael Jr., Gillian, Kiely, and Thomas. He is also preceded in death by his sister Kathleen. A celebration of his life will begin at a Catholic mass Wednesday, September 17 at 11:30am at St. Stephen the Martyr Catholic Church, 23331 Sam Fred Road, Middleburg Virginia. Donations can be made in his honor to the V Foundation for Cancer Research, 106 Towerview Court, Cary, NC 27513.

MERRILL--Nathaniel . The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Nathaniel Merrill, whose realism style of directing helped define an era in Met production history. In all, he directed 14 new productions, including the legendary Met premiere of Die Frau ohne Schatten, in addition to staging numerous revivals between 1956 and 1985. His much admired production of Der Rosenkavalier remains in our repertory today. We offer our sincere condolences to his wife, Pamela, and his children, Hank, Christopher, and Linda. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Dir.
As the news sinks in for Lehman Brothers employees that their firm will file for bankruptcy, it seems a certain melancholy has set in.

According to people briefed on the matter, Lehman Brothers will file for bankruptcy protection on Sunday night, in the largest failure of an investment bank since the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert 18 years ago.
For those who need a little bit of levity on a tense day, we present some mood music.

Barclays withdrew from talks to buy Lehman Brothers early Sunday afternoon, casting yet more gloom on efforts to save the investment bank. Barclays, based in London, said it was unable to reach an agreement on credit guarantees for Lehman’s troubled assets.
Corrected: As many of Wall Street’s chieftains returned to 33 Liberty Street on Sunday morning, the situation surrounding a potential rescue plan for Lehman Brothers seemed as fluid as ever.

Three weeks ago, when my school asked 20 upperclassmen to help with a summer institute for freshmen, 80 showed up. At the end of August, our technology coordinator asked students to help her configure our laptops. Many kids spent the last free Saturday of summer vacation dragging icons across a screen. The school year at Science Leadership Academy here in Philadelphia has now begun, and our freshmen are noticing that the end of our school day stretches much longer than the end of the teachers’ paid instructional time. They are asking the same question that regularly stirs up our visitors. “Why do they stay?” Even as I write this, student laughter is floating up from our café — late on a Friday afternoon. Some have stepped out to get Chinese, and now they are back — to hang out with teachers in the principal’s office. Given every opportunity to leave, both our educators and students regularly decide to stay.

Environment | Until now, indoor farming (hydroponics and aeroponics) has been small-scale. But farmland is in high demand. Alberto Contador took the overall lead of the Vuelta a España by leading a Spanish sweep in the 13th stage. Contador finished the 130-mile stage in 5 hours 52 minutes 35 seconds. He leads Levi Leipheimer by 1:07 in the standings.

Carlos Moyà defeated top-seeded Richard Gasquet of France, 6-2, 6-4, to reach the final of the BCR Open Romania in Bucharest. He will play the defending champion Gilles Simon of France, who defeated eighth-seeded José Acasuso of Argentina, 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-4. The sixth-seeded Moyà was more aggressive and appeared fresher than Gasquet despite winning a grueling three-set quarterfinal on Friday.

Asafa Powell cruised to victory in the 100 meters and the Olympic champion LaShawn Merritt won the 400 at the World Athletics Final in Stuttgart, Germany. Powell won in 9.87 seconds, and Merritt nipped Jeremy Wariner by 0.01 to win the 400 in 44.50.

To the Editor: I don’t know where Seth Sherwood learned the history in his “France’s Isle of Beauty” (Aug. 31), but I learned early on that Christopher Columbus was Italian, who discovered the Americas while sailing for the Spanish, not “who is conventionally assumed to have been Spanish.”.

To the Editor: I very much enjoyed Elinor Burkett’s article, “The Lure of Namibia” (Aug. 24), but was disappointed that no mention was made of one sight there. I speak of the largest-known meteorite in the world, Hoba, which weighs in the area of 60 tons. Little is known of its history, when it landed or why there is no crater, but there it stands, a visitor from space consisting of iron mostly that hit the earth about 80,000 years ago.

To the Editor: Geraldine Fabrikant’s Heads Up column “Hotel Upgrades: You’re Giving Me That Room? No Way” (Aug. 31) was a laugh. As a bell attendant at a four-star hotel in Boston, I have daily interactions with people who always try for upgrades. Take it from a pro; the example of the guest who tries for upgrades with a tip works best. Desk agents have incredible discretion with room types and can easily get you a better view or a bigger room. There is one important thing to remember. Hotels do sell out. In that case, you can scream all you want, but you will not be upgraded. You will just be shuffled around.

“Cooking in Wartime” (Aug. 31) reminded me of my childhood in Germany during World War II and what seemed then to be my mother’s crazy reaction to dangerous circumstances. She, like many Kriegsfrauen, as wives of men who were willingly or unwillingly fighting Hitler’s war were called, tried to provide normalcy for their children. Despite bombing alarms, a meal needed to be cooked and carried several flights to the basement while bombs were falling, with the admonishment not to spill, a tall order for a 6-year-old. I only realized years later that this was my mother’s way to hold at bay the paralyzing fear that shook my whole body. Stephanie Gruner’s prenatal motherly instincts were right on target: keep the family safe via the path of normalcy, channeling anxiety into the attack of staples, transforming them into sustenance.

Anyone who has bet on football often enough to endanger his marriage and finances is familiar with the eerie precision of ''the line.'' The book's goal, of course, is to be ''result neutral.'' So if the Bears are a 7-point favorite over the Packers and money starts piling on the Bears, the line will inch up until the Packers are attractive enough for money to start flowing toward Green Bay, at which point the line might move back down, and so on. But the mystery to most bettors is how the line is set in the first place. An inaccurate opening line can be costly to an individual casino -- or bookie in the passenger seat of a van with tinted windows -- as sharp gamblers rush to the side that's providing surplus value. Which is to say that setting the opening line is not a trivial matter.
