NEXT year Honda and Toyota will go head-to-head with new gas-electric hybrid cars. We all know what to expect from Toyota; its Prius is the best-selling hybrid, with more than 180,000 sold in 2007 alone. The next generation is likely to be better and more efficient. Honda will counter the Prius with a four-door hatchback it is calling the Insight -- named after Honda's first hybrid, a two-seater discontinued in 2006. The new Insight will be unveiled next month at the Paris Motor Show.

JAFFE--Erwin A., was born on August 28th, 1928, and died September 5th, 2008, in Hackensack, NJ, eight days after his 80th birthday. He studied at Rutgers University where he received a Ph.D. in Political Science before becoming an educator at the University of Nevada in Reno, the University of New Hampshire, New England College, and California State University, Stanislaus. He was a teacher and mentor to students who became educators, lawyers, authors, public servants, involved citizens, and members of various professions in almost every state of the nation. He added to scholarship in political philosophy through his writings and lectures in the United States and abroad. Those who are left will carry on his legacy. They include his wife of 51 years, Marianne, his sister Geraldine Applebaum and family, his many students and friends whose lives he touched and influenced. Remembrance contributions may be sent to Doctors Without Borders because Erwin Jaffe believed in people without borders.

BARTOLINI--Leonardo. The officers and staff of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York mourn the loss of their colleague and friend Leonardo Bartolini, senior vice president in the International Research division of the Bank's Research and Statistics Group. Leonardo was one of the Bank's most respected analysts of global macroeconomic and monetary policy issues. His research and policy work centered on monetary policy execution, interbank markets, central bank intervention, exchange rate regimes, and capital controls. Most recently, he had been studying cross-country differences in monetary policy implementation and the behavior of the money markets. Leonardo came to the United States from Italy to pursue a graduate education in economics. He received a Ph.D. from Princeton University in 1991 after completing his dissertation, ''Essays on International Capital Markets under Uncertainty.'' Leonardo joined the New York Fed in 1995 as an economist in the Foreign Research department and held various positions before being made a senior vice president in 2002. From 2000 to 2004, he served as head of the International Research division. For two periods in the 1990s-1990-95 and 1998-Leonardo worked as an economist at the International Monetary Fund. During his years at the IMF, he made significant contributions to the institution's work agenda, particularly in the area of exchange rate analysis, and published extensively in leading economics and policy journals. Leonardo was very modest about his own professional accomplishments, but he was quick to support and encourage younger economists beginning their careers. He inspired all of his colleagues at the IMF and the New York Fed with his integrity, intelligence, and quiet authority, and he was loved as a warm and generous friend. We extend our deepest condolences to Leonardo's wife, Jin, and his young son, Lorenzo. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, September 13, at the Tillman Chapel, Church Center for the United Nations, 1st Avenue and 44th Street, New York City. Donations may be made to the All Things Project of the Neighborhood Church of Greenwich Village, 269 Bleecker Street, New York, NY 10014. Timothy F. Geithner, President and Chief Executive Officer

CARROLL--Thomas J., 81, a Wall Street veteran, formerly of Unionville, PA, died September 11 at his farm in Middleburg, VA surrounded by his family. Carroll, the son of the late Harry Joseph and Kathryn (McLaughlin) Carroll was born and raised in Philadelphia, PA. He left high school prior to graduation in 1945 to serve in the United States Army until the end of World War II. Carroll began his professional career in 1947 at the investment firm of Cartwright and Parmelee, in New York City. In December of 1969 he founded Carroll, McEntee & McGinley, a primary government bond dealer, now part of HSBC. He was an Emeritus Trustee of The Foxcroft School in Middleburg, VA. He started the Christopher T. Carroll Foundation, which donates money to cancer research grants across the U.S. A lifelong horseman, he was involved in foxhunting, steeplechase and flat racing. His wife Joan preceded him in death in 2003. They mourned the death of their son Christopher Carroll of Chicago, IL in 2001. He is survived by Margaret Eldridge of San Diego, CA, Cornelius X. Carroll (Sally), of Windmere, FL, Michael Carroll (Lori) of Glenview, IL, Joann Linden (Lindsey) of Reston, VA, Thomas J., Jr. (Margaret) of Rectortown, VA and Moira Carroll of Chicago, IL; two sisters, Mary Nicholson and Regina Lauria; and grandchildren Leah, Christopher, Corey, Michael Jr., Gillian, Kiely, and Thomas. He is also preceded in death by his sister Kathleen. A celebration of his life will begin at a Catholic mass Wednesday, September 17 at 11:30am at St. Stephen the Martyr Catholic Church, 23331 Sam Fred Road, Middleburg Virginia. Donations can be made in his honor to the V Foundation for Cancer Research, 106 Towerview Court, Cary, NC 27513.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

There's something horrifying about watching Adrian Peterson play. Like Earl Campbell before him, the quick, powerful tailback seems to be running way too hard, his fragile legs pounding the artificial turf like pistons. Injuries cost Peterson chunks of his three seasons at the University of Oklahoma, and even as a rookie last year, when he gained more than 1,300 yards rushing, a bum knee kept him out of two games. ''The only thing I can control is the hits I take,'' Peterson says. ''I've got to go down and avoid the big blows.'' This new strategy will come as welcome news to the Bears (who gave up 224 yards to Peterson in Week 6) and the Chargers (296 yards in Week 9). Peterson's other strategy for the new season: Avoid even the small blows. ''People forget I was a sprinter,'' he says. ''There aren't a lot of guys in the league that can flat-out outrun me.'' B.C.

HOFF--Margo. Modernist artist Margo Hoff died Sunday, August 17th, in the Spartan, Manhattan loft which served as both her painting studio and home. She was 98 years old. Her work is in the permanent collections of the Whitney, Metropolitan, Art Institute of Chicago, the Victoria and Albert Museum (London), the Biblioteque Nationale (Paris) and many other public and private collections worldwide. Ms. Hoff was born (1910) and raised in Tulsa, Oklahoma. As a six-year-old she modeled small figures from the clay the well-drillers left behind. At 14 she won a silver medal in ''Free Hand Drawing.'' After two years at the University of Tulsa, she relocated to Chicago to pursue the study of art. She first found success with her edgy, figurative work while still a student at the Art Institute of Chicago in the mid-1940s; a one-man show at the Wildenstein Galleries in Paris (1955) brought international recognition. She moved permanently to NYC in 1960, where her more abstract collage paintings attracted immediate institutional and critical attention; ''The Crowd'' (1960), a 40'' x 30'' paper collage and acrylic on canvas, was purchased by the Metropolitan Museum of Art that same year. She would later exhibit with Betty Parsons. As artist-in residence she taught at numerous American universities as well as in China, Brazil, Lebanon and Uganda. She is survived by a daughter, Mia, of Edinburgh, Scotland. A memorial service is pending. (More information about Margo Hoff's life and career is available at MargoHoff.com.)

CANOEING IN THE SVENCIONELIAI REGION, July 10, 2008 Mallory Williams, 21, a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. ''Out of all the countries I have visited, Lithuania has been by far one of my favorites. I got to enjoy a kayaking trip an hour outside of Vilnius and appreciate what the rural lifestyle had to offer. The trip was organized by a friend -- her family and friends, all amateurs to the sport came together to enjoy one another's company as well as the scenery and a barbecue. I was the newest to the group and therefore was instructed by Grandpa to make a wish and throw a coin over my shoulder for good luck. I think we were all united in a way after that. They assured me that Americans aren't known to come around that particular town, and I think there was a small effort to show me what we've all been overlooking. The scenery was beautiful, and we enjoyed the berries we found in the woods -- the cherries were sweet, and the blueberries reminded me of Maine. What I find is most important and most satisfying in traveling is getting to appreciate and absorb the common life and perspectives of the people rather than just their churches and monuments. I was shown their domestic humility and how much sweeter it makes their cherries.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

KURZBAND--Dr. Toby. Toby Kurzband died peacefully on September 10, 2008 at age 99 of natural causes. His beloved wife Diana died in 1994. He will be remembered with great love and affection by his daughters, Paula Feder and Karen Hewitt, his grandchildren, Corin Hewitt and Sarah Weaver, and his many dear friends, teachers, and former students. He graduated from the University of Chicago and received his Ed.D. at Teacher's College, Columbia University. Dr. Kurzband was a distinguished educator and administrator with the NYC Board of Education. He taught art at Bronx HS of Science, became Principal at PS 1M and later, Superintendent-District 2M. He was prominent in the field of Jewish education. In his later years, he taught at the University of Rhode Island, Pace University, Pratt Institute, Marymount College, and Penn South Senior Center. In his long, productive lifetime as an educator and artist, he inspired creativity in his family, friends, students and teachers. Contributions in his name can be sent to Penn South Program for Seniors. A memorial service will be held in January.

It didn't take long for Barry Zito's $126 million seven-year contract with San Francisco to be viewed as one of the worst deals ever made. Zito's contract is far from over, though, and while his record is well under .500, he's not injured; redemption remains possible. Not so for some other players whose contracts would seem to border on legalized embezzlement. Herewith, some of the most ill-conceived contracts given out during this lastdecade of lavish free-agent spending. CARL PAVANO

LESSON PLANS Preschool started this week. I had a wonderful summer of teaching part time and hanging out with kids on city playgrounds. There are moments when I can't believe I get paid to do this (tempered, of course, by moments when I don't get paid nearly enough to do this). This summer, there were more of the former. I worked with two students at their summer camps, and I worked weekends with one student at his family's country home. Summer seemed to have a superhero theme. Two girls showed up to summer camp dressed as Spider-Man and Batman for no apparent reason (other than the obvious cool factor). I played superheroes on the playground and blasted off with a (highly imaginative) student from the tip of the Egyptian pyramids into outer space. (Yes, my job is cooler than yours.) I saw preschoolers develop seemingly random, yet fervent obsessions with the state of Wyoming and chicken pot pie.

RASMUSSEN--Arthur E., of Walton, 85, died at his home September 3rd after an extended illness. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Joann, their children and spouses - Mark Rasmussen and Zheng Ping of London, UK; Will and Jane Rasmussen of London, UK; Kim Rasmussen and Glenn McGuiness of Bovina and New York City; Ann Rasmussen and Chris Cerf of Montclair, NJ and six grandchildren. Born November 2nd, 1922 in Englewood, NJ, Arthur studied at Middlebury College (VT), and the University of Chicago, completing his MA at sea while serving in the Merchant Marines. He later served as an officer in the Army during World War II. He acquired his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1947. He was awarded an honorary doctorate from Hartwick College in 1995. Arthur joined Booz, Allen & Hamilton, moved to Philco, then to Congoleum Nairn Corp. From 1957-67 he was Financial VP and Director of Avco Corp. He became President of Household International Inc in 1967 at age 45, retired from that position five years later, then served as its Chairman from 1972 to 1984. He also served on the boards of Amoco (Standard Oil Co.), Central and South West Corporation and Abbott Laboratories. He also served on the boards or their derivatives of a long list of not-for-profit organizations, including The University of Chicago, Northwestern University, Hartwick College (Vice-Chair), The Field Foundation of Illinois, Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, Adler Planetarium (Chicago), and the National Business Council for Consumer Affairs. Art and Joann moved to Walton in 1990 where he served as a Director of Delaware National Bancshares, National Bank of Delaware County, and State University at Delhi. He had real estate holdings in three states, and became founding director of the Catskill Center for Conservation and Development and the Delaware County Conservation Association. A major supporter and board member of the Institute for American Values, he helped bring the Institute together with the University of Chicago to form the Council on Civil Society. He provided startup funding for a degree in family support at the University of Chicagos Graduate School of Social Services Administration the first such program in the nation. Active with the National Association of Scholars, he worked to encourage more stress on liberal arts at American colleges and universities. He also served on the National Alumni Forum, working to improve governance on university boards of trustees. Arthur said his charitable work, after retiring from business, opened ''new vistas in the sunlit upland of life.'' Appropriately, he named their upstate New York property ''The Sunlit Uplands''. Arthur's greatest loves were his wife Joann, four children, six grandchildren, the great outdoors and poetry. He constantly challenged himself to master new subjects, aid numerous causes and inspire countless people. He made a fortune and gave it away. He brimmed with optimism, never looking back to regret. He taught us how to keep to our responsibilities. He challenged us to sharpen our thinking and focus our lives with his favorite question: ''What are your plans?'' A memorial service will be held to celebrate his life on Thursday, September 18th at The New Hope Community Church at 45 Stockton Avenue in Walton, NY at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the Walton Fire Department.

I'm sorry, sir, but you should have been preparing for the booth long before you hung up those cleats. Despite the explosion in media outlets, the number of broadcast jobs available is relatively small (perhaps half a dozen new national TV gigs are filled each year), and the competition for them is brutal -- unless you're a future Hall of Famer. ''The Michael Strahans of the world get recruited when they retire,'' says Howard Katz, the N.F.L.'s senior vice president of broadcasting. ''Others have to do it differently.'' For them, the league offers the N.F.L. Broadcast Boot Camp, a three-day workshop that puts players through mock telecasts, as well as radio- and local-TVstyle interviews. Among the 2007 grads are former quarterback Tim Hasselbeck, now with ESPN; ex-Rams tight end Roland Williams, who will do analysis for CBS College Sports; and offensive lineman Ross Tucker, who hosts a show on Sirius Satellite Radio. This year's camp had almost twice the number of applicants, a trend the league expects to continue.

To the Editor: Those of us working in the nursing home industry every day fight the image of the nursing home as a place where one should never send Mom or Dad. Thankfully, Gabrielle Selz, in her Generations essay, ''In an Unlikely Place, a Family Mom Never Imagined'' (Aug. 17), describes a different experience.

Could agility, speed, balance, rhythm and the ability to memorize complex patterns have something to do with it? We're not talking the O-line here, the guys whose job it is to impersonate a refrigerator, but wide receivers, defensive ends, running backs, cornerbacks, free safeties -- why not? When Jerry Rice, Emmitt Smith and Jason Taylor appeared on ''Dancing With the Stars'' and were obliged to master the rumba, the quickstep, the waltz and the pasodoble, they executed. (Smith, in fact, won in 2006. Taylor, pictured above, finished second earlier this year.) ''How can you be so light and so big at the same time?'' one judge marveled. Has he never seen a football game? Football is dancing, arranged around a ball. The parallels abound: plays (choreography), drills (exercises), footwork (allegro), the snap count (four for nothing), heart (heart). Like all metaphors, this one breaks down sooner or later. Ballroom dancing is itself a metaphor for love, whereas football is a (very tired) metaphor for war. Dancing goes for poetic effect, whereas football comes down to points and inches. Maybe the real surprise isn't that football players can fox-trot -- and do it well -- but that they dare to do it at all. The football player with the guts to risk abuse for taking up dancing has got to be confident in his manhood. Look at Lynn Swann, back in the '70s, going off to ballet class to improve his jump. A boy named Lynn.

1. Basic Instinct On the Patriots' first offensive play, the Giants diverged from the script, made several mistakes and still managed to put a hit on Brady, convincing themselves they could get to the All-Pro quarterback. The Patriots faked a reverse to wide receiver Wes Welker and attempted a screen pass to running back Laurence Maroney. On screens, offensive linemen typically block the defensive line for a few seconds, then release and head downfield to block for the receiver. Defensive tackles are expected to turn and follow them (A). But neither Barry Cofield nor Fred Robbins did. Robbins instead pursued Welker. Cofield, sensing a pass play, ignored Maroney and headed for Brady (B), using a ''rip'' move to shed left guard Logan Mankins (not shown). A rip is when the defender punches under the arm of the blocker and brings his own arm up, ripping the blocker's arm away. Cofield hit Brady (C) just after he released the ball, and the pass was incomplete. ''We got lucky,'' Strahan says. ''There are about five guys doing the wrong thing on this play.'' Cofield could see the surprise in Brady's eyes. ''Just his reaction, the way he got up,'' Cofield says. Notes Strahan: ''If they had completed this and gained 30 yards, we're on our heels. It's all about psyche.''

RESNICK--Donald. Artist 80 years, died peacefully at home on September 12, 2008 surrounded by family and friends. He graduated from Hobart College, Geneva, New York. Among the renowned artists Don studied with are Raphael Soyer, Seymour Lipton, Julian Levi, and Oskar Kokoschka. Painted in Maine and on Long Island, Don's works portray a distinctively American landscape and continue the heritage of American Post-Impressionism, while remaining individual and distinctive in style. His large-scale canvases reveal great masses of forms and shapes, beautiful moving fields of color and a brilliant sense of light. He is represented by Hammer Galleries of New York, Odon Wagner Gallery of Toronto and the River Gallery of Damariscotta ME. His work is in numerous private and public collections including Portland Museum of Art, Maine, National Museum of American Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC, The Farnsworth Art Museum, Rockland, Maine, the Nassau County Museum of Art, New York and the Heckscher Art Museum, Huntington, New York. He has a great love of laughter and life, and will be greatly missed by his beloved wife Jeanette, son David with his wife Iwonka and children Sam, Anja and Mollie, and his daughter Helen, her husband Howard and child Samantha, and his sister Judith and brother Ken. You better believe it. And the reason is simple: players are bigger and faster than they used to be. How much bigger? Between 1970 and 2006, the average weight of N.F.L. players at every position increased (defensive tackles, for example, grew by 20 percent). Speed is a bit more difficult to assess, since there are no systematic records of 40-yard-dash times for N.F.L. players. It's reasonable, though, to assume that the percentage increase in player speed over this period was similar to the percentage change in 100-meter-dash times: taking world-record times in this event, we can infer that player speed increased 4 percent. Now let's focus on a collision between a running back and a linebacker, and analyze it according to Newton's Second Law of Motion. This basic law of physics tells us that the force of a hit is equal to a player's mass times the acceleration he feels as a result of the hit. Consider a running back who breaks into the defensive secondary and reaches top speed as he motors for the end zone. Unfortunately for him, he's blasted head-on by a middle linebacker who has also built up a full head of steam. They collide violently and fall to the turf. Newton's Second Law tells us that the force of this impact can be approximately three-quarters of a ton. (The scientific term for this is ''getting your bell rung.'') That force is proportional to the product of the player's speed and mass, if we assume a given time (about 0.15 seconds) for the duration of the collision. By factoring in gains in mass and speed, we can estimate that the force of a full-speed hit in the N.F.L. has increased by as much as 25 percent since 1970. Hence the cliché ''football is a contact sport.''

Until last November, Jason Witten was living a nice, anonymous life on the obscure end of the Pro Bowl roster. Then he caught a pass against the Philadelphia Eagles. It was late in the game when Tony Romo hit Witten across the middle, just as two Eagles sandwiched him, snapping off his helmet. No matter. Witten ran 30 yards without it before being brought down. Suddenly the 26-year-old was a celebrity tight end, on a level of veneration reserved for Tony Gonzalez and Antonio Gates. In truth, a case can be made that Witten is the league's best tight end. He led the position last year with 96 catches for more than 1,100 yards. But what separates him from his peers (and endears him to purists) is his interest in blocking. He powered the Cowboys' running game with tough, in-line blocking, a skill he cultivated under the skeptical eye of Bill Parcells. On those plays, he prefers to keep his hat on. BRYAN CURTIS

Champ Bailey of the Denver Broncos didn't play cornerback until he got to college at the University of Georgia, but nobody had to tell him it was the toughest position in football. He had studied Deion Sanders and Darrell Green, two of the best ever at the position. And another thing: ''I looked at how much money they made,'' says Bailey (No. 24, right). ''That tells you how tough it is.'' In Bailey's view, those men were the archetype of what is now arguably the rarest player in the N.F.L.: the shutdown cornerback. Because so many teams play zone defense, the cornerbacks' job is changing; he is less frequently asked to take on a receiver man-up, something that Bailey does to such devastating effect that opponents have been known to avoid passing to his side of the field entirely. In 2006, he had 10 interceptions and didn't give up a single touchdown.

NICHINSON--David Bernard, of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Great Neck, New York, passed away at age 87 on September 5, 2008 following complications of heart surgery. He was the beloved husband of Arline Judith Nichinson for 54 years and the admired, caring and respected father of Laurel Nichinson and Dr. Bradley Nichinson. Dave was the son of Benjamin and Gertrude Nichinson, born on April 11, 1921 in Boston, Massachusetts. He attended Boston Latin School prior to graduating with a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from M.I.T. in 1942. After graduation he became a Staff Member at the M.I.T. Radiation Laboratory. He holds several patents including the Automatic Astrocompass, the Mechanical Resonant Scanner, and the Precision Tachometer System. After M.I.T. he joined Kollsman Instruments, a leading international developer and manufacturer of aviation instruments, where he later became President and CEO. He was a member of the Apollo Space Mission Navigation and Guidance Team. He was a member of the Young President's Organization and a Director of the Metropolitan President's Organization. Of the many other organizations he served on in a leadership role he was most proud of his contributions through his work as Chairman of the Long Island Chapter of The National Alliance of Businessmen, for which he received special recognition from Presidents Johnson and Nixon. After leaving Kollsman he became President and a Director of Aiken Industries which subsequently was acquired by Norlin Industries and then Amstar Group. He later served as a special adviser to Weiss, Peck and Greer's buyout activities and was on the Board of Directors of several companies. In his personal life he was a devoted husband to the love of his life, Arline, an original June Taylor Dancer, and was always a very supportive and giving father. He was artistic in his own right but also enjoyed opera, theatre, music, art, tennis, golf, bridge and fixing countless things with rubber bands and paper clips. He was an extraordinarily kind man with unparalleled integrity, ethics, modesty, not to mention his great sense of humor. Despite the sadness of his leaving us he had a wonderful and rich life. He loved and was loved without reserve. He was healthy throughout his life and always possessed, even in his final days, a strong and sharp mind. Donations may be made in his name in continued honor of his wife to the: Boca West Cancer Research Unit, c/o Nancy Fried 20621 Links View Circle, Boca Raton, FL 33434.

Say this for Mark Bavaro's breezy debut novel, ''Rough & Tumble'' (St. Martin's Press, $24.95): It is undoubtedly the best work of fiction ever to begin, '' 'H slot out Z-Motion Sixty-two Semi Y-Hook Z-Flag on two, on two!' '' Bavaro, you may recall, was the New York Giants' All-Pro tight end during the latter half of the 1980s. Powerful, smoldering, blue-collar and deeply Catholic, he was custom-tailored for New York's gritty self-image, and now he has decided to stretch out and try his hand at writing a novel concerning a powerful, smoldering, blue-collar and deeply Catholic tight end for the New York Giants. Call it semifiction. Bavaro takes care beforehand to disclaim any real-world parallels with his story, which will surely disappoint those literal-minded readers wondering about the book's flashy, hard-living linebacker or its fascist but inspirational coach. The story follows one Dominic Fucillo through a purgatory of physical ailments and lost love and seedy incidents involving gamblers and compromised teammates and dialogue like ''Cuz I'm gonna take you with me . . . to hell!'' There are stops along the way for some grim moralizing about drugs and abortion. Time was, football novels were swinging, druggy affairs that captured the native humor of the locker room. (These books were often made into films starring Burt Reynolds's mustache.) Think Dan Jenkins's masterpiece of the genre, ''Semi-Tough,'' or ''North Dallas Forty,'' by Peter Gent. That was a different N.F.L., however. In those days, Jenkins would lose himself in a stewardess's cleavage. Perhaps it says something about today's league that Bavaro lavishes the same sort of loving detail on, of all things, a team meetin T.C. a giant of letters

HITTING THE HIGH NOTES Luminaries from many fields turned out last week for a book party in Manhattan for Wynton Marsalis, the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center. Mr. Marsalis and the historian Geoffrey C. Ward have written ''Moving to Higher Ground: How Jazz Can Change Your Life.'' Joining the party was another author: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, better known for his skills on the basketball court. Mr. Abdul-Jabbar wrote ''On the Shoulders of Giants: My Journey Through the Harlem Renaissance,'' which was published last year and discusses black professional basketball in Harlem from the 1920s to the 1940s, as well as jazz musicians and other artists from the era.

If the N.F.L. had a Museum of Natural History, the Green Bay Packers should, by all rights, be found alongside the Providence Steam Rollers in the extinctspecies exhibition. Green Bay's population of barely 100,000 makes it by far the smallest city in major-league sports. Thanks to its reputation for being too cold, too remote, too boring and too white, Green Bay faces enormous challenges in attracting players. And despite a record 12 championships, the Packers have endured extended dry spells that might well have destroyed their fan base. They don't even have a deep-pocketed owner: the team is the N.F.L.'s only nonprofit corporation, held by 112,015 shareholder fans, many of whom own just a single souvenir share. So how have the Packers managed to survive -- let alone thrive -- in the modern N.F.L.? The league's almost socialist revenue-sharing rules and the salary cap have certainly helped. But they don't account for the performance both on the field and at the bank: since 1993, the team has had the best regular-season record, and has built up a rainy-day fund of $127 million. Much of the credit goes to the business acumen of the team's seven-member executive committee and its recently retired C.E.O., Bob Harlan. Composed of prominent Wisconsin executives, the committee is chosen from a 45-member board elected by the shareholders. The board selects the C.E.O., while the executive committee approves major expenses and meets monthly to review football operations and finances. Both groups serve pro bono. The team is managed so well that, in 2003, SportsBusiness Journal named it the world's best-run sports franchise.

PAUL--Jean Lithgow. The family mourns the death of their beloved mother and grandmother on September 7, 2008, in Westwood, MA, at age 89. Born on October 4, 1918, she was the daughter of Leslie and Kate Lithgow of New York City. She attended the Brearley School and Vassar College. In June 1940 she married Rev. James A. Paul, who took up the post of vicar (later rector) of The Church of the Holy Trinity (Episcopal) in New York. After the untimely death of her husband in 1957, she raised her three children, served as President of the Ladies' Christian Union and continued to be active in the Episcopal Church. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and spent many summers in Wianno on Cape Cod. In January 1981 she married Dr. Oglesby Paul (no relation to her first husband). He was then Professor of Cardiology and Dean of Admissions at the Harvard Medical School. They lived in Dedham, Massachusetts, and later at Fox Hill Village in nearby Westwood. Dr. Paul died December 22, 2007. She had a wide circle of cherished friends with whom she kept in close touch. She leaves three children and their spouses, James and Susanne Paul, Douglas and Elizabeth Paul, and Patricia and John Olive (of New York City), as well as two stepchildren and spouse, Rodman and Roberta Paul and Marguerite Paul (of Atlanta). She also leaves four grandchildren, Timothy and Jonathan Paul, Nicholas Paul and Elizabeth Olive and two step - grandchildren, David and Andrew Paul. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Dedham. A memorial service will be announced later.

Here's the exact date the football commentariat began its infatuation with Mario Williams: Nov. 18, 2007. That day, the Guy Drafted Before Reggie Bush and Vince Young registered a sack against New Orleans. He had another sack the next week and two and a half sacks the week after that. In the final six weeks of the season, he notched a total of 10, a staggering Reggie White-type achievement. Williams, who had been plagued by injuries, was finally in possession of his gifts. He has a quick step toward the quarterback -- he runs the 40 in 4.6 seconds -- and, at 6-foot-7, the long arms for redirecting thrown balls. He spent the off-season working on countermoves, the kind of crafty gamesmanship that allows a defensive end to rely on something other than athleticism. Now we're wondering what Bush and Young will have to do to catch up to Mario Williams. B.C.

Three and a half seconds: That's approximately how long a quarterback has to decide where to throw the ball. How does he survey the options while a swarm of humongous, angry men seek to pancake him? It seems obvious: a quarterback needs to think, to look at each of his receivers and make a calculation. This is one reason N.F.L. teams put so much stock in the Wonderlic intelligence test, the theory being that quarterbacks who are better at algebra will make better decisions. Unfortunately, the theory is wrong. If quarterbacks were forced to contemplate their decisions, they'd get sacked every time, a classic case of paralysis-by-analysis. What recent brain research suggests is that quarterbacks rely on their unconscious; an experienced quarterback picks up defensive details he's not even aware of. Although he doesn't consciously perceive the blitzing linebacker, the quarterback's unconscious monitors his movement. When the QB glances at his receivers, his brain converts these details into fast emotional signals, so that a receiver in tight coverage gets associated with fear, while an open man triggers a burst of positive feeling. It's these inarticulate emotions, and not an elaborate set of calculations, that tell the best quarterbacks when to let the ball fly. In the pocket, it turns out, it pays not to think.

THE rising interest in vehicles powered by electricity -- either part-time, as in hybrids like the Toyota Prius, or in battery-only cars like the Tesla Roadster -- has increased the pressure to develop more efficient devices to store the power. Progress has been steady, but huge breakthroughs have not emerged from the research labs. The baby-step pace is prompting automakers to move cautiously with their production plans. Toyota, which had been expected to use lithium-ion batteries in the next-generation Prius, announced that the car, which goes on sale next spring, will stick with proven nickel-metal-hydride chemistry.

The man plays like a frustrated wide receiver. It's not just that Antonio Cromartie caught -- that is, intercepted -- a league-leading 10 balls last season (and 2 more in the playoffs). It's that he's prone to chase the ball with abandon. ''I feel like once the ball is in the air, I have to turn into the receiver,'' Cromartie says. He's great with the ball in his hands: his zigs and zags past stunned offensive players are now grainy staples of the YouTube canon. Last year, he picked off Peyton Manning three times in a regular-season game -- a first for any player -- and then picked him off again in the playoffs. He even returned an errant field goal 109 yards for a touchdown against the Vikings. Cromartie, 24, spent the off-season in unofficial ''two-a-days'' with Deion Sanders, the rare cornerback ancestor who also comported himself like a wideout. Sanders offered Cromartie his blessing. At this rate, it seems a little redundant. B.C.

Enron, the former energy behemoth, reported $63 billion in assets when it famously spiraled into bankruptcy protection in late 2001. WorldCom, the telecommunications giant, had $107 billion in assets when it slumped into Chapter 11 protection the following year.

The Institute of Contemporary Arts, London's first arts center devoted to avant-garde art, culture and ideas, is celebrating its 60th birthday. Tucked away within the Nash terraces that line London's Mall, the building's classical façade defies the ICA's radical manifesto. Originally conceived in 1947 by poet, anarchist, art critic and historian Herbert Read as a "laboratory" or "playground" for contemporary arts, it continues to present a program of work from emergent artists and radical thinkers.
Standard & Poor's downgraded the American International Group's long-term and short-term counterparty ratings on Monday night, a move that could presage the eventual collapse of the insurance giant.
“Enter Laughing” is getting a hilarious second-chance staging by the York Theater Company.
A nonprofit adoption agency has designed a program in Illinois that provides foster children with adoptive parents and surrogate grandparents.
Barbra Streisand was a strong admirer of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton during the Democratic presidential primary, but she has since become a supporter of Senator Barack Obama.

In the early hours of Monday morning, the World Association of Newspapers posted a lengthy communique on its Web site calling the Google-Yahoo advertising partnership anti-competitive and urging regulators to block the deal. According to its Web site, the World Association of Newspapers represents 76 national newspaper associations and more than 18,000 publications in five continents. Its communique led to flurry of headlines that essentially said "Newspapers Around World Oppose Yahoo-Google Ad Deal."

The Web may seem ubiquitous to most of us, but its creator, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, keeps seeing its limitations. And he keeps trying to do something about those limitations, and make sure the Web is as open and widely accessible as possible.

In this final stretch of the presidential campaign, with blog posts and ads and campaign e-mails all rolling by so quickly, it seems we're all in need of a little guidance to cut through - as our colleague Adam Nagourney wrote this morning - the "fog" of what's thrown up on the wall to see what sticks. This is an effort to grasp onto the meaningful. And sometimes, to offer up what's available for laughs along the way. We're calling this feature "Last Words," but by no means will it be the last word of the day or night. We'll note what's catching our fancy, and feel free to suggest what's caught your eye.

The science debate has begun -- sort of. Senator John McCain has submitted answers to the 14 questions on science and technology policy asked by ScienceDebate08, the group that has been trying to arrange a live debate between the candidates. Addressing rumors that he might yet seek to run for re-election, Representative Vito J. Fossella issued a statement this afternoon to firmly say that he was sticking to his decision not to seek a sixth consecutive term."I am deeply humbled by the outpouring of support that I have received from people throughout the district through these difficult times, but I am not a candidate for Congress," Mr. Fossella said in a statement released by his office. "As I have stated before, my priorities are my family and serving the people of Staten Island and Brooklyn."

On Monday the Swedish Elitserien became the last European league to begin its 2008-09 season, which it did before a capacity crowd of 7,038 fans at the Kinnarps Arena in Jönköping.

Top city officials held a press conference on Monday to reassure New Yorkers that despite a weekend that reshaped the landscape of Wall Street, the city had long been fiscally prudent in preparing for a downturn in the financial sector."The things that New Yorkers need to know is that we planned for a day like today," said Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, trying to quell fears on a day where the storied Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy, Merrill Lynch announced it would be bought by Bank of America New York State allowed the insurance giant A.I.G. to access $20 billion in subsidiary assets, and the Dow had the largest drop since the days after 9/11.

As city and state officials assessed the potential fallout from the collapse of Lehman Brothers on Monday, the speaker of the State Assembly said he expected the State Legislature to reconvene in an emergency session to address the faltering economy.

Nearly all of the results from last week's primary races were decided by wide enough margins, enough to avoid the painstaking recount drama that often besets New York City elections. There was one tight race, however, in a relatively obscure race for a position of Democratic district leader in Flushing, Queens. This race involves a former city councilwoman, Julia Harrison, who has run for several positions since leaving the Council after the 2001 election.

Internet | Sir Tim Berners-Lee, World Wide Web creator, says the Internet needs a way to separate rumor from real science. Not I.Q. ratings, because Web sites, like people, "can vary in all kinds of different ways" -- but "labeling Web sites in different ways." Also, with only 20 percent of the world on the Web, "has it been designed by the West for the West?" [BBC]
Lisa Kahane stood at the corner of Intervale Avenue and Home Street, surprised by what she saw -- two-story row houses with blue awnings and aluminum siding.
Parents take their children to the doctor to help keep them well. So it's always chilling to read stories about children who are harmed as a result of medical care.

Four years ago at the Athens Paralympics, the United States didn't even have the opportunity to play for the gold medal. The team was upset by Canada in the semifinal and had to settle for bronze, as chronicled in the popular documentary film "Murderball." Since that day in Athens, the U.S. has been on a mission to get back to the gold medal game and sit atop the medal podium once again. On Monday, the Americans got one step closer to its goal, narrowly defeating Britain, 35-32, to earn a berth in the championship game.
Your Money writers Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard answered readers’ questions about the impact of the turmoil in the financial services industry on consumers and investors.

Dedicated bus lanes are starting on 34th Street on Monday as part of the city's effort to reduce congestion along one of the busiest roadways in New York. The red lanes, on a two-mile stretch from First to 11th Avenue in Manhattan, will be in effect from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. and will be enforced by the police.

The stock market isn't doing as badly as one might have feared -- although it's just broken below Dow 11,000 as I write. But Felix Salmon suggests that we look at my old standby, the TED spread, shown above -- and it's looking kinda spiky. All in all, way too soon to conclude that we won this game of Russian roulette.

Business | A counterweight to "innovation economics" (two posts down): a blogger asks what innovation means in investment banking -- in light of the tumbles of Lehman, Bear, Fannie and Freddie? Is innovation what caused the trouble in the first place? What good is it, if it flows from "greed, ignorance, fools and their money"? And can it get us out of this mess? Is Goldman Sachs innovative, or the opposite? [NEXT, Nussbaum on Design]

Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin not only provided a boost to ABC's "World News with Charles Gibson" last week, but she also proved popular during prime time. In Rolling Stone's new comedy issue, prominent comedians are asked to name the "funniest movie ever" and the "funniest TV ever." Robin Williams makes the best choice for funniest film ("Dr. Strangelove"); Gilbert Gottfried ("Duck Soup"), Tina Fey ("Election") and Billy Crystal ("Some Like It Hot") also make good selections; and Jimmy Fallon chooses what you might expect Jimmy Fallon to choose (the "Naked Gun" movies). As for television, Chris Rock goes for "The Simpsons" (excellent pick), Eric Idle opts for "Flight of the Conchords" (very good), and Larry David cites "The Phil Silvers Show" (hilarious) and "Amos 'n' Andy" (huh?).
As Christina Ripp watched her U.S. teammates finish the first quarter of the women's wheelchair basketball gold-medal game trailing Germany, 12-9, she did not panic.

With the news that his school would be receiving an F on the city's report card this week, Seth Phillips, the principal of Public School 8 in Brooklyn Heights, sent a letter [pdf] on Friday to parents, offering his own explanation. Congressman Charles B. Rangel ducked reporters on Monday as he appeared before friendly audiences in Harlem and midtown Manhattan, declining to answer reporters' questions about his finances and his hiring of a forensic accountant to review his Congressional ethics disclosure records for additional problems.At an event in Harlem on Monday morning, the congressman told reporters that he planned to meet with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, but declined to elaborate. In New York, the push for paid leave for workers who take time off to care for a newborn or a sick family member has faltered, with the Democratic-controlled State Assembly approving such legislation, but the Republican-controlled Senate blocking it.

Boneless (or butterflied) leg of lamb may be the best meat for grilling: it cooks reasonably quickly but still develops an irresistibly crunchy crust, and, even better, that crust can be flavored in minutes before it is cooked with any of a dozen combinations of seasonings. And the meat itself has exquisite flavor and really needs no more than salt.

While we are no longer taking questions for this feature, readers are encouraged to continue the discussion in the comments.

Two prominent Wall Street firms have faltered, with Merrill Lynch agreeing to sell itself to Bank of America for roughly $50 billion to avert a deepening financial crisis. And another prominent securities company, Lehman Brothers, filed for bankruptcy protection and hurtled toward liquidation after it failed to find a buyer after a Sunday filled with brinkmanship.
Updated: Shares in the American International Group plunged 50 percent on Monday morning, as uncertainty over its vital credit rating clouded its future.

Economics | What has economists and policy-makers juiced lately: the new field of "innovation economics." It goes beyond tax and spend. The new focus is on number-crunching the hard data from innovations that work and making policy to match. For some reason, this hasn't been a huge focus of dismal scientists before now. But not a moment too soon? [Business Week]

At the restaurant Perbacco you want to get the baked pasta with truffled zabaglione. Correction: you need to get the baked pasta with truffled zabaglione, a dish that also includes speck, buffalo milk mozzarella and béchamel.

Best Buy said Monday that it would acquire Napster, the digital music pioneer that has refashioned itself into a music subscription service, for $121 million.

Did the United States orchestrate the recent war between Georgia and Russia to boost Senator John McCain's presidential chances? Vladimir Putin, Russia's prime minister, suggested as much during an interview with CNN late last month, and many readers of The Times Moscow bureau's Russian-language Livejournal blog agreed. The bureau recently posted a Russian translation of a Times article covering Mr. Putin's remarks to its blog and asked its readers what they thought of their prime minister's accusation. Given Apple's super-secretive ways, it's quite a shock to find a company engineer disclosing something about the iPhone's future innards on a public social networking site.

Psychology | Is Sarah Palin turning people into head cases? You be the judge, as readers describe her appearances in their dreams and nightmares. "She hands you a $20 bill. She marries you. She tells you to kill all the animals in the zoo. She's your barista." [Slate]

The banking crisis that gripped Wall Street this weekend is sending a shudder through City Hall. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his top deputies plan to gather Monday morning to assess the potential economic fallout from the liquidation of Lehman Brothers and the sale of Merrill Lynch, which together employ 85,000 people, many of them in New York City.Mr. Bloomberg was worried enough about the situation that he canceled a high-profile trip to California, where he was to meet with Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Monday.

With oil supplies a concern in the wake of Hurricane Ike, Congress will turn full attention this week to its politically charged energy fight as both the House and Senate are scheduled to bring broad energy legislation to the floor.
The first wave of rescuers prepared for the worst as they made their way to the Bolivar Peninsula in Texas, which was hit hard by Ike's storm surge.

Biography | A biography explores Florence Nightingale's responsibility for the profession's low status and pay. As this review says, "Her unshakeable conviction that nursing represented a call from God, reinforced perhaps by the blinkers of her own secure social position ... led her fiercely to oppose moves to organize nurses into associations." [TLS]

Wall Street and the federal government played a game of chicken over the weekend, and neither side backed down, pushing Lehman Brothers into bankruptcy and setting off worries of a worldwide sell-off when markets open on Monday, The New York Times's Floyd Norris and Vikas Bajaj reported.

Fear and greed are the stuff that Wall Street is made of. But, as The New York Times's Ben White and Jenny Anderson report, inside the great banking houses, those high temples of capitalism, fear came to the fore this weekend.

Even though the Federal Reserve refused to provide a financial backstop to potential buyers of Lehman Brothers, concerns over what may unfold in the market on Monday led it to dramatically loosen its standards on making emergency loans to major Wall Street investment banks, The New York Times's Edmund L. Andrews reported.

As the reverberations following the stunning developments in the financial industry over the weekend began to spread, Wilbur Ross, founder of private equity firm WL Ross & Company, made his prediction for what to expect next.
When TPG Capital stepped in to lead a $7 billion bailout of Washington Mutual in April, it may have been catching a falling knife, The Deal says.
It's the end of an era for Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm that brought Wall Street to Main Street.

Bank of America's dream of dominating the brokerage business always seemed to elude it, even after it transformed itself from a regional bank into a consumer banking powerhouse through two decades of big acquisitions.
Charles O. Prince III, the former chairman and chief of Citigroup, has found a new home, according to The Wall Street Journal.

As European stock markets opened sharply down Monday, major central banks said that they were braced to intervene to stabilize money markets after the upheaval on Wall Street, The New York Times's Carter Dougherty and Julia Werdigier reported.

Futures contracts on American stocks declined along with the dollar on Monday in Asia, dragging down the half-dozen stock markets in the region that were open, The New York Times's Keith Bradsher reports. Asia's biggest financial markets were closed for a major holiday.

The Italian government seemed to make progress Sunday in brokering a deal that would keep Alitalia flying after concerns over the weekend that the airline might have to ground flights because it could not get jet fuel, according to The New York Times's Caroline Brothers.

Stanley Fink, one of the most influential and wealthiest figures in London's financial circles, is back on the scene less than two months after officially retiring from the Man Group, the world's largest listed hedge fund.
U.S. regulators will not allow mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to pay their departing chief executives multimillion-dollar severance packages outlined in their contracts.
CVS Caremark says it is standing by its $2.7 billion bid for Longs Drug Stores, despite the announcement Friday by Walgreen Company that it had tabled a $3 billion offer for Longs.

Electronic Arts said Sunday that it had withdrawn its $2 billion hostile takeover bid for Take Two Interactive, ending an eight-month struggle involving two of the biggest names in the video game business, The New York Times's Matt Richtel writes.
Think Global, a Norwegian maker of electric vehicles, plans to raise $80 million in a third round of funding by the end of the year, VentureWire reported Friday.
The swift, sharp and short-lived collapse of United Airlines shares last Monday was followed by a week of finger-pointing, The New York Times's Miguel Helft reports.

UBS, under scrutiny in the United States for the conduct of its offshore private-banking unit for wealthy Americans, hopes to reach a settlement with the Justice Department and regulators within the next two weeks, The Financial Times reported.

In June, Gov. Charlie Crist announced that Florida would buy one of the state's two big sugar enterprises, the United States Sugar Corporation. Environment | San Antonio will capture methane gas from its residents' waste and sell it. The city also recycles wastewater and makes compost from sewage. It's a "renewable recyclable trifecta." [Associated Press]

From time to time, I intend to post exceptional poems on the subject of aging. One of my favorites is "The Old Fools" by Philip Larkin, called to my attention several years ago by a novelist-turned-friend, Hilma Wolitzer.

Sport | If he hadn't hot-dogged it at the end, Usain Bolt could have shaved his world record at the Olympics from 9.69 seconds to 9.55, physicists calculate. They used TV footage to measure his deceleration in the final two seconds, when he extended his arms and thumped his chest. [New Scientist]

Andrew Berends, a documentary filmmaker who lives in Brooklyn, only had the chance to make a phone call about 15 hours after he was detained by Nigerian officials while gathering footage of women at a market in the Niger Delta, an area rich with oil and with frequent militant uprisings. The moment he could, he called a friend in Nigeria and instructed him to get in touch with the United States Embassy and with Aaron Soffin, the 26-year-old associate producer of Mr. Berends's film ''Delta Boys.'' ''Aaron, good morning,'' began the concise e-mail message that Mr. Soffin received when he woke up at 8 a.m. on Labor Day. It gave the barest facts about Mr. Berends's arrest in Port Harcourt, Nigeria, and ended: ''He is in trouble and needs help, fast.'' Mr. Soffin, who lives in the East Village and had been planning to leave that week for Rwanda, stared at the message, trying to figure out what to do. His first thought: Call someone who will know what to do.

SHOR--Shannon, aka Patti Jacob, on September 11, 2008. Beloved wife of Jack Shor. Dear mother of Joanna Jacob, Daniel Jacob, Daniel Shor, Arkey Shor and mother-in-law of John Post, Jie Hua Shor. During the, ''Big Band'' era, she sang and recorded with Charlie Spivak, Buddy DeFranco, and Tommy Dorsey. In later years she was a counselor to victims of addiction to alcohol and other drugs. Funeral services private.

The victory moved South Florida to No. 12 from No. 19 in the Associated Press poll.

DEAD CONFEDERATE ''Wrecking Ball'' (TAO/Razor & Tie) Hardy Morris, the lead singer of the Athens, Ga., band Dead Confederate, has a good voice for rock 'n' roll, and he uses it with all appropriate conviction. Within the first few seconds of ''Wrecking Ball,'' a well-put-together debut album, he's already snarling over a guitar riff, anxious to bring the pot to a boil. But then when he does, a minute and a half in, there's a moment of startling recognition. ''Over and over I'm ashamed,'' Mr. Morris howls. He sounds a lot like Kurt Cobain, and the chorus distinctly recalls Nirvana.

SELASSIE--Mary - Ann, be loved mother and grandmother, passed away in her home, September 11th, 2008 in NYC at age 72. A dedicated volunteer, she cherished her role as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 35 years. She was also involved in many outreach committees in her church. She was a life member of the Church Club of New York, Cathedral Guild. City Gardens Club and AWOGA. Originally from Sierra Leone, BA in linguistics, University of Wisconsin; MA in Education, Columbia University; she started out at the United Nations continuing on to teach for 30 years. She is survived by her children Astaire and Sengal, grandchildren Lukas and Eden. brothers Dr. Eldred Wright and Mr. Ernest Wright and sisters Mrs. Amelia King, Mrs. Ola Campbell and Mrs. Admira Williams. Visitation will be on Tuesday, September 16th from 1-3pm and 68pm at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel (Madison and 81st St.). A funeral service will be held on Wednesday September 17th 1:30pm at the Church of the Heavenly Rest (Fifth Avenue and 90th St). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the United Thank Offering c/o Church of the Heavenly Rest.
KOREY--Barry, M.D., died September 13 in the arms of his beloved wife and children. May his name be a blessing.

HERSH--Albert on Saturday, September 13th, at the age of 93. Loving and beloved husband of Kit, founder of PlyGem Industries, on the New York Stock Exchange. Former president of the National Hardwood Association and former president of Cold Spring Country Club. So proud of being an Eagle Scout along with his brothers Edward, Bernard and Leon. Prouder still of his children, Jeffrey Hersh, Los Angeles, California, Judy and Jerry Cohn, Great Neck, New York and his granddaughter Lisa Schoen. Incredible stepfather to James, Stacy, Jill and Peter Margolin and ''Pappa Al'' to their children. A celebration of his life will be held in October. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Humane Society of Boca Raton, FL.

The Cowboys' offensive output in Week 1, 487 yards, ranked behind only the Eagles' 522. Donovan McNabb spread his 361 passing yards around; receivers DeSean Jackson, Greg Lewis and Hank Baskett had 100-yard games. Tony Romo will rely on Jason Witten and Terrell Owens as usual. Owens will move into second place on the N.F.L. career list with his next touchdown reception; only Jerry Rice will have more. Dallas has 40 victories on Monday night, the most in league history, and it is 20-1 when Marion Barber has at least 11 carries. But the Cowboys have lost three of their last four games against the Eagles, including the last two at Texas Stadium. Romo struggled in those games, throwing one touchdown pass and five interceptions. He was sacked seven times. ANDREW DAS

DARIUS RUCKER ''Learn to Live'' (Capitol Nashville) No pop star has ever needed rescuing from his reputation more than Darius Rucker, frontman of Hootie & the Blowfish, perhaps the least consequential successful band ever. Though it had a string of hits in the mid-90s -- it's 1994 debut album ''Cracked Rear View'' has gone platinum 16 times over -- those songs felt like anomalies: warm, largely optimistic bar-band anthems carried by Mr. Rucker's burly baritone.

O'BRIEN--Sally, A. Sally O'Brien, 78, of Greenwich, CT died Friday, September 12th from injuries sustained in an accident. She was surrounded by her family. She is survived by her two daughters and eight grandchildren. Her daughter Morgan Coffey and her husband Joe Coffey of Chevy Chase, MD, and their four children: Rory, Sam, Bennett and Max. Her daughter Sarah Tierney and her husband George Tierney of Fairfield, CT and their children Sam, Isabel, Nicholas and Hope. She also leaves her beloved sister, Suzanne Powell and her family of Wellesley, MA. And her sister Natalie Gibbons. Born Sally Stebbins in Boston, MA on September 27, 1929. She graduated from Jean D'Arc Academy. After graduating from Manhattanville College in 1951, Sally worked in the White House for then First Lady, Mamie Eisenhower. Sally was a 50 year resident of Greenwich and one of the most legendary and successful Greenwich realtors. She began her career at Preferred Properties and opened her own firm, Sally O'Brien & Associates in 1980. Sally was a gifted athlete and an avid sports fan. Her greatest joy in life was being with her family, especially her eight grandchildren Sally was predeceased by her husband Royall D. O'Brien and her daughter Hope Stebbins O'Brien. Memorial services are pending. Contact Leo P. Gallagher for details 203869-1513.

With Fashion Week here, it's time to introduce a new collection of puzzles. Start by solving the first six puzzles, each of which will give you a five- or six-letter answer word. Then follow the instructions for the final puzzle, ''Complete Ensemble,'' to get the answer to this question: Why are fashion houses so concerned about about hem lengths?

SORKIN--Sidney, of Merrick, New York, died on September 12, 2008 at age 91. Beloved husband of Lilly Sorkin for 68 years, loving father of Larry (Joan) and Steve, and adored grandfather of Andrew (Pilar) and Suzie. He had an abiding love of books, photography, Gilbert & Sullivan, and crossword puzzles -done always in ink. He had infinite patience, a keen intellect, and a caring and generous spirit. He will be warmly remembered by all who knew him. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a favorite charity.

CARROLL--Thomas J., 81, a Wall Street veteran, formerly of Unionville, PA, died September 11 at his farm in Middleburg, VA surrounded by his family. Carroll, the son of the late Harry Joseph and Kathryn (McLaughlin) Carroll was born and raised in Philadelphia, PA. He left high school prior to graduation in 1945 to serve in the United States Army until the end of World War II. Carroll began his professional career in 1947 at the investment firm of Cartwright and Parmelee, in New York City. In December of 1969 he founded Carroll, McEntee & McGinley, a primary government bond dealer, now part of HSBC. He was an Emeritus Trustee of The Foxcroft School in Middleburg, VA. He started the Christopher T. Carroll Foundation, which donates money to cancer research grants across the U.S. A lifelong horseman, he was involved in foxhunting, steeplechase and flat racing. His wife Joan preceded him in death in 2003. They mourned the death of their son Christopher Carroll of Chicago, IL in 2001. He is survived by Margaret Eldridge of San Diego, CA, Cornelius X. Carroll (Sally), of Windmere, FL, Michael Carroll (Lori) of Glenview, IL, Joann Linden (Lindsey) of Reston, VA, Thomas J., Jr. (Margaret) of Rectortown, VA and Moira Carroll of Chicago, IL; two sisters, Mary Nicholson and Regina Lauria; and grandchildren Leah, Christopher, Corey, Michael Jr., Gillian, Kiely, and Thomas. He is also preceded in death by his sister Kathleen. A celebration of his life will begin at a Catholic mass Wednesday, September 17 at 11:30am at St. Stephen the Martyr Catholic Church, 23331 Sam Fred Road, Middleburg Virginia. Donations can be made in his honor to the V Foundation for Cancer Research, 106 Towerview Court, Cary, NC 27513.

As a teacher, I always find it easier to keep my students focused when they can see the connection between what they are studying and their own lives. Those that read newspapers (few) or watch the news (not a majority) are already connected: after all, the federal government is our largest local employer, with many parents and siblings working in various branches. But many neither read or watch the news unless I push them, so I have to find other ways of making those connections. One effective way is inviting guest speakers involved with or covering the federal government to our class. Another is to examine the impact of federal policy on the lives of the students and their family. Both are a regular part of my instructional approach.

Smith, the minority leader of the State Senate, asked the Legislature and Gov. David A. Paterson to convene "and take every action necessary to protect New York's future." Mr. Paterson has not yet decided whether or not to call legislators to Albany for their second special session in as many months to address the state budget. Washington Mutual shares extended their downward spiral Monday as investors wagered on which troubled financial firm could be next to fall following the demise of Lehman Brothers Holdings and Merrill Lynch.
BitTorrent, the peer-to-peer content distributor, has raised a $17 million third round from previous investors DCM and Accel Partners, as well as DAG Ventures, according to peHUB.

CSX said two additional nominees put forth by The Children's Investment Fund would gain seats on its board, after the third-largest U.S. railroad company lost an appeal to block them.
A California law firm will sue Fannie Mae on Tuesday on behalf of holders of the mortgage finance company's preferred shares, a lawyer with the firm said late Monday.

National City, a Midwestern regional bank battered by mortgage losses, has won stockholder approval to authorize new shares to allow for a $7 billion capital infusion, the bank said on Monday.

Adecco of Switzerland, the world's no. 1 recruitment company, said on Tuesday that it was dropping its proposed 1.3 billion pound ($2.4 billion) unsolicited bid for British rival Michael Page, two weeks ahead of a British regulatory deadline to make a formal offer.

Alitalia appeared to inch back from the verge of bankruptcy Monday as four of its nine unions agreed on the outline of a business plan for the carrier, but negotiations were to continue on the thornier challenge of a new labor contract.
Shareholders of Wendy's and Triarc approved a $2.34 billion deal on Monday that will make the nation's No. 3 hamburger chain a part of billionaire investor Nelson Peltz's empire.

Travel | A business-travel blogger confesses to being baffled by tipping in restaurants. Who precisely gets the tip? It's a labor issue, as illustrated by recent incidents of management taking its cut. Such cases show "the absurd uncertainty that lies at the heart of the practice." "How far does this sharing go? Does the dishwasher benefit? The chef?" [Gulliver]

Religion | In Britain, where congregations are dwindling, Christians go to dating workshops to help them find a partner. But an online Christian dating agency says it's not a good idea to use pickup lines like, "You float my ark" and, "I didn't believe in predestination until tonight." [London Telegraph]

Readers of last week's post, "Catching Seniors Before They Fall," about the nation's leading research center devoted to fall prevention, were hungry for more information about medical issues, exercise programs and home safety steps to reduce the risk of falls, the leading cause of injury and disability in seniors.

Afghanistan | Two articles (here and here) agree that the Afghan insurgency should really be called the Afghan-Pakistan war. The Taliban and its Qaeda guests were from the start "a projection of Pakistani state power," writes Christopher Hitchens. Since Obama is the more militant about Pakistan in the campaign, he adds, his election could augur a protracted war under a liberal President that liberals don't want. [Spectator, Slate]
Share prices kept falling overseas today. Markets that were open Monday generally lost around 1 percent more today. Those that were closed did much worse.

Film | The German director Andreas Dresen on his drama "Cloud Nine," about geriatric sex: older people "fly a bit higher in their passion. Perhaps they're asking themselves how often they will experience this again?" He worked at an "aesthetic" for showing aging, lovemaking bodies onscreen. That's a taboo he links to "a cultural fear of death." [Sign and Sight]

Advertising | Microsoft's new ad campaign featuring Bill Gates and Jerry Seinfeld is part of the culture wars, an article suggests, with the geeky Gates playing the antithesis of elitist Apple and its "aspirational cool." Next stop, Sarah Palin's house? [Economist, Los Angeles Times]

An entry in the N.F.L. Injury Report on Monday reversed the outcome of the San Diego-Denver game, during which running back LaDainian Tomlinson of the Chargers was bothered by a jammed toe. Denver won.

An obituary on Thursday about Oded Schramm, a mathematician who developed an equation that can be applied to a variety of physics problems, misstated the field of research of his doctoral thesis. It was complex analysis, not topology.
An article on Aug. 23 about the Chinese men’s Olympic field hockey team misidentified the individual who is known as Wei Wei. It is the player named Meng Lizhi — not his mother, Au Sutao.

An article on Monday about residents of the Simi Valley, Calif., area who died in Friday’s train collision in the San Fernando Valley referred incorrectly in some editions to Carol Becker, to whom one victim, Maria Elena Villalobos, a fashion design student, was taking a new sketch for a blouse when she was killed. Ms. Becker was a friend of Ms. Villalobos, not her former elementary school teacher.

An article in some editions on Aug. 25 about the political legacy of Hyman Schorenstein, a Democratic kingmaker in Brooklyn and delegate to the 1924 Democratic National Convention whose great-great-niece Marissa Shorenstein was a delegate to the 2008 convention, misstated the year that Mr. Schorenstein, according to family lore, persuaded Alfred E. Smith, a former presidential candidate and New York governor, to place Herbert H. Lehman’s name in nomination for governor. It was 1932, not 1933.

An article on Sunday about the deadly crash of a Metrolink commuter train and a freight train in California referred incorrectly to the employer of the commuter train engineer, who was killed in the crash. The engineer was employed by a Metrolink subcontractor, not an Amtrak subcontractor.

An article on Sept. 3 about a pledge by officials of the telecommunications company Alcatel-Lucent that they would push ahead with the integration of the troubled French-American company misstated the number of jobs the company had cut since it was created in a 2006 merger. It is about 9,000 jobs — not 16,500, the total number of jobs the company plans to cut by the end of 2009. (The incorrect figure also appeared in a July 30 article about the company’s top two executives stepping down. That error was discovered while researching this correction.).

An article on Monday about plans for the Smithsonian Institution outlined by G. Wayne Clough, its new chief executive, misstated the goal of the institution’s capital campaign. It is to raise more than $1 billion over five to seven years, not $5 million to $7 million.

EVANS--Judith. Brilliant, gracious, spirited, resilient, Judith was a true partner to our beloved founding president, Eli Evans, and a devoted mother to their cherished son, Josh. The Board of Directors and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation grieve with Eli and Josh and with their expansive circle of family and friends throughout the world. May they find comfort in Judith's courage and enduring love. Martha Minow, Chair Julie Sandorf, President

A slender young woman hung 30 feet in the air, coiling her body around two pieces of black silk that were attached to the rafters. A crowd watching below screamed as she unraveled herself and started falling toward them and then gasped with relief as she came to a stop just above their heads. The woman, Anya Sapozhnikova, was performing her aerial circus act, but this was not Cirque du Soleil, and there was no big top. Instead, it was a warehouse party in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
DUNN--Oscar L., 1914-2006. With Oscar's spirit remember your high school band, support ''C'' students, then go fishing with a friend after mixed doubles. ''Back home again in Indiana...'' Alex

CHONG--Lawrence M. The Mental Health Association of NYC mourns the death of our esteemed Board member. Former President and current Co-Chairman, he provided 15 years of visionary leadership to the organization. His compassion, wisdom, advice and dedication to the MHA and its mission will be sorely missed. Heartfelt condolences to Barbara and the entire Chong family. A jury convicted six defendants on Monday of plotting attacks on public facilities. They were among 12 men accused of planning to attack major sites around Melbourne as part of a radical Islamist cell. Prosecutors said the targets included the Melbourne Cricket Ground during the 2005 championship game of the Australian Football League, and the Australian Formula One Grand Prix. None of the attacks were carried out. Four defendants were acquitted, and the jury was still considering the charges against two others. An Algerian-born Muslim cleric, Abdul Nacer Benbrika, was found guilty of leading the group.

Victims of a stampede Monday in Pasuruan, East Java, Indonesia, who are shown in light cast by an orange canopy. At least 21 died in the crush, and several were injured. The stampede happened as people lined up for gifts of about $4 a person from a wealthy family, a tradition during the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.

(Fox) HOUSE When last we saw House (Hugh Laurie), he was trying to piece his memories -- and his life -- back together after a bus accident that resulted in the death of Amber (Anne Dudek), Wilson's girlfriend. This season premiere begins as Wilson (Robert Sean Leonard, left) returns from an extended leave and announces that he's quitting Princeton-Plainsboro Teaching Hospital. House thinks that's a bad idea. And the timing is terrible since House has to figure out why the hard-working 37-year-old assistant to a feminist leader collapsed during a business meeting. SCHWIND--Michael. NYU School of Law mourns the loss of alumnus Michael Schwind who served on the faculty from 1964 to 1994. A pioneer in comparative law, he trained countless foreign lawyers. He was a committed colleague, beloved teacher, and pillar of the Law School community. He will be deeply missed. Richard Revesz, Dean, NYU School of Law

YUAN--Michael Shengtien, (November 17, 1959 to September 14, 2008). Dr. Michael S. Yuan died on September 14, 2008 after a long and courageous battle with lung cancer. Dr. Yuan was an Associate Professor of Clinical Dental Medicine at Columbia University College of Dental Medicine. Dr. Yuan was born in Taiwan (ROC) and had a brief acting career in the movies with a leading role in the Taiwanese motion picture ''Jade Love'' (1984). After he earned his dental degree at National Taiwan University and completed two years of military service, he came to the United States in 1988 for additional studies at Columbia University. Between 1988 and 2000 he specialized in Orthodontics, earned a Master's Degree in Dental Sciences, and a Ph.D. Degree in Anthropology. He joined the faculty of the College of Dental Medicine of Columbia University as Assistant Professor of Clinical Dental Medicine in December of 2000, where he assumed teaching responsibilities in human anatomy (for both medical and dental students), oral biology and orthodontics, while also continuing some teaching activities in anthropology. He also co-authored a major anthropological text, ''The Human Fossil Record, Brain Endocasts, The Paleoneurological Evidence.'' During his all too brief academic career Dr. Yuan became one of the most beloved teachers in both the medical and dental school at Columbia, as was evidenced by three Teacher of the Year Awards by the College of Physicians and Surgeons and the Edward V. Zegarelli Teaching Award by the College of Dental Medicine in 2008. His empathy for and devotion to his students were legendary. Even as his disease took its toll, he continued to meet all his classes to deliver his meticulously crafted lectures. Dr. Yuan is survived by his mother, Mrs. Li-Jiuan Wu Yuan (Tainan City, Taiwan), his sisters Grace and Susan, and their families. He will be remembered fondly by his many students, friends, and colleagues throughout the world. Ira B. Lamster D.D.S., M.M.Sc. Dean Letty Moss-Salentijn D.D.S., Ph.D. Senior Associate Dean for Academic Affairs Thomas J. Cangialosi, D.D.S. Chair, Section of Growth & Development Director, Division of Orthodontics Columbia University College of Dental Medicine

DALESSANDRO--John J. II (Jack), of New York and Southampton, NY died peacefully at home on September 14th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. He was 71. Jack leaves his beloved wife of 37 years, Frances Wynne Callahan (Fran) and his nephew, Alfred J. Callahan III. Jack graduated from Eastern Military Academy, Huntington, NY and from Villanova University, class of 1959. He served in the U.S. Army Reserve. Jack began his career with McDonnell and Co. and went on to found the John J. Dalessandro Co., a floor brokerage firm and member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 35 years. He was president of the Stock Exchange Luncheon Club for three consecutive terms. Most recently, Jack was a trustee of the Allianz Global Investors Sponsored Closed End Funds. Jack was an avid vintage car enthusiast and rallyist in Bridgehampton and Italy. In 2006 and 2007 he raced in the Mille Miglia. He was a member of the Bathing Corporation of Southampton, the Meadow Club of Southampton, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, and the Sailfish Club of Palm Beach. His family will receive friends at the O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, NY on Thursday, September 18th from 7 to 9pm and on Friday, September 19th from 2 to 4pm and from 7 to 9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said in celebration of his life at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, Southampton, NY on Saturday, September 20th at 9am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his name to Villanova University Development Office, 800 Lancaster Avenue, Villanova, PA 19085-1603.

Talking Business: Joe Nocera. [A23.]

GERALD--William L. The staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) note with sadness the death of our esteemed colleague William L. Gerald. Dr. Gerald, who joined MSKCC in 1992, was a surgical pathologist with a special interest in cancers of young people and the molecular biology of cancer. He was a noted researcher whose work centered on identifying and characterizing the clinically relevant molecular alterations in human cancers and the changes in gene expression that contribute to the development of cancer. He will be deeply missed for his collaborative spirit, which led to the application of his research in diagnosis, prognostication, and therapeutic design. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Lucta, and his family. Marc K. Rosenblum, Chair, Department of Pathology Charles L. Sawyers, Chair, Human Oncology and Pathogenesis Program Robert E. Wittes, Physician-in-Chief Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center
