An article on Monday about Senator Barack Obama's record-setting fund-raising in August, of $66 million, misstated the amount he has raised over all. It is more than $440 million, not $340 million.

BOOTH--John E., August 23, 1919 to September 10, 2008. John E. Booth started his career at The New York Times, remaining with the Times for 10 years, less wartime service in Belgium and France during World War II. The major part of his work at the Times was as an editorwriter in the Sunday Department and as a writer with the Drama Section. Mr. Booth also contributed to the Times' editorial pages. Subsequently Mr. Booth joined the press staff of the Marshall Plan in Paris and London. Returning to New York City, Mr. Booth joined the Twentieth Century Fund, becoming Associate Director in 1970. John Booth contributed to the Atlantic, Harper's, Theater Arts Monthly, Stage and co-authored the classic ''Actors Talk About Acting', Random House, 1963. He also wrote ''The Critic, Power and the Performing Arts'', Columbia University Press, 1991. Mr. Booth was co-founder and first President of the Theater Development Fund (''TKTS'' in Times Square). He served on the boards of the American Place Theater, Playwrights Horizons and AfroAmerican Total Theater. At the time of his death he was an active member of the TDF's Independent Committee on Arts Policy. John Booth began teaching writing at Sing Sing Prison in 1990. Then, after moving to Santa Fe in 2002, he taught at the New Mexico Penitentiary where he was named ''Volunteer of the Year for 2007''. John will be greatly missed by his associates in the theater, the many inmates whom he taught, his family and many friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Heart Mountain Prison Project, 1223 St. Francis Drive, Suite C, Santa Fe, NM 87505.

Remarks by Senator John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee, at a town-hall-style meeting in Orlando, Fla., on Monday, as transcribed by The New York Times: '' America is in a crisis today. Unemployment is on the rise, and our financial markets are in turmoil. Americans are concerned about our economic future. Let me say something: the economic crisis is not the fault of the American people. Our workers are the most innovative, the hardest working, the most skilled, the most productive, the most competitive in the world. That's the American worker. My opponents may disagree, but those fundamentals of the American worker, their innovation and entrepreneurship, the innovation of small businesses, those are the fundamentals of America, and I think they are strong. But they are being threatened today, those fundamentals are being threatened today because of the greed and corruption that some engaged in on Wall Street. We have got to fix it. We have got to reform the way they do business.''

Senator Barack Obama went to Granby High School in Norfolk, Va., last week to talk about education. But first, he said, ''I've got to spend just a brief moment talking about politics.'' In case there was not enough in real life, presidential campaign drama is about to land Off Broadway. ''Farragut North,'' a play by Beau Willimon centered on ''a hotshot press secretary's rise and fall during a tight presidential primary race,'' will begin preview performances on Oct. 22 at the Atlantic Theater Company in Manhattan, a spokesman for the show said Monday. It officially opens on Nov. 12.

An article on Sept. 3 about a pledge by officials of the telecommunications company Alcatel-Lucent that they would push ahead with the integration of the troubled French-American company misstated the number of jobs the company had cut since it was created in a 2006 merger. It is about 9,000 jobs -- not 16,500, the total number of jobs the company plans to cut by the end of 2009. (The incorrect figure also appeared in a July 30 article about the company's top two executives stepping down. That error was discovered while researching this correction.)

Former President Bill Clinton is welcoming a galaxy of international stars to the annual meeting of the Clinton Global Initiative later this month, including Senator John McCain, the Republican presidential nominee, whom Mr. Clinton has vowed to help Senator Barack Obama defeat in November. The event, scheduled to run Sept. 23-26 in New York, is nonpolitical and has featured prominent Republicans in the past, including Laura Bush in 2006. CARROLL--Thomas J., 81, a Wall Street veteran, formerly of Unionville, PA, died September 11 at his farm in Middleburg, VA surrounded by his family. Carroll, the son of the late Harry Joseph and Kathryn (McLaughlin) Carroll was born and raised in Philadelphia, PA. He left high school prior to graduation in 1945 to serve in the United States Army until the end of World War II. Carroll began his professional career in 1947 at the investment firm of Cartwright and Parmelee, in New York City. In December of 1969 he founded Carroll, McEntee & McGinley, a primary government bond dealer, now part of HSBC. He was an Emeritus Trustee of The Foxcroft School in Middleburg, VA. He started the Christopher T. Carroll Foundation, which donates money to cancer research grants across the U.S. A lifelong horseman, he was involved in foxhunting, steeplechase and flat racing. His wife Joan preceded him in death in 2003. They mourned the death of their son Christopher Carroll of Chicago, IL in 2001. He is survived by Margaret Eldridge of San Diego, CA, Cornelius X. Carroll (Sally), of Windmere, FL, Michael Carroll (Lori) of Glenview, IL, Joann Linden (Lindsey) of Reston, VA, Thomas J., Jr. (Margaret) of Rectortown, VA and Moira Carroll of Chicago, IL; two sisters, Mary Nicholson and Regina Lauria; and grandchildren Leah, Christopher, Corey, Michael Jr., Gillian, Kiely, and Thomas. He is also preceded in death by his sister Kathleen. A celebration of his life will begin at a Catholic mass Wednesday, September 17 at 11:30am at St. Stephen the Martyr Catholic Church, 23331 Sam Fred Road, Middleburg Virginia. Donations can be made in his honor to the V Foundation for Cancer Research, 106 Towerview Court, Cary, NC 27513.

MEYER--Jill, 59 years old, died peacefully at her home in Chappaqua, NY on September 14, 2008 surrounded by her family, after a bout with cancer. She grew up in Hewlett, NY, attended Boston University and received a Master's from Columbia University Teachers College. Jill taught Special Education at the Shield Institute in the Bronx, NY and also taught at the Pace University's Little School in Pleasantville, NY. She wrote many Jingles for special occasions and began a successful singing career at age 50. She had a wonderful generous spirit and made friends with whomever she met. She will be greatly missed by her beloved husband, Douglas Meyer, mother Bette Greenberg, twin sister Penny Bleyer, daughters Sara Meyer (and dog Isabella), Emily (Meyer) Jacobs, son-in-law Daniel Jacobs, mother - in - law Elaine (Meyer) Glasgall and the family's Dalmatian Sadie. Memorial Services will be held Tuesday, September 16, 2008 at 1:30pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY in Westchester (914)664-6800.

Confusion swirled on Monday over reports of an incursion by United States forces into Pakistani territory in South Waziristan. Local residents and a Pakistani government official said two American helicopters had been repulsed when Pakistani soldiers fired at them. But the Pakistani and United States militaries denied any such incident, and a Pakistani intelligence official said an American helicopter had mistakenly crossed the border briefly from Afghanistan, leading Pakistani ground forces to fire into the air.

Edgardo Vega Yunqué, whose novels and stories about life on the Lower East Side of Manhattan were picaresque, combustive and sometimes flamboyantly comic expressions of the Puerto Rican experience in New York, died on Aug. 26 in Brooklyn. He was 72 and lived in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn. The cause was probably a blood clot, said his daughter, Alyson Vega. She said he had died suddenly in the emergency room at Lutheran Medical Center.

Education policy in recent years has emphasized individualistic aspects of learning. A focus on accountability and achievement testing, giving priority to “results,” has promoted a view of learning as a competitive enterprise, responsive to incentives and sanctions. But this businesslike vision of schools ignores something of great value that schools also have to offer — membership in a community. Schools are people, too.

The Times has assembled a panel of experts to answer readers' questions about financial regulations, government bailouts and the Wall Street upheaval shaking markets worldwide. The participants are Mark Zandi, Bert Ely, Dwight M. Jaffee and Bob McTeer. (Read the panelists' bios.) The discussion is moderated by Catherine Rampell, the online editor for economics.

Mark Zandi is chief economist and co-founder of Moody's Economy.com, where he directs the company's research and consulting activities. He also advises the Republican presidential nominee, John McCain, on economic issues. Dr. Zandi's research interests include macroeconomic, financial and regional economics. Recent areas of research include studying the determinants of mortgage foreclosure and personal bankruptcy, an analysis of the economic impact of various tax and government spending policies, and an assessment of the appropriate policy response to bubbles in asset markets.

A thought I had today: as I understand it, when the Titanic hit that iceberg, at first the crew didn't think it was so bad. The ship's hull was divided into watertight compartments, and not enough of them had been ripped open to sink the ship. But the flooding from the initial hole tipped the ship, and the compartments were open at the top, so that compartments that hadn't been ripped open by the impact of the iceberg started filling up, tipping the ship even more, flooding more compartments ...
Washington Mutual, the struggling savings and loan, has been working on several efforts to save itself, including a potential sale, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

After Dr. Dean Ornish, the diet expert, suggested in the "End of the Diet Wars?" post that a new consensus was emerging on the proper diet, Lab readers ardently disagreed and criticized his arguments. Dr. Ornish has now replied to Lab readers as well as to Gary Taubes's arguments on diet posted earlier.

As sources of oil become harder to exploit, oil majors like BP and Shell could become increasingly reliant on squeezing oil from tar sands in Canada for their supplies. Tar sands also are a way for major oil guzzlers like the United States and Europe to reduce their reliance on unstable parts of the world for sufficient amounts of fuel to power their economies. Venezuela, too, is the other country that is home to major tar sands (but whether U.S. firms could work there is questionable).

Updated, 6:34 p.m. | Sidewalks and traffic around the new Bank of America Tower, diagonally across from Bryant Park, were closed this afternoon after glass fell from the 50th floor of the skyscraper at 1:55 p.m., according to police officials and eyewitnesses. It appeared that no one was injured, although emergency medical workers treated a person who apparently suffered a seizure at the scene. It was not clear if the seizure was related to the falling glass; the man was not struck by the glass.
ELKO, Nev. - Senator Barack Obama fashions himself as the candidate of change. And when he arrived here on Wednesday, that change encompassed more than politics. It included his clothes.

My brother, my mother and I jointly own a condo in downtown Manhattan. For the past 14 years I have been living in the apartment. Since I have been paying all the common charges and taxes on the apartment, I have been claiming the property tax as a deduction on my income tax returns. I have recently moved and we now want to rent out the apartment. My question is, can we have all the profits generated by the apartment go to my mother since she is retired and in the lowest tax bracket?
(Clockwise from top: Getty (4), WireImage (2))

In February, I signed a contract to buy a condominium in a building that is still under construction. Since then, the owners have lowered prices across-the-board on their Internet site and in newspaper advertising. This will have a negative effect on my resale value in the future. They have done this without sending out an amendment to the original offering plan. Does this give me the right to rescind my offer? The offering plan clearly states that they cannot increase or decrease prices without making an amendment to the plan.

New York State on Tuesday began offering an "enhanced driver's license," one of a number of non-passport citizen travel documents that are making their way down bureaucratic government pipelines. While it looks and functions as a license for driving, only United States citizens can get the voluntary new license (or the non-driver equivalent), which means it can be used for land and sea crossings to Mexico, Canada and the Caribbean islands.It is also a high-tech card, equipped with a vicinity Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) chip that will broadcast a number to pull up biographic and biometric data for the border officer. (What is good for E-ZPass and Wal-Mart is good for people, too). "The same information that is in the front of the enhanced driver's license document is in the database," said Ken Brown, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles. They are also sending a sleeve out with the ID, he said. "What it does is prevent transmission of that secure number."

In the first lawsuit against the city for the 2003 Staten Island Ferry crash to go to trial, a federal judge awarded $18.3 million on Wednesday to a former fish market worker paralyzed in the crash -- more than double the highest amount granted so far to any of the 130 victims who settled before trial.

Jarett Dillard is a senior receiver at Rice. He holds almost every Rice career receiving record and leads all active N.C.A.A. receivers in receptions, receiving yardage and touchdown receptions. He also graduated with a degree in political science. Jarett will be checking in with The Quad from time to time to give readers an inside look at his season. Here he writes about the Owls' loss to Vanderbilt and how Hurricane Ike helped to bring the team closer together.

Let the pundits talk of red and blue states. In the world of children's best sellers this season, those two primary crayon box colors are ensconced here in competition with books about gingerbread men, counting fingers and toes and mastering alphabet and vocabulary.

The closing ceremony is over, and the athletes are packing their bags, partying or just sleeping it off at the Athletes' Village as we post this. But there was also competition on Wednesday before the ceremony, the last few athletic events of what has been a record-shattering Paralympic Games.

The Uruguayan architect Rafael Viñoly is known for his use of undulating forms, glass walls and environmentally sensitive materials. His completed buildings in New York City include Jazz at Lincoln Center, in the Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle, and the Housing Court and Hall of Justice buildings in the Bronx.Mr. Viñoly's latest New York City creation, an expansion and renovation of the Brooklyn Children's Museum, had its opening on Wednesday in Crown Heights. A number of city officials, including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, joined the museum's president, Carol Enseki, and board chairman, William D. Rifkin, at the ceremony. The museum, at 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, formally reopens to the public on Saturday. Planning for the project began in 1997.

Just a brief note, before I head on the road, to mention that I've received quite a nice honor for my sustained examination of the science and politics of global warming, from the North Pole to the White House. It's the John Chancellor Award for Excellence in Journalism. Jane Mayer, a staff writer for the New Yorker who has spent years investigating the Bush administration's response to the 9/11 attacks, is also a winner, making this the first year two awardees have been named.

Americans remain overwhelmingly negative about the current state of the economy and think it is only getting worse. And for many, that hits close to home: One in 3 say their family is worse off today that it was four years ago, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

A money manager advises that the ultimate flight to quality is under way, and he cannot find Treasury bills to buy. He told me that he had to go out to December to find a T-bill that he could purchase with any yield at all, and that was well under one-tenth of a percentage point. The others, if they could be purchased at all, were available only for the amount they will be worth when they mature.
The S.E.C. stepped up its rhetoric against naked short selling today, and imposed rules that sound really tough. What they don't do is impose a reasonable financial penalty.

Archeology | New research recasts a portrait of an old relative, the Neanderthal: a brain with a volume slightly larger than our own ... capable of language ... tools and weapons reasonably sophisticated. So why did they lose out to modern man? There may be no one answer; rather, "a collection of related, but unique, short stories of extinction." [National Geographic]

Updated, 1:09 p.m. | The Bloomberg administration has decided to settle a longstanding class-action lawsuit over homeless families' access to shelter in New York City, ending costly litigation that has dragged on since May 1983, through four mayoral administrations. The settlement, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced at a news conference this morning, comes as city officials acknowledge that the mayor's plan to reduce homelessness by two-thirds by 2009 has fallen far short of its goals.

"Monday Night Football" is carrying ESPN to a number of cable ratings victories. Monday's "MNF" game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Philadelphia Eagles ranks as the most-watched telecast in cable television history, ESPN said on Tuesday.
Neal Stephenson's books include "Snow Crash," "The Diamond Age," "Cryptonomicon" and the three-volume Baroque Cycle. His new novel is "Anathem."

The American International Group and its assortment of businesses run the gamut from aircraft leasing to life insurance for Indians to retirement plans for elementary schoolteachers. Parts of the company have been battered by the credit crisis.

History | Happy Constitution Day. The occasion this year is marked by the re-dedication of Montpelier, newly restored home of James Madison, the document's architect. The library where Madison did most of his research and thinking includes a spot on the floor where he is believed to have spilled ink. Much more has been spilled over the document since. [Associated Press]

Russia moved to bolster the country's increasingly stressed banking sector Wednesday, as the global economic turmoil deepened fears that the country could face a situation similar to the one 10 years ago.
A generation of Americans is still trying to recover from the diet wars. Years of obsessing about fat, calories and carbs has left everyone, well ... fatter.
The British mortgage lender HBOS said Wednesday that it was in talks to be acquired by the bank, the Lloyds TSB Group, after shares of the lender collapsed this month on concerns that it might fail.

New York City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. sought to ensure New Yorkers that the near collapse of major financial institutions in the New York City will not affect the city's long-term health and spirit.

With two weeks to go before he must make more than a dozen recommendations on how to get ground zero rebuilding on schedule and on budget, the executive director of the Port Authority said on Tuesday that he had not yet solved the linchpin problem: how to build the underground mezzanine of the World Trade Center Transportation Hub.The executive director, Christopher O. Ward, told the commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that he was still confident he would meet the Sept. 29 deadline for delivery of his report. But Mr. Ward, who can be disarmingly candid, acknowledged that his own deadline for setting deadlines had been perhaps "overly ambitious."

Neither rain, nor rain, nor even more rain could keep Javon Ringer down last Saturday. In fact, it played in his favor, or at least his statistics' favor, as Michigan State slogged through a sopping wet 17-0 victory against Florida Atlantic.

Senator Barack Obama is going on the air today with a two-minute commercial in which he speaks directly to the American people about the current economic crisis and what he would do about it if elected. The ad marks yet another round in the ongoing tug-of-war between Mr. Obama and his rival, Senator John McCain, over which party and which candidate is better equipped to guide the country back to economic health.

Samsung Electronics, the South Korean consumer electronics giant, has made an unsolicited $5.85 billion cash offer for SanDisk, a Silicon Valley maker of flash memory cards that are critical components of popular devices like MP3 music players and digital cameras.

U.S. federal regulators made a round of calls to a number of banks recently to feel out potential interest in buying Washington Mutual, should it eventually falter, The New York Post reported.

The annual summer retreat of the sea ice cloaking the Arctic Ocean appears to have ended with the ice not quite matching last year's extraordinary recession, polar scientists said Tuesday. Still, the scientists, at the National Snow and Ice Data Center in Boulder, Colo., said that the extent of the ice in the Arctic this summer was 33 percent smaller than the average extent tracked since satellites started monitoring the region in 1979, and that the long-term trend is toward an ice-free summer in the Arctic Ocean within a few decades.

In a new sign of market turbulence, managers of a multibillion-dollar money market fund said on Tuesday that customers might lose money in the fund, a type of investment that has long been considered as safe and risk-free as a bank savings account, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques writes.

European stocks opened higher Wednesday in response to the Federal Reserve Board's rescue of the insurer American International Group, but an early rally in Asia lost steam in late trading on concerns about the U.S. financial system and China's economy, The New York Times's Matthew Saltmarsh and Keith Bradshaw wrote.
Heavily armed militants opened fire on the United States Embassy in Sana, Yemen, and detonated a car bomb at its gates.
Executives from General Motors and the Ford Motor Company pressed their case on Tuesday for $25 billion in federal loans in a series of high-level meetings with lawmakers in Washington.
British bank Lloyds TSB is in merger talks with HBOS, the biggest mortgage lender in the United Kingdom, according to press reports.
UBS, the Swiss banking giant, was sued on Tuesday by one of its former top private-banking clients, Igor Olenicoff, as a federal investigation into its offshore services unfolds.
The chairman of the American International Group's profitable aircraft leasing arm is expected to lead an effort to buy back the unit, The Wall Street Journal reported.

A group of current and former reporters at The Los Angeles Times sued the owner, Samuel Zell, on Tuesday, accusing him of recklessness in the takeover and management of the newspaper's parent, the Tribune Company, The New York Times Richard Pérez-Peña reports.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. - Senator Barack Obama stood beneath the stars - surrounded by the ones from Hollywood - and tried to soothe the concerns of worrying Democrats here on Tuesday as he held the biggest fund-raising night of his campaign.

BAA, the British airport group, is putting London Gatwick on the block. The move to sell the second-largest airport in the United Kingdom comes amid mounting pressure from the country's regulators to break BAA up.

The fact that the current crisis hasn't yet led to a steeper downturn, with many more layoffs, should be considered a victory for Ben Bernanke and Henry Paulson, The New York Times's David Leonhardt writes. After some early missteps, they have acted aggressively to keep the financial system functioning - including Tuesday's stunning takeover of A.I.G. - while still forcing Wall Street to suffer for its sins, Mr. Leonhardt says.

Porsche, whose speedy roadsters are synonymous with excitement and luxury, effectively claimed control on Tuesday of Volkswagen, born as the maker of the so-called people's car and now Europe's largest automaker, The New York Times's Nelson D. Schwartz reports.
The federal government has named chairmen to oversee the mortgage finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which were seized this month.

There is a tiny shred of good news for Lehman Brothers, the beleaguered investment bank: one of the investments of its Healthcare Venture Capital arm, a biotech company called Fluidigm, is set to go public this week. That is, if the markets cooperate, The New York Times's Claire Cain Miller.

Linens 'n Things , the bankrupt housewares chain, may be forced to liquidate during the holidays after Cerberus Capital Management dropped a prospective plan to buy it, The New York Post reported.

An expected guilty plea by Samuel Israel III, the hedge-fund manager accused of faking his own suicide, was again delayed Tuesday after his lawyer said that Mr. Israel was still suffering the effects of treatment for withdrawal from an addiction to painkillers.

ROOSEVELT--J. Willard, of Orient died May 18, 2008 at home. He was 90. He grew up in NY, NY, went to Groton and Harvard; studied piano with Nadia Boulanger in France. He was a musician and composer, taught music for many years and was a member of the Long Island Composers Alliance. He served in the Pacific during WWII as Commander of the USS Greene, APD. Son of Kermit and Belle Willard Roosevelt, his grandfather was President Theodore Roosevelt. Greatly loved by all, he is survived by his wife Carol of Orient, son Dirck of Cambridge, MA, daughter Elizabeth Aldred of Brewster, MA, three grandsons, a greatgranddaughter and many nieces and nephews. Family and friends are invited to attend a memorial service at the Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace, 28 E 20 St., NY, NY on September 27, 2008 at 3pm. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Music Program of the Harlem School of the Arts, NY, NY.

BALIS--M. Earl, died on September 15, 2008 surrounded by a loving circle of family and friends. A biochemist, he spent his professional life at Sloan Kettering Institute beginning in 1949 when it was a small group of scientists focused on one problem: curing cancer. Throughout his life, he never lost his appreciation for the miracle of life and the wonder of science. He was a great bridge player, an adequate tennis partner, and an enthusiastic singer. He is survived by his beloved wife of 63 years, Bernice, his daughters, Andrea and Ellen, sonsin-law, George and Douglas, and grandchildren, Jesse and Sophia. He was beloved and he will be missed. Donations in his honor to the Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida will be appreciated and will help others, which he would love.

BIRAN--Avraham. The Hebrew Union College family records with profound sadness the death of Avraham Biran, former Director of the Nelson Glueck School of Biblical Archeology on our Jerusalem Campus and former Director of the Department of Antiquities and Museums for the State of Israel. Dr. Biran, a third generation Israeli, was a leading archeologist who explored Trans-Jordan, Iraq and Israel. During a critical period between 1949 and 1955, Dr. Biran was the District Commissioner of Jerusalem, as well as Senior Member of the Israel delegation to the Mixed Armistice Commission of Jordan; he continued to serve in his role as diplomat for many years for the government, here and abroad. We easily could continue to describe his remarkable career, however, we would not be doing his life justice if we were not to describe his vigor and enthusiasm. Any one of us who was blessed to know him was inspired by his gusto and contagious optimism. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem and may Avraham's memory be a blessing to all who knew him. Rabbi David Ellenson President Barbara Friedman Chair of the Board

When we last tasted aglianico wines from Southern Italy in 2005, I remarked that they would complement all sorts of food, not just the specialties of their region. Texas barbecue was one of the options I thought about at the time. At this tasting, Charles Scicolone and Chris Cannon, our guest tasters, mentioned lusty meatloaf with tomatoes, pizza Margherita and lamb grilled over wood as food they'd like to wash down with a bottle of aglianico. Thinking of grilling over wood and also of the barbecue that had come to mind years ago, I decided to capture what was left of summer with a mess of spare ribs, slow-roasted for succulence, then finished quickly on the grill with a soy and tomato marinade and glaze. I'm not a fan of packaged spice mixtures with some chef's name slapped on them, preferring to concoct my own. I used smoked paprika, ground cloves, salt and pepper for a spice rub. I also threw some soaked hickory chips on the bed of coals, to enhance the smoky allure of the ribs.

ORBACH--Bette (nee Mishkin), 79, of Boca Raton, FL passed away on September 12, 2008 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Fred Orbach. Devoted mother of Stephen (Lynne) and Larry (Philip) Orbach and Cindy (Bruce) Nimhauser. Adoring grandmother of Zachary and Ross Nimhauser. Cherished sister of Mitzi Einstein. May her memory be a blessing.

SCHULL--Gene, dearest husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, died at the age of 83 on September 13, at St. Luke's Hospital. He leaves his wife of 57 years, Rebecca, son Jonathan, daughter-inlaw Betsy Wood, daughters Deborah, Elinor, son-in-law Fleming Meeks and grandsons Henry and Sam Meeks. He is survived also by his extended family: Geoff, Margolit, Jeremy, Eric, Melina, and Jennifer, Lee, Jared and Alexandra, and by a cousin, Gilda Michnoff. Gene was a native New Yorker. His parents, Minerva and Max Schull, owned kosher butcher shops in New York and Long Beach. At the age of 17 he enlisted in the Navy and served for four years as radioman 2nd class in the South Pacific during World War II. He studied photography in Los Angeles on the GI Bill, and worked for several years as a commercial photographer in New York. His next career, as a sales manager, took him and his family from Long Island to Miami, then to Cleveland, Dublin, Edinburgh and London. With children grown, Gene and Rebecca settled in New York and in Los Angeles where Gene became a pilot-flying was a great love of his life. He was an insightful photographer, a natural born inventor, storyteller and improviser. He was a lover of life, of his family, open to everything and everyone, and grateful for his good fortune. Even during his final battle with cancer he would say ''I'm the luckiest guy in the world.'' Characteristically, he surprised us at the end. He died in his sleep, his loving family beside him. ''They shall mount up with wings as eagles...'' Isaiah 40:31.

JETS RELEASE PUNTER The Jets released punter Ben Graham on Tuesday after a game against the New England Patriots in which his net punting average was 27.3 yards per attempt. The Patriots started all four drives after Graham's punts inside Jets' territory. Graham took an unusual route into the N.F.L., starring first in Australian Rules Football in his native country. He took over the Jets' punting duties in 2005 as a 31-year-old rookie and put together two of the top single-season net punting averages in franchise history in 2005 (37.9 yards, second) and 2006 (37.8, third).

SCOTT--Edward L. Jr., 86, of Short Hills, NJ died peacefully Sunday, September 14th. A graduate of Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Points, NY and the University of California Berkeley, Mr. Scotts professional career was in New York as President of E.L. Scott & Company, an international trading business which he founded in 1959. His company was one of the first tenants at the World Trade Center when Tower 1 opened its doors in 1970. Operating from offices in New York and Florida, his firm became the largest dealer in the world of essential oils used for French and American perfumes. He was also the largest importer of concord grape juice and apple juice concentrate, and the largest exporter of cedar wood oil. After President Richard M. Nixon's trip to China in 1972 to open the avenue of trade with the U.S., Mr. Scott was one of the first American businessmen invited to visit China. He is survived by his beloved wife of 54 years Janet Irene, sons Christopher Scott of Short Hills, NJ, Preston Scott (Suzanne) of Morristown, NJ and daughter Penelope Kernen (Joe) of Short Hills, NJ; and grandchildren Blake, Scott and Margaux. A celebration of his life will begin Friday, September 19th at 11:00am at Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, NJ. In lieu of flowers. contributions may be made to the Twin Towers Orphan Fund.

It has been more than a week since the Republican National Convention ended, and in many ways life in St. Paul is back to normal. Tear gas no longer clouds the streets, windows shattered by protesters have been replaced, and the thousands of visitors have left town. But questions are now emerging about the tactics that the police used to control the many rallies and marches that took place. Last Wednesday the city officials appointed two former federal prosecutors to review the planning and strategies used by the police before and during the convention.

DALESSANDRO--John J. II (Jack), of New York and Southampton, NY died peacefully at home on September 14th after a long and courageous battle with cancer. He was 71. Jack leaves his beloved wife of 37 years, Frances Wynne Callahan (Fran) and his nephew, Alfred J. Callahan III. Jack graduated from Eastern Military Academy, Huntington, NY and from Villanova University, class of 1959. He served in the U.S. Army Reserve. Jack began his career with McDonnell and Co. and went on to found the John J. Dalessandro Co., a floor brokerage firm and member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 35 years. He was president of the Stock Exchange Luncheon Club for three consecutive terms. Most recently, Jack was a trustee of the Allianz Global Investors Sponsored Closed End Funds. Jack was an avid vintage car enthusiast and rallyist in Bridgehampton and Italy. In 2006 and 2007 he raced in the Mille Miglia. He was a member of the Bathing Corporation of Southampton, the Meadow Club of Southampton, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, and the Sailfish Club of Palm Beach. His family will receive friends at the O'Connell Funeral Home, Southampton, NY on Thursday, September 18th from 7 to 9pm and on Friday, September 19th from 2 to 4pm and from 7 to 9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said in celebration of his life at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, Southampton, NY on Saturday, September 20th at 9am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in his name to Villanova University Development Office, 800 Lancaster Avenue, Villanova, PA 19085-1603.

There's great news for both fish and fishermen in the forthcoming issue of Science, as my colleague Cory Dean reports. A global survey of more than 11,000 fisheries points to a profitable system to protect fisheries from collapsing. Hope you've enjoyed lunch with Rick Tocchet (thanks to TGOR on Ottawa's Team 1200 for the tip). It's a fine time-tested recipe, and sometimes we'll saute some mushrooms and mix 'em in with the sauce. Get big 'shrooms and don't slice them too thin, use plenty of butter, and be sure not to overcook them (they should have a bit of crunch to them). When they're almost done, throw the sauce into the pan and stir a couple of times. When the pasta is done, drain it and put the pasta in the pan and stir a bit more, which gets the sauce all through the pasta without splashing it on your shirt by mixing them at the table. A great pre-game meal.

The unemployment rates for New York City and the state shot up in August as the economic downturn left more people without jobs, the State Labor Department said on Thursday. The city's unemployment rate rose to 5.8 percent, from 5 percent in July, as more than 5,000 private-sector jobs were eliminated, the department reported. "Although the crises at Lehman Brothers and A.I.G. appear to be working out so as to avoid immediate large-scale layoffs, the continued financial sector turmoil guarantees that job losses on Wall Street will climb rapidly over the next few months," said James Brown, an analyst with the department.

Physics | A science article wonders why going backward in time happens only in fiction like Martin Amis's "Time's Arrow" or Alan Lightman's "Einstein's Dreams." Music | So, Van Morrison has banned alcohol from his concerts because he finds it ruins the musical experience when fans visit the bar. The presidential nominees have poured more than $15 million into television advertising since the end of the parties' national political conventions, mostly in a handful of battleground states in the Midwest, according to a study released Wednesday by the University of Wisconsin Advertising Project. In the week after the Republican convention, Senator Barack Obama spent $7.7 million on advertisements in 17 states, while Senator John McCain spent $7.8 million on spots in 15 states.

IN their polo shirts, khakis and Top-Siders, some of the patrons at Bar Martignetti on Broome Street in SoHo might have blown in from Nantucket on a gust of salt air. They included establishment regulars like Ross (right), who preferred to be identified by his first name only. Ross accessorized his yachting regalia with the requisite gold Rolex and Turk's head rope bracelet, his hair coiffed in the manner of the young J. F. K. Was his preppie style authentic? Hard to say. These days the look is nine-tenths aspirational, noted Anthony Martignetti, one of the owners. ''The real boarding-school types have gotten a lot more hipster,'' he said. ''They eschew the country club look.''

JENNIFER BOLES DWYER, 36, ATLANTA PEAKOFCHIC.COM Jennifer Boles Dwyer is an admirer of Charlotte Moss, Sybil Connolly and Parish-Hadley, and a booster for classic English decorating and its effluence: demilune tables, good lighting, books by Bunny Williams, Brunschwig fabrics. Hers is a personal blog -- in other words, no advertising -- with about 2,000 daily subscribers, she said, and 1,500 additional ''readers.'' (One of them, Stephen Drucker, the editor of House Beautiful, hired her as a contributing editor.) Ms. Dwyer, who has been helping run the family business (which makes printing presses), turned to the blog as an outlet for her interest in design history. ''My goal,'' she said, ''is to encourage people to look to the past while embracing the new and modern. You can find a lot of inspiration in the past. It's how you present it that makes it new.'' JOSH RUBIN, 34; EVAN ORENSTEN, 42; AMI KEALOHA, 30; TIM YU, 27 (FROM LEFT); NEW YORK COOLHUNTING.COM Despite the geekiness of its 90s name, Cool Hunting shows off some pretty cool stuff, like a body-temperature-regulating jacket from Helly Hansen; the faux-nai ve paintings of Michael Swaney, a Barcelona-based Canadian; and a ''saddle stool'' made from an actual saddle by Fernando Akasaka, a Brazilian furniture designer. Josh Rubin, who has silver replating let us restore and beautify your silver bbeen a Web and CD-ROM designer, started the site as a de- sign-source archive for his own use (he used blogging soft- ware, he said, because it was well-suited to making an archive). Five years later, Cool Hunting has been redesigned for advertising and, as of Wednesday, has amassed 5,152 entries. Its general theme, said Mr. Rubin, who lives in Chelsea with Mr. Orensten, two dogs and some Jean Prouve chairs, ''is the obsessive-compulsive process.'' Last month, he added, it had more than 330,000 unique visitors.

ZARIN--Harry , 94, of Southbury, CT died Friday September 12, 2008. He was the beloved husband of the late Fay Zarin and adored father of Michelle, Judith, Nancy and Deborah. Mr. Zarin was born November 3, 1913 in Gomel, Russia to Sadie and Isidore Zarin. He immigrated to New York at the age of 10 and grew up in Newark, NJ and Brooklyn, NY. He was active in the labor movements of his day and was part of the artistic scene in 1930s Greenwich Village. He was also a talented athlete and, at one point, was recruited to play semiprofessional football. As a child, Mr. Zarin showed artistic promise and was given his first easel by the St. Vincent de Paul Society. He continued to paint for his entire life, maintaining a studio wherever he lived and completing the last of hundreds of paintings just two months before his death. In addition to art, classical music was a lifelong passion. He held a special affection for Franz Schubert, whose music he once described as ''tears dipped in honey.'' In business, Mr. Zarin first worked as a textile designer. He then bought and developed a successful kitchen countertop and cabinet business, Roseline Products. Besides his loving daughters, Mr. Zarin is survived by his adoring brother Sol and sister-in-law Beverly, sons-inlaw, Gerald Rosenfeld, Carl Salter and Jeffrey Marqusee, nephews, Michael and Larry, 10 remarkable grandchildren and step-grandchildren and two adorable great-grandchildren. He will be greatly missed. All services were held privately. In honor of Harry Zarin, memorial contributions can be made to the Art Students League, 1215 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10019. The Southbury Funeral Home of Munson-Lovetere, 235 Main St. North, is in charge of services. To send an online condolence, please visit www.munson loveterefuneralhome.com.

An expert panel of the National Academies is urging Senators Barack Obama and John McCain to restore the position of White House science adviser to the prominence it enjoyed before President Bush took office. The panel is also calling for the candidates to prepare to move quickly to fill important science, engineering and health-related positions and to choose appointees according to professional expertise and integrity, not politics or policy views.

MANDEVILLE--Philip Kempton . The Board, staff and youth of the Andrew Glover Youth Program extend our deepest condolences to the family of Kempton Mandeville, our longtime board member, treasurer, and friend. For the past 25 years, Kempton gave so generously of himself to help our small community-based nonprofit and the youth we serve. With his considerable talents and easy-going disposition, he assisted us in myriad ways --working on our database, dressing up as Santa Claus at our annual Christmas party for our youth, opening his home to our youth for an annual BBQ picnic so that they could have a summer outing away from the city. Kempton was a true gem. He will be sorely missed by all of us. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family. MANDEVILLE--Philip Kempton, 52, died Wednesday, September 10, at home in Sherman, CT. Born in New York City, Kemp was the son of Hubert T. Mandeville and Ann Adams. A graduate of Fairfield Country Day School, the Hotchkiss School and St. Lawrence University, he was most recently self-employed as a financial computer consultant. Previously, he was Vice President of the Mandeville Foundation in New York City from 1985-2002. In that role, he helped support such diverse causes as The Sherman (Conneticut) Chamber Ensemble and the Andrew Glover Youth Program, an alternative-to-prison program in Manhattan. He was an active leader in many community groups: Naromi Land Trust (board, treasurer), Sherman Chamber Ensemble (board), Sherman Nursery School (board), Lake Mauweehoo Club (vice-president), Sherman Library (volunteer). He was also a member of the Yale Club of New York City. He was an avid guitar player and member of the Sherman Bluegrass Ensemble and other groups. Kemp is survived by his wife of 26 years, Nancy Gage Mandeville, and three children, Elizabeth, William, and Allison. He is also survived by his brothers Christopher, Matthew, Jonathan, William, and Ross, and his sisters Meredith Mandeville Hollis and Morgan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Andrew Glover Youth Program, Inc., 100 Centre St., Room 1541, NY, NY 10013.

BALLARD--Ernest S., Jr . We mourn the passing on September 14, 2008, at age 83 of our esteemed retired partner Ernest (''Bud'') S. Ballard, Jr. Bud led the LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae (now Dewey & LeBoeuf) trusts and estates practice from 1967 to 1988 with skill and grace, earning the highest respect and affection of all who worked with him. As Chairman of the Sheltering Arms Childrens Service, Bud contributed to the reform of New York's child care system. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife of 60 years, Jeannette Haien Ballard, their daughter, Jean, and grandson, Henry. Dewey & LeBoeuf LLP BALLARD--Ernest Schwefel, Jr., (1925-2008), died peacefully on September 14 after a brief pneumonia. Born in Portland, Maine, the sixth of seven children, Ernest Ballard, known as Bud, attended Phillips Andover Academy, Illinois State Normal University in the US Navy V-12 program and Notre Dame University in the Navy Reserve Officers Training Corps before serving in the United States Navy in the Pacific Theatre until 1946. After completing his training in law at the University of Michigan in 1950, Bud moved with his wife Jeannette to New York City. Bud practiced law in New York City, specializing in trusts and estates, first at Bleakley, Platt, Gilchrist and Walker (1950-1957), then at Davis, Polk, Sunderland, Wardwell and Kiendl (1958-1966), and finally, as head of the trust and estates department, at LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby and MacRae until 1988. In addition, Bud served on the board of directors of the Sheltering Arms Childrens Service and of Mannes College of Music. Bud is survived by his wife of 60 years, Jeannette Haien, pianist and writer, by his daughter, Jean Ballard Terepka, and grandson, Henry Ballard Terepka, all of New York City. He is also survived by his oldest sister, Susan Ballard Boal of Charlevoix, Michigan, his youngest brother, Samuel Sloan Ballard, of Chebeague Island, Maine, and numerous nieces and nephews. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in memory of Ernest Ballard may be made to Episcopal Social Services, the agency that recently acquired the daycare and early childhood education programs of the Sheltering Arms, whose board Bud chaired from the late 1960s to the early 1970s (Episcopal Social Services, 305 Seventh Avenue, New York, New York, 10001-6008).

MADE with skintight stretchy material that hugs the torso, waist and thigh, the one-piece triathlon suit may at first appear to be a throwback to 1920's swimwear -- or perhaps something a superhero might wear. But those who don this highly technical sleeveless garment (alone or underneath a wetsuit) for an entire triathlon -- swim, bike and run -- aren't doing it to make a fashion statement or to fight crime. Not having to change twice during a race saves time, but early versions of this three-in-one garment, which emerged just over a decade ago, were considered far from über-apparel, said Walter DeNino, a former Olympic triathlete. The padding in the rear, for instance, which was supposed to mimic that of a bike short, used to fill with water during the swim.

When one of my younger students turned out to be unable to focus in class for a week — choosing instead to harass other students by cursing and calling out during class with wild abandon — I first tried speaking with her about the problem. This week's schedule is highlighted by several conference matchups, including Louisiana State at Auburn in the SEC and Wake Forest at Florida State in the A.C.C. If recent history is any guide, L.S.U. at Auburn may be the most tightly contested contest of the day. The last four matchups between the teams have been decided by a touchdown or less. Will this year make it five in a row? And can Florida State regain some of its standing in the A.C.C. by snapping a two-game losing streak to Wake Forest? Don't forget about Georgia. Just a week ago, its game against Arizona State seemed like the most intriguing matchup of the weekend. The Sun Devils' loss to U.N.L.V. changed that, but the Bulldogs will face a stiff challenge out in the desert. As always, feel free to disagree with the picks and to let us know why you did by dropping a line in the comments section.

The promise of an electronic device that can serve as an acceptable substitute for a daily newspaper should get a boost this Monday, when iRex Technologies releases its latest e-reader, the iRex Digital Reader 1000.

Should taxpayers be celebrating the federal government's Wall Street bailouts? "I think the federal government is much more likely than not to make money off of AIG, Fannie, Freddie, and whatever else it winds up buying," writes Brad DeLong, the Berkeley economist and why-oh-why-can't-we-have-a-better-mousetrap blogger. On the Q.T. is a travel questionnaire for stylish globe trotters.
Henry M. Paulson discusses a comprehensive approach to shoring up financial institutions.

Updated, 4:54 p.m. | A talk show host from Massachusetts was seriously beaten with a baseball bat during a robbery in front of an apartment building in the Bronx early on Sunday, the police said on Friday.

Autos | Volvo wants to put bugs in its cars. That is, it's studying African locusts to see if cars can imitate the insects' ability to avoid colliding with each other as they swarm. The idea is to develop an algorithm to mimic the insect's ability to send visual stimuli directly to its wings, then use it in a car's computerized safety features. [Wired]

Last week, I posted excerpts from the awesome mail (postal mail) that you, the witty and articulate readers, sent me when I needed to test the Earth Class Mail service. But when I typed up a laundry-list of the random items that you enclosed, I mentioned a recipe from St. Thomas for Spicy Coconut Pork Chops.

Today is New York's second annual Park(ing) Day, where parking spaces became parks for a day with lawn chairs, sod, grass and trees. (See a video from last year and a list of 50 spots around the city.) Among the participants in the project, which runs from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., are Architecture for Humanity, Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer and the Buckminster Fuller Institute.
From Ashlee Vance at Bits:

Adding his weight to a hotly partisan race, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today endorsed City Councilman Michael E. McMahon for the Congressional seat on Staten Island now represented by Representative Vito J. Fossella.

I have been the fortunate recipient of limes from Suzanne's mother and the preserved version from Suzanne -- and though you can't get the former, regular lemons work just fine in making the latter (which is incredible on hamburgers). --MBI don't imagine I'm the only grown woman who still gets care packages from her Mom, but her boxes contain not baked goods but limes. Not just any limes, but Mexican limes from my parents' garden in Los Angeles.

Now that American International Group has officially announced that there will be a shareholder vote on the issuance of warrants to the Federal Reserve, the race is on. Can A.I.G. find another willing lender before the vote?
Monday, Sept. 15

TERRIBLE SIMILE ALERT: The college football season is like a pint of Guinness. The first few weeks are like the initial pour (Guinness recommends the double pour) with our glasses partially filling up with creamy (mostly out of conference) college football knowledge. Then comes the second pour, which is like the first few weeks of conference action, where our glasses are filled to the brim before the stout begins to settle and the creamy head rises to the top.

CORAL GABLES, Fla. - Senator Barack Obama offered his support on Friday to granting the Treasury Department the "broad authority as necessary to stabilize markets and maintain credit," but he said any rescue plan also should include an economic boost for working families.

The switching gear made by Cisco Systems tends to lurk in the deepest, darkest parts of data centers. It pushes information between servers and storage systems and funnels data out to the myriad networks that combine to form the Internet. When everything functions well, Cisco's hardware lives in relative anonymity.
A bird's-eye view of the making of the cover for The College Issue.

Winston Churchill said that stakes in the the Battle of Britain were no less than "the survival of Christian civilization" -- how do you think he'd take this news from an article in The Times of London? "Islamic law has been officially adopted in Britain, with sharia courts given powers to rule on Muslim civil cases." The article continues:
Consumers do not need to be reminded about how much their electric bills have risen in recent months. But Con Edison thought it was worth telling customers that they are not entirely to blame.
The Times's Diana Henriques on the federal government's move to shore up money markets.
The Times's Diana Henriques on the federal government's move to shore up money markets.

"We see Iceland as the world's laboratory for a decarbonized future," Ingibjörg Sólrún Gisladóttir, Iceland's foreign minister, said last year. Of course, she was talking about the country's plan, announced in 1998, to become to the world's first hydrogen-based energy economy. Iceland wants to be free of fossil fuels by 2050.

The N.H.L. will throw "the world's greatest arena rock band" Def Leopard at their fans in "an opening day spectacular." They're calling this "NHL Face-Off Rocks™ 2008" (don't forget the "™"), a nice clunky title. Whatever happened to "Game On"? -- not that we miss it.

If personal property is stolen out of a common area in a co-op, does the co-op have any responsibility (legally or monetarily) to the victim of the theft? Does this change if the person who stole the bike is an employee or relative of an employee of the co-op?

Iraq | The troop surge didn't work, U.C.L.A. researchers say. Rather, they hypothesize, ethnic violence reduced the death toll by clearing out turbulent Baghdad areas beforehand. Satellite images showed these areas were pretty dark at night at the start of the surge, and didn't return to normality with brighter lights as the surge proceeded. [Foreign Policy, Envplan]

I was elected to the board of my self-managed co-op. After several meetings, I asked to see the minutes of the last five years so that I could better understand the building and its management. I was told that I did not have the right to see these minutes. It was my understanding that a board member has the right to see all corporate documents. Is that correct?

I recently moved into a Lower East Side co-op. I found after I closed on the apartment that the co-op operates Sabbath elevators, which stop at every floor automatically. What is the legality of religious rules in a publicly held co-op?

In the middle of an unsettling week for the stock market, with a seemingly infinite number of investment options but none looking any good, what better place to turn for reassurance than the public library? That, more or less, was what a 60-year-old former city schoolteacher named Marc was thinking on Wednesday, the day the Dow Jones industrial average slid 449 points, the second big drop this week.

The new Travel issue of T Magazine, featuring a cover photographed in the otherworldly rain forest of Washington State's Olympic National Park, is a festival of fall escapes near and far. There are pit stops in Zurich for shopping; Northern California's Lake County, which is having a wine-fueled renaissance; an intellectual's dive bar in Chicago; and Matera, Italy, home to the country's most original new hotel. (It's in a cave.) The French designer Jacques Grange invites us for a look at his globe-trotting lifestyle, while the Japanese tastemaker Hirofumi Kurino, of über-cool United Arrows, gives his take on Tokyo's classic cool. And, for a dose of some optimistic urban energy, we take a closer look at two booming capitals -- Dublin and Hong Kong -- and give you a guide to Europe's creative juggernaut, Amsterdam.

Melissa Cohn, the founder and CEO of The Manhattan Mortgage Company, answered selected readers' questions about obtaining mortgages to buy real estate in the current economic climate. She is no longer taking questions.

Now that London's most important designer, Gareth Pugh, has flown the coop for Paris, the city's notoriously fickle press is eager to find the Next Big Thing. Enter DavidDavid (a favorite of the IHT's Suzy Menkes and style.com's Sarah Mower), who was the standout this week at Fashion East, the Topshop-funded organization that each season awards money to three designers to show their collections. (Louise Grey and Natascha Stolle were the other two recipients.)

Considering all the bad news that's out and about, a newspaper isn't the first place you'd turn to for escapist comfort reading. But bypass the headlines and go directly to the culture section of Britain's Daily Telegraph and you'll be immediately transported into the cozy, quietly witty world of Alexander McCall Smith, who is serializing his latest novel, "Corduroy Mansions," an ensemble domestic drama set in the Pimlico apartment house of the title, in a 20-week run that started September 15.
The McCain campaign has said it will release Sarah Palin's tax returns and when it does, tax attorneys will have their pencils sharp and ready to go over the numbers.

Anyone who doubted the clout that the Working Families Party has achieved in the decade since its inception need only to have attended the organization's 10th anniversary celebration and fund-raising dinner Thursday night in Manhattan.
Dr. Fredric E. Gerr on preventing repetitive stain injuries.
Tony Duquette's Abalone Chandelier.
Notable research studies now recruiting patients.

Books | A reviewer faults audiobook producers for casting narrators who don't fit the text. "I can't listen to Sean Penn read Bob Dylan's autobiography without thinking, 'That's Sean Penn reading Bob Dylan's autobiography.' " And Brad Pitt trying out his Spanish in "All the Pretty Horses"? Sorry. Not mentioned: Debra Winger reading "The Brothers Karamazov." Yikes. [Slate]
Talking points for patients and physicians.

The markets are still waiting for American International Group to fully disclose the terms of its agreements with the Federal Reserve, and for the government to disclose its intentions with respect to A.I.G.

Whenever we write about Microsoft and its Vista operating system, we get a flood of comments from Bits readers. Many write off the software company and Windows as simply so over. Others are long-time fans who feel let down.

Here's a wonderful, hilarious and devastating rant about a) why the credit agencies don't work as well as the market; and b) why we would be better off if they went away. Couldn't have said it half as well myself, and since I'm not blogging these days, I won't even try. Read it and laugh.

In April, New York City officials announced plans to close the city's 850-bed intake center and shelter for homeless men in the former Bellevue psychiatric hospital on the East Side of Manhattan, and move the services to the Bedford-Atlantic Armory in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. (The Bellevue building would be redeveloped into a hotel and conference center, officials announced in March.) Some advocates for the homeless have reacted with outrage, and the city's decision -- which requires state approval -- is the subject of a public protest and State Assembly hearing today.
More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Sept. 19:
Aired Thursday night on NBC: Hey, you know that Wells Fargo stagecoach you see in the commercials? I saw it heading out of town today, 100 miles an hour.

Aired Thursday night on NBC: Due to the current crisis on Wall Street, President Bush announced just a few hours ago that he's canceled a trip to Alabama. That's true. Yeah, Bush said, "Under the circumstances, I didn't think it was right to leave the country."

Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Somebody hacked into vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin's e-mail account and posted it all online. Apparently, the hacker was able to figure out her password, which turned out to be "bible hockey lipstick gun."
What we're looking at on the Web today ...
The backless stools in the dining room bring to mind the Spotted Pig, as does the dinner menu's emphasis on comforting, unpretentious fare.

It's junior hockey night across Canada and the fine states of Maine, Michigan, Oregon, Pennsylvania and Washington. The bunker remembers stories about great, albeit rainy, nights spent running for buzzer-beater fries and a chocolate shake at Dick's on Queen Anne before the Seattle Thunderbirds dropped the puck at the barn called the Arena.

There's some good news -- and we hope the last news -- on the Mississippi ballot front. Faced with his Supreme Court declaring his ballot illegal, Governor Haley Barbour has given in. He has agreed that the Senate race between Roger Wicker and Ronnie Musgrove should be with the other federal races, near the top of the ballot.
CNBC coverage of President Bush's speech concerning the sweeping government plan to restore confidence in the financial markets.
The green salad here can't be beat: it's fresh, bright, intensely flavorful, straightforward and quick to make. But it is equally valuable as a cornerstone for a host of other creations.

Start an independent bookstore in New York City, and "People say, 'Are you out of your mind?'" says Cynthia Conigliaro, who did just that nine months ago on the Upper East Side. She sometimes thinks customers come into her Lexington Avenue store, Archivia, which specializes in art, architecture and design books, just to gawk at her. "They want to come in and look at you like you're some curiosity," she said.
Charles D'Ambrosio is the author of two story collections, "The Point" and "The Dead Fish Museum," as well as a collection of essays, "Orphans."
Dr. David M. Rempel on easing the pain of desk-work.

Below is the second and final set of answers from Dr. Irwin Redlener, an authority on disaster preparedness at Columbia University, who is taking readers' questions this week. While we are no longer taking questions for this feature, readers are encouraged to continue the discussion in the comments.

The prospect of a government bailout of the financial system raised all kinds of questions Friday, but one of the biggest was this: How much would it cost the government -- and, by extension, United States taxpayers?

The Mets got the kind of win they've been looking for -- a 7-2 victory over the Nationals -- with a dominant performance from Johan Santana and an offensive surge led by Brian Schneider's two home runs. But they gained no ground on the first-place Phillies, who were led by starter Cole Hamels and received a key two-run home run from Pat Burrell in their 4-3 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

Steven Banks, attorney in chief of the Legal Aid Society, called Yvonne McCain on Tuesday night to tell her that he was finally settling the lawsuit for homeless families that he had brought in her name 25 years ago.

GREEN BAY, Wis. - Senator John McCain gave a few new details of his economic proposals at a speech here Friday morning, but the address seemed as much a political shot at Senator Barack Obama as a policy prescription.

Panic turned to elation on Wall Street early Friday, as the prospect of a vast government-led solution to the current financial crisis spurred a surge in shares of brokerages and banks.
Kim Severson answers more reader questions about Alaska.
