Willie Randolph's most assertive moment as the manager of the Mets came in the first round of the 2006 playoffs. He went into that series against the Dodgers having suddenly lost both Pedro Martinez and Orlando Hernandez to injuries and was down to just one reliable starting pitcher - Tom Glavine.
A first look at the newly renovated Brooklyn Children's Museum.
So why not me? The entire financial sector has just lost its shorts.

The westward extension of the No. 7 subway line will be built without a new station at 10th Avenue. That became even clearer this week after the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority let a deadline pass on a contract option for preliminary construction of the 10th Avenue station.
What's in the Daily News? I'll tell you what's in the Daily News. Story about some guys ...

Teachers at 89 elementary and middle schools will receive bonuses of several thousand dollars each, based on the progress their schools made on report cards released this week, Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced. The bonuses, which total $14.2 million and will go to slightly more than half of the 160 high-poverty schools the city deemed eligible, are part of Mr. Klein's efforts to promote pay-for-performance programs in the city's schools.

As government officials and members of Congress consider plans for a bailout after the economy's downward spiral this week, the candidates will continue to strike economic themes on Friday. After calling for the ouster of the head of the Securities and Exchange on Thursday, Senator John McCain plans a speech today in front of the Green Bay, Wisc. Chamber of Commerce to discuss his approach to the financial crisis.
It is a fear of every columnist that a column will be overtaken by events before it is even read. That happened to me today.
The Treasury Department said on Friday that it would use $50 billion to back money market mutual funds whose asset values fall below $1, in another step to contain raging financial turmoil.
More of your "late night" humor (send via the comment link below):
A cold war appears to have broken out between JPMorgan Chase and Citadel Investment Group, as the giant Chicago hedge fund poaches trading staff from the banking colossus amid the credit crisis.

Politics | On his blog, the "Red State, Blue State" author offers data to suggest it's easier for Sarah Palin and other governors of small states to maintain high approval. Theories: small states get more federal money, and have part-time legislatures in less conflict with the governor. Also, in big, diverse states, "it's harder to keep all the voters happy." [RedBlueRichPoor]

The head of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve began talks on Thursday with Congressional leaders on what could become the biggest bailout in United States history, Edmund L. Andrews of The New York Times reported.
Who's benefiting from the woes at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs? Apparently JPMorgan Chase, for one.
Bain Capital and Hellman & Friedman have teamed up on a bid for Lehman Brothers' investment management unit, Bloomberg News reported.

Morgan Stanley stepped up its merger negotiations with Wachovia on Thursday as it considered ways to shore up its finances amid the market's current turmoil, The New York Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin and Eric Dash reported, citing people involved in the talks.

Merrill Lynch's deal to be bought by Bank of America is not expected to affect the $500 million line of credit the bank extended to United Artists, the film studio run by Tom Cruise, The New York Post reported.
Washington Mutual, the struggling savings and loan that is reportedly exploring options including a sale, has at least five potential suitors, according to press reports.

The financial crisis has turned the race between Senators John McCain and Barack Obama into an audition for who could best handle a national economic emergency, The New York Times's Jackie Calmes and Jeff Zeleny write.

American financial institutions borrowed a record $47.97 billion a day, on average, from the Federal Reserve in the latest week in a scramble for cash as the global credit crisis deepened, Federal Reserve data showed on Thursday.

A seesaw day on Wall Street ended with a rush of euphoria Thursday as investors raced back into beaten-down banking shares, heartened by signs that the government is taking more drastic steps to tamp down problems plaguing the financial markets.
Bank of China, the world's fifth largest bank, said it was opening its wallet for a stake in the Rothschild banking dynasty.
UpTake, a travel search startup founded by a former general manager at Yahoo's travel group, said it raised a $10 million second round of funding led by Trinity Ventures and Shasta Ventures.

Lexicon | An article explores why "retard" has become such a trendy term lately, from MTV to "Tropic Thunder," inspiring a "hate speech" controversy. In the putdown-heavy "online snarkosphere," the word and its variants "have that retro, old-skool [sic] styling that is not only in vogue but also handy when that puerile, playgroundy connotation is precisely what's needed." [Salon]
Dow Jones & Company said Thursday that Kraft Foods would replace the American International Group in the Dow Jones Industrial Average when trading begins Monday.
Each Friday, the Fantasy Football Librarian is here to help.
Video

As the rest of the financial community was scrambling to get its money out, a government-owned German lender gave Lehman Brothers what might be called a parting shot in the arm, transferring 300 million euros to the investment bank on the same day it filed for bankruptcy.

A private equity consortium led by Providence Equity Partners dropped its bid for Informa, the London-based publisher of Lloyd's List maritime newspaper, after tight lending conditions reportedly made it impossible for the group to increase its 1.9 billion pound ($3.5 billion) offer.
A reader named Evelyn suggested sending Ed Hochuli words of encouragement to buck him up.
Mergers and acquisitions could become even more complex in a few months, when new accounting rules kick in related to business combinations and fair-value calculations, Compliance Week writes.
As the American investment banking industry seems to teeter, many investors are asking why the sovereign wealth funds from the Middle East have not stepped up.

The Yale Endowment, which has led the academic world in investment returns in recent years, reported a return in its most recent fiscal year of 4.5 percent for its $22.5 billion endowment, The New York Times Geraldine Fabrikant reported.

A group of Italian investors withdrew a bid on Thursday to buy Alitalia, the national airline, after six of the company's nine unions failed to back a rescue plan, a move that edged the carrier closer to failure.
Traders who have sought to profit from the financial crisis by betting against bank stocks were attacked on two continents.

In a blow to private equity firm Lone Star, HSBC dropped a $6.3 billion offer for 51 percent of Korea Exchange Bank, blaming turmoil in financial markets and ending what would have been the biggest cross-border move in South Korea's bank sector.

The Russian government will inject up to $20 billion into domestic stocks in an effort to halt the free fall of the Russian stock markets, President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Thursday, in the most direct effort yet to use oil profits to ease a deepening stock market crisis there, The New York Times's Andrew E. Kramer reported.

Economic forecasting firm Global Insight announced Thursday that it had agreed to be purchased for $200 million by information giant IHS, continuing a wave of consolidation that has swept through the research industry.

Ignoring a presidential veto threat, the House on Thursday approved measures aimed at curbing speculation by hedge funds and others in oil and other commodity markets. It said federal regulators did not have the tools or manpower to track trading abuses.

MBIA and the Ambac Financial Group may have their debt rankings cut several grades by the credit ratings company Moody's Investors Service after Moody's raised its forecast for losses on securities backed by subprime mortgages.
The unemployment rates for New York City and State shot up in August as the rapidly spiraling economic downturn left more people without jobs, The New York Times's Patrick McGeehan reported.

Books | A British TV comedy producer on things not to do before you die. As for books, don't waste your time with "Ulysses" ("It does sound rubbish, doesn't it?"); "Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas" ("dreary ramblings of an unreliable and workshy tosspot"); or the "Iliad" ("There's a big fight between Achilles and Hector and that's about it.") And seven more. [Times of London]

Wall Street's powerful rally on Thursday in the last two hours of trading spilled across the Pacific Ocean on Friday morning as shares rose from Tokyo to Sydney, The New York Times's Keith Bradsher reported.

For the second time in a week, a multibillion-dollar money market fund has been forced to take extraordinary steps to deal with sudden cash withdrawals by nervous institutional investors, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reported.

Film | In the last of his monthly columns for The Believer, Nick Hornby says "Doctor Dolittle" (Rex Harrison version) is worth academic study "to degree level and possibly beyond" as "a monument to the stupidity, vanity, and pointlessness of commercial moviemaking." A chimp had to be trained for six months to fry bacon and eggs. [Believer excerpt only]

Energy | A different take on ethanol: higher global food prices, increased air pollution, a spreading "dead zone" in the Gulf of Mexico from a surge in fertilizer use, and mounting evidence that growing a gallon of corn ethanol produces more greenhouse gases than burning a gallon of gas. [Yale.edu]

Iran | Roots of Iran's nuclear ambitions, recalled by the Shah's nuclear adviser in the '70s: "I always suspected that part of the Shah's plan was to build bombs. So I came up with a plan to dissuade him ... But I think that if the Shah had remained in power he would have developed nuclear weapons because now Pakistan, India and Israel all have them." [New Statesman]

Science | A biologist says people's belief in ghosts and alien abductions harks back to our tool-making history. Unlike other animals, humans understand cause and effect, and that gave rise to the invention of tools as well as a "belief engine" in the brain. "We want to believe there is a reason for it all." Wait, what was that noise? [ABC News Technology and Science]

Bird's Nest designers Herzog and de Meuron are not the only A-list European architects unveiling plans for towers in New York City these days. Plans were recently released for a new residential tower designed by Dutch master Rem Koolhaas's Office for Metropolitan Architecture, which is creating compelling, thought provoking designs for cities around the world.

Michelle Wie salvaged a ragged round with a birdie-birdie finish to remain alone in fourth place after the third round of an L.P.G.A. tour sectional qualifying tournament. Her closing birdies gave her two-over 74 at Mission Hills Country Club in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

Shadow Play won the $551,225 Little Brown Jug at Delaware County Fairgrounds in Ohio, pulling away for a six-and-a-quarter-length victory in the second leg of the pacing Triple Crown. Shadow Play, a black colt, paced a mile in 1:50 1/5.
Shaquille O’Neal predicted 10 to 15 more victories for the Knicks this season, following last season’s poor record that led to the hiring of Coach Mike D’Antoni.
Mandy Patinkin puts the accent on fortissimo for much of this clean, largely well-acted staging of “The Tempest.”
A man charged in the killings of four people who died during a June killing spree in Illinois and Missouri has been charged with murder in four more bludgeoning deaths.
An Episcopal bishop, whose diocese is moving toward splitting from the national church, was ousted from ministry.

Agriprocessors Inc., an embattled kosher meatpacker with a plant in Postville, Iowa, named a corporate lawyer from New York to be its chief executive, responding to an ultimatum from the leading kosher certifying organization.
Lt. Gov. Sean Parnell of Alaska conceded to Representative Don Young in the Republican primary for Alaska’s only House seat.
This lumpish musical adaptation of the beloved Charles Dickens novel is one of those unfortunate shows that are neither witty in themselves nor able to inspire wit in others.

Gov. Haley Barbour agreed to move a special election for Trent Lott’s former Senate seat to near the top of the November ballot, ending a dispute that had threatened to delay the start of absentee voting.
Flashing headlights and honking horns penetrated the early-morning sky as police officers and first responders led drivers in a slow procession across the new Interstate 35W bridge in Minneapolis.

BOULDER, Colo. - With a smile on his face and a bit more spring in a step that's typically quite bouncy, Colorado Coach Dan Hawkins left the Colorado locker room last night to visit with a throng of friends and family.

A 25-yard field goal by Colorado’s Aric Goodman gave the Buffaloes a 17-14 overtime victory. After scoring two touchdowns in the game’s first five minutes, the Buffaloes did not muster another score during regulation.
A former New York City police officer convicted of murdering a man after an argument over a parking space in 1996 has been granted a release from prison after a judge overturned his conviction.
“Elite Squad” is a relentlessly ugly, unpleasant, often incoherent assault on the senses from Brazil.
“A Thousand Years of Good Prayers” is a gentle, pleasantly unrushed piece of moviemaking.
FRONT PAGE.

For Mike Mussina, Thursday's game will always be a career highlight. He won his final game at Yankee Stadium and came off the mound to a standing ovation, waving his cap to the crowd. He cared so much about the moment that he preserved the dirt from his spikes.
The financial crisis was the top issue on the campaign trail, with Barack Obama in New Mexico and John McCain and Sarah Palin stumping in Iowa.

An article in the special Wealth and Personal Finance section on Sept. 10 about tax planning gave an incorrect attribution for a quotation about the dangers of inherited wealth. It was Scott D. Michel, a tax lawyer at Caplin & Drysdale — not Scott J. Bakal, a tax lawyer at Neal Gerber Eisenberg — who said: “You almost never see a criminal tax case where you have inherited wealth, because they come with inherited lawyers, inherited advisers, inherited accountants. There’s a structure in place. With people who start from nothing and end up under a waterfall of money, the structure isn’t there, and there’s nobody to say ‘no’ to an abusive shelter.

An article on Sept. 4 about accusations by a former police commissioner in Canada that political interference in the United States led to the rendition of Maher Arar misstated Mr. Arar’s travel itinerary before he was detained in New York in 2002 by immigration officers and sent to Syria, where he says he was tortured. Mr. Arar was returning home to Ottawa from a family vacation in Tunisia by way of Switzerland; he was not returning from a vacation in Switzerland. The error also appeared in an article on Aug. 15 about a United States appeals court decision to rehear a case in which Mr. Arar is seeking civil damages from a number of federal officials. And the error was repeated on Aug. 31 in an editorial about that case.

An article in some editions on Thursday about an announcement by Barclays Capital that it would purchase Lehman Brothers’s headquarters in Manhattan as part of a deal to buy Lehman’s main securities-trading operations misstated the sum that Barclays has agreed to pay for the naming rights to the New Jersey Nets basketball arena planned in Brooklyn. It is $400 million, not $40 million.
A picture caption on Thursday with a theater review of “Forbidden Broadway Goes to Rehab” reversed the identity of two actors. Jared Bradshaw was at the left, and Michael West was in the center.

An article on Thursday about the presidential race in Virginia misstated the name of the military base in Virginia Beach that employs John Smith, a machinist who said he thought people were looking for change and would therefore back Senator Barack Obama. The base is the Naval Air Station Oceana; there is no Oceana Air Force Base.

An obituary on Thursday about Norman Whitfield, a songwriter, producer and arranger for Motown Records, omitted part of the name of the label’s founder. He is Berry Gordy Jr., not Berry Gordy. It also referred incorrectly to a recording Mr. Whitfield produced for the Temptations, a Motown group. The Temptations won a Grammy for their single “Cloud 9,” not their album of that name. (Both were produced by Mr. Whitfield.) And they won in 1969 — the single was released late in 1968 — not 1967.

An article on Thursday about the Mayor’s Management Report, which assesses how New York City government responded in all areas during the past fiscal year compared with the previous year, misstated the number of free condoms the city distributed in fiscal year 2008. It was 39,070,000 — not 39,070.

A music column on Thursday about nudity in opera, including Karita Mattila’s nude appearance in Richard Strauss’s “Salome,” misidentified the source of the story on which the opera is based. It is the New Testament, not the Hebrew Bible.

An article on Thursday about the falling share prices of the investment banks Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs misstated, in some editions, the market performance on Wednesday of shares in Wachovia, which is said to be considering a merger with Morgan Stanley. The shares fell 20.76 percent, or $2.39, not 2.39 percent.

A front-page article on Thursday reported on discussions the investment bank Morgan Stanley has had with possible merger partners. It cited two people who were said to have been briefed on a conversation in which John J. Mack, chief executive of Morgan Stanley, had told Vikram S. Pandit, Citigroup’s chief executive, that “we need a merger partner or we’re not going to make it.”.
Dr. Steinberg was a food-loving doctor who threw himself into the chocolate business, eventually helping to make one of the most highly regarded fine American chocolates.
The one place where the Yankees are teammates first and icons last, where they are in the game but somewhat sheltered from public view, is the dugout.
A rare orchid is blooming for the second time ever at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a blessed event that has spurred envy among growers.
At the United States Military Academy at West Point, modern soldiers study war as Sophocles wrote it.

FITZGERALD--Thomas J., on September 17, 2008 of Malverne, NY and Chatham, MA at the age of 80. Beloved husband of the late Patricia. Loving father of Marie Richardson, Jane Kelley, and Susan Fitzgerald. Adoring grandfather of Connor Patrick Richardson. Cherished companion of Joan Day. Dear brother of Patricia A. Fitzgerald and John B. Fitzgerald. Graduate of St. Peter's College, Class of 1951. Retired as Senior Vice President after a career of over 30 years with Equitable Real Estate Investors. Family will receive friends Thursday from 7-9pm and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Avenue (corner Peninsula Blvd.), Lynbrook. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:45am Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to: St. Francis Hospital Foundation, Office of Development, 100 Port Washington Blvd., Roslyn, NY 11576. For further details, please visit www.flinchandbruns.com.

In an 8-to-0 vote, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday morning to grant landmark status to the former Wheatsworth Bakery, a 1928 factory on the Lower East Side that was famous for making Milk-Bone dog treats. The factory at 444 East 10th Street, between Avenues C and D, was one of five sites that were given landmark protection, including a former bank branch on the Lower East Side, a Harlem firehouse, and recreation centers in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and Tompkinsville on Staten Island.

STEINWAY--Henry Z. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of its former President and Chairman, Henry Z. Steinway, on Thursday, September 18 in New York City at the age of 93. A great grandson of the firm's founder, Mr. Steinway was actively involved with the Company up to the time of his death, maintaining an office at Steinway Hall in Manhattan. Born in New York City in 1915, Mr. Steinway began his association with the firm as a factory apprentice in 1937 following graduation from Harvard. He rose through the ranks, becoming Factory Manager in 1946 upon discharge from the service, and was named Vice President in 1947. He served with distinction as President from 1955 to 1972, and as Chairman from 1977 to 1980. In 1980 he became a Consultant to the Company, a position which he held to present day. He married Polly Zinsser in 1944, who survives him, as does his sister Lydia Steinway Cochrane, and his five children. Henry Z. Steinway was a true piano man, and his familiar presence at Steinway Hall was our greatest treasure. An avid correspondent with curators, customers, Steinway dealers and celebrated artists through the years, Mr. Steinway enjoyed a perspective of the changing musical world that few in our industry will experience. Though his typewriter is silenced, our lives have been forever enriched by his personal warmth, his candor, and by his unwavering faith in the instrument that we craft. To Polly and to Lydia, his children and grandchildren and his extended family, we offer our love and our heartfelt condolences. He will be sorely missed. Thomas Kurrer, President and CEO Ron Losby, President Americas STEINWAYHENR ST

Hueco Tanks State Historic Site (6900 Hueco Tanks Road No. 1; 915-849-6684; www.tpwd.state.tx.us/spdest/findadest/parks/hueco--tanks) is open 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday to Thursday and 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. Friday to Sunday May through September; 8 to 6 daily October through April. Admission is $5, and picnic and camping facilities are available. Guided pictograph tours -- there are three tours, varying in difficulty -- are offered at 10:30 a.m. and 2 p.m. Wednesday through Sunday. Because the number of visitors is limited to protect the site, reservations are strongly advised. The areas West Mountain, East Mountain and East Spur are open only to those with guides; North Mountain offers limited self-guided access. All first-time visitors are required to watch a 15-minute orientation video.

Reopening festivities this weekend at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, in Crown Heights, will include concerts and samplings of the museum's new programming. The performances, at 1:30 and 3 p.m., will feature Louie Miranda on Saturday, and Alex & the Kaleidoscope Band on Sunday. Through Nov. 30, the museum is open Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Wednesdays through Fridays, 1 to 6 p.m. (until 8 p.m. on Fridays through Oct. 24; Totally Tots opens at 11 a.m.); closed Mondays and Tuesdays. Through November, admission is $5, free for members and children under 1; afterward, admission will be $7.50. Information: (718) 735-4400; brooklynkids.org.

Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s suggestion that paying higher taxes is ''patriotic'' set off on Thursday a major public tussle between Mr. Biden, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, and his Republican counterpart, Gov. Sarah Palin. Mr. Biden, of Delaware, said in an interview on ''Good Morning America'' on ABC that he and the Democrats' presidential nominee, Senator Barack Obama, ''want to take money and put it back in the pocket of middle-class people.'' In an Obama-Biden administration, he said, Americans who earn more than $250,000 should expect to pay more in taxes.

FOR CHILDREN BATTERY PARK CITY PARKS CONSERVANCY (Saturday) Fishing, cycling, art making, rocking out: the conservancy offers all of it on Saturday. In a celebration of National Estuary Day children are invited for catch-and-release fishing (10 a.m. to 2 p.m.), art projects (11 a.m. to 2 p.m.) and a concert by the Brooklyn bluegrass and rock group Astrograss (12:30 to 1:30 p.m.) in Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park (accessible from Battery Place and the West Side Highway), Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Miniature Lance Armstrongs can also try the Tour de Parc from 10:30 a.m. to noon, an event for ages 3 to 9 in which children follow different routes (one for bicycle riders, one for those on training wheels, scooters or tricycles) through the Battery Park City parks, beginning at the Esplanade Plaza (reachable from Liberty Street). The tour includes bike decorating, safety instruction and a not-too-challenging obstacle course. Preregistration (and helmets) required: (212) 267-9700. All events free; bpcparks.org.

Gov. Sarah Palin and other elected officials have been disinvited from an anti-Iran rally scheduled for Monday at the United Nations, organizers of the rally and the campaign of Senator John McCain said. Malcolm I. Hoenlein, the executive vice chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations and a leading promoter of the rally, disinvited Ms. Palin, Mr. McCain's running mate on the Republican presidential ticket, and other politicians after Democrats, Jewish organizations and members of Congress protested that her appearance would turn the rally into a partisan political event.

An article on Sept. 4 about accusations by a former police commissioner in Canada that political interference in the United States led to the rendition of Maher Arar misstated Mr. Arar's travel itinerary before he was detained in New York in 2002 by immigration officers and sent to Syria, where he says he was tortured. Mr. Arar was returning home to Ottawa from a family vacation in Tunisia by way of Switzerland; he was not returning from a vacation in Switzerland. The error also appeared in an article on Aug. 15 about a United States appeals court decision to rehear a case in which Mr. Arar is seeking civil damages from a number of federal officials. And the error was repeated on Aug. 31 in an editorial about that case.

KATZMAN--Robert, M.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Robert Katzman, long-serving former chairman of neurology. His pioneering research determined that Alzheimer's disease is a process separate from normal aging. He also played a prominent role in the creation of the National Institute on Aging. He was an exemplary practitioner, researcher, administrator and mentor, greatly admired by colleagues, faculty and students. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Katzman family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University KATZMAN--Robert M.D. The Saul R. Korey Department of Neurology of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourns the death on September 16 of its former chair. Dr. Katzman came to Einstein in 1957 and rose to chair of neurology in 1963. He served until he moved to the University of California at San Diego in 1984. He was one of the first clinician-neuroscientists to insist, in 1976, that Alzheimer's disease was not normal aging but a genetically influenced degenerative brain disease. His pioneering efforts galvanized national and international research toward its potential remediation. He was a driving force behind the creation of the National Institute on Aging of the NIH. We express our gratitude for having served and trained under his visionary leadership and extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Nancy, his two sons, David and Daniel, and his entire family. Mark F. Mehler, M.D. Alpern Professor and University Chairman, The Saul R. Korey Department of Neurology Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

LEVY--Shirley R., died September 18, 2008, after living 86 full years as a wife, mother, grandmother and kindergarten teacher. She is survived by her four children and their families: Mitchell Levy and his partner, Sheri Lockhart, Toby Levy and her husband Rick Holman, Fred Levy and his wife Jennifer and Donald Levy and his wife Barbara Bennett; her grandchildren William Levy and his wife Tina, Elyse Levy, Asher Holman, Michael and Jessica Levy, and Jacqueline and Andrea Levy. She had been married to Melvin J. Levy for 55 years, who predeceased her. A service to share her memories will be held at 9:30am on Sunday, September 21, 2008 at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to be made to the Institute for Retirees in Pursuit of Education, Brooklyn College, 2900 Bedford Avenue, Room 3160 Boylan Hall, Brooklyn, NY 11210-2889.

BERLIN (Reuters) -- An American soldier who admitted involvement in the shooting of detainees in Iraq early last year has been sentenced to seven months in prison and will be dishonorably discharged, the Army said on Thursday. The soldier, Specialist Belmor G. Ramos, 23, pleaded guilty at a court-martial in Germany to charges of conspiracy to commit premeditated murder. He agreed to testify in the trials of other soldiers in the case, the Army said.

Senator John McCain is standing by comments he made to a Spanish-language radio station in which he refused to rule in or out a meeting with Prime Minister José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero of Spain. His ambiguous statement earlier this week raised questions about whether Mr. McCain intended to direct his remarks at Mr. Zapatero. In an interview with Radio Caracol Miami on Tuesday, Mr. McCain spoke only in generalities when asked whether, as president, he would sit down at the White House with Mr. Zapatero, who has clashed with the Bush administration over Iraq.

MILLER--Madeleine M. (Mrs. John V. Hogan), of Forest Hills Gardens and Northport, NY, passed away on Sunday, September 14. Predeceased by her loving husband, John V. Hogan, her parents, Ray E. and Dorothy Blanks Miller, of Wilmington, DE and Forest Hills; and by her son, Richard John. Madeleine died peacefully with her loving family around her. She leaves behind sons Doug and Russell, daughters-in-law Nancy, Deborah and Joanne, former wife of Richard, and seven grandchildren: Caitlin, Ashley, Lindsay, Lesley, Scott, Nora, and Ella Hogan, all of whom miss her deeply. Madeleine attended Pine Manor College and the University of Arizona, she was a music librarian at Adelphi University and a graduate student of composer, Leo Kraft. Long time member of the West Side Tennis Club and St. Luke's Episcopal Church, she loved opera, the New York Philharmonic, playing bridge with good friends and the QE2. We shall always cherish her memory. A funeral service will be held Saturday, September 20 at 1:00pm at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY 11375. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

Workers at a meatpacking plant in Grand Island, Neb., on Thursday protested shift changes made to allow Somali Muslim employees more time to pray during Ramadan. The changes had been put into place after earlier protests by the Muslim workers. Thursday's counterdemonstrators said the new shift times would cut their hours and pay. Later in the day, managers at the plant, owned by JBS Swift & Company, announced that the shift changes would be rescinded.

KLIMENT--Stephen A., Architect, author, teacher and editor, Stephen Kliment touched our lives as colleague and mentor. At AIA New York, he served on the Board of Director and was editorial director of Oculus and eOculus, among many other publications and journals during his career. His work on a book about African-American architects represented a longtime commitment to making the architectural profession more diverse. The Board and staff of AIANY extend condolences to his family and friends.

PRENSKY--Henry David, D.D.S., born in New York City December 5, 1917, died of complications from chronic emphysema in Palm Beach Florida on September 16, 2008, at the age of 90. Community leader, organizer of Floridians for Healthcare, Palm Beach Democratic Club, lecturer, founding member of the Board of Directors of the School of the Arts Foundation, Dreyfoos School of the Arts, West Palm Beach. Memorial Celebration to be announced in Palm Beach. Dr. Prensky is survived by his son, William; a daughter, Catherine Prensky Mason of New York City; three grandchildren, Joel Mason of Wisconsin, and Josh Mason and James Regan of New York City; and three great-grandchildren. No information on service yet, but donations for the Bryna Prensky Visual Arts Scholarship Fund or the David Prensky Music Scholarship fund for graduating seniors at the Dreyfoos School of the Arts can be sent to: School of the Arts Foundation, P.O. Box 552, West Palm Beach, FL 33402.

Wall Street's powerful rally on Thursday in the last two hours of trading spilled across the Pacific Ocean on Friday morning as shares rose from Tokyo to Sydney. Heavy buying propelled the Nikkei 225 Index to a gain of 3.3 percent in the morning trading session in Tokyo. The All Ordinaries Index climbed 3.9 percent in Australia, the Kospi Index increased 4.8 percent in Seoul, and the Hang Seng Index leaped 6.0 percent in Hong Kong.

Fashion | A blogger doubts Vanity Fair's widely reported $300,000 appraisal of Cindy McCain's outfit at the Republican convention. It "said her earrings, if real, were three-carat diamonds worth $280,000." But pros say it's "impossible to estimate the size of a diamond-and even to tell whether it is synthetic or natural-from a photograph." [The XX Factor, Slate]

Business | A blogger says the ban on short selling "smacks of overkill" because the practice takes up a "paltry" percentage of financial stock shares. (Shorting is when you borrow a security and sell it, expecting a drop in value so you can buy it back at a lower price and keep the difference.) The likely real culprits: panicky "plain vanilla money managers." [Business Week]

Sport | Rule No. 1 in moose hunting: "Never kill a moose more than a mile from a vehicle of some sort." That's because, well, moose are huge: "remember that you will have about 400 to 700 pounds of meat and up to 65 pounds of antlers to transport from the kill-site to home." Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the struggles of the Houston Astros in the aftermath of Hurricane Ike misstated, in some editions, the number of hits they had in their first four games after the storm disrupted their schedule. It was 12, not 11.
